column8:
So here's my Philltastic review of Final Fantasy 8:

Overall I thought it was a decent game. Not my favorite, not the worst. This makes total sense after FF7. They really went harder to make longer, more intense cutscenes and summons. They even borrowed musical cues from FF6 and 7. And they really went hard to focus on character development. They did some decent jobs with FF6 and 7, but FF8 is by far the most development of any of the other ones. The thing is, it's all for Squall. That's not a bad thing. Like in the previous Fantasy games, some characters got a good amount of love, some characters got next to nothing. In this, it's the Squall show. The other characters kinda exist, but not a huge amount of growth. It does actually make Squall a rather well explored person.

I also don't understand why the sorceress is such a big deal... when people can use their girlfriends to do magic. Why does it matter if someone else can do magic. Also, Adel doesn't wear a bra. So there's full on nudity that should've been censored. This remaster did upscale and redo the models so the characters look nice, as long as they are models. Some of the NPCs are more background elements so it stands out.
Gameplay wise, I think it's anti-first time player. The whole girlfriend system is kinda confusing, and has a pretty steep learning curve. You actively make yourself weaker the more you level, and that's not really explained. When in reality to power up you need to never level, and just shove magic into your strength holes. Ironically, the best way to power up... is to play the card game and run from every battle. So an interesting concept, but I think not an amazing one.

Storywise, it's just pretty darn random. Things just... happen and come ouf of left field. "Oh right we're totally orphans who were raised together. Of course I go back in time to see someone else's past. Of course the sorceress is posessed by a sorceress who wants to find a sorceress to crunch time together for reasons unexplained." And... I did see a fan theory about Squall. I actually enjoy it and think it's a solid one (though I'm pretty sure the FF8 director said it's not true)... about Squall dying at the end of disk 1 (https://squallsdead.com/). He gets murdered by the sorceress and the rest of the game is his final moments before he passes completely. And the end of the game his entire life flashes before his eyes, and he is kaput. He doesn't even appear in the "real" part of the ending either. I like to think of this theory as real.

Joguei Final Fantasy VIII exaustivamente na infância, nas lendárias game houses da época do PS1. Sempre fui fascinado por esse jogo: o sistema de Junction que parecia complexo demais (e ainda é!), as Guardian Forces com animações que eu nunca pulava, e a história completamente brisada que mexia com minha cabeça. Foi o jogo que me fez gostar de RPG japonês.

Quando saiu pra PC em 2013, comprei na hora. Mas, sejamos honestos: aquela versão era bem limitada. Interface travada, controles que não funcionavam direito (quando funcionavam era só na base da gambiarra com Joy2Key da vida) e sem suporte decente pra resoluções modernas. Mesmo assim, fui longe: acumulei mais de 60 horas e cheguei bem perto do fim.

Anos depois, com o lançamento da versão Remastered, finalmente parecia a chance de terminar essa jornada com dignidade. Mas veio o Windows 11… e junto dele uma série de problemas: o jogo travava, dava erro de inicialização e simplesmente não era confiável. Acabei deixando engavetado.

Até que, recentemente, instalei no Asus ROG Ally rodando o sistema Bazzite — e, pra minha surpresa, o jogo rodou perfeitamente fluido. Sem bugs, sem travamentos, e o melhor: reconheceu meu save antigo da versão de 2013 da Steam. Pude retomar exatamente de onde tinha parado, no finalzinho do jogo, e finalmente ver os créditos rolando depois de tanto tempo.

Veredito: se você também ficou pelo caminho por causa das limitações técnicas da época, essa é a hora. O remaster tem seus detalhes estranhos, mas respeita a essência do original. Jogar isso no ROG Ally com Bazzite foi como dar um abraço no meu eu criança — só que agora com gráficos decentes, desempenho impecável e controle funcionando sem truque.

Platinumed this on PS4. FF8 Remastered has really breathed new life into this amazing albeit experimental RPG. The hi res textures and the new models look incredible and make it feel like it's a whole new game. For those hesitant about starting FF8 for the first time, make this the version you start with. 

FF8 took the classic formula and really expanded on the character development system and battle system of Final Fantasy 6 (for those familiar with it. Also those who grew up in the U.S. in the early 90s will probably know it as Final Fantasy 3.)  While the story itself might seem confusing, it's a simple chosen one storyline similar to FF1 told more through subtlety and visual cues than anything fully spelled out for you. As a result, casual gamers who prefer a more "spoonfed" story might take issue with it. Also, the system, while notorious for being exploitable, deserves another look and definitely appreciation for its design philosophy and how well thought out it is. It's not perfect but this game certainly deserves more praise than it often gets from the community and gamers at large.

column8: 我的青春呀~

So this is a cautious recommendation - the first two thirds of the game are quite good, especially the first third, the last third is a tangled piece of crap - now I know it's an old game - but really playing it in 2025 was quite a jarring experience.

The good:

-Combat - FF8 has the best, fastest and crispiest combat of all the PS1 are Final Fantasies (FF7-FF9) 

-The junction system - I have to admit this is probably my fourth time playing the game - and I only really started understanding it - it's wonderful once you figure out how it works..though unnecessarily complicated 

-Triple triad card game - especially in the beginning until you get all bullshit rules added around second half of the game


so..it should be really good right? well.. the problem is - yeah I like the combat, but there is not enough of it - it gets interrupted by cutscenes and plot all the time - so let's get to the bad

The plot - starts out decent but it becomes total non-sense even by Final Fantasy standards..and that's saying a lot - really the pacing is terrible

Laguna sequences - irritating as hell

Dungeon design - almost all dungeons are too short, or make you run around in circles - gee what could be more fun

..sigh..I liked this game as a kid, I liked it in the beginning but I just can't bring myself to finish it - so yeah - if you are a fan of the franchise give it a try - otherwise I wouldn't start here

I have been playing this game since I was 6 years old and continue to replay it ever couple of years ever since. This game means a lot to me for personal reasons and will forever be my favorite game of all time. The story is incredible and the grinding and junction system is a lot of fun. Finding how to craft weapons found in magazines and unlocking new ultimate abilities as well as summons (Guardian forces) that you can find 'hidden' or more complicated to find or get ones; its all a lot of fun to grind doing so while enjoying the greatest music and characters and storyline. Yes the story may confuse some so pay attention and you'll click some things together I don't want to spoil anything. Thank you for remastering this game to allow it to be more accessible I have loved seeing FFVIII included in KH and Dissidia over the years but still feel it should have more recognition. BEST GAME EVER.

column8:
I feel I owe Final Fantasy VIII an apology. For 26 years, I believed its reputation as not only bad but possibly the worst mainline Final Fantasy game to release. Not helping was the fact that it was living in the shadow of what I—and most—would consider to be likely the greatest of them all: Final Fantasy VI and VII. While it's true it does not match either of those previous titles, I was wrong to think it was a terrible game. It's quite good, for the most part.

Pros:

- Characters: The entire roster of your party members is memorable and likable. Nobody is annoying, and everyone is relatable. Their character development is subtle yet appreciated. From the calm times to the hectic moments, their thoughts and reactions are grounded, and everyone brings a unique flavor with their demeanor to help round out a great cast.

- Performance: No surprises here. This remaster, released in 2019 and based on a 1999 PS1 game, has no performance issues—even on handheld devices. I never once experienced any oddities with the game engine, so optimization concerns should not be worried about.

- Visuals: The updated character models are a major step up. (More on this in the cons.)

- Audio: Excellent music score.

- Plot: For the most part, the plot is good. I do feel it stumbles towards the end of the game, but for the first three-quarters, it feels solid.

- Battle Mechanics: A great traditional turn-based system.

- Triple Triad: While many Final Fantasy mini-games result in hair-pulling, teeth-grinding bouts of madness, the Triple Triad card game was not that bad. Spending time playing it also helps the actual game with the card refinement ability, which made me feel I wasn’t just wasting my precious time on mini-game garbage.

Cons:

- Character Development: While I appreciate that the game doesn’t get bogged down or linger on ridiculous drama, more character depth and development would have been helpful. After 70 hours and feeling like I know these characters, I still feel many are underdeveloped, and that is a shame.

- Visuals: Holy crap, this remaster was a lazy attempt in many ways. The updated character models are noticeably contrasted by the extremely blurry backgrounds, NPCs, and certain other assets. The remaster did not use any AI upscaling to assist with these low-resolution results, and it really should have been better.

- Plot: The plot seems to lose itself towards the end. Outside of Squall and Rinoa, the interpersonal relationships of the other characters all seem to be swept under the rug. The time travel aspect feels lazy, and with a game that already has an entire world to explore—even a world-changing event with the moon involving outer space—the time travel element seems unnecessary. Suddenly revealed plot twists often feel too contrived, and it seems like too many things were thrown at the wall as the story progressed. This detracts from the uniqueness of the first three-quarters of the game.

- Junction System: I won't go into too much detail, but it’s terrible. The game does a terrible job of explaining it (and many other things) to the player, which makes it even worse. Even with the switch function, it's just annoying when you have to change up up your squad members. Its quite frankly bizarre. The magic system also sucks, as drawing magic can be incredibly tedious. The fact that the more junctioned magic you use lowers your character's overall power is counter-intuitive. While you can use abilities to refine items and cards into magic as well, its still a miserable time suck. It’s all too complex and tedious, and I can’t think of anything positive to say about it.

- Level Scaling: Not a fan. It really diminishes the reward of powering up.

I’m really glad I finally experienced this game in full. While there are certainly aspects that sour the experience, overall, it’s still a title I can easily recommend. Within the Final Fantasy series spanning I to XIII (excluding XI, as it’s an MMO, and noting that I have yet to play IX, XV, or XVI at the time of this review), I’d say it falls somewhere in the middle. VI and VII remain far superior in my eyes, but I would replay VIII before ever considering another run of XIII. I rank it right between X and XII, as X reaches greater highs but suffers lower lows, whereas XII, lacks the charm I found in both VIII and X.

If you’ve never experienced this game, give it a shot. It’s not perfect, but you’re bound to have a great time.

Sem duvida a melhor historia da franquia....de longe. 

O sistema de drenar magia pode ser cansativo para pessoas como eu que não gostam de farmar. O que os demais JRPGs tem de farm de level, esse tem farm de magias.
O sistema de junctions é quebrado apenas para quem já conhece o jogo, o que não seria um problema. Porém o mesmo sistema te instiga a não usar as magias acopladas no seu personagem.
Os GF(summons), embora bonitos, passam a ter um dano não tão expressivo no terceiro CD.

Ps: A tradução do Japones para o Ingles teve problemas. O ''whatever'' que o personagem tanto fala, está errado. Acabou fazendo o personagem principal ter um ar de soberba, o que não confere com o material original.

95/10

Years ago, I played this on the PS1 after coming away from legendary JRPGs such as Phantasy Star 4 and Final Fantasy 7 very impressed and wanting more. I was hugely disapointed, and very bored by it. 

After many years of reading internet hype stating it's misunderstood, and how the QoL features if the Remaster made it much better, I decided to give it another go on the cheap. And unfortunately, it's still crap. The QoL additions make it more bareable (lord knows screen load times are far more tolerable), but overall all the issues of the original (silly easy/dull gameplay, emo-vibes etc.) all remain. 

I love the music though, and some of the summons are very cool too. There's no doubt that there are some cool moments in here. But yeah, it's a crap game really. A reminder of how hardcore Final Fantasy fans are pretty blinkered creatures, unable to view things with any remote objectivity.

column8: El juego es bastante similar a la versión publicada en el 2013, con algunas diferencias. Cambio de modelos de los personajes principales, mayor compatibilidad con controles, filtros gráficos, algunos cambios en el arte de las cartas, los logros son mas accesibles y la música ahora esta en formato MP3.

[b]El más raro y más experimental... pero también uno de los más queridos.[/b]
FFVIII cambia muchas cosas respecto a otros títulos clásicos: el sistema de magias, el de mejoras, y la forma de subir de nivel. Tiene una historia compleja, algo enrevesada, pero con momentos muy memorables. La remasterización mejora los personajes, pero deja los fondos igual, lo que choca un poco.

[u][b]Lo bueno:[/b][/u]

Historia original y con personalidad.

El sistema de Guardian Forces y enlaces da mucho juego.

BSO espectacular como siempre.

[u][b]Lo malo:[/b][/u]

No es fácil de entender al principio.

Gráficamente irregular (modelos HD vs fondos antiguos).

[b]¿Vale la pena?[/b]
Sí, si buscas algo diferente dentro de la saga. No es perfecto, pero tiene alma propia.

I wanted to try out this classic FF title… but honestly, I came out of it with mixed feelings.

- The Good :

I really enjoyed the GF system. Hunting them down, unlocking them, and boosting abilities was actually fun.

I liked the leveling and AP grind, especially the customization through junctions.

The remaster features (speed x3 , etc.) definitely help with pacing and cut out some of the annoying parts.


- The Bad :

The story didn’t click with me. The orphanage twist felt random and poorly explained.

I couldn’t connect with the characters at all. Squall is way too cold and distant, and Linoa just felt inconsistent—falling for Seifer, then suddenly switching to Squall without much depth or build-up.

Triple Triad (card game)? Nope. Too many confusing rules and random regional changes. I dropped it fast.

Despite the remaster, some mechanics still feel outdated or overly complex for no reason.

- Conclusion : 

at the end if you enjoy digging into systems, optimizing builds, and grinding, this might be your kind of FF. But if you’re looking for a strong story or characters that stick with you… there are better Final Fantasies out there.

>>>  Personal score: (6/10) – Not terrible, but definitely not for me.

Il vaut mieux prendre le jeu original et le modder, car bien que la communauté soit active et que pas mal de contenu soit disponible au niveau d'améliorations de textures autres que les personnages (le seul point travaillé par ce remaster), les mods semblent plus complets pour le titre non remasterisé. Des textures plus propres pour tous les environnements hors combat auraient été très appéciables mais rien n'est finalisé pour l'instant et derrière un paywall contrairement aux mods FF8 normal.
Outre cet aspect, c'est toujours un plaisir de replonger dans ce titre, même si c'est probablement surtout de la nostalgie, certaines mécaniques du jeu étant plutôt mal optimisées. Je pense notamment au vol de magie qui prend vraiment trop longtemps même si c'est supplanté par la création de magie dès obtention des bonnes compétences à cet effet.

Systems are unique, and different from anything else in the series and it does take a short while to get going but this game has some of my favourite characters, moments and story moments in any of the series.

If you like JRPG's, its a hard recommend!

column8:
I won't lie, this game has serious flaws, even by a 20-year-old game standards, but its worth the play to understand the innovations in it and addressing common criticisms of other JRPG's.

Cons: lots of areas on the map require you to walk toward the camera without a clear indicator that there's an exit or activation area. There's lots of muddy backgrounds that don't appear interactable, but they are. Third, there is not an option for the ATB gauge to pause while you're selecting options. The monster turns are adjusted such that I didn't realize this until well into my first play-through.

Pros: The card-game is well-integrated into the systems available, if the rules are obscure, they do offer a variety in gameplay. Knowing that I needed to junction instead of level-grind was a big help.

Betrayals: Almost every JRPG has your LEVEL as the primary driver for growth. While this it isn't inherently bad, this ubiquity means that a player's first instinct is to grind in the early levels, making this a much harder game. No where IN THE GAME does it explain that enemies' strength grows with your level. Also the magic you can Draw from enemies improves with level, but these curves don't match.

Additionally, the GF's grant access to basic commands. Without them, you can't even use items. One might think that using an item would not require a mystic creature, and the idea of a GF-less run is essentially impossible because of this. I can't help but feel this was an intentional design decision, further cementing a "Narrow style" of play. ( I don't like having my arm twisted )

I'm tempted to restart the game ( on Disk 2 now ) due to how much I've missed or been conditioned to miss by the rest of the industry.

While I like the idea of the GF being trained and Magic Junction systems, I think these systems were reskinned and refined in FFIX much better.

column8:
If you haven't played this game yet, I suggest picking this one up. I played the original PSX version years back, and one thing that still amazes me is how, in certain cutscenes, it mixes full-motion videos (FMVs) as pre-rendered backgrounds while letting you control the character or triggering quick-time moments. That kind of blend was revolutionary back in the day. It felt like the game was ahead of its time.

The remastered version offers better-detailed 3D models for the main characters, as well as specific Guardian Forces and monsters, but it still retains the old models for minor NPCs and some enemies. It’s a bit of a visual mismatch at times, but the upgrades do make a noticeable difference where it counts (and if it really bothers you, there are mods that can cover that gap).

Honestly I wouldn't mind if they price this game higher while adding all of those things I just mentioned that are lacking, but at the end of the day it is modable so you can fix what you find lacking.

I recommend this version over the older release available on Steam commonly referred to by fans as the 2013 PC re-release (or Final Fantasy VIII in the Steam listing). That one requires a Square Enix account to access some features, while this remastered version doesn’t. It’s a smoother, more accessible experience overall, especially on modern hardware.

I have seen reports saying this game is unstable. For the first 10 hours, I have played this game on my Surface Pro 8, Gaming PC (Running on Linux) and Steamdeck, I can confidently say I experience none of those, so feel free.

Il miglior FINAL FANTASY!!

Ich möchte vorweg eines sagen: Final Fantasy VIII war mein erstes Final Fantasy – die Windows-Version von 2000. Ich habe also einen sehr nostalgischen Blick auf das Spiel.
Es unterscheidet sich stark von anderen FF-Teilen: Zum einen durch den eher realistischen Stil der Charaktere, zum anderen durch ungewöhnliche Gameplay-Mechaniken – allen voran das Magie-/Koppelsystem.
Es ist sicher nicht jedermanns Lieblings-Final Fantasy und auch nicht so populär wie Teil 7 oder 10.
Aber eines muss ich sagen: Der Soundtrack ist absolut genial!
Und jetzt zum Remaster:
Es ist natürlich super, dass das Spiel wieder auf modernen Systemen läuft – meine alte CD-Version ist aus technischen Gründen heute nicht mehr spielbar.
Aber wenn man davon absieht, ist eigentlich gar nicht so viel „remastered“ worden.
Die 3D-Modelle wurden deutlich überarbeitet, aber die Hintergründe nur minimal – teils wirken sie sogar unschärfer oder weichgezeichnet. Dadurch fällt der Kontrast zwischen den neuen 3D-Modellen und den alten Hintergründen für mich noch stärker auf als im Original.
Die Weltkarte wurde gar nicht angefasst, die Zwischensequenzen ebenfalls nicht.
Ach ja, und es gibt jetzt ein Cheat-Menü …
Ich finde, FF8 ist kein schweres Spiel, und durch diverse Exploits kann man es sowieso ziemlich brechen – also braucht es das meiner Meinung nach nicht.
Das Vorspulen ist aber stellenweise sehr angenehm, gerade bei sehr... sehr langen Animationen von GF´s die man nicht zum zwanzigsten mal sehen möchte. Muss jeder für sich entscheiden.

Trotzdem!
FF8 ist ein wirklich gutes Spiel mit einer abgedrehten Story, coolen Charakteren, netten Kämpfen und – wie gesagt – einem fantastischen Soundtrack.

column8:
[h1]7/10[/h1]
Final Fantasy VIII sits in an unfortunate position between the legendary FFVII and the excellent series tribute FFIX. VIII is still a good game that really defined the series’ trend of radically changing with every entry. It's truly commendable how unique this game feels, instead of trying to capture the success of FFVII again. 

However, these dramatic changes found in VIII hinder the game from being one of the series’ best. The coming of age tale juxtaposed against a world defined by war is beautiful, but these themes feel a little undercooked. Likewise, the magic system of VIII is great for fine control over your party, but relies heavily on boring statistical management. And yet, despite these shortcomings, the legacy and innovation of VIII far outshine any issues I had with the game.

[table]
[tr]
	[th]Positives[/th]
	[th]Negatives[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]✅ Whimsical narrative
✅ One of the most innovate Final Fantasy games
✅ Strong character relationships 
[/td]
	[td]❌ Combat is micro management heavy
❌ Underdeveloped story elements
❌ Somewhat empty world map
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]A Story of Gardens and SeeDs…[/h1]
What makes FF VIII’s main cast so unique is their shared circumstances. Squall and friends are struggling with the first stages of adulthood, whilst attending a militaristic school that expects them to be soldiers. I really liked when the cast expressed their youthfulness, little moments of brevity to distract from their dire responsibilities. Their similar ages also helps the party relationships develop naturally, I really enjoyed their interactions.

These expectations of responsibility weigh heavily on Squall. He is such a great protagonist, he’s cold and brash like Cloud, but also just way more of an asshole. The story does a fantastic job annoying you with his shitty behaviour before sympathising with his insecurities. It’s lovely seeing his friends’ support slowly open him up. His bond with Rinoa in particular has become one of my favourite relationships in the series.

While I love the rest of the party, they lack the development Squall and Rinoa receive. Outside of the main cast, there are far more notable examples of half baked characters. While I enjoy her ambiguity, the main antagonist is far too distant from the story's events. I was most disappointed in Seifers role. The story sets him up perfectly as Squall’s rival, facing similar anxieties, yet he ends up feeling like nothing more than a recurring boss.

The main story took a while to win me over, but I did enjoy the adventure overall. It throws you off the deep end with intense missions and high stakes, which really sells how overwhelmed Squall feels. But it's clear more time should’ve been spent developing the school setting to highlight the characters’ dual lives, and make Balamb Garden feel like a home for the player. 

There were several interesting threads that kept me captivated (Laguna in particular), but not all of them receive satisfying resolutions. The story has a tendency to just throw a lot of things at you simultaneously without any breathing room. There's an infamous reveal about halfway through the story that’s meant to change everything, but the characters move past it so quickly that I question how necessary the twist was at all.

Thankfully I’ll always remember these locations thanks to the beautiful graphics. The remaster improves the character models, however the pre-rendered backgrounds remain unchanged, so the contrast in quality is a bit odd at times. 

While their resolution is dated, the backgrounds still look gorgeous and add so much personality to every locale. I especially enjoyed when the game blended pre-rendered cutscenes with actual gameplay. These sequences are excellent, they’re used in very clever ways to add so much spectacle, despite the technological limitations of 1999.

[h1]A World with Endless Magic to Draw…[/h1]
VIII’s combat is built around two new systems, Junctions and Drawing. Each spell is its own resource, one that can be drawn from enemies and junctioned to increase certain stats. If you play RPGs that focus on micromanaging menus to become unstoppable, you’ll love this. As someone who likes making active decisions in combat, I didn’t enjoy this combat much.

Junctioning comes with a lot of issues; It's not explained clearly, drawing magic takes a lot of time and micromanaging equipped magic within limited inventory space is tedious. But the worst part is how it encourages optimising the fun out of gameplay. Ultimately, no strategy is going to beat spamming normal attacks in every fight with your strongest magic equipped. Since using magic will decrease your stats (and it’ll probably do less damage than attacking), what's the point of doing anything else?

However I quite liked Guardian Forces, VIII’s take on summons. The Guardians you equip plays a major role in your character's build, as it determines their abilities and bonuses. Guardians learn more abilities over the adventure, and you can even teach them specific commands, but since characters can equip several Guardians at once, I never felt the need to do this. The summon animations are cool, but they’re quite long and I find it odd you can use them over and over.

I think the exploration VIII is a little lacking compared to other titles but still pretty good. There's not a lot of places to find off the beaten path, a few chunks of the world map tend to feel strangely empty. Thankfully the few side zones are still quite interesting and add a lot of flavour to the world.

The main locations really pull their weight though. Each town is so unique, jam packed with charming characters or interesting secrets.I can’t stress enough how great the pre-rendered backgrounds are for breathing life into every area. Even if it’s underused, the school setting is such a unique idea for this series’, the Garden itself looked excellent.

Thankfully the world map is hiding a lot of useful stuff, such as creatures hoarding powerful spells or mighty guardians in hidden dungeons. But you can’t talk about VIII’s side content without talking about Triple Triad, a card game that nearly everyone in the world seems to play. It’s very simple but quite fun, and you can easily see how it influenced optional minigames across countless RPGs.

And as always with this series, the music is simply astounding, I can tell a lot of these tracks will stick with me for a very long time. VIII’s soundtrack is very good at showcasing just how at odds this world feels; sci-fi clashing against magic, children managing wars, VIII’s world is one of charm, terror, and confusion, and the soundtrack captures that perfectly.

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
I enjoyed my time with Final Fantasy VIII, but I prefer most of the other entries in the series. The beautiful thing about Final Fantasy is how varied every title is, both narratively and mechanically. I’d still recommend VIII to people interested in the series, knowing that some people are gonna love this one a lot more than me.

VIII’s combat is built around two new systems, Junctions and Drawing. Each spell is its own resource, one that can be drawn from enemies and junctioned to increase certain stats. If you play RPGs that focus on micromanaging menus to become unstoppable, you’ll love this. As someone who likes making active decisions in combat, I didn’t enjoy this combat much.

Junctioning comes with a lot of issues; It's not explained clearly, drawing magic takes a lot of time and micromanaging equipped magic within limited inventory space is tedious. But the worst part is how it encourages optimising the fun out of gameplay. Ultimately, no strategy is going to beat spamming normal attacks in every fight with your strongest magic equipped. Since using magic will decrease your stats (and it’ll probably do less damage than attacking), what's the point of doing anything else?

However I quite liked Guardian Forces, VIII’s take on summons. The Guardians you equip plays a major role in your character's build, as it determines their abilities and bonuses. Guardians learn more abilities over the adventure, and you can even teach them specific commands, but since characters can equip several Guardians at once, I never felt the need to do this. The summon animations are cool, but they’re quite long and I find it odd you can use them over and over.

I think the exploration VIII is a little lacking compared to other titles but still pretty good. There's not a lot of places to find off the beaten path, a few chunks of the world map tend to feel strangely empty. Thankfully the few side zones are still quite interesting and add a lot of flavour to the world.

The main locations really pull their weight though. Each town is so unique, jam packed with charming characters or interesting secrets.I can’t stress enough how great the pre-rendered backgrounds are for breathing life into every area. Even if it’s underused, the school setting is such a unique idea for this series’, the Garden itself looked excellent.

Thankfully the world map is hiding a lot of useful stuff, such as creatures hoarding powerful spells or mighty guardians in hidden dungeons. But you can’t talk about VIII’s side content without talking about Triple Triad, a card game that nearly everyone in the world seems to play. It’s very simple but quite fun, and you can easily see how it influenced optional minigames across countless RPGs.

And as always with this series, the music is simply astounding, I can tell a lot of these tracks will stick with me for a very long time. VIII’s soundtrack is very good at showcasing just how at odds this world feels; sci-fi clashing against magic, children managing wars, VIII’s world is one of charm, terror, and confusion, and the soundtrack captures that perfectly.

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
I enjoyed my time with Final Fantasy VIII, but I prefer most of the other entries in the series. The beautiful thing about Final Fantasy is how varied every title is, both narratively and mechanically. I’d still recommend VIII to people interested in the series, knowing that some people are gonna love this one a lot more than me.

As a long time fan of the Final Fantasy franchise, there is a lot I liked about Final Fantasy VIII - the story, characters, music, and world are magnificent and the Remaster does a good job (with the understood technical limitations) of giving it a nice coat of paint and a cleaner look.

Unfortunately it's hard for me to recommend this to anyone but hardcore FF, or OG FFVIII fans, the game's junction system is overly complex, the progression systems feel broken a lot of the time and you end up having to deal with a number of difficulty spikes because of it, and finally you rely quite a bit on Summons (Guardian Forces) - which have lengthy attacks that you'll need to sit through time and time again making each battle feel like it's really dragging on.

I feel like the game is so mechanically broken and frustrating that it's hard to recommend on its own merits.

All of that said, I still really appreciate this entry into the series, and it's clear the developers were trying a lot of new things in the franchise at the time - but I'd still only recommend this to series veterans or those that have played this game before and know what to expect.

column8:
[h1]Final Fantasy VIII was one of my very first video games[/h1] I still remember seeing that incredible game jacket at the game store, whispering "Play me," in the most subtle yet irresistible way!

Fast forward 24 years and I’ve finally finished it, thanks to the PC Remaster and a few mods (for music and UI). The university/training setting feels so relatable, capturing the essence of young growth & self-discovery. The characters feel super human, mature, and emotionally compelling. The writing? Simply stellar—one of the best stories I’ve experienced across any medium. Still mentally dying about that ending...

Yeah the gameplay (junction system) is unconventional but that’s precisely part of FFVIII’s unique charm. There’s an undeniable vibe to this game, an atmosphere of melancholy and aching sadness, all wrapped in breathtakingly beautiful moments. Few medias have ever managed to evoke such emotions in me, especially with its incredible OST that stays long after the journey ends.

The plot is intricate, layered with deep meaning and driven by the personal struggles of its main characters. I truly loved every moment of it! Time travel and sacrifice have always been some of my favorite themes in storytelling.

I will forever cherish this treasured memory. 

Thank you, Final Fantasy VIII, for shaping a part of who I am today.

PS: The pc port is just fine! You can x3 speed to make grinding less tedious and use endless limit breaks (use it for grinding but keep it off in the main story for normal challenge)

Oh dear, this is first Final Fantasy during my journey through series that i much more don't like than like. What i like it's graphics, this both modern and fantastic looking world full of beautiful background and nostalgic reto CGI cutscenes. And Nobuo Uematsu music is awesome. But rest? Oh boy, i almost hated this game for the rest. Plot has no sense and is full of holes, shortcuts and fortunatly coincidences and wordbuilding is sever lacking. I don't like any of characters, most of them is just dumb and Squall is antipathetic, annoying puppet on strings with no human brain or emotions. Gameplay wanted to be revolution for series and its time and is absolutly tiring, over convoluted and time consuming. You need to constant grind something, magic or cards (i don't like card games) and traditional character development is little important in comparison to many chained together mechanics. And most of enemies are damage sponges. Thank you remaster for speed time, because i don't know if i would have patient to complete this game otherwise.

"...Whatever"

This game gets a lot of hate from people because of the magic system and how badly it deviated from traditional systems in the Final Fantasy series. However it made it that you could tinker with it as much as you want to get things done your way. There is of course a best build for most characters, but at the end of the day it's just like many other Final Fantasy systems and it was unique and different from the others. The story did have a few holes in it you had to really dig through the information and side quests to figure out what the hell was what and who was who, but at the end of the day- the story did show how so many things from so many places can intertwine and create what we have to push through to the future.

It does show that once you go behind the curtain of what you see, you'll learn that sometimes you are no more a puppet in the stage that is your own life. With confidence, strength, and persistence you can try to forge your own path forward, but it doesn't mean it's going to be one you wanted- so always be aware of the surrounding circumstances.

Overall impression of this low effort "remaster" is this was done by passionless employees who couldn't care less about the job, knowing they were only contracted to just further extend the copyright or something mundane like that. They didn't do it because they actually care about the games legacy and want to preserve the story in an up to date format. Its genuinely insulting... Still nothing done to it years later.

Other retro re-releases or retro/arcade collections come with nice features like borders as opposed to black bars, borders that could display character portraits and concept art from the game, or skins simulating TV sets and arcade cabinets or just scanline filters. This both preserves the quality of the game rendered at its native resolution and creates a nostalgic aesthetic. Look at the Sega Classics collection, Capcom Arcade collections and even the way arcade games are displayed in game in the Yakuza series. Heck even emulators do it better! 

All we really got was some redrawn models which only manage to make the flaws of the blurry pre-rendered backgrounds look more awful, some boosters/cheats and an inferior alternative to the PocketStation, Original and 2013 PC version mini-game, Chocobo World.

Still no analogue/walk run sensitivity, probably still no vibration, they DID eventually patch the horrendous original PC music, so that's something. It may take more time to clean up pre-rendered backgrounds, but in the era of "AI" is that even an excuse anymore?

There are some amazing modders working on both this and the 2013 version. I'm paranoid to list them or specific features of the mods if there's a chance it might attract Square-Enix lawyers since the only respectful remaster we might ever get of this game is from modders. But these mods are divided across versions and require above average (IMO) modding experience to set up. 

I've gone through hoops just to play this game the way I remember it. Tried desperately to acquire another CRT TV or monitor after my last one died, looked for 4:3/low res displays online to play the original game (which I've purchased numerous times over the years), I've gone through the drudgery of trying to learn complicated modding when I'm lucky to even get the free time to play anymore. I just want to experience the damn story as it was meant again!!!! Why is it so difficult?!

I'm being harsh because I love this game. I grew up with this story. The way it touched on mature themes many youth such as myself were going through when we first played it, that maybe not a lot of Western media handled with sensitivity at the time (it was the "Attitude Era" when edgy media was cool, bullying was rampant and boys were told to be a man and take abuse. We couldn't "just run away"). 

This game was my introduction to JRPG's and manga/anime story conventions. The first media aimed at youth with characters, simply put, who were going through shhh that I recall experiencing. Those themes may have been tropey/cliche for experienced Japanese media fans even then, but I was just a kid with limited access and it was revolutionary for me.

I want this work to be preserved for the lessons it taught me and the emotions it helped me understand as I experienced similar things in my own life. Like the deaths of people close to us, recognising and understanding trauma/defence mechanisms (Our boy, Squall), bullying/violent school rivalry and understanding the opposite sex (I at least became self-aware as a painful introvert watching Squall's blunders and missed signals LOL)...

Some hate Squall for the same reason many of us love him. Seeing Squall's complex and draining internal monologues about life, death, relying on others and everything in between, then seeing him hesitant to express his feelings openly. And the few patient supportive friends/family figures enduring with him as he steadily grows over the course of the journey..

Its an honest take on something many of us have experienced and is incredibly cathartic to witness.

If its really too much work, at least give us an OVA like VII Advent Children. Hell, even give me the story as a VN or just a graphic novel. Its just tragic that this gem is not available in a modern format that captures its beauty in both art and storytelling.

I hate that a game I'm so passionate about I can't even really show off to my nearest and dearest because of the painfully bad condition of all versions on the market and the work that needs to be done to fix it.

Final Fantasy VIII Remastered – A Journey Through Time
I first played Final Fantasy VIII back in 1999, and even then, the main character, Squall, resonated with me deeply. His struggle to communicate his thoughts and emotions felt relatable, while Laguna represented the kind of person I aspired to be—someone who embraced friendships, took risks, and kept moving forward despite setbacks.

Now, on this second playthrough with the remastered version, I found myself appreciating the game on a much deeper level. While FFVIII’s gameplay and story can be complex—even for the most focused player—I’d recommend taking the time to understand the underlying themes. The real heart of the story isn’t just in the plot; it’s in the characters themselves. Once I let go of trying to piece everything together immediately and just enjoyed the journey, I found the experience much more rewarding.

Gameplay & Mechanics – A Fresh Perspective
The Guardian Forces (GF) and magic system can be as powerful as you allow them to be. Back in 1999, I relied heavily on GFs, which was a blast at the time. However, this time around, with a better understanding of the Junction system and the Triple Triad card game, I optimized my team at a lower level, using their unique abilities to my advantage more effectively. This approach added a new layer of strategy that made the game even more fun.

Looking back, my younger self would be amazed at how much I’ve "leveled up" as a player. I pushed for a 100% completion run, collected all the cards, and mastered each character’s Limit Breaks—from Quistis’ Degenerator to Squall’s Lion Heart, which made combat feel incredibly rewarding.

A Must-Use Feature – 3x Speed Boost
It’s worth noting that Final Fantasy VIII originally had a slow-paced battle system, which might feel sluggish by today’s standards. Thankfully, the remastered version includes a 3x speed boost, which I highly recommend using. It makes grinding, battles, and general exploration much smoother without taking away from the experience.

Final Thoughts
Revisiting Final Fantasy VIII has been both nostalgic and eye-opening. While some aspects of the game might feel dated, its storytelling, character depth, and unique gameplay mechanics still stand the test of time. Whether you're a returning player or a newcomer, take your time, embrace the journey, and enjoy the ride—because Final Fantasy VIII is more than just a game; it’s an experience.

column8:
Bon, évidemment je vais recommander ce jeu hein, après plus de 1000 heures passées dessus...

FF8 n'est pas nouveau pour moi. J'en avais déjà fait le tour extensivement à sa sortie, en 1999. Je me souviens encore de ce moment où, avec un ami et ma blonde, j'avais démarré le jeu fraîchement acheté dans la PlayStation, appuyé sur l'option New Game, et où la cinématique avait démarré. Nous l'avions écoutée sans dire un mot, subjugués. Une fois celle-ci terminée, sans nous concerter, nous avions juste redémarré le jeu pour la réécouter. Les cinématiques de ce jeu sont bonnes à ce point-là.

Les Final Fantasy ont rythmé ma croissance vers l'âge adulte; FF4 et FF6 ont ponctué mon enfance, FF7 a coloré mon adolescence et FF8 est arrivé à ce moment délicat où la société nous affuble de cette description d'adulte mais où nous sommes encore en réalité dans ce no-man's land entre un cortex frontal encore incomplet et la véritable maturité. Je me suis immédiatement identifié. [i]J'étais[/i] Squall, et [i]j'étais[/i] amoureux de Rinoa, sans savoir comment exprimer ou résoudre ce nœud dans ma vie.

Inutile de dire que je me suis plongé dedans à pieds joints, et que j'en ai exploré tous les coins et recoins possibles. Même après l'avoir refait avec des yeux d'adultes, l'histoire est encore excellente. Certains personnages manquent tout de même un peu de profondeur, mais ce n'est après tout pas le but: le réel but de l'histoire est l'exploration de Squall et de ses sentiments et relations, et sa découverte progressive qu'il n'est pas, après tout, seul. Après l'avoir terminé plusieurs fois, les mécanismes du jeu n'ont plus eu de secrets pour moi, et je me suis rendu compte qu'il était possible de maximiser presque toutes les stats de nos personnages en utilisant certaines skills qui permettent de gagner de l'argent à l'infini et de transmuter certains objets en d'autres. Dans ma vocation complétionniste (ça vient de loin n'est-ce pas), j'ai commencé le laborieux processus.

Après ~200h (je ne me rappelle plus du chiffre exact), j'ai renoncé. Cela fonctionnait, mais était par trop abrutissant et répétitif.

Mais je n'avais pas oublié...

Et maintenant, après avoir acheté de nouveau cette version très bien remastérisée sur Steam (je pense que c'est la 4e fois que je rachète ce jeu sous une forme ou une autre), je me sens accompli. Ça m'a pris ~130 h pour compléter toutes les facettes primaires du jeu, et par après ~1300 h pour maxer mes stats et maxer mon inventaire (enfin pas tout l'inventaire, mais presque, et je saurais comment faire pour faire le reste, ce n'est encore qu'une question d'investissement de temps). Je suis virtuellement invincible et Omega Weapon (et à plus forte raison Ultimecia) n'ont été pour moi que des formalités.

Soyons honnête, je ne l'ai pas fait "à main", vu qu'une fraction absolument abominablement élevée de ce temps est passée à jouer dans des menus, mais j'ai codé une série de petits scripts auto-hotkey que je démarrais pendant la nuit qui faisait le gros du travail pour moi, et desquels je récupérais les fruits le matin. Est-ce que je me sens coupable de ne pas avoir mis mon huile de coude (doigt) pour ce faire ? Pas du tout, et honnêtement peu me chaut ce que d'autres pourraient penser: je l'ai fait pour moi-même, et je me sens satisfait à ma mesure.

J'ai maintenant matérialisé ma vision de ce qu'était une game parfaite de ce jeu que j'avais entrevue, il y a si longtemps.

Recommandé.

If you've never played FF8 -- sure, this is a good version to play if you'd like to play it on PC. If you HAVE played FF8 and you were hoping for a "Remastered" version, this is not the purchase for you. Here's a list of things that have been updated:

- Character models are higher rez
- x3 speed, No Encounters, and instant turns/limit breaks/healing, all at the press of a button combo

... and that's it. The backgrounds remain blurry, translation is the same, and Chocobo World remains inaccessible.

column8:
🔹 LE « VILAIN PETIT CANARD DE LA LICENCE » ?

FINAL FANTASY VIII a la lourde tâche de passer après le succès commercial & critique qu’a été son prédécesseur. Ainsi, rien d’étonnant que sur ses épaules repose l’ambition d’aller plus loin, de rêver plus haut...
En lançant une « Nouvelle Partie », ce qui m’a immédiatement séduit a été la mise en scène plus endiablée, ainsi que des graphismes améliorés poussant davantage les capacités de la PlayStation jusqu'à avoir des personnages aux proportions plus réalistes dans de beaux décors pré-calculés, sublimant un univers lui aussi contemporain, & poussant le côté science-fictionnel plus loin encore que FINAL FANTASY VII.
Le sel de cet épisode repose principalement sur l’importance de la magie, avec le choix de la lancer sur les adversaires en la puisant directement chez l’ennemi ou en la stockant dans notre réserve personnelle après l’avoir volée à ce dernier. De prime abord, ce fonctionnement n’est pas très clair selon moi, la faute à des tutoriels manquant un peu de clarté. Puis, finalement, c’est tout le fonctionnement de ce système qui est bancal. Mais c’est pourtant simple : plus on emmagasine de la magie (en la créant via des capacités spéciales, en la puisant dans des sources de magies trouvables un peu partout à travers le monde, ou encore en la stockant comme précédemment expliquer), plus nos héros augmentent leurs caractéristiques (Attaque, Défense, etc.) & deviennent plus puissants. Mais ceci, à condition d’avoir associé les bonnes magies aux bonnes caractéristiques ! Cependant... après quelques essais & un réel investissement à la comprendre, on se rend compte que la proposition est assez intéressante, l’importance de la magie se montrant en fin de compte particulièrement maligne.
Plus besoin, également, de points de magie pour pouvoir invoquer de puissantes entités. Cette fois-ci, elles ont aussi des HP (health points), & tant qu’elles en ont, il est possible de les convoquer durant les batailles. Elles peuvent aussi apprendre des capacités grâce à des points de compétence (PDC) que l’on reçoit en récompense des combats. Ces compétences permettent d'augmenter la puissance des « G-Forces » (le nom donné aux Invocations de cet épisode) & d’augmenter les caractéristiques des personnages, mais aussi d’utiliser de nouvelles techniques.
Rapidement, en se laissant porter par l’histoire, on réalise à quel point la mise en scène cinématographique que je qualifiais tantôt de « plus endiablée » se montre plus osée & rythmée que dans FFVII, apportant un véritable dynamise à plusieurs séquences narratives épiques, accentuées par des cinématiques dans lesquelles les personnages en 3D sont parfaitement incrustés, les rendant toujours jouables alors que les séquences continuent de se jouer en arrière-plan !
« FFVIII » aborde un scénario empreint de magie ainsi que de romantisme, rendant cet opus plutôt unique, en nous proposant même deux équipes de protagonistes aux destinées qui semblent se chevaucher... Mon regard sur les principaux personnages formant le groupe de héros principaux a, en premier lieu, été plutôt négatif. Ceci, à cause de protagonistes adolescents qui ne m’ont pas convaincu par leur caractère, leur comportement, ni même leur personnalité (certains se montrent froids, immatures, irascibles, irresponsables...), vis-à-vis des enjeux de l’intrigue. Seul l’un d’entre eux m’a paru avoir assez de caractère, de maturité & de recul pour porter le poids de la situation générale sur les épaules. Cependant, j’ai trouvé que le trio formé par la seconde équipe fonctionne plutôt bien, car on ressent l’alchimie & la complicité entre les trois compagnons d’armes, leurs aventures parfois teintées d’humour & de légèreté, qui m’ont beaucoup plus.
Puis... le second acte (le CD2) se présente soudain comme plus mature dans ses enjeux, ainsi que dans sa narration. Mais aussi plus épique ! D'ailleurs, c’est le cas depuis le dernier chapitre du premier acte (fin du premier CD). Alors, l’ensemble des principaux personnages m’a beaucoup moins séduit que ceux de FFVII, certes, mais, au final, il faut reconnaître que leur psyché devient peu à peu intéressante, faisant d’eux des protagonistes peu à peu attachants. Également, des révélations importantes commencent à émerger dans ce second acte, apportant une profondeur insoupçonnée à l’histoire qui ne cesse de nous surprendre jusqu'à son dénouement. Celle-ci nous entraîne jusqu'à avoir ce sentiment de ne plus avoir envie de lâcher la manette, malgré quelques révélations qui manquent parfois d’émotions & de sentiments.
L’intrigue est portée par une OST (original soundtrack) toujours aussi bonne, & qui doit sa célébrité à deux morceaux : « Liberi Fatali », ainsi que le morceau pop « Eyes on me », le thème musical principal (que je n’aime décidément pas), interprété par la chanteuse chinoise Faye Wong.
Cependant... cette version « remastered » manque très clairement d'ambition & d'envie. Une proposition faignante, selon moi. Car offrir un modèle 3D de personnage & de certains PNJ (personnages non-joueurs) certes très beau & plus lisse, ne suffit pas à une version remastérisée, surtout lorsqu'on fait le choix de délaisser tout ce qui aurait également mériter un soin particulier, comme : une amélioration graphique générale en HD (arrière-plans, cartes du monde, plus de PNJ retravaillés...), une amélioration des couleurs, des effets visuels & des ombres, mais aussi des cinématiques en 30 images par seconde au lieu de 15 d’origine, de même que pour la fluidité d’images générale qui aurait pu passer en 60 ips, un passage d’écran en format 16 : 9 aurait également été très appréciable, tout comme une possibilité de contrôle analogique de la caméra sur la carte du monde (la caméra actuelle étant, selon moi, très agaçante), etc. Ce « remaster » ne se contentant en fin de compte que de maigres options de personnalisation & de difficultés supplémentaires (dont certaines options désactivent l’obtention des succès).
En définitive, FINAL FANTASY VIII réussit le pari d’être un digne successeur à la série. C’est un opus qui a beaucoup à offrir, malgré quelques idées bancales. Un bien meilleur opus que son aîné, dû à sa volonté d’offrir des cinématiques plus belles, des graphismes plus poussés, une mise en scène plus dingue, ainsi qu’un univers qui va plus loin dans sa proposition. FFVIII est une franche réussite, & malgré cette version « remastered » décevante, si vous parvenez à passer au-dessus de cela, vous serez alors acteur / actrice d’une très chouette expérience vidéo-ludique.


🍃 CÆLIXIV

column8: クラッシュ多すぎ

本人第一次玩8代
优点：
1.音乐是真的好，不仅仅是王菲的《eyes on me》，好几首音乐都让我留下了深刻的印象
2.枪刃、斯考尔这个人设这么多年还是很帅
3.剧情还是不错的，在当初1999年，确实是天马行空，配得上“幻想”。男女主的感情线也写的挺不错。
缺点：
1.gameplay过于奇葩，不仅仅是古董就能解释的，感觉比我小时候玩的仙剑1还让我难受，可以说几十个小时的电子酷刑都不为过——①是升级会导致越来越难打，几乎是负反馈；②没有任务指引，经常不知道怎么触发任务；③地图是切割式的小地图而不是那种完整的大地图，再加上迷宫很复杂甚至迷宫里存档点都不太多，所以经常迷路+卡关；④小地图也就罢了，小地图是2D的模糊的背景（估计是没高清化吧），导致有些地图出入口完全无法认出来。
2.没有中文
综上，除非是像我一样对8代剧情感兴趣想亲手过一遍的，极其不建议购买游玩，否则真是至少十几个小时的电子酷刑

column8:
No he jugado TODOS los Final Fantasy, pero he jugado algunos y todos son buenos. A FFVIII le tengo un cariño especial porque fue el primero que jugué de toda la saga y su historia me encanta. Pueden decir lo que quieran del juego menos que es un juego malo por que no es cierto. Siendo sumamente objetivo, el remastered si podría haber sido mucho mejor, pero teniendo en cuenta todos los problemas que tuvieron espero de todo corazón que Square Enix compense eso con un REMAKE de este juego porque de verdad que es maravilloso. La historia de este juego compensa los errores de los desarrolladores. Pero por otra parte los desarrolladores hizieron lo que pudieron y se nota bastante sobre todo la mejora del diseño de los personajes. 
Ahora le hablaré a Square Enix. 
Square Enix, este juego es una maravilla. POR FAVOR HAGAN UN REMAKE. 
Estoy completamente seguro de que será el final fantasy más vendido de toda su carrera. 

Lo único que puedo decir es que no hagan caso a las malas referencias. Tanto si han jugado el juego como si no, SI vale la pena. Y siempre la valdrá por que este juego de verdad es maravilloso.

column8:
FF8 was the first ff game I played and beat. I do have a lot of good memories of this game. Esp. since it was pre internet time for me. So, I had to figure things out myself. Well, mostly. My bro helped out and one of his friends. Looking back and replaying it. The story and characters were so so. Magic system was broken, esp when I figured out that you boost stats with it. So, I stopped using magic in the game altogether. It does have one of the best mini games. The card game was great.
To me, FF7 was way way better. But that is my option.

Now comes this poor excuse for a remaster. It was half done to say the least. Only the main characters got touched up. Hard to over look when your main character, who is touched up, is talking to a pixilated person. Only the text boxes and menu look sharp and great.

I cant recommend this remaster version if you love this game.

column8:
Sigma simulator, just notice the main character's dialogue.

Not a fan of the integration of modernity at the core of Final Fantasy games, I think Final Fantasy 8 is where it really started. Why is the entire game centered around a modern high school setting with computer screens and all while the rest of the world largely still fights with swords? Like the writers could not come up with something better than just their own teen years. The other characters are ok but not that memorable. There are just nice dramatic scenes that were never achievable before at the old school launch date of this game. The fantasy of this universe is unbelievable, it's too big and too ungrounded. Often you walk into strucutures or towns that just feel like a North Korean town thats entirely empty, with infrastructure and buildings seemingly with no purpose, has no reason to exist, yet it exists simply because it was artifically put there by writers. Lots of structures and scenes are just obscene, like massive monolithic structures made out of massive rotating razor blades and missiles with actual eyes in them as if I'm seeing angels described from the bible. It's understandable they didn't have budgets or the capacity to create very populated cities and what not. But the previous final fantasy games dealt with that limitation just fine. I feel like a lot of final fantasy games after this release (except IX) also struggle with weird universes that just make no sense anymore. Perhaps it's just their previous multi millions of profits that made the entire franchise stagnate and the writing talent just did not keep up with the improvements of technology and hardware of consumers.  The previous Final Fantasy games were different, their stories , universes and lore more believable, concise and consistent.
Eventhough it's not perfect this game is still good.

column8:
Final Fantasy VIII is a game I wish I could love more than I do. It has a solid, interesting setting, an amusing story with twists, and some truly unique ideas. Unfortunately, everything positive about it is heavily weighed down by the grindy and, frankly, unfun gameplay—even with the conveniences added in the remastered edition, like speeding up the game or toggling random encounters on and off.

I won’t compare FF8 too much to FF7, as FF7 isn’t one of my all-time favorite Final Fantasies, but it’s clear FF8 was trying to be unique. Square, riding high on FF7’s popularity, took risks with this game.

The junction system is one of those risks. In theory, it’s an interesting evolution of FF7’s Materia system. It lets you use magic to power up your characters in unique ways, affecting their stats and abilities. Summons, or Guardian Forces, serve a dual purpose—they’re not only powerful attacks but also central to the junction system, allowing for deeper customization.

Unfortunately, the execution of the junction system turns it into a tedious mess. While the game explains the basics, it doesn’t teach you the nuances or warn you about how you need to approach the game differently from a typical JRPG. You have to grind for magic, junction up to 99 spells to maximize stats, and constantly manage your resources. Instead of feeling rewarding, it just becomes frustrating.

Random encounters only make this worse. You’re not grinding for experience or money but for magic and junctioning materials, which feels pointless. The enemies scaling with your level adds another layer of annoyance. The game effectively punishes you for fighting too much by making enemies harder without giving you meaningful advantages. To play optimally, you’re better off avoiding most encounters altogether and focusing on junctioning—an unintuitive and tedious system.

On top of that, every character feels the same mechanically, outside of limit breaks. There’s little to no distinction between them beyond minor gimmicks like Squall’s R1 trigger for extra damage. The heavy reliance on customization through summons and junctioning eliminates any unique character traits, which makes combat feel flat and uninspired.

On my original PS1 playthrough, I made it to the final dungeon but couldn’t bring myself to finish the game. By that point, I was so indifferent to the battle system that I didn’t care about defeating the final boss. It’s a shame because, while the story isn’t amazing, it’s amusing and has some fun twists. The romance and backstory elements, though a bit rushed, were surprisingly entertaining for a Final Fantasy game.

Overall, unless you’re someone who loves grinding and doesn’t mind unintuitive mechanics, I can’t recommend this game to the average Final Fantasy or JRPG fan. It’s a game best suited for the most hardcore players who enjoy figuring out and breaking complex systems.

column8: 入门做

I've played this a bunch on PS1. I never got through Ultimecia's Castle, however, I may have made more attempts on beating this game than any other. 

I'm gonna spoil this game while also giving you a good reason to actually play and enjoy it despite it being one of the dumbest stories ever told.

FF8 is literally "The Room" of JRPGs. I don't think they intended the story to come across as this dumb and contrived, but there are a lot of jokes they definitely intended to tell and actually manage to land the laugh. So, unlike Tommy Wiseau, they were actually trying to be funny some of the time.

I love to make fun of The Room, and I also love to make fun of how stupid FF8's story is. From the first mission it is completely insane and illogical. So you're telling me that Galbadia invaded a city that was already part of their own country just cause they wanted to reactivate their radio tower, which happens to be the only radio tower in the world? They activate it and then bounce. If this was part of some kind of evil plot that the people of Dollet would have wanted to stop, why didn't they just turn it off? They also mention that the internet already exists by cable. How does this make any sense?

And what was the purpose of turning on the radio tower? The Galbadian president wanted to broadcast a press conference. A press conference. That's why they had to invade a country. To broadcast a press conference. And why was that press conference so important? Just cause he wanted to tell the world that he was hiring the sorceress as ambassador. That's it.

They mention somewhere else that the sorceress is capable of brainwashing people. So you would think that maybe that would tie into why the wanted to broadcast the sorceress, so she could brainwash all the people in the world. Well, her brainwashing ability basically never gets mentioned again, and doesn't even matter. (I mean she has it, but she only brainwashes Seifer. Literally only Seifer) Just think of how cool that story would have been if she used a TV broadcast to brainwash the whole world into mindless cultists, and then everyone you talk to would be all "Hail Sorceress Edea!!"

Nope. Nothing that makes sense or would be clever ever happens in this game. 

Then one day you find out there's a giant blob monster living in the basement of the school that Headmaster Robin Williams owes a lot of money to. And you kill the blob monster. In just enough time to save the school from a missile attack. Mind you the missiles were already flying toward the school before you found out about the blob guy. You also save the school from the missile attack by turning on its anti-gravity ship mode--which nobody knew it had this whole time.

Anyway, I'm not going to do the whole plot. But if it's stupid and almost never hinted at with foreshadowing (like every well written story does), it will happen, and add nothing to character development or dramatic tension. Like when we found out that all the main characters were raised together in the same orphanage, but they forgot. Does that fact matter in the slightest anywhere else in the story? Absolutely not. 

Also, the sorceress was the matron of the orphanage. You would think that with a back story like that they would do something like make the sorceress unbeatable in battle, so the party has no choice but to try to remind her that she raised them all as orphans and then the power of friendship wins her over or something. Nothing like that happens. And also, the sorceress is Robin Williams wife. 

It does get even dumber, but I'm not going to go into everything here.

But I do have to appreciate the character chemistry. Squall is just extremely emo while everyone else is extremely annoying. He just wants to do his mercenary job, listen to My Chemical Romance and be left alone so that nobody can ever give him the pain of being abandoned ever again. But the world has conspired against him to not only force him create bonds with people, but also that every person he meets has to be insufferably eccentric and annoying. 

His hot teacher is trying to put the moves on him, but he just gets annoyed with her. Selphie and Zell are insufferably annoying. Why does Zell have that awful Mike Tyson tattoo on his face? Why is it that when Selphie says the dumbest things, she's actually being the only person that makes any sense in the world? Rinoa is a total brat. And Irvine is one of those guys who think's he's Andrew Tate.

FF8 is from an era where they really really wanted to sell physical strategy guides so they basically made it a requirement. You're just gonna have to look up a lot of stuff, but if I can make this game 30 times easier for you, Siren can refine tents into curaga spells. Don't even bother looking for the White SeeD Ship, just look it up.

Anyway play it if you like knowing what brain damage feels like. 10/10. I'm gonna beat it this time.

column8:
26 years later and it's still the most beautiful Final Fantasy in terms of atmosphere, ambience and aesthetics. The art style, the music, the architecture of the buildings, the character designs, they're the best from the best of Square.

The story isn't everyone's cup of tea, though in my opinion it's the most beautiful romance story ever made, as the chemistry between the 2 lead characters is wonderfully written, leading to what feels like very natural character development for the main character. Square knew they were writing one of the best love stories ever made, and that's why they made it the logo for this game.

The good:

The story is beautiful and focused on the highly relatable inner struggles of the main character. Both as a child and as an adult in my 30s, I relate to Squall. He is not the typical, all-conquering alpha male in video games from that era. He is flawed, he feels moments where he doesn't know what to say or do, he is very human. Yet he still rises to become a great, respected leader and never lets it go to his head.

As mentioned before, the beauty, music and feel of the world of FF8 and it's characters is the best amongst FF. Everything makes you feel something, e.g. Balamb Garden's feeling of a school in your home town. 

There is plenty to do, explore and with the boosts/cheats offered by this remastered version e.g. 3x speed, you can skip a lot of the tedious stuff and just enjoy the bits you have interest in.

The bad:

The story is wonderful, though there are gaps/unanswered questions that, to this day, fuel raging debates and fan theories on the internet.

As mentioned before, the story is almost entirely focused on the main character. This naturally comes at the expense of many of the other characters who can feel forgettable or under developed.

Some optional tedious side quests and item grinding that rely on a lot of luck and patience rather than skill due to FF8's many events related to RNG (random number generator) e.g. low chances of ending up with an item that you need or the limit break that you want certain characters to use in certain battles.

26 years later and it's still the most beautiful Final Fantasy in terms of atmosphere, ambience and aesthetics. The art style, the music, the architecture of the buildings, the character designs, they're the best from the best of Square.

The story isn't everyone's cup of tea, though in my opinion it's the most beautiful romance story ever made, as the chemistry between the 2 lead characters is wonderfully written, leading to what feels like very natural character development for the main character. Square knew they were writing one of the best love stories ever made, and that's why they made it the logo for this game.

The good:

The story is beautiful and focused on the highly relatable inner struggles of the main character. Both as a child and as an adult in my 30s, I relate to Squall. He is not the typical, all-conquering alpha male in video games from that era. He is flawed, he feels moments where he doesn't know what to say or do, he is very human. Yet he still rises to become a great, respected leader and never lets it go to his head.

As mentioned before, the beauty, music and feel of the world of FF8 and it's characters is the best amongst FF. Everything makes you feel something, e.g. Balamb Garden's feeling of a school in your home town. 

There is plenty to do, explore and with the boosts/cheats offered by this remastered version e.g. 3x speed, you can skip a lot of the tedious stuff and just enjoy the bits you have interest in.

The bad:

The story is wonderful, though there are gaps/unanswered questions that, to this day, fuel raging debates and fan theories on the internet.

As mentioned before, the story is almost entirely focused on the main character. This naturally comes at the expense of many of the other characters who can feel forgettable or under developed.

Some optional tedious side quests and item grinding that rely on a lot of luck and patience rather than skill due to FF8's many events related to RNG (random number generator) e.g. low chances of ending up with an item that you need or the limit break that you want certain characters to use in certain battles.

column8: Existe muita crítica a esse jogo, por conta do pouco esforço que a Square fez para melhorá-lo. Contudo, pra quem, como eu, gastou horas e horas no início da adolescência jogando esse FF, vê-lo de volta com as melhorias pontuais que foram feitas é muito satisfatório. Joguei por 36h, fiz 100% do game, obtive todas as conquistas e posso afirmar: em momento algum foi chato ou cansativo. A melhoria de velocidade em 3x é o diferencial que faltava (principalmente nas partes em que o draw é necessário). Os outros cheats eu não utilizei. Sem dúvida, o FF da minha vida. Recomendo a todos que sejam mais saudosistas em relação ao original e recomendo a quem ainda não o conhece. Vencida a primeira barreira do sistema de Junctions ele se mostra muito interessante para a personalização do jogo. FF8, foi um prazer jogá-lo novamente!

[h1] Final Fantasy VIII Remastered – Toujours aussi unique, pour le meilleur et pour le pire [/h1]

Final Fantasy VIII, c’est le FF bizarre. Celui qui tente des trucs, qui divise, qui a des mécaniques cheloues. Et ce remaster ? Il fait le strict minimum : graphismes un peu lissés, quelques options de confort, mais rien de révolutionnaire.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Un gameplay qui demande un vrai déclic [/h2]

Le système de jeu est spécial. Pas de mana, pas de niveaux classiques, mais un truc basé sur les associations de magies. Tu dois "voler" des sorts aux ennemis et les équiper pour booster tes stats. Sur le papier, c’est original. En vrai, ça casse le rythme et pousse à farmer comme un malade. Soit tu captes comment abuser du système et le jeu devient trop facile, soit tu galères à mort. Pas de juste milieu.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Une histoire mémorable… et parfois absurde [/h2]

L’ambiance est cool. Les SeeD, les rivalités entre académies, les combats de GF (les invocations du jeu), tout ça marche bien. Mais le scénario part en live. Y a des twists lunaires, des incohérences énormes, et pourtant… ça reste un voyage marquant. Squall est un héros atypique, froid et cynique, et même si son évolution est parfois maladroite, elle reste intéressante.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Un remaster paresseux, mais qui fait le job [/h2]

Visuellement, c’est mieux que l’original, mais ça reste basique. Les persos sont plus nets, mais les décors sont toujours flous. Heureusement, y a des options pour accélérer le jeu ou zapper les combats aléatoires, ce qui rend l’expérience moins frustrante.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Verdict : un FF à part, qu’on aime ou qu’on déteste [/h2]

Final Fantasy VIII Remastered, c’est exactement le même jeu, avec juste quelques petits ajouts pour le confort. Si t’as aimé l’original, tu seras content d’y rejouer dans de meilleures conditions. Mais si t’accrochais pas à son gameplay étrange à l’époque, ce remaster ne change rien.

ff8的战斗系统是我玩过JRPG里最无趣的，召唤兽动画又巨拖沓，还好能开加速功能
我正常玩，20H里这破战斗系统体验真是糟透了，反正遇到什么怪无脑召唤GF轰就完了


什么攻略里压级打法根本就是浪费时间折腾（敌人会随着你的等级增强能力）

因为正常游戏流程根本不需要折腾压级（这招倒尾声行不通了…不花时间研究一下这游戏战斗系统后面根本打不过…最后我就开游戏内置金手指通关了）


还有攻击魔法全是鸡肋，所有魔法又要从敌人身上抽取
除了武器（鸡肋）没有装备系统，GF（召唤兽）就是你的装备，然后装备魔法来给你增加属性
最烦最烦就是更换队友又要手动交换装备的GF！！还有很多BOSS身上可以抽取GF千万别漏了，漏一个等于少一件装备……我已经漏好几个了……

我真是服了以前FF8战斗系统设计师这奇怪的设计思路


对于游戏本身也是曾经的白月光，年少时买来大几张盗版光碟入坑，被片头CG动画震撼得不要不要的
碍于语言障碍也没能深入了解剧情，也没能通关

可惜现在年纪大了，这会体验这种剧情已经……对现在的我来说味如嚼蜡吧，好像FF8编剧和FF7是同个人，男主角高冷性格都不带变的（笑

最后32H不到就通关了（支线基本全略过，战斗系统没有深入研究，最后几个BOSS开内置的修改器通的，要不然根本打不过，发现通关成就完成率只有12%……），算是了却年少而不得的遗憾吧

column8:
So this is a pretty lukewarm recommendation, I think if you are a hardcore fan of JRPG's or Final Fantasy and haven't played VIII, I think this is the best way to experience it... 

For a long time Final Fantasy VIII has been one of my least favorite Final Fantasy games, but the remaster actually helped to ameliorate some of the issues I have with it.

The game comes with enhancements that let you turn off combat, as well as a 3X option, and these two things actually make playing the game so much more enjoyable.  There is also a pretty big cheat that you can turn on that makes it almost impossible to die... I didn't use that, but it's there for those that really just want to experience the, in my opinion, lackluster story.

It was the 3X option was what I heavily relied on, and that's what made the game so much more enjoyable for me.  

Combat feels much smoother at 3X speed, also drawing magic is a lot less annoying at this speed.  The only downside is exploring towns and the world map at 3X is way to fast, I found it really hard to control my character and move him the way I was trying to, it was also tough to speak to NPC's... but the normal speed feels like you are a snail sluggishly moving across the towns or world map.. I think having a 1.5X or 2X option would've been ideal for this.

Of course 3X speed doesn't fix many of the other issues I have with the game, mainly how the story ultimately unfolds, and characters are still really bland, they seem to mostly be there to tell Squall what a good boy he is, and the draw system, even when 3X faster, it can still be pretty annoying and take much longer then necessary.  I really don't understand why they made drawing magic such a tedious and boring chore.

A shining beacon in this game is the music, Nobuo Uematsu is one of my favorite video game composers and he just doesn't miss, this is another fantastic soundtrack by him, it's so good that I even bought a physical copy of it.

So yeah, overall this is still one of my least favorite Final Fantasy games, but, the enhancements took it from a game I couldn't bring myself to play... to a game that I 100% completed... so take that as you will.

I played FFVIII several years ago, and since then I haven't really gone back to play it until now. I did like it when I played it all those years ago, but I didn't love it. Replaying it now, I still have the same feeling towards it. 

The main thing everyone talks about in this game is the junction system and how annoying it is. I actually like the junction system itself, but there are some things about it that make it really annoying. I hate having to draw magic. It takes forever and its not fun having to do it with three different characters every time. You end up sitting there for 15 minutes just drawing magic over and over. I know you can get magic from triple triad, but that also takes forever because you have to wait for your opponent to play the card you need, which that also takes forever. 

I also don't like that every time the party changes or you have to play Laguna, you then have to re-do your entire junction system. Its extremely annoying and you spend way too much time in the menus. 

My other biggest complaint is the cast is really underdeveloped. No one is bad, but most of the characters aren't memorable and don't really have any story arcs. Squall, Rinoa, Laguna, Edea, and Seifer are the only real standouts. Quistis stops having any development like 2 hours into the game. Zell is just there. Irvine has nothing after the assassination attempt, and Selphie has one moment with her home being destroyed. Other than that, these characters are really underdeveloped. 

Now what I mainly liked is the combat. Its pretty much the same as VII and IX, so its really good. The cutscenes are beautiful, and the music is amazing. I also really liked all the locations that you go to. I also enjoyed the story for the most part. I think the remaster does a good job of making the player models look really good. I just wish they had put more effort into making the rest of the game look as good as the character models. 

Overall I would give FFVIII an 8/10. It ranks somewhere in the middle of the series for me. Some good, some bad. But its overall a good time.

系統：5/10
音樂：100/10

[h2] 【該不該入手？】 [/h2]
完全是靠《Eyes on Me》這首神曲去支撐我把他破完。
聽過以後喜歡的，也想體驗舊遊戲的感動，可以一試，
但沒愛就不必要受苦了，去找劇情影片更稱心，
故事能感動到我，但遊戲系統真的是太舊太麻煩了。

[h2] 【劇情評價】 [/h2]
故事相對於其他代的FF沒有那麼重的使命感，沒那麼王道，
反而更偏重描繪男主角的心態成長。
[h3] 不完美才是完美 [/h3]
女主角應該是歷代最接近現實，她會[b]任性、懼怕、勇敢、貼心、調皮、溫柔[/b]，
她沒有一個完美的人設，但不完美的東西反而更能讓大家共鳴，反而更完美更真實，
這比起7代角色更能打進我的心裡。

對我來說最大的遺憾是劇情沒有好好交待 [spoiler]男女主各自家庭過去所發生的事 [/spoiler]。
畢竟 [spoiler] 《Eyes on Me》承載的男主父，女主母的愛情。 [/spoiler]


[h2] 【系統評價】 [/h2]
[h3] 召喚獸G.F. [/h3]
遊戲採用從FF4代開始的ATB系統，
問題在於要裝上召喚獸(G.F.)才能選擇「技能」

[h3] 什麼是技能？ [/h3]
[b] -用道具 -用魔法 -抽取(吸怪身上的魔法)  [/b] 
以及把召喚獸升高後才能拿的
[b] -輸出招數 -復活 -加攻 -G.F.攻擊 [/b]  等等

這些都是技能，而只能裝3個

[h3] 特殊技 [/h3]
沒有傳統意義上的技能選擇，
每個角色都有指定一招特殊技，男主男配=QTE連擊，女主女配=直接放技能，

[h3] 魔法 [/h3]
想用魔法要找怪抽/在地圖找點抽，
而抽取都是其中一個要裝G.F.技能才可以使用的能力，

聽起來很亂，而玩下去的前幾個小時也被他的G.F.系統弄得很亂，
到破完其實也沒有研究透徹，但輕微研究過後確實有比較好玩，
也許當年算是一項革新，但以2025年來看則會很勸退。

[h3] 地圖 [/h3]
場境是3D正常比例的人物在一張2D的地圖上行走，
所以會很容易判斷錯路，會經常撞牆
原版FF7 FF9會好一點，因為人物都是Q版形像，在不同場境走得比較流暢，
而FF10也生在PS2年代所以也得到改善。
