I overcame trials. Trials you wouldn't believe. Trials that, quite frankly, are impossible for the common human mind to comprehend... I became a Triple-Triad master. I studied my opponents cards, watched as they placed cards down that were obviously not a very good placement ( they put a 2 facing an open space). What fools. In the end though I beat the CC group, along with every single man, woman and child. They stood no chance against my Quistis card, and not only did I beat them, I even took all their cards in the process, and I don't feel sorry for them. Triple Triad is a merciless game, they knew what they were getting into when they played for the first time.

Final Fantasy VIII is a decently controversial game. It is still considered part of the golden age of Final Fantasy, and in my opinion, rightfully so, but that doesn't change the fact the different approach to the RPG gameplay rubbed people wrong. I personally grew to love the Junction system, and I'll explain later as to why. What people didn't hate however, is the story this game tells. FFVIII in my mind is probably THE romance Final Fantasy. Sure you see romance in some of the other games, but it's this one where I think the romance is actually the main part of the story, Whereas in others it feels like more of a side plot. (The main couple is on in the background image behind the FFVIII logo). With it's amazing plot, really good romance story (probably the best that I can think of), a very under-rated game play, and it's amazing score, Final Fantasy VIII has a lot to offer.

[Story]
The main focus of this games story is the progression of Squall and Rinoa's relationship. It might be a bit hard to see it as the plot of the story feels like it takes a much bigger presidence over this story, but there is a difference between plot and story. After every event or plot point, the focus of, for example, the cutscene that might play, is always on Rinoa or Squall reacting to either each other/something that happened to the other person (or something they did), or it's a all cards in romantic vibe scene. Even if I were mistaken and/or wrong, the love story between the two is still definitely the best part about the game, and is also the best part about the game, and again, if I am wrong, (which I'm confident I'm not) the theme of this game is for sure definitely love. Now understand that this is just the main story, it's not the only story the the game focuses on, cause if it were, the plot wouldn't be so centred around war.

[Plot]
Your main character (Squall) is basically apart of an elite private military group called SeeD, that gets paid to aid in whatever is needed of them to do (so basically you're a mercenary). After becoming a member of SeeD, Squall and a few other characters are sent on their first mission as members of SeeD to aid in a towns revolution against the army of Galbadia, a country that threatens the safety of all people in this world, as the leader of Galbadia's intentions, may not be of his own volition. The real reason SeeD was made will soon come to the forefront, to oppose Squall and his allies.

[Characters]
The main cast of characters you take control of are for the most part not the best compared to other games in the series. That doesn't mean they're bad, it just means that they're not memorable when it comes to the things they do, but personality wise, I'd say they're good. The reason for this from what I assume, Is because the main focus was less on the group as a whole, and more on the main two, which are easily the best characters in the series. Best romance story I've ever seen actually, at least in video game form. Some might not like Squall, as I think most people are kind of over the Edgy archetype, but with how they tell his story I think it makes up for it, as the game is able to show that it makes sense he is the way he is. I'd also argue he's not really edgy, more just a mix of shy and hurt by the only person he considered family leaving him, so he cuts everyone else off. The second character in the main romance is Rinoa, the leader of a small resistance group, who asked SeeD for some agents to aid in their resistance against the Galbadian Army, who in control of the town she lives in. She acts warm and compassionate, but is also a bit naive to the world and how it works in it's current on the brink of war state. 

[Gameplay]
FFVIII may appear to be your standard rpg. the genre where you level up your character, and your stats increase/get better... boy are you wrong (for the most part). Squaresoft/Square Enix presents the Junction system, a system that was introduced in this game, and was never used again. Why? Cause everyone hated it. Why did they hate it? Three reasons. It's a far reach from your typical rpg gameplay, they couldn't get into it, and lastly they didn't learn to understand it within their gameplay time. I am in no way talking bad about said people. It is completely understandable that an individual will stop playing a game that they do not understand. I am mearly saying that people who do learn to understand it will definitely love it. It's unique, and it's a lot of fun to play with. The real problem is with a system such as this, it makes the menu a little ugly and confusing to look at. 
The best way to describe it for the sake of this paragraph is, instead of having your stats increase from leveling up, most of your stats will only increase based on your GF's abilities, and how much of what kind of magic you "junction" (put into) a specific category). I personally think the game fails to explain the most crucial part, which is the amount of magic, and how big of a difference it makes. (10 Water< 100 Water< 50 Ultima< 100 Ultima).

[Score/OST]
I basically get to this part of the review in basically every review I've made, as I believe background music makes a project 10x better, and it's especially apparent when it comes to these games. There is a reason Final Fantasy always wins best soundtrack at game awards. The music is masterfully crafted. I first played this game around 4 years ago (never beat it til now) and yet despite that, the background music for places like towns or Balamb GARDEN are already tugging at my nostalgia. you will NOT hear this kind of music simply for some random village or town in most western games, as western games put more of a focus on music in the main theme and/or high to low level action scenes. Nobuo Uematsu has made some of the best music I have ever heard, and this game has probably got the best in the series. 
I have a list of music I think people should check out, but I'd like to first put a focus on these specific tracks, as they are all different iterations of the same song called Eyes on Me. In order of favourite to not as fovourite but still my favourite, these tracks are Julia (or Julia's main theme), Eyes on Me (basically the lyrical version of Juliet), Love Grows, Waltz for the Moon, and My Mind. The last two are a little more different from the first three mentioned, My Mind being Rinoa's main theme, and Waltz being more of a ball room version of the song. Julia and Love Grows are more of specific instrument versions of the main song (Eyes on Me), Julia being piano focused, and Love Grows being a Heckelphone-Clarinet. And of course, there is Eyes on Me, which could be seen as the main love theme for the main couple. I highly suggest you DO NOT listen to this one until you play the game, but if you must, go ahead.
List of other songs in order: The Loser, Succession of Witches, Fragments of Memories, The Man with the Machine Gun, Liberi Fatali, Fithos Lusec Wecos Vinosec, Ami, Trust Me Breezy, The Landing, Balamb GARDEN, and Fisherman's Horizon.

The first time I played this game, I won't deny I couldn't get into it, but after getting into the game again, I can easily say this is my second favourite Final Fantasy, and is probably my favourite story in the series (Sucker for romance I guess).
column9:
I overcame trials. Trials you wouldn't believe. Trials that, quite frankly, are impossible for the common human mind to comprehend... I became a Triple-Triad master. I studied my opponents cards, watched as they placed cards down that were obviously not a very good placement ( they put a 2 facing an open space). What fools. In the end though I beat the CC group, along with every single man, woman and child. They stood no chance against my Quistis card, and not only did I beat them, I even took all their cards in the process, and I don't feel sorry for them. Triple Triad is a merciless game, they knew what they were getting into when they played for the first time.

column8:
Way better than I remember, to be honest. I remember tearing into this game when I was younger after coming off the absolute joy of Final Fantasy 7 and Tactics, thinking this was a step down in terms of story and game play.

And it is. The game is intensely shallow with a system that punishes you for engaging with it. The best way to win is to not fight. Get as little XP as possible, play a ton of Triple Triad, turn your cards into items and those items into spells. Buff yourself with those spells and go hog wild with end game stats against level 10 enemies. 

To top that off, the story is definitely kind of all over the place. Its disjointed and hard to follow, even now that I'm an adult and have the mental capacity to understand what's going on. 

But all that doesn't matter. The story might be kind of all over the place, but in the moment the melodrama is exciting. The whole combat system might be kinda goofy, but its still fun and infinitely customizable. And most of all, the characters are fun and endearing. They're a bunch of goofy teenagers who really have no idea what they're doing but by god, they're doing it and they're gonna do their best at it. 

Adjust your expectations to it, and Final Fantasy 8 is a wonderful, memorable experience. If you try to come at it like its going to stand toe to toe with Final Fantasy 7, 6, or 9, and you'll walk away disappointed.

column8: 在今天通关了这部26年前的游戏，不愧称之为最具爱情色彩的最终幻想，一首由王菲演唱的Eyes on me，讲述了从茱莉亚和拉格纳在酒吧的相互注视，相互喜欢，相互约定，到拉格纳重新踏上战场，跳崖受伤半年渺无音训，在酒吧等候半年的茱莉亚不知道拉格纳是死是活，也或许是对当初连开口都没有的承诺，失去了信心，就这样嫁人了，到主线剧情双方子女莉诺雅和斯考尔在舞会上的相知相遇，一路的冒险中双方了解到相爱，这算是一部跨越两代人的爱情故事，即使这部游戏的画面在26年后的今天显得没有那么精致，但这部作品无疑是最终幻想系列游戏里剧情讲述最好的游戏之一

column8:
엔딩 어렸을때 보고 지금 또 봤지만 여전히 무슨내용인지 모르겠는건 마찬가지
그래도 포럼의 각종 해석을 참고해 내 개인적인 해석을 적어보도록 하겠음

일단 포럼에서 유명한 엔딩 해석 두가지
[spoiler]

1. 스퀄사망설
일단 포럼에서 많은 반응을 얻는 해석들



1. 스퀄사망설

스퀄이 1부에서 죽음을 맞이하고 나머지 내용은 그저 스퀄이 살아있을때 이루고 싶었던 주마등이라는 내용





2. 리노아 얼티미시아설

리노아는 미래로 타임워프 한 뒤로 기억을 잃어버렸고 스퀄과 한 약속들이 기억의 단편속에 남아 스퀄과 약속한 장소에서 계속 그를 기다린다는 내용

---------------------------------





내 해석 : 이 게임의 내용은 타임패러독스라는 것



0 . 의문점. 고아원

1) 왜 부모가 살아있는 아이들이 고아원에 맡겨진 것일까

2) 엘로네는 누구인가 왜 마녀가 된 것일까

3) 리노아는 아무런 연관점이 없는데 어떤 연관점으로 고아원팸에 끼어들어간 것인가



1. 부모관계 및 능력

스퀄 : 라그나와 레인 사이의 아들(SEED 능력 보유)

엘로네 : 라그나와 ???의 딸(SEED 능력 X)

리노아 : 켄웨이와 쥴리아 사이의 딸(SEED 능력 X)



2. 왜 부모가 떠난 것인가

이데아가 운영하는 고아원의 아이들은 부모가 존재하는 시간선과 현재의 시간선이 나뉘어져서 버려지게 되었다는 것을 알 수 있음(DISK3~4부분)



3. 리노아는 누구인가(중요)



먼저 리노아는 쥴리아와 켄웨이 사이의 딸로 알려져 있지만 켄웨이와 리노아 사이의 부녀지간이 막역하지 않다는건 게임 스토리 내내 많은 컷신들을 통해 볼 수 있음

즉, 이 둘은 친부녀 사이가 아닌 것을 추측할 수 있음.

결론은 리노아는 원래 라그나와 쥴리아 사이에 생긴 딸이고 이걸 알면서도 켄웨이 대령이 받아줘서 양녀로 들이게 된 것.



4. 그럼 엘로네는 누구인가?

엘로네가 스퀄의 친누나라는 사실은 엔딩을 보면 알 수 있는데 그 논리대로라면 내가 위에서 설명한 내용이 완전 엉터리가 될 수 밖에 없음

결론부터 말하면 엘로네는 스퀄의 친누이가 맞음.

위에 1번에서 엘로네의 부모관계에서 어머니만 ???로 된 이유가 궁금했겠지? 엘로네의 엄마는 사실 쥴리아였던 거야. 파이널판타지8의 세계관은 리노아 대신 엘로네가 존재해야 했을 세계관이고 마녀(이데아)가 시공간을 건드리면서 엘로네와 스퀄이 남매로 있어야 할 세계관에 리노아가 태어나면서 엘로네가 그 세계관에 계속 존재하기가 힘들어진 것임(그래서 엘로네와 리노아는 만나는 씬 조차도 없음)



5. 왜 이 세계관에 나오는 사람들은 시간 압축을 하려는 것인가

이유는 간단함 죽어야 할 사람을 죽이고 살아야 할 사람을 타임루프로 살려버리니깐 시공간이 어지럽혀져서 태어나지 않아야 할 사람, 괴물, 이런것들이 태어나는 거임

그 중 하나가 리노아고, SEED 학원마다 있는 이상한 외계인들임



6. 그럼 마녀한테 영혼을 안팔면 되잖아 시공간을 왜 일부러 어지럽히는거야?

시공간을 어지럽히는 이유 ---> 죽은 사람을 살리려고
여기서 부터는 스퀄 사망설을 좀 참고했는데 1부에 나오는 스퀄과 2부에 나오는 스퀄은 같으면서도 다른 인물이 아닐까 싶어

스퀄 사망설에서 주장하는 사람들의 말대로 스퀄은 디스크1 마지막 부분에서 죽음을 맞이했다고 봄. 하지만 이때 리노아가 마녀한테 영혼을 팔아서 스퀄은 프롤로그의 시점으로 타임루프 하게 되었고 우리는 그 시점부터 게임을 진행하게 되는 것임



디스크 2부터 스퀄은 묘하게 이질감을 느끼면서 리노아에게 호의적인 감정을 보이는데 이 스퀄은 사실 타임루프를 거친 정신적으로 나이먹은 스퀄일 수도 있다는 것

이때부터 리노아는 마녀한테 영혼을 팔았기 때문에 정신이 타임슬립되서 의식이 과거로 왔다갔다 하는것 같음



7. 그럼 누가 시공간을 건드린 거야?

시공간을 건드렸다 = 마녀에게 영혼을 팔았다 = 마녀가 되었다

시간선에 관여를 하는 인물은 마녀에게 영혼을 팔리고 마녀가된다는 설정인거 같음

가장 먼저 마녀가 된 이데아는 리노아가 태어나면서 타임패러독스로 존재할 수 없게된 엘로네를 숨기는데 시간의 힘을 썼음 그리고 마녀가 됨

엘로네는 자신을 찾아주길 바라는 마음에 과거의 아버지 세대의 기억에 스퀄 일행을 주입시켜서 과거를 수정하려고 함 그리고 마녀가 됨

리노아는 사이퍼의 교전에서 치명상을 입은 스퀄을 살리기 위해 시간을 되돌렸고 마녀가 됨



8. 결론

시간이 압축되면서 엘로네는 리노아가 있어야 했을 자리에 대체되며 스퀄은 엘로네를 기억속에서 잃어버림.(엔딩장면에서 얼굴 블러처리되는 연출)

그리고 리노아는 다른 가능성의 세계에서 스퀄을 기다린다는 내용



하지만 이 수많은 루프 과정속에서 스퀄이 리노아를 기억해내게 되고 엘로네에게 리노아를 찾아달라고 부탁하면서 엘로네는 하나밖에 없는 남매의 부탁을 승낙하게 됨.

그리고 또 다시 시공간에 관여를 하게 되고 타임루프는 리노아를 찾을때까지 계속된다는 내용임

[/spoiler]

FIRST THING FIRST
If you're into modding FF8, this isn't the right copy for you. Find FFVIII on Steam without 'REMASTERED' in the title. That older (and more buggy) version is compatible with more mods and the bugs can be fixed with them as well.

Anyway, back to the review. Here's my two cents.

I'd say FFVIII is the toughest FF game to master because the tutorial sucked (reminded me how FFX used to do its tutorial), but the story and character development paid off really well despite that being the standard of FF games already. It took me maybe like 10 revisits to finally lock in and beat the entirety of the game without losing interest. After doing that, replaying the game again was a breeze. The music also kept me going.

Not sure why but the translations are weird in certain sections of the game, making the game tougher to read than any software documentation I've ever stumbled upon, lmao. Classic Square's PS1 titles tend to have this problem, I've noticed.

My favorite entry in the franchise story-wise and music-wise, but I really couldn't shake the gameplay.

column8:
학창시절 파판8 오프닝을보고 충격받은 그 느낌을 아직도 잊을수가 없다.
그당시 오프닝 바다 (물) 그래픽은 엄청난 충격을 받았었다. 아마 그이상의 그래픽을 보진 못했다.
CRT TV 로 봤을때 느낌과 지금 4K TV로 볼때의 느낌은 전혀다르다. 해상도가 맞지 않는것도 있지만 그당시의 감동을 지금 TV로는 절대 느낄수가 없다.
그것과는 별개로 게임은 수십년이 지나고서 이제야 하게됐다. 미남 미녀 아니면 출연조차 할수없는 파판8 명성답게 8등신 미남 미녀가 줄줄히 나온다. 근데 게임성은 기존 파판8과 다르다보니 이질감이 너무 심하다.
그리고 레벨업을 안할수록 게임이 쉬워지기 때문에 레벨 노가다조차 할수가 없다.
레벨을 올리면 안되는 RPG가 이렇게 피곤할지 몰랐다. 저레벨 플레이가 편하긴 하지만 그렇다고 최종보스가 쉬운것도 아니라 엄청난 노가다를 하긴 해야한다. 시스템이 알아갈수록 재미는 있지만 편한 시스템은 절대 아니다.
그럭저럭 할만은 했지만 바뀐 시스템은 불호에 가까워서 한번 게임을 멈추면 손이 자주 가진 않았다.
저레벨 플레이가 부족해 최종보스와 그전에 한번 막혔는데 노가다 하기는 막막하고 다행히 무적 시스템이 있어서 그냥 저냥 엔딩은봤다. 

평가 : ★★★ (옛날 오프닝 처음봤을때 느낌은 ★★★★★)
Gutes Spiel, schlechtes Remaster!

Really enjoyed this. I played it when it came out and I was like, maybe 11 years old, only got around 60% of the way through back then. Now I'm in my mid 30's and it's still a very tough game lol. I completed it using cheats, as I'm more about the story anyway. If you're worried about not being able to beat it, activate the cheats from the 'Esc' button menu, that's where you can make all GFs level 100 and everything else, this gave me, (a SERIOUSLY underleveled character at the end around lvl 20 lol) 9999 hp and I beat all 4 final bosses easily. Really happy Square included the cheats as I don't like games which are too difficult and this made it extremely enjoyable for me. Loved the characters and story, great game!

column8: I love the Final Fantasy series. This one is... Rough. While it can be mastered, the stats of your characters are in constant flux as you tie magic to those stats. Magic is a consumable resource that you have to pull from enemies during battle. You're de-incentivized from using spells because doing so negatively impacts your characters' stats. You can rely on your summons to do most of your damage, but you're also punished for doing that by lowering your SeeD rating. Weapon upgrades feel like a moot point of the game. Triple Triad would be great aside from some of the punishing rules enforced; plus the fact that you basically need to trash a bunch of cards to upgrade your weapons. Story is kind of interesting so far (I'm towards the end of disc 2), but overall doesn't outweigh the poor game design. The game feels like it was designed around gimmicks that cheese your stats up rather than grinding or progressing logically throughout the game.

column8:
Este juego es más que un simple JRPG, es un pedazo de mi infancia que siempre llevaré conmigo. Final Fantasy VIII fue uno de los primeros videojuegos que jugué con verdadera devoción, y volver a él en esta versión remasterizada ha sido una experiencia que no tiene precio.

¿Qué puedo decir? Desde el icónico inicio con Liberi Fatali hasta esos momentos inolvidables como el baile en el Jardín o las batallas épicas contra los G.F., FFVIII me hizo soñar cuando era niño, y ahora, años después, me sigue conmoviendo como si fuera la primera vez. La historia de Squall y Rinoa, con sus altibajos emocionales, sigue siendo igual de cautivadora, y el sistema de enlaces, aunque peculiar, se siente único y flexible incluso ahora.

La remasterización le da un lavado de cara visual que, aunque no es perfecto, logra mantener la esencia del original. Los personajes están más detallados, los escenarios se ven mucho más limpios, y hasta las invocaciones de los G.F. lucen impresionantes con sus animaciones renovadas. ¿Lo mejor? Puedo usar las opciones de avance rápido cuando quiero subir de nivel, lo cual es una bendición para los que tenemos menos tiempo que antes.

Claro, algunas cosas han envejecido, como ciertos diálogos un tanto simples o momentos en los que el ritmo se siente un poco lento, pero ¿sabes qué? No importa. Cada vez que escucho esas melodías compuestas por Nobuo Uematsu, siento que vuelvo a ser ese chaval que se pasaba horas con el mando en las manos, explorando los Jardines y enfrentándome a Artemisa.

Si, como yo, creciste con este juego, la remasterización es una excusa perfecta para redescubrirlo. Y si nunca lo jugaste, estás frente a un clásico que merece ser experimentado al menos una vez en la vida.

Final Fantasy VIII no es solo un juego; es un viaje lleno de nostalgia y magia que siempre tendrá un lugar especial en mi corazón.

column8:
Neither the 2013 version or this, the Remastered version, are perfect. Let's just make that clear.

It's an old game, that has been ported and in a way that leaves things to be desired.
I've seen what modders can do and it tells you how much more it could have been improved.

But this one I can recommend. The music, the general feel, and the controls are good.
Graphics are a bit updated (but more could have been done imo), and there are fast forwarding and other stuff you can enable if you want.

You don't need to hassle with 3rd party software or accounts and such. It just works, and it works well.

Buy it on a sale and enjoy the ride.

Realmente, Final Fantasy VIII como remaster cumple... Mejorando los modelos de los personajes, el diseño de los escenarios, la interfaz y el mundo abierto haciendo que se vean mucho mejor y menos pixeleado que el juego original, además de esto incluye cromos para Steam, un autoguardado y diferentes trucos como velocidad x3 o maximizar a tu personaje

En mi opinión, a pesar de eso sigue valiendo la pena el remaster... Entre los 2 te recomiendo el remaster si quieres una mejor experiencia, el original puedes considerarlo como una opción más barata o para mods si es lo que buscas

Igual manera, Final Fantasy VIII es un buen juego sea donde sea que lo juegues
good

[h1] It's FF8 [/h1]

[h2] Info [/h2]
If you've never played a Final Fantasy game, this is a unique one. The leveling system applies to your party and your enemies, which means the game can be as easy or as hard as you want to make it.

You play as a group of teenagers trained as children mercenaries in mercenary hogwarts.

- The game gets harder if you overlevel but forget to mind your Guardian Forces (GFs)
- The game gets overly easy if you mind your GFs, play triple triad, and try to stay at a low level throughout
- This version is the way to go if you want the additional perks the devs added on
- Original FF8 PC release is the way to go if you want to use mods
- Tons of sidequests, lots of abilities, hundreds of ways to break the game and bend it to your will
- The triple triad card game can net you the most powerful weapons in the game very early

[h2] Pros [/h2]
- Story's good, main character's depressed and rude to people but eventually comes out of his shell
- Angelo is good dog
- Speed up, draw 100, invulnerablility "hacks" added onto the game as a bonus
- Uses the PS1's original music instead of the midi's from the original pc version
- Crystal Remastered mod can be applied to both the base PC version AND this remastered version. Check it out if the vanilla version's not for you. They revamped the leveling system and paired each character with a GF instead of whatever weird mechanics they had originally set up.

[h2] Cons [/h2]
- Chocobo quests were removed and weren't really fixed (angelo search isn't better)
- Hard to call this a remaster with only the 3d models really remastered
- Wish they upscaled backgrounds and environments, it's off-putting to see backgrounds that were meant to be dithered by obsolete CRTs
- Some NPCs and interactable objects are fuzzy and hard to make out that you would be able to perform actions with/on
- Rinoa is a naive Mary Sue that can't decide if they're a damsel or not
- Not enough Angelo limit breaks
- Too much exposition in certain points that aren't really necessary. Should've made some of them optional, not everyone's like me and has an attention span.
- Cuts to Seifer's backstory or motivation, and the cuts to the Laguna past/present maps and interactability, make the plot more scattered and less cohesive. If Square enix ever re-works the game again, add more content for Laguna at the very least.

column8:
Depois de investir 66 horas intensas em Final Fantasy VIII e alcançar a cobiçada platina, posso afirmar com convicção que esta experiência é verdadeiramente memorável. O jogo conseguiu envolver-me completamente com sua narrativa rica e personagens inesquecíveis.

Pontos Positivos:

História Cativante: A trama complexa de Squall e seus companheiros é repleta de reviravoltas emocionantes e momentos que tocam o coração. A profundidade emocional dos personagens faz com que cada jornada e desafio seja significativo.

Sistema de Combate Inovador: O sistema de Junction é único e oferece uma infinidade de estratégias para os jogadores experimentarem. A possibilidade de personalizar as habilidades e status dos personagens com as magias coletadas adiciona uma camada extra de imersão.

Trilha Sonora: A música composta por Nobuo Uematsu é simplesmente espetacular. As melodias orquestradas dão vida às cenas e se tornam parte integrante da experiência de jogo.

Gráficos e Arte: Considerando a época de lançamento, os gráficos e a direção de arte de Final Fantasy VIII são impressionantes. A atenção aos detalhes nas paisagens e nos designs dos personagens continua sendo um ponto alto.

Mini-jogos e Missões Secundárias: O jogo está repleto de mini-jogos divertidos como o Triple Triad, além de várias missões secundárias que enriquecem a narrativa e oferecem recompensas valiosas.

Alcançar a platina neste jogo não é tarefa fácil, mas a sensação de conquista e a profundidade da experiência fazem com que cada minuto valha a pena. Final Fantasy VIII é um clássico que continua a brilhar mesmo após todos esses anos, proporcionando uma aventura épica e emocionante que nenhum fã de RPG deve perder.

column8:
Posiblemente el peor Final Fantasy, su historia se pone cada vez más incoherente desde el disco 2, y su sistema de stats y combate es el peor de la saga, incluso el sistema de FF2 es más divertido que el Draw Magic  y el hecho de que apenas puedes usar las mejores magias ya que las usas para mejorar stats

Otro problema es el nivel de los enemigos, al nivel 100 tienen demasiado HP, por lo que es mejor pasarte el juego a niveles bajos con stats mejorados por vinculacion, lo cual es una ironía con los demás juegos donde grindear tenia su recompensa

Los personajes  principales si son buenos, no los mejores ni de lejos, pero al menos tienen algo de carisma, lo único rescatable de esta entrega, siendo Squall el menos atractivo en este apartado

Sólo lo platiné por amor a la saga y mis ganas de platinar cada entrega, pero no lo recomiendo a menos que solo vayas por la historia principal y no todo lo que ofrece el juego, que se siente tedioso después de un tiempo

Fun JRPG with an interesting story, compelling characters, fantastic music, and a lot to do. Solid 9/10.

I just finished playing it for the first time ever, and I really enjoyed it! The core combat mechanics are pretty interesting, though it can take some time to get used to, but once I realized how they worked, they were easy and really empowering to use. Some of the added cheats in the remaster like 3x speed are really helpful for grindy parts of the game, though you could play it all without a lot of grinding if you wanted to. There's a lot of variability in how to play the game, and there's a lot of content as well. Without a guide, there's plenty you might miss out on, so definitely use one if you don't want to miss anything.

Well, I cannot reccomend this game to everyone because it has it's problem's but when the game is on it's high notes, it makes up for all the wrongs it makes on the way. This game is all about those small interpersonal and romantic moments that ended up making me care for characters that I disliked or was not interested in. 

Big downside for everyone may be the junction system and certain story beats (it always has to be time travel isn't it?). For me the junction system was easily abusable and in general quite easy to understand, for some it might be too much.

Big recommend from me but be wary that I warn you before you buy. Maybe try to play on your friend-friend's copy a bit to mess around with the system and to see wether you are hooked, either by gameplay, story or both.

Nostalgia that hit like a ton of bricks when 'fithos lusec' starts playing. 

I enjoyed playing this as a kid, although I never understood the junction system then, but thanks to youtube, I can easily break it now. I'm mowing down everything with ease, and I love the fast forward button, because it helps the slower dialogue scenes flow faster instead of mashing the button and praying for it to work. I also have less time to game now versus when I was a kid, so that speedy dialogue helps. 

If you enjoyed it as a kid, I'd say give it another go if you're looking for a trip down memory lane with fresh graphics, and a different appreciation of the story from an older point of view.

Everyone is also looking prettier now. Squall is closer to his goal of being the best looking guy in the room.

column8: This is simply my number one game ever.

There were different times back then. After the success of Final Fantasy VII, the team wanted to do something new, and they did. At times, they took the game too far.

Final Fantasy VIII is an ambitious title: from the graphics, bombastic opening and confusing story (at times). I remember playing the game back on release and really enjoying the combat system, however, I never finished it.

Now, years later, I can fully understand what they were trying to do. The level up system is very unique, although very broken for a game like this. You can easily go to the extremes: the game can become unplayable or excessively easy. I totally recommend a guide. Money also works differently because you have a "salary", which you can increase through a quiz. It's all very bizarre for this type of game. Nevertheless, I do enjoy how much you can customize your characters. But the Junction System is a very divisive topic in the FF community.

The presentation is mixed in this remaster. It has great looking characters, but the backgrounds and FMVs look awful. You need to mod the game to get the most out of it.

As for the story, it has its moments. It does go bonkers at the end. I can see why so many people have made theories about this gone. As for me? I really enjoyed Squall development. Not all characters get their spot, as other FFs, so you are bound to find some that are only there to fill the quota of party members.

Overall, it was a great experience. I commend Squaresoft for trying something to bold. I don't think you should skip this one. I had fun with the system, and the cinematic aspects of the game are extremely well done, even if the remaster doesn't make them justice. It's a game developed by a company at the peak of their game. And whether you like it or not, it will leave an impression on you.

An interesting trip to the past. As a huge FF7 fan, I've always been cautiously curious about this one, so that will be my main comparison/reference point. Mixed feelings overall. They definitely took some risks with this - especially with the gameplay systems. They overcomplicated everything in a bad way. Drawing magic is annoying, all the player power derives from 'junctioning' (equipping) 'guardian forces' (summons), and difficulty scales as you level. If the remaster didn't include built in cheats and a speed increase, I probably would've given up. On the flipside, these graphics seem pretty sick for the time, and a step up from the previous title. I was also impressed with the handling of various scenes blending and transitioning between FMV and regular gameplay. The music, while not as memorable for me as FF7, was still excellent. The haunting sorceress' theme stuck out to me the most. The story was convoluted and not presented in the best way, but got pretty wild by the end with some timey wimey stuff that I didn't actually hate. The characters were less memorable for me, but it's hard to compete with FF7 in that regard. A mixed bag, but I'm glad I finally took the time to experience this piece of history from a genre I love.

column8:
Not my first playthrough of this game, though my first time with the remastered version.

FF8 is a mess. The gameplay has more problems to it than I care to write about, the story relies on the player accepting a whole lot of unknowns, deus ex machina, and unexplored concepts being the basis for the main plot, the sidequests are either annoying or incredibly abstruse, enemy variation is extremely low, parts of the UI is very confusing to a new player, and a lot of mechanics are practically used only once or twice before they become obsolete or just not used again, despite obviously having originally been meant as mechanics to be used a lot more.

Basically, there's a ton of great ideas put into this game, most of which don't actually work well together, and the rest not getting the time to shine. Like they just didn't have the time to properly put everything together well. Like they had all the parts of a machine, but instead of assembling it properly, they just threw all the parts together in a box and called it a day.

The good parts are the story outside the aforementioned problems, the various locations that are both beautiful and interesting, great characters(both visually and story wise) and their interpersonal relationships, the music score, the summons and some of the limit breaks, the cutscenes, and the creativity of the story.

But in spite of all its flaws, FF8 is a game that manages to be more than the sum of its parts. A lot more. There is a magic to it that you just won't find anywhere else.

100% in 85 hours, including all cards and sidequests. (Can definitely be done in less.)

column8: Meu Primeiro jogo que comprei na vida e meu final fantasy favorito

Final Fantasy VIII Remastered é uma excelente versão para os fãs do clássico que agora podem reviver essa história épica com gráficos melhorados e recursos modernos. A remasterização traz visuais mais nítidos, com personagens e cenários mais detalhados, o que faz uma grande diferença em relação à versão original de PS1.

A música, composta por Nobuo Uematsu, permanece um dos maiores destaques do jogo, com trilhas que capturam perfeitamente o tom emocional da narrativa, desde os momentos mais tranquilos até as batalhas épicas. Além disso, a remasterização traz alguns ajustes de qualidade de vida, como aumento de velocidade, a opção de desativar encontros aleatórios e a possibilidade de pular cenas, o que facilita a experiência sem alterar o núcleo do jogo.

Em resumo, Final Fantasy VIII Remastered é uma ótima opção para reviver ou descobrir uma das aventuras mais fascinantes da era dos RPGs clássicos, com a vantagem dos gráficos renovados e melhorias que deixam a experiência mais acessível para os tempos atuais.

After the fantastic Final Fantasy VI and VII, expectations were high for Final Fantasy VIII (FF8). Overall, FF8 is an unpolished gem with great ideas, an interesting world, story, and characters who are all flawed to some degree, which is a recurring theme in the game. 

However, the dialogue and/or English translation is not always good. On the one hand, some plots, characters, and events seem to come out of nowhere. On the other hand, the game tells its story in a subtle way, often letting the player connect the dots by showing rather than telling and by character behavior. Some information is also hidden in optional interactions with NPCs, notes, and game objects. It seems that the developers were too ambitious for this game, as some of the originally planned content was cut.

Furthermore, the gameplay and UI make the game very tedious to play. The junction mechanic is quite innovative and allows a lot of freedom in customizing your character, but organizing your characters through several nested menus is quite a task in itself. The junction system is not intuitive, and the tutorial does a poor job of introducing the overall concept. It is easy to get it wrong, which can eventually make the game so difficult that you have to restart. Moreover, the last part of the game suddenly gets much harder than the rest of the game.

The junction system is basically a collect & convert system. You collect (grind) magic and convert it into better magic (the ability to convert has to be unlocked first). The magic can then be applied to various stats (some of which have to be unlocked first) to improve your character. Unfortunately, you have to switch characters regularly, and swap all your magic between them. Fortunately, the game offers a function for this (under 'switch'). Another nice feature is the 3x time boost, which increases the speed of the game and makes grinding and long journeys more bearable.

The graphics are okay, but the backgrounds are blurry, which is in stark contrast to the sharp, remastered character models. For this reason I played with a 4k texture mod (Angelwing ULTIMA). The sound and especially the music is great, as well as the cinematics (especially considering the age of the game).

All in all, I would not recommend this game to everyone. It is not a game for a mainstream audience due to its clunky mechanics and UI, as well as its sometimes obscure storytelling. The story is quite deep, but not always well told. Personally, I wanted to know more about the world and the characters which kept me going. Whatever, I even like the protagonist Squall.

I really loved this game. I really loved the story and the characters. I also absolutely loved the music. There were many aspects of the GF and draw systems that annoyed me. I did not do all the side quests and find all the GFs, although I could always do another play through. I thought the system of upgrading weapons was interesting, but I suppose I didn't put enough time into playing the card game to get enough items for all the weapons.

Just as a note, I was able to complete the game so quickly because I moved my save from the non-remastered version, which I thought was really fun ( I liked chocobo world) but because of the game crashing at the same boss without any way to fix it and no chance of doing any updates, I managed to move my save over to this version and finish the game.

遊戲系統有別於系列其他作，腳色沒有MP，魔法是像道具那樣有使用次數，用完了則需要從敵人身上抽取或用道具煉成，而腳色能力值基於裝備的G.F(招喚獸)與魔法，在操作腳色需要頻繁切換的時候，G.F和魔法也需要在腳色間頻繁的轉移，頗為麻煩，遊戲後期的平衡不佳，可直接使出特殊技和讓敵人物防歸零的輔助魔法太強，使得戰鬥難度極低，演出華麗的G.F則是華而不實的代表，在漫長的登場演出後，打出的傷害可能還不如物理角的一發普攻，不過還好戰鬥還算爽快，卡片小遊戲簡單有趣(除了隨機手牌規則)，整體還是值得玩玩，劇情方面個人則認為有點芭樂。

Playing through all the Final Fantasy games for the first time and wow this might be my favorite. Fantastic story and main character in this one. The junction system was deep and complex but once you get it you can easily break the game. 

 I wish the side characters got some more development as they really didn't get into their background much. Drawing magic was a bit annoying and having to set up characters was a pain when they would get unequiped after a story moment.

Combat was similar to FF7 with some minor tweaks but it worked well enough and the added 3x speed boost was a huge time saver as the animations are really long. 

Story really resonated with me but if you don't like the main character you might not enjoy this as it is heavily focused on him in this entry especially. Otherwise I recommend this game whole heartedly!

column8:
[h2]Final Fantasy VIII is a shockingly disappointing entry. While it has the most unique and interesting setting for its story—a genuinely compelling and present antagonist, as well as an equally strong player party—it also features the most overdesigned progression system in the series, leading to an overall horrid gameplay experience.[/h2]

[h3]Story and Setting[/h3]
Players control Squall, a member of the SeeD organization, an elite mercenary force whose services are early on being requested to take part in a political conflict between Galbadia and the surrounding nations. As a SeeD, Squall and his party can use Guardian Forces (“G.F.”), which are this game’s version of the iconic summons, to accomplish their goals and face the greater threat of an enigmatic Sorceress seemingly manipulating the unfolding events.

While the first two discs are a very slow burn, which struggle to introduce the larger themes of the story or, frankly, develop the futuristic setting in a meaningful way, discs three through four get to indulge in what FFVIII is best at—surrealism by virtue of its time travel setting as it is enabled by the game’s antagonist. 

Questions that are hinted at during the initial twenty-or-so hours are amazingly recontextualized as the story progresses, and especially Squall profits from a new writing quirk that not too many FF games use—which is reasonably liberal use of internal dialogue, which in his case roughly contrasts his very introverted demeanor. It gives character interactions within his party a lot of weight, and while not all of them are well-developed, such as Irvine or Zell, it still conveys a nice sense of chemistry between the various party members. The game’s antagonist, too, is a lot more present than many other FF villains, which helps build up her character from the very end of disc one all the way to the finale. 

Disc four deserves special mention, as the story delves into harsh surrealism, playing further with the time travel theme of the story and how this, as well as other elements of the setting, such as the usage of SeeD’s G.F., impacts a character's psyche. It is very difficult to write within a time travel setting, and even more so to represent such to the player, and FFVIII succeeds in that more often than it fails.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3348246138

While the writing may not be perfect, it is by far the most interesting that Final Fantasy has ever been and is a visual spectacle; the greatest hurdle for it is the very slow first disc, as well as ultimately some storybeats and characters remaining underdeveloped. 

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
The beating heart of FFVIII is the Junction mechanic. A fairly complex progression system, in which traditional leveling, gaining stats, as well as acquiring skills and magic, is largely grounded into this second gameplay system. How it works is that the player has a combat ability called "Draw",  which is used to acquire both G.F. summons as well as magic. Acquired magic then replaces equipment, accessories, and stat gains, as each magic has innate stats that can be “junctioned”, i.e., slotted onto a character’s stats, depending on the G.F.’s that the player has equipped.

For example, a player may have Ifrit as a G.F. junctioned onto Squall; Ifrit may be leveled to allow certain magic, like Cura, to be further junctioned onto Squall’s Strength, Spirit, or whichever stat and then scales by the raw amount of the magic that you possess, up to a limit of 100. 

This is atrocious for a variety of reasons. It all but eliminates power scaling from leveling up and completely removes all equipment sans your individual weapons from the game; it effectively punishes the active usage of magic while incentivizing mind-numbing, continuous Drawing of every new spell that may be useful for any of your characters. 

It is, inherently, a system that is complex for the sake of appearing sophisticated but is effectively just the aforementioned traditional progression systems squished together into something that is vastly inferior. I do like, however, that G.F.’s have their own progression path alongside the player characters, for which you can influence the order by what abilities are being learned.

Combat naturally suffers from the above, however, and given the smaller player party of just three characters at a time, as well as the utter dependency on G.F. to diversify their skill set, it makes it feel like the only palpable difference is their individual Limit Break ultimate abilities.

Furthermore, the game’s balance suffers immensely. Not due to the inherent bad design of the junctioning, but by the ability to convert items into magic and crafting materials. A lot of this can be gained incredibly early via a card game side activity called Triple Triad. Player’s can gain high-level magic, therefore incredibly high stats, and the crafting materials necessary to finish multiple ultimate weapons before even exiting the starting town with very minimal time investment.

To have fun with FFVIII means to ignore this and to only engage with these aspects of its design on a surface level as to not utterly rip the game apart, which is a shame since it also features some incredibly well designed bosses, among which is probably the best final story boss in the series, and equally strong dungeon design. 

[h3]Graphics and Sound[/h3]
As a Remaster, FFVIII is a total joke. This version supports higher resolutions only insofar that you may get to enjoy letterboxing; the FMV cutscenes haven’t been touched at all, and while they still are very impressive both visually and how the game manages to fluently switch from gameplay into them, they simply look incredibly crunchy on modern screens. In Borderless Windowed, the game features persistent screen tearing regardless of your screen settings. In Fullscreen, however, the game would crash my actual monitor upon quitting, which is fantastic fun. 

Apart from these complaints, which are unique to the game as a Remaster, FFVIII is a better-looking title than FFVII and arguably FFIX, thanks to the aforementioned amazing integration of FMV sequences into the gameplay.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3347760727

The new, higher-resolution player models look grossly out-of-place given the neglect of the otherwise gorgeous backgrounds and are frankly a downgrade from the original models because of it. Character animations are also more expressive than each of the other FF PS1 titles, and the game still excels at presenting its setpieces well, especially towards the end of the game. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3344229971

The soundtrack is very unique, fitting with the game’s story, though I wouldn’t call it a very classical Final Fantasy score. Nevertheless, it remains stunning with excellent combat tracks, like [i]The Legendary Beast[/i], as well as environmental tracks such as the hauntingly beautiful [i]The Castle[/i].

[h3]Technical Issues and Performance[/h3]
All of my issues remain with the above Remaster-specific criticisms. I did not encounter any crashes or miscellaneous issues. 

[h3]Final Thoughts[/h3]
Final Fantasy VIII had the potential to become my favorite entry of the series and is the only title, not just in its series but in general, that I think would benefit from a proper Remaster that entirely removes this frankly amateurish abomination of an RPG system from it. It’s an incredibly interesting setting, with competent worldbuilding, writing, and presentation, that is still so thoroughly unfun to do anything within that I can’t stand the thought of playing it again, nor to recommend it past the interest of just how it is different from every other entry in its series.

It is, inherently, a system that is complex for the sake of appearing sophisticated but is effectively just the aforementioned traditional progression systems squished together into something that is vastly inferior. I do like, however, that G.F.’s have their own progression path alongside the player characters, for which you can influence the order by what abilities are being learned.

Combat naturally suffers from the above, however, and given the smaller player party of just three characters at a time, as well as the utter dependency on G.F. to diversify their skill set, it makes it feel like the only palpable difference is their individual Limit Break ultimate abilities.

Furthermore, the game’s balance suffers immensely. Not due to the inherent bad design of the junctioning, but by the ability to convert items into magic and crafting materials. A lot of this can be gained incredibly early via a card game side activity called Triple Triad. Player’s can gain high-level magic, therefore incredibly high stats, and the crafting materials necessary to finish multiple ultimate weapons before even exiting the starting town with very minimal time investment.

To have fun with FFVIII means to ignore this and to only engage with these aspects of its design on a surface level as to not utterly rip the game apart, which is a shame since it also features some incredibly well designed bosses, among which is probably the best final story boss in the series, and equally strong dungeon design. 

[h3]Graphics and Sound[/h3]
As a Remaster, FFVIII is a total joke. This version supports higher resolutions only insofar that you may get to enjoy letterboxing; the FMV cutscenes haven’t been touched at all, and while they still are very impressive both visually and how the game manages to fluently switch from gameplay into them, they simply look incredibly crunchy on modern screens. In Borderless Windowed, the game features persistent screen tearing regardless of your screen settings. In Fullscreen, however, the game would crash my actual monitor upon quitting, which is fantastic fun. 

Apart from these complaints, which are unique to the game as a Remaster, FFVIII is a better-looking title than FFVII and arguably FFIX, thanks to the aforementioned amazing integration of FMV sequences into the gameplay.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3347760727

The new, higher-resolution player models look grossly out-of-place given the neglect of the otherwise gorgeous backgrounds and are frankly a downgrade from the original models because of it. Character animations are also more expressive than each of the other FF PS1 titles, and the game still excels at presenting its setpieces well, especially towards the end of the game. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3344229971

The soundtrack is very unique, fitting with the game’s story, though I wouldn’t call it a very classical Final Fantasy score. Nevertheless, it remains stunning with excellent combat tracks, like [i]The Legendary Beast[/i], as well as environmental tracks such as the hauntingly beautiful [i]The Castle[/i].

[h3]Technical Issues and Performance[/h3]
All of my issues remain with the above Remaster-specific criticisms. I did not encounter any crashes or miscellaneous issues. 

[h3]Final Thoughts[/h3]
Final Fantasy VIII had the potential to become my favorite entry of the series and is the only title, not just in its series but in general, that I think would benefit from a proper Remaster that entirely removes this frankly amateurish abomination of an RPG system from it. It’s an incredibly interesting setting, with competent worldbuilding, writing, and presentation, that is still so thoroughly unfun to do anything within that I can’t stand the thought of playing it again, nor to recommend it past the interest of just how it is different from every other entry in its series.

推完7re后对老版ff感兴趣，再加上看到有人说7 8 9 10的剧情都是中上，就趁着打折入了。
————————————感谢大佬们无偿免费制作的高清mod！————————————
      游戏性来讲，内容很多，要和NPC重复对阵刷幻卡，也要像网游一样练级，还要满世界的跑凑物品。
      可玩性来讲，对我而言其实比较痛苦，是回合制但不是完全是，我开着倍速操作，很多时候敌人比我先动，不开吧动画又太慢；幻卡更是难中难，游戏设计上高度绑定幻卡，不刷幻卡很多魔法道具都没有，但是NPC设计的还不简单，很容易就被拿走了心爱的Lv10角色卡，气死我了。
      剧情上来讲，因为和前代7是同一个编剧，所以男主性格类似，自闭症社恐，不同的是该作加了很多气泡，给玩家补充此时男主的内心想法。
      有几个点印象深刻，[spoiler] squall背着昏迷的rinoa一路走着，还是第一次看到squall如此用力的表达自己[/spoiler]；[spoiler] squall和rinoa伴着一曲eyes on me，在飞空艇内公主抱[/spoiler]
      现在回想，laguna才是真男主吧（笑。
      期待有生之年的重重制版（然后又被分为三部曲 拆开卖）

说句老实话，如果这部是个电影，我会评价：好老套好公式的剧情；但是这是个游戏，我跟着squall走完了这段时光，见证了他的成长，结局不出人意料但是让我很开心。

Being completely honest, this game is very underwhelming. It has a interesting plot and cast of characters especially Squall. It has its heartfelt and comedic moments. But overall the story isn't something to take you by surprise. 

The gameplay Junction system is not enjoyable in my opinion, if this game was to ever be Remade I feel as if the Junction system needs to be reworked. 

Music is a highlight, exploration and world building was very intriguing. Overall 3/5

paras FF

Final Fantasy VIII Remastered brings a much-needed graphical upgrade to the classic game, with character and monster models completely revamped in full HD. Squall, in particular, stands out, benefiting from the Dissidia design, and characters like Quistis, Rinoa, and Laguna also look sharper than ever. Unfortunately, not everything received the same treatment—backgrounds and world map textures remain unchanged from the original PlayStation version, leading to a jarring contrast between the highly detailed characters and the blurry, outdated environments. The 4:3 aspect ratio is also intact, with black bars on the sides of modern widescreens.

On the audio front, it’s all good news. The original soundtrack is back and sounds even better than before, with tracks resuming seamlessly after battles, an issue from the original game now fixed.

In terms of gameplay, the addition of the 3x speed boost is a game-changer, making the turn-based combat more enjoyable and reducing the grind of drawing magic. Two other helpful cheats—no random encounters and invincibility—allow players to focus more on the story if they wish. However, certain sequences still feel awkward in fast-forward, particularly when moving through tight spaces or using Guardian Forces, where precision is key.

While it’s a joy to relive the enhanced character models and hear the incredible music, the lack of attention to backgrounds and some minor technical hiccups hold it back from being a perfect remaster. Ultimately, whether or not it’s worth the price depends on how much these upgrades matter to you. If you're a fan of the speed boosts and visual enhancements, it’s worth the investment. If you’re sensitive to dated textures and rough edges, you might want to wait for a sale.

This remaster is pretty whatever if you're looking at it as JUST a remaster, but if you're looking at it as simply a way to play FF8, then this is 100% the definitive version, especially if it's on sale.

It has upscaled textures, actual button prompts, QOL cheats that you can use from your controller unlike almost every other FF port, new character models that while controversial in appearance are leagues better than the laughably low-poly PS1 models, etc. It's much better than the simple copy and paste port of the original.

Yeah you can mod it to fix the blurry backgrounds or play in widescreen or whatever, but I still believe this remaster is superior to the og even without mods.

Final Fantasy VIII es un clásico que sigue siendo relevante hoy en día. Su historia emocional, jugabilidad innovadora y gráficos impresionantes para la época de su salida, lo convierten en una experiencia que no te puedes perder.

La historia sigue a Squall Leonhart, un joven estudiante de la academia militar Balamb Garden, que se convierte en líder de un grupo de mercenarios llamados "SeeD". Junto a sus compañeros, Squall se enfrenta a una amenaza global: una poderosa hechicera llamada Ultimecia, que busca viajar en el tiempo y controlar el mundo.

El juego cuenta con un sistema de combate por turnos llamado "Junction", que permite a los personajes equipar "Guardian Forces" (GF) para obtener habilidades y estadísticas mejoradas. También introduce el sistema "Draw", que permite extraer magia de los enemigos y utilizarla en combate.

- El sistema de combate puede llegar a ser lento y confuso.
- La historia puede ser difícil de seguir en algunos momentos.

column8:
[h1]The score alone has kept me coming back for 25 years[/h1]

I bought [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] originally when released in 1999 for PlayStation and again when [i]Remastered[/i] dropped on PSN in 2019, so my many hours aren't logged here. Despite that, in 25 years I still haven't managed to clear this beloved title, though I've come close twice. That's neither here nor there really because I have happily played this game like it's the multi-hour Nobuo Uematsu music video it is. Seriously, this score is on par to the composer's [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] soundtrack in its delight and range. "Balamb Garden" and "Eyes On Me" by Faye Wong were tracks that colored my adolescence more than I care to admit. It took me a long while to realize I would keep returning to this game because of the music, more than the gameplay. 

But don't just go out and get the soundtrack just yet. 

[i]Remastered[/i] is a whole lot prettier in 4K on PC with the high-res models than the polygonal jitteriness of the original on PlayStation, though the seemingly untouched pre-rendered backgrounds are lackluster and in need of attention; I'm sure a high-res upscale fan mod probably exists to clear that up like fans did with [i]VII[/i]. But this remaster does include some nice features like cheat modes to turn off encounters and the ability to speed up the game by a factor of 3--huge for the repetitive GF animations that you must sit through for their damage (hey, they were awesome to watch in the 90s but we're all over scantily-clad Shiva. Ain't nobody got time to watch her throw ice 100 more times.).

But why haven't I cleared this in a quarter century of having it? Turns out you need to actually take time to understand junctioning, and grind a fair bit on top of that. Being the caveman Quake/FPS player that I am, math and stats were for nerds, and I was ignorant to how JRPGs like this worked. (Again, I blame the charm of the soundtrack for keeping me just racking up hours than trying to understand it.) So I deserved to be annoyed when I got to the end, twice, and discovered I couldn't beat the final fight as I hadn't been strategic with my magic or fought enough fights. 

That's my only warning I have for you and my largest complaint of the game: clock your hours and level up, no cutting corners. The rest of this game, well, it's just honey and summer, bliss to behold and hear even if the in-between encounters can stall things. column9:
[h1]The score alone has kept me coming back for 25 years[/h1]

I bought [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] originally when released in 1999 for PlayStation and again when [i]Remastered[/i] dropped on PSN in 2019, so my many hours aren't logged here. Despite that, in 25 years I still haven't managed to clear this beloved title, though I've come close twice. That's neither here nor there really because I have happily played this game like it's the multi-hour Nobuo Uematsu music video it is. Seriously, this score is on par to the composer's [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] soundtrack in its delight and range. "Balamb Garden" and "Eyes On Me" by Faye Wong were tracks that colored my adolescence more than I care to admit. It took me a long while to realize I would keep returning to this game because of the music, more than the gameplay. 

But don't just go out and get the soundtrack just yet. 

[i]Remastered[/i] is a whole lot prettier in 4K on PC with the high-res models than the polygonal jitteriness of the original on PlayStation, though the seemingly untouched pre-rendered backgrounds are lackluster and in need of attention; I'm sure a high-res upscale fan mod probably exists to clear that up like fans did with [i]VII[/i]. But this remaster does include some nice features like cheat modes to turn off encounters and the ability to speed up the game by a factor of 3--huge for the repetitive GF animations that you must sit through for their damage (hey, they were awesome to watch in the 90s but we're all over scantily-clad Shiva. Ain't nobody got time to watch her throw ice 100 more times.).

But why haven't I cleared this in a quarter century of having it? Turns out you need to actually take time to understand junctioning, and grind a fair bit on top of that. Being the caveman Quake/FPS player that I am, math and stats were for nerds, and I was ignorant to how JRPGs like this worked. (Again, I blame the charm of the soundtrack for keeping me just racking up hours than trying to understand it.) So I deserved to be annoyed when I got to the end, twice, and discovered I couldn't beat the final fight as I hadn't been strategic with my magic or fought enough fights. 

That's my only warning I have for you and my largest complaint of the game: clock your hours and level up, no cutting corners. The rest of this game, well, it's just honey and summer, bliss to behold and hear even if the in-between encounters can stall things. With the help of the fast forward, I plan on making my final shot with this. Third time's the charm..?

It’s ya boi zushi/bryce and I’m here for my dumb opinion on another video game. Without further ado…..


Story:6/10(I will say, the story is actually pretty good despite what I was told via friends and looking online on other platforms but I agree on the issues it has like the story telling and dialogue can be pretty wonky and non authentic. The whole time concept will leave you with a feeling that ur dumb cuz the plot in the ending goes haywire lol. Without its kinks, it’d be a 8/10)


Setting:8/10(starting out in a school was a change of pace compared to all the other games which is 1-7 at this point.I am not complaining about that though,to expand to outside this into a whole “children learn school and crafts and fight in grown up wars as Mercs” with the first mission is a crazy leap I love and without telling too much, I just like the different settings. They’re beautiful.)


Art:8/10(Now I don’t want FFVII fans to sue me cuz I love FFVII dearly but the art and character design in FVIII are better than FFVII. 
The character designs feel more real than previous installments. Overworked design in FFVII may be better and the town themselves BUT the dungeons were,in my opinion mostly either just as good as VII or slightly better and it doesn’t help VII that you go (SPOILER) to space in VIII and that whole section was perfect.)


Music:10/10(I could write a 3 page essay per song for the soundtrack about why each song is practically peak. I will not delve deeper but I will give 3 favorite songs….1.The extreme…
2.The castle….3.wounded)


Characters:10/10(Hot take but in my opinion there were no bad characters, maybe some bad dialogue that makes defining moments for characters and their development through the story but the characters themselves are just phenomenal. People complain about squall and his emoness but he’s a great character and his emoness just adds some spice to it. Rinoa is a beautiful and well written female lead. Quistis is 10/10 design and her little arc was cool, she’s nice. Selphie is adorable and truly chaotic and she eats crayons even as an adult. Zell is a final fantasy Mike Tyson,that’s all I’ll say. The main villain is great, her motivations may not be but her design(s) are 10/10.)


Battle/fights:7/10(this is where the fun DOESNT begin. I’ll be brief and simple. junction was confusing to use and I didn’t even grasp it until end of disc 3, luckily the moment I truly understood it i absolutely violated the rest of the game. My other complaint is the level scaling, enemy scaling the same as you but getting better faster than you is just plain bullying and that sucks. Outside of mechanics,what saves this section from a terrible ranking is the fact that boss fights do indeed look cool and attack animations boss and partners alike are very cool.Everyone loved on triple triad,it looks fun but i got bullied by almost every NPC I played against so I don’t have the same sentiment but it isn’t terrible.)

Overall:9/10.mathematically it’s an 8/10 but I’m giving it an extra 1 so 9/10 cuz it made me cry….Anywho I recommend this game and it’s a great game but I will say it might be a bit hard so I wouldn’t recommend to a new comer to the series nor to someone who’s never played a video game ever before

column8: non c'ho capito un cazzo

Posiblemente, el título de la saga Final Fantasy que más divide a los fans. O lo adoras, o lo detestas.

Voy a empezar por el juego base. Suele ocurrir que cuando una saga se vuelve de nicho, los devs empiezan a innovar y se atreven con cosas raras y nuevas. FF8 es el resultado del abrumador éxito de la aventura de Cloud, que provoco tremenda lluvia de fumadas en las oficinas de Square y las arcas llenas para hacerlo posible.

Lo más controvertido del titulo es sin duda el sistema de enlaces.
En resumidas cuentas, tus estadísticas no suben únicamente subiendo de nivel, si no que puedes mejorarlas enlazándolas a tus magias (que en este titulo son consumibles que puedes obtener de diversas maneras). 

Esto provoca que, si sabes jugar bien tus cartas (nunca mejor dicho), el titulo te da herramientas para mejorarte a ti mismo sin importar el nivel en el que se encuentra tu personaje. Y créeme que te da muuuuuuchas herramientas.
Final Fantasy 8 tiene el inicio y tutorial más denso y pesado de toda la saga. El sistema tiene tantas capas que necesita de estas explicaciones.
Pero una vez comprendes como funciona... OH BOI... te vas a sentir hasta mal por conseguir magias que, enlazadas correctamente, fulminan jefes en dos golpes.

Por poner un ejemplo. Enlaza 100 unidades de Aqua previamente farmeadas a tu ataque físico + 100 unidades de Drenaje a tu enlace de estado = Haces un megatón de daño y te curas el daño causado.

Hay mil y una posibilidades. Pero esto provocó que a lo largo de los años las opiniones sobre el titulo y lo diferente que era de base a sus hermanos dividiera a la comunidad. No todo el mundo estaba dispuesto a tener que estar farmeando magias y haciendo malabares con las estadísticas. Y es comprensible.

El juego de cartas sigue siendo TOP de minijuegos en los JRPG del mundo mundial y la historia no esta tan bien contada como me gustaría. Hay mucho lore escrito en las guías internas del juego que la historia va a dar por sentado que has leído.

Sin embargo, yo le tengo un cariño especial por nostalgia y no he exprimido bien el sistema de enlaces hasta esta ocasión en la que he probado el remaster.

Ahora al remaster:
Vamos a empezar rompiendo el melón. Square perdió los masters originales de prácticamente todos los títulos de esta época. Aun no soy capaz de entender los chanchullos que habrán tenido que hacer los equipos para remasterizar este juego. Y me congratula decir que el resultado es visualmente inmejorable. Si, no es un remake, así que no hay nada desde cero, y lo que no se ha podido arreglar sigue roto, como los fondos prerrenderizados que están un poco borrosos.
Todo el juego esta a 4:3 por esta razón.

Musicalmente esta correcto, hay arreglos ligeros de los temas de Uematsu, que son EXTREMadamente buenos (like por referencia viejuna), y las mejoras de calidad de vida son prácticamente obligatorias ya, porque este juego tiene un ritmo leeeeeeeeeeeeento, y el x3 te salva.

Faltan algunas cosas del juego base, como el minijuego completo de chocobo world, que no se, debía estar en otro disco y lo dejaron fuera. Y a Sirena la han puesto una faldita para que no vaya a coger frío.

Esta reseña se esta alargando más que un día sin pan así que... conclusión:

Si jugaste al original, juégalo, esta chevere.

Si no jugaste al original, juégalo, esta chido. PERO ten en cuenta que es un JRPG que te va a pedir que estudies y comprendas sus mecánicas para que lo disfrutes al máximo.

column8:
Final Fantasy VIII has the awkward position of being sandwiched between the two of the greatest JRPGs ever made, which coupled with some inspired but ultimately confusing game design and story decisions leaves the game pretty divisive for series fans.

The presentation is significantly improved over its predecessor whether you're playing the remaster or not. The character models out in the field no longer have toasters for hands and are much closer to resemble the proportions of an actual human being. It also includes the integration of FMV backgrounds, with set pieces that must have been seriously impressive on the PS1.

Equally as ambitious is the story. It attempts to tackle some interesting themes through the eyes of an intentionally off-putting protagonist, with it's perception of 'time travelling' and how it plays out being in my opinion genuinely novel and engaging. And of course series composer Nobuo Uematsu kills it again, matching each scene and battle perfectly.

Unfortunately the story has some other issues, both the characters and pacing. I can happily accept a flawed main character, but the accompanying party members aren't nearly interesting enough to make up for how boring he is. The romance between him and Rinoa (which is supposedly a huge focus of the game) is really difficult to buy into, thanks to how rude and aloof he is. [spoiler]Laguna's romance and relationships are done significantly better, and it was much easier to get invested into his story rather than the A-plot. [/spoiler] 

Character progression is completely bizarre. Trying something experimental is entirely welcome, and it would be unfair to expect something equal to the materia system of VII, but it's just so counter intuitive. Since you use given quantities of magic to power up your stats, those being the same you actually cast in battles, your disincentivised from using magic without weakening your party. Along with the level scaling (!) it leaves the difficulty curve feeling wonky and inconsistent.

TL;DR: It's definitely a strange but certainly not bad game. I'd actually say it's pretty good, there's just some key areas that whilst experimental can really bring it down. However, if the weird progression and story sit right with you, you'll really enjoy it. Personally I'd still recommend it... just not before recommending you play VII or IX first.

column8:
Alright, hear me out on this.

Final Fantasy VIII is one of the best RPGs ever made, and probably my favorite FF game outside of XII. The systems and story, and world design are pretty peak and you can see it's influence in nearly every FF after it. Also, Triple Triad amirite?

However, this port is lazy as hell. Squeenix spent all their resourcing on the models and cheats, instead of remastering the game as a whole. The blurred backgrounds and the higher res models clash horribly, which is a huge problem from a consistency standpoint (and in all their remasters honestly). 
They seem to just tackle the low hanging fruit, and not be willing to put in the work to make a complete package. 
It's half remastered at best. And while I appreciate the quality of life upgrades it affords (3x mode is great for shortening the lengthy startup/GF animations), it's not what people want out of a remaster. [i]They want it to run on their modern systems, in a modern window, with upscaled assets. [b]All the assets.[/b][/i]

Thank god for the modding community doing the work this two bit corporate shithouse refuses to do. The texture mods out there make this game incredible, plus add a little CRT Reshade filter, and you have the definitive version of Final Fantasy VIII. 

But Squaresoft didn't deliver it, so I don't think they deserve the profit. So here's what I think. I do not recommend FFVIII as it stands, what I suggest is: [b]Wait for the game to go on sale, and pay $5 to Squeenix for their $5 port. Then take the extra $15 and put it towards the mod projects that actually make the definitive version possible.[/b]

Get your shit together, Square. You don't deserve to be rewarded for doing inconsistent work on one of the best games ever.

（1）战斗系统:即便我玩过的jrpg量已经很多了，atb系统也聊熟于心，但ff8系统着实让我犯蒙了一阵，又是动态等级要压级又是融合指令的，找菜单找了半天也找不到装备栏，游戏初期都不知道该怎么提升自己，打的十分憋屈。之后还是请教群里一些老玩家才大致搞懂，要结合GF技能学习和融合魔法两大子类，属于变相的装备。在学习如道具精致、魔法精致等精致技能后，即可实现利用材料间转换，让战斗资源逐渐丰富，进而使得角色慢慢变强，随着流程推进逐渐开始爽玩。
（2）角色养成体验:因为我是玩的是压级打法，前期玩着是很憋屈的，大概是从学园解锁飞行移动后去刷仙人掌让手上大部分GF学到关键技能后体验开始指数函数式提升。调整融合魔法种类与积攒魔法数量，使角色数值逐步上升；为了强力被动技，通过查阅精致表去刷取素材，一刷就是一下午，老ff在养成正反馈方面真的爽。
（3）角色bd体验:在前中期技能有限情况下不断调整融合GF，使得各种GF技能的补集趋于全能，终局甚至可以通过忘之草和其他GF能力药获取更高阶技能，再借由精致技能道具化，使得魔法、GF技能品质更高，终局bd灵活多变，通过自己的筛选，搭配出心目中最棒的阵容。
（4）世界感:高清化时代之前的ff在隐藏内容方面一直在线，这些隐藏不仅丰富游戏内容、提升探索感，更重要的是呈现出一种世界感——驾驶飞空艇前往很多之前去不到的地点，这个过程也在观览整个星球的城镇分布与地貌表现，特殊NPC事件透露一些故事设定同时，也让整个世界充满生气，可惜随着图形技术提升，场景与NPC建模成本提高，从10代开始便不再看到这种开着飞空艇跨越世界地图，说到这里我真的很希望7代重制的第三部能实现自由开飞空艇探索整个世界的功能。
（5）故事体验:第一张盘主角团的行动还比较平淡，主要介绍人物、世界观设定，进入到第二张盘后，主要反派登场后故事代入感逐渐提升，在fh篇章花费大量流程准备音乐会，并抛出“我们都喜欢你，希望和你在一起，共度这些时光。”“把这些话记在你心底，当你需要了，就大声呼唤我们，我们都会等着你。”“把这些话记在你心底，当你需要了，就大声呼唤我们，我们都会等着你。”，男女主情感线逐渐升温，到为救莉诺雅的情感爆发，之后当在诸神黄昏上初次响起《eyes on me》这首歌的时候我的心被融化了，这个时候本座在我心目中已经位列神作行列。
（6）个人思考:ff系列从12开始的单机正传剧本口碑一直不太行，我感觉主要是缺少我玩过的8 9 10这三部作品中共同的十分出色的女主塑造与男女主之间的感情线，同时过于注重宏大世界观与神明设定，但高清化时代游戏制作成本提升，为平衡成本作品长度有限，很难支持宏大背景塑造。真切希望之后作品能努力刻画女主，丰富男女主感情线，题材灵活一些少一些神话背景也没什么不好。
总结，本作在gameplay与故事讲述上的塑造放到今时今日仍不过时，能让我两周算上sl的时间总共爆肝100h，充实且愉快，期待未来能再看到深刻刻画女主与男女主感情线的ff正传新作。

Final Fantasy VIII is really fun! It doesn't explain the "junction" combat system very well, so it's easy to bounce off this game. But the system isn't all that complicated, it just takes a bit to get used to, because it's quite different than a typical JRPG.

The remastered version has worked well for me. I do wish they went further with the remaster, would have been nice if Square Enix spent the money to update the background art and textures as well as the character models. I read somewhere they lost the source code to this game, so it's tricky for them to modify. In any case, it's a fun play.

The setting: You're in Hogwarts school for special forces. In this world firearms are (highly) effective, but these "special" forces use swords, whips and nunchucks to dispense liberty across the world via mercenary work to keep the school economicaly afloat. Also you're underaged which constitutes a violation of the Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child on the Involvement of Children in Armed Conflict (OPAC) and it constitutes a warcrime according to the International criminal court (ICC Statute, Article 8(2)(b)(xxvi) and (e)(vii)). Not only that but you were recuited from an orphanage which adds fuel to the fire. Your real goal as a member of the special forces is to protect from and (if necessary) kill your CO's wife.

It's an amazing game that I had fond memories of. It was impossible to top FF7 imo, but it was a good sucessor. Story, characters and gameplay are all engaging, and the junction system, altough yes it completely breaks the game if you know what to do, it was nice discovering and tinker with it on the 1st playtrough back on release.
This port it's a mess though, there's mods that make it better, but doesn't take away how bad a job square did porting this.

column8:
I didn't really know or expect much jumping into this game.
Classic high-school romance, right? Maybe.
It was hard to get my head around the ancient game design and menus.
But there was something refreshing about that.
I didn't know it was going to be a 50+hr experience, but it never felt like a drag.
The characters felt real,
And I learned something valuable from each of them.
I learned a lot from this game,
It made me reflect.
I would recommend it to anyone.

It is Final Fantasy VII as I remember it and works well with xbox controller.  It is not a remake or a significant improve over the orginal.  The main improve is in the quality of the sprites and battle graphics.  The cinematic cut scenes do not seem to have improve in a meaningful way, not like it would be needed as the cinematic cut scenes were the best part of the orginal.  Of course, it has the same problems as before, the weak plot, the grinding, the system for improving your character that is simply too complicated.  I knew all this going into the purchase and I felt I made good purchase, if you remember the orginal and want to pick it up a again, this is a good option.  If you are new Final Fantasy, then you should know this is one of the weaker games in the series.  I consider Final Fantasy 6, 7, 9, 10, or 12 to be much better choices to start with.

column8:
Ich kann die zuteilen negativen Kommentare verstehen, da die Grafik für eine Remake-Version wirklich nicht wunderschön aussieht. Auch die fummelige  Steuerung ist zuweilen ein Krampf. Aber auf mein Spielvergnügen hatten diese Punkte dennoch keinen großartig negativen Einfluss: Die fabelhafte Story ist nach wie vor erlebenswert und konnte, zumindest mich, ausreichend von den Mankos ablenken. Die Länge des Abenteuers und die Spielmechanik (rundenbasierte Kämpfe, Level-Sytematik etc.) haben mich sogar so sehr bei Laune gehalten, dass ich den Ehrgeiz hatte, alle Errungenschaften zu sammeln. Dabei ist mir aufgefallen, dass die Remake-Variante machbare Achievements zu bieten hat, während die andere bei Steam angebotene Version übertriebene Erfolge verlangt (1.000 Kämpfe in der Remake-Variante waren schon ein unnötiger Zeitfresser, aber 10.000 wären wirklich zu viel des Guten!). Wer auf eine Komplettierung der Achievements also Wert legt, ist hier mit der Remake-Version deutlich besser beraten.

Mein abschließendes Fazit lautet: Ich kann das Spiel allen empfehlen, die an einer spannenden und emotionalen Story interessiert sind und dabei rundenbasierte Kämpfe zu schätzen wissen. Die Grafik ist zwar kein Highlight, muss das Spielerlebnis aber auch nicht zwingend behindern, da sie immer noch deutlich besser ist, als das hochgelobte FF7.
