I don't know how to feel about Final Fantasy VIII. So I'm going to say my gut-check thoughts, maybe ramble a little about it, then maybe come back later and edit this review when it simmers more. I could wait, but it's routine for me to log things once they're done, so... let's do it.

I absolutely LOVE the characters of Final Fantasy VIII. Zell is funny but I love his character growth especially after he makes a huge mistake and starts taking more responsibility for things. Selphie's great, very spunky. Irvine has a GUN in a JRPG! Whoa! That's automatic brownie points. Quistis is awesome because she's intelligent but willing to speak her mind as well. Rinoa's wonderful, and she might be my favorite love interest in the series now. Squall is a fantastic protagonist.

What makes Squall stand out from other protagonists in FF is the train of thought they use in dialogue. We see what Squall is thinking very often in this game through the use of his inner dialogue, and I think that really elevates him up to being in the upper tier of FF protagonists for me.

I do like Edea, but she runs into the same issue that Beatrix does in FF9, where it doesn't really make a ton of sense to me why she's not playable permanently. It was cool to use her for a bit but it just feels like a waste of XP to do so since she's gone so soon. I know there's a story reason why she's not in the party permanently, but why write her OUT of the story when you could write her IN the story. I would've loved the angle of her being with the party until the end thematically due to her personal connection with the party.

Speaking of that connection, that was a pretty wild lore drop, and it came at a weird time too. Without spoiling much, FF8's issue with its story is all these lore beats that feel like they're not paced or timed well. They feel very sudden.

Take Ultimecia, the game's big bad for example. Ultimecia isn't even mentioned in the plot until around halfway through Disc 3? Why? The fake-out antagonist thing would be cool, but you can't just drop a new antagonist on me, explain why she's bad (I agree, she's bad), then steer the story hard left on a collision course with them. It doesn't really work for me. Ultimecia ultimately feels half-baked unfortunately.

Another character I didn't really buy was Seifer. He's on the cover of this game and I don't really get why. He's not in the game THAT much when you really think about it. I never really bought into his character or really understood the point of it. Am I supposed to feel sorry for him? Am I supposed to feel for him the same way I do for Riku in Kingdom Hearts 1? If the game established Seifer as more of a friend to Squall like KH1 does for Sora and Riku, I would buy it more. But instead the game portrays Seifer as Squall's rival at the beginning, with his only two friends being Fujin and Raijin. If Squall was actually Seifer's friend, and that was established enough, it would work much better in my opinion.

The characters, though, are FF8's strong suit. It's what the game does the best. Having a much more contained party of 6 compared to many other FF games makes it so the characterization really shines through. I really appreciate that because the story is a little... so-so.

Which doesn't mean bad, but I think the story gets a little shaky at times, and gets a bit nonsensical. I felt a little lost in the plot at certain points, to which I would then realize, "Oh, I'm not lost, it's just a bit ridiculous." I do think it gets more nonsensical after Disc 1, which plays into that infamous "Squall is Dead" theory. I... don't really believe that theory, but they use the story's nonsensical shift as evidence of it, and I think that's believable. The tone itself doesn't feel like it shifts, but you slowly start to realize that FF8's world is more whimsical and complicated than it initially seems. Like the complete opposite of FF7's world, for instance, which sees to ground itself in its own setting throughout. FF8 does not and it feels like we get more and more into the realm of nonsense in the form of Sci-Fi, aliens, space, timey-whimey shennanigans, the Moombas and etc.

JRPG nonsense isn't bad. I have a high tolerance for it and I actually like it! But sometimes that stuff muddies up the plot, and makes it feel like it's all over the place, you know? Especially when there's SO MUCH of that in FF8.

The game does some interesting things with flashback sequences. In these sequences you play as a completely different set of characters in the past - Laguna, Kiros, and Ward. These guys are cool, but the way this is handled mechanically bugs me a little bit. There were multiple times where I had to reload, because none of my Junctions were carried over properly to Kiros. One instance was when I was using Edea for the brief time she was available, and couldn't transfer her Junction because she didn't appear in the Junction Exchange screen. That was kinda frustrating. What also sucks about these sequences is that the payoff for them kinda sucks. Y'know, I thought these were going to tie into the plot in a way that was way more significant than it actually ended up being with how much build up we got, but I ended up being really disappointed by it - especially since I really liked Laguna as a character. He has a little bit of Zack energy and I love how hopeful and silly of a guy he is.

The last thing I want to talk about is the gameplay. And many might assume at first impression so far that I might be talking about the Junction system, but no, I'm not. I actually like Junctioning!

If you asked me to explain how Junctioning works, I would not be able to tell you. It's something you have to play with and get used to in order to learn it. I love the mechanic. It's not perfect, but I did find it really fun, and I love how customizable it is. I guess if I had to nitpick, I do think it makes everyone feel a little samey by the end, and I hated that the final boss picked party members at random that were unequipped, even though there's a little workaround for that.

My issue with the gameplay is drawing charges for Magic. I think that's awful. It makes FF8 play very boring. I know you can use the various Guardian Force abilities to convert cards and items into Magic. Cool. I did that a lot. But it doesn't change my point here, which is that it derails the pacing entirely into a trainwreck. Constantly having to stop and tank hits in battle to restock the items, cards or straight-up drawing the magic you need is terrible. That's an awful mechanic. And I think honestly that's partly what disrupts FF8's pacing a ton.

I get that it's experimental, it's different, bonus points for trying something new, but ehh... I just can't help thinking how this game would be at least 50% better with a regular MP system. And instead of charges dictating how much of a boost junctioned Magic gives, give each spell a different base value. Something like that would've been so much more enjoyable. FF8's gameplay really caused me to drag my feet with it, and I probably would've finished this game a lot sooner if it wasn't for my distaste for playing it.

Hence why FF8 feels really weird to rate for me. It has dull gameplay compared to others in the series, interesting experimental mechanics (Junctioning) and storytelling mechanics (flashbacks), a story that somehow strums the line between okay, good and peak, and of course - some of my favorite characters in the series.

If I cut FF8 a lot of slack for being on the PlayStation 1, and I give them credit for being experimental and trying things - because FF SHOULD try new things after 8 entries... I can feel comfortable giving it a great score. Let's let it simmer more though. This is for now - ask me again in 3 months, 6 months, or a year, and we'll see how I feel.

Score: 85

(We stan Rinoa btw)

column8:
This game sucks. 

The gameplay sucks. The draw/junction system is tedious and obnoxious. The leveling system sucks. Since the enemies level up with you, grinding can actually make you WEAKER through its bizarro math if you don't constantly upgrade your junctioned magic. Triple Triad completely turned me off, so I just completely ignored it and had no trouble beating the game.

The plot sucks. Somehow none of the characters got any development aside from Squall and Rinoa. I spent 35 hours in this damn game and I still know next to nothing about Quistis and Irvine. Maybe a little about Zell being a goof. That's about it.

The only thing it had going for it was that it was relatively pretty for a PS1 era game. That's all. The only compliment I can muster for this game. What a cat turd of a game.

thumbs up overall but only with the caveat that as of 2024 this remastered version is pretty easy to mod the textures in the backgrounds following guides on youtube/reddit/forums. i wouldnt play this version without texture upgrade mods. also the sounds are pretty rough and grainy sounding. the soundtrack seems to be easier to mod on the 2013 "OG" version but not in this remastered version. its not just the soundtracks either every summon ive used so far just sounds bad -- grainy and blown out. still, the last time i played this was back on ps1 growing up and i am enjoying the hell out of it. maybe i should have got the 2013 version over this one, but im going to just play this one and deal with it. game itself 9/10, this remsatered version is probably like a 6.5/10. it might be easiest to get a rom of the ps1 game but i had the money and got it during one of the steam sales and wanted the most updated character models, which do look great.

havent tried on steam deck but ive read it should work until you sleep, sleeping it apparently messes with the soundtrack or can cause crashes.

소싯적 삼성 정발판(영문버젼)으로 구매해 매우 재미있게 즐겼던 파판 시리즈의 8탄. 과거의 추억을 되살려
다시 플레이 해보았지만 그때의 감성만 가지고 클리어하기엔 너무나 오래된 게임이며 지루하기 짝이 없는
너무나 과대평가된 게임.

장점 - 큰 스케일과 화려한 연출(발매 당시 기준)
           스팀 버젼으로 세일 시 저렴한 가격에 소장/즐길 수 있음


단점 - 20년이 넘은 고전 게임인 탓에 현대의 눈높이로 즐기기엔 너무나 부족한 그래픽과 사운드
        - 드로우 노가다와 카드 노가다를 강요하는 지루한 게임 플레이
        - 일본게임 특유의 유치한 대사와 병맛 연출
        - 한글패치 부재로 유저패치와 유저 그래픽 패치를 해야 그나마 해볼만 해지는 불편함

총평 - 파판 매니아라면 모를까 파판에 딱히 팬심이 없는 일반인 입장에서는 라이브러리 +1외에는 아무런 가치가
없는 작품. 특히 노가다를 싫어한다면 최악의 작품이 될 수가 있기에 클리어를 노린다면 편하게 게임에서 제공하는
각종 부스터와 치트를 키고 할 것을 권장함.

column8:
Sans doute mon Final Fantasy préféré ✨

L'OST de cet opus est un banger absolu (en même temps Nobuo Uematsu !), et l'histoire est très prenante. 
On y incarne Squall, un élève de la Balamb Garden University (aka BGU) très réservé et assez asocial. Au tout début du jeu, il est très facile de le détester mais, au fur et à mesure que nous avançons dans l'histoire, on en apprend un peu plus sur lui et... l'évolution du personnage est appréciable. 
Tous les persos ont un petit quelque chose qui a fait que personnellement je me suis attachée à chacun d'entre eux (pas tous en fait ! (Seifer je te détesterai toujours)).

Ce remaster est visuellement appréciable au niveau des personnages : ils sont plus détaillés et plus "lissé" (rien à voir avec la bouillie de pixel et le semblant de visage de la version 99 ! (Mais qu'est-ce que je l'aime cette bouillie moi ❣️)). Pour un jeu de l'époque, on avait quand même des mécaniques assez intéressantes et le fait de mêler à certains moment un léger gameplay pendant les cinématiques rendaient tout ça innovant pour l'époque. 
Oui je sais, je parle de l'original malgré que je poste un avis pour le remaster mais c'est la nostalgie qui parle, excusez-moi.

Le système de G-Force et de capacités est assez intéressante et les associations élémentaires pour renforcer notre perso sur leurs caractéristiques sont sympas.
Le fait de pouvoir voler des sorts à des ennemis (voir même des G-Forces) est quelque chose que j'ai toujours apprécié (j'en ai passé des heures à essayer de voler le plus de sorts possible (et parfois, quand ça veut pas ça veut pas !! Mais un peu de persévérance, de temps et on y parvient quand même...)).

Bref, cet avis pour dire que le remaster est agréable malgré les couacs visuels qu'il peut représenter parfois. Je suis bien contente de pouvoir redécouvrir cette merveille avec des persos de mon enfance mieux détaillés pour la plupart. 

Et j'allais oublier le plus important ! Si vous aimez les jeux de cartes, vous allez adorer le Triple Triad ! Je peux passer des heures à jouer à FFVIII uniquement pour jouer aux cartes, c'est assez addictif mais par contre certaines règles sont très punitives ! 

Que vous soyez des nostalgiques ou bien des nouveaux joueurs, je vous souhaite une agréable (re)découverte 🌿

ガチ世代、時代と年齢と青春がバチっとはまった時のFFです。
今でも序盤の流れを覚えていて遊んでいて懐かしさを感じます。

ただｗ… 昔みたいな情熱で遊べないってのが今買って遊んだ正直な気持ち。最初に出てくる恐竜を倒してやるぞ！！と意気込んでレベルを上げていたあの頃と比べるとそこまでは出来ない。リマスター版とは言ったものの正直今遊ぶにはしょぼい。
カードゲームも終盤の激強カードで遊んでた感覚からするとよっわよわだし、これから魔法をドローしまくる作業を考えると正直萎えてしまったｗ

買って損した気分では無いけどまー なつかしさを感じるなら動画でも探してみた方が手軽で楽だなと思った。

後ただ雰囲気だけ味わいたい人ように、無敵など簡単に進められるいわゆるチート的な機能がある事でもなんか萎えてしまった。やりがいがって大事ね

不愧是在ff7光环之下做的（竖大拇哥）可以看得出来经费非常充足）那个年代的游戏使用了大量的高质量cg非常棒，主题曲也专门找了王菲来唱。至于游戏性上注意了这部作品有了不小的革新。先是等级——注意了这一作的怪物强度是随主角团等级变化的！！！！！也就是说练级没有任何必要甚至可能会起反作用！！！总之相对而言最优解是不要练级，遇到野怪抽完魔法直接逃跑！！至于练能力可以去找找攻略。魔法不再是可恢复的mp或是次数，而是变成了可以抽取的能力，需要从各地图上的抽取点或是怪物身上抽取。个人认为是非常有新意而又经典的值得体验的一部作品。steam上没有汉化需要去其他地方找汉化补丁，国内有人做了高清化mod的重置版可以上b站搜什么的都可以搜到。最后骂一句SE ：）
印象深刻的两点：打牌和王菲

column8:
10/10
It's not a game, it's a great work of art, it's a touching movie, it's a romantic and moving epic. FF8 is the most worthy of the title FINAL FANTASY in the whole series, and it's one of the most fantastic and romantic works in the whole game history.
Most importantly, it often reminds me that at one point in time, mankind was still so purely in pursuit of innocence and beauty, of a love that no evil could ever desecrate. The kind of purity and true love that human beings used to try their best to describe and portray, the kind of love that they are willing to give up everything for someone, is totally different from the post-modern full of nowadays, which is full of questioning and mocking everywhere.
The best FF in my heart, bar none. Nowadays I can't help but get mesmerized and weep just by hearing its OST.

column8:
When I first played this game, not long after it's original release, I wasn't very keen on it. It didnt help that it followed FF7 and then had FF9 come along after it, with both of those being some of my favourite FF games. But I've grown to appreciate this game a lot more over the years and have a much higher opinion of it now. 

With hindsight I think this game was just ahead of its time as it shook up the formula quite a bit with the junction system. Once you understand how to use the junction system, it's a lot of fun. If you're willing to spend the time farming the items and cards for refining into spells you can make your characters massively overpowered early on but it isnt mandatory. You can get by the majority of the game with just gathering spells from monsters, draw points and the occasional card game at a steady pace.

The way Guardian Forces are handled is probably my favourite use of them in any FF game. Having them learn abilities that can provide more functions for battle or further boost your stats complements the junction system nicely although I'm not a big fan of the overly long summon animations.

The fact that enemies scale with you in this game always seemed like a controversial choice but it's nice that you are never really pressured to grind battles to gain levels. In fact its more advantageous to keep your level low.

The main characters and story I think are probably one of the games weaker points. Other than Squall and maybe Zell I feel like the other characters aren't as memorable as ones from other games. They story is good but again probably overshadowed a little by some of the other games and it can be a bit hard to follow at times. However the soundtrack is amazing and is one area where it definitely stands above a lot of other FF games.

Looking at the remastered version itself, it kind of feels like a low effort remaster. The character models have been upgraded and while they do look nice it clashes badly with the backgrounds which havent been upscaled at all and still look as they originally did. The FMVs also are unchanged from their originals so any changes are pretty much limited to the character models. You could pretty much get the same result with the original version and some graphics mods. I didn't encounter anything gamebreaking or anything like and it runs well enough. it just doesnt feel like much effort went into it.

So to sum it up. Final Fantasy 8 the game is definitely worth trying, as it's one of the better FF games. The worth of the remaster itself is probably down to whether you're happy or not to try and mod the original version.

column8:
He jugado Final Fantasy desde el 7, en su estreno, hasta el 15. Jugué a Final Fantasy VIII cuando era una rata, en play station, con los ojos de los personajes como dos puñaladas a un tomate en formato pixel. En aquel entonces me pareció de una épica acojonante. Recuerdo que este juego, en mi país, estaba envuelto en polémica por un asesino que tras jugar esto mató a su familia. Entré buscando violencia y sangre y salí maravillado con sus 2 primeros CD's.

El juego nos cuenta la historia de Squall, un estudiante algo imbécil de "el jardín de balamb" que podría ser un instituto privado perfectamente pero que aquí es una empresa que se financia de forma dudosa y se sustenta de forma dudosa también (Squall no paga un carajo porque es huérfano, que alguien me explique cómo puede seguir matriculado). El instituo en cuestión es una academia militar que busca crear soldados que cumplan misiones y den dinerito al jardín (mercenarios) y a los propios soldados claro. Intuyo que aquí está el filón del sustento de las instalaciones pero, claro, al poco de empezar ya te dicen que han aceptado un contrato de 4 hippies muertos de hambre (la resistencia de Timber) por cuatro duros, so...

La historia no está mal. Busca desarrollar a sus personajes (fundamentalmente y en exclusiva a Squall y Rinoa) aunque lo hace de forma acelerada y torpe.  Tú tienes totalmente claro que va a crearse una parejita pero tiene cero sentido que esto ocurra. Sin embargo cumple en sus dos primeros CD's, como decía. A partir del tercero, se fumaron y porro y encima debieron quedarse sin pela para completar correctamente la historia y se marcan un Naruto por toda la puta cara.

En lo jugable, es el clásico JRPG a turnos pero con algunos elementos que tienen interés y que, sin embargo, se cargan el juego. Si no has estado en una cueva los últimos 25 años sabrás de qué hablo: el puto sistema de enlaces. Resulta que puedes romper el juego, en el primer CD, con 4 habilidades que puedes aprender rápidamente. Estas habilidades son:

-Carta: Permite convertir monstruos en cartas. Te dan PH (útil para desarrollar las invocaciones de este juego, que te potencian) pero no te dan experiencia. Es decir, no subes de nivel. Luego veremos por qué interesa esto.
-Convertir cartas: Permite transformar cartas en objetos.
-Convertir objetos en magias de fuego, hielo y rayo: Permite convertir objetos (trozo de bom) en magias (Piro, piro+ y piro++).

Y listo, acabas de joder el juego. ¿Por qué? Pues porque los monstruos "crecen contigo", como los Pokémon. Si tus personajes tienen nivel 10, los enemigos rondan ese nivel y por tanto sus stats y hechizos también. ¿Qué ocurre? Pues que tu fuerza la determinan las magias enlazadas. Así que eres level 10, te has inflado a conseguir aire artico y has enlazado Hielo ++ a la fuerza, por lo que ahora tienes a Squal level 10 con 120 de FRZ. De una hostia estás metiéndole a un boss más de 3k de daño. El boss es nivel 10 y tiene una defensa que da puta risa. El boss muere de 2 golpes. Uno si eres experimentado en los enlaces. Además de esto puedes robar las magias a los enemigos, lo cual ya potencia esta dinámica y, en fin... Así funciona. Si encima te dedicas a jugar a las cartas con la peña, a saco, cosa que en mi caso ha ocurrido porque me gusta el minijuego, con algo de suerte sacas cartas bastante tochas que te dan acceso a magias poderosas como artema o meteo que, directamente, te pueden hacer invulnerable a la magia con enlaces a resistencias elementales o capear la fuerza y meter 9999 con una galleta a nivel 15.

La versión remastered no mejoró nada de esto porque se hizo desde la puta pereza. Los acabados gráficos están de puta madre en los personajes (NPC y jugables) pero los escenarios solo recibieron un reshade ligero. En el mapa continental el suelo está en cuadrados dividido, es un canteo serio. Además existen errores de traducción. Por ejemplo puedes extraer 5 magias Aqua a un enemigo y te indica que has extraido 5 magias Aquas. Y dices... bueno ok... Pero claro, luego extraes 5 magias Piro++ y el juego te dice que has extraído 5 magias Piro++s. Te casca el plural en los símbolos. En fin, desastre.

Y claro... Aquí viene la pregunta. Si la historia no es la gran cosa, si los personajes... bueno, si el sistema de juego está roto... ¿Por qué lo has jugado hasta completar todos los logros si ya lo jugaste en su versión de salida cuando Franco era cadete? Pues en primer lugar por la nostalgia, y en segundo lugar... No tengo ni idea. El juego tiene ciertos secretos (que tampoco aportan mucho) en su mundo, tiene una historia secundaria (Laguna) mucho más interesante y exprimible (si hubieran querido) que la del prota... Pero por algo, atrapa. El universo, la atmósfera de conflicto militar, ciertos temas que se tocan en la obra (sacrificar tus vivencias, tus vínculos, por mantener tu poder y salvar a los que amas), hay algo en él que te invita a ver dónde termina.

¿Lo recomiendo? En rebaja y si los combates por turnos no te incomodan, si. A 19,99? no.


¿Alternativas a FFVIII? Pues... El IX o el X, que tienen más cariño en su desarollo... O Sea of Stars, Persona 5 Royal, así a ojo.

Pero si escoges jugar FFVIII, intenta no romperlo y disfruta de Laguna por mi. Nos vemos en otro comentario.

column8:
[h1][b]Final Fantasy VIII - Remastered[/b][/h1]

[b]Rating: 5/10 - Mediocre[/b]

Pretty much everything about this game rubs me the wrong way. [b]Final Fantasy VIII[/b] is simply a[b]Mediocre[/b] game. Characters are boring and most of them barely develop during the story - on top of that they have the collective charisma of a dying houseplant. The story itself just didn't draw me in at all. It feels underdeveloped and combined with the boring characters just simply isn't enjoyable. 

Combat is pretty unimpressive as well. The junction system, while pretty interesting as a concept, is combined with the annoying and mind-bogglingly boring draw system. There's also the fact that the game has fucking level-scaling, one of the few mechanics that automatically makes [i]most[/i] games worse just by being in the game.

Overall [b]Final Fantasy VIII[/b] is a pretty [b]Mediocre[/b] game, not necessarily [b]Bad[/b]. I can sort of see what some find in this game but I honestly don't - to me it's just a disappointing and boring experience.

Great; 8/10.

This game certainly earns its reputation as the black sheep of the franchise - the new combat system centered around the acquisition and junctioning of consumable magic for stat boosts, item refining and enemies keeping pace with your characters' levels does more harm than good for the actual gameplay. Combat is fun yet but characters can feel homogenous, and the game encourages you to do a hell of a grind, with varying levels of tedium.

That said, the story is engaging and sensitive, even if it does go wildly off the rails near the end of the game. The game's presentation is awesome, by way of its graphics still looking gorgeous for such an old game - even considering the slightly-sloppy remaster - for example, cutscenes are firmly groundbreaking for its time, and the music is a treat with a ton of awesome tracks, too.

Worth a play if you can go in with an open mind and a stomach for grind.

Worth a play if you can go in with an open mind and a stomach for grind.

column8: Un classico intramontabile ed mio parere uno dei capitoli migliori che gioca sull'effetto nostalgia di tanti vecchi videogiocatori

The first Final Fantasy game that I didn't like. In fact, I disliked it so much, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone, and I can't say the same for all the other Final Fantasy's I've played.

Imma get right into it, the junction system was a solid idea, very poorly executed. I understand that they tried to make a game where grinding wasn't necessary, and they succeeded, but the result was a game with the most boring combat I've ever had to endure. While I actually enjoyed drawing from new enemies to see what new spells/GFs I could get, barely any of the spells were of any use both from a spellcasting and junctioning standpoint. And once you figure out which spells are good and how the junction system works, you break the game so badly it becomes unfun, you end up steamrolling through everything, bosses included. 

And don't even get me started on the snoozefest of a story. Literally no characters had any development outside of Squall and Rinoa, and even then it was pretty minimal. Everyone else was just along for the ride. And for me personally, even when "exciting" stuff was happening, I could bring myself to care, I tried, but I couldn't do it.

If I have anything positive to say about this game, it's the Laguna sequences, music, the last few hours of the game and the final dungeon. The way that final dungeon was designed should be used as an example for how to do a final dungeon. Without spoiling anything, I didn't get interested in the story until right before you get your final ship. From there onward, game was great, the other 80% was painful however.

So why not drop it, why even complete it? Probably because I'm stubborn and told myself I'd play through all mainline FF games, and 8 was on the list next.

3/10.

레벨 가변 시스템이 들어있음
불편한 길찾기

그외 비추천이지만 난 잼나게 했음 (한글화 해주신 분들에게 아주 큰 감사인사 드려요)

위에 써있듯 레벨 가변 시스템이 있음 
초반 몹이라도 *파티원 레벨에따라 적 레벨이 올라가면서
능력치가 오르고 높은 등급,다른 마법을 들고 나옴

맘먹고 올릴려고 하면 금방함
하지만 적당히 하면서 클리어 하고 싶으면 (치트없이)
마법 드로우 노가다 + 저렙 케릭터 보유(일부러 렙업을 안시키는 케릭)
컨셉으로 하시면 그냥그냥 할수있음
추가로 겜 중반쯤 특정마을에서 
알테마 마법을 구할수있는데 돈있는거 다 털어서 구하는걸 추천함

UI,장비 기타 등등 오래된 겜이라 
어딘가 불편하고 장비가 없는게 가장 아쉬웠음
무기는 업글개념이라  바꿔낄수도 없고
장비 능력 그것을 정션에 넣어놨는데 
어느정도 마법 드로 노가다를 하지 않으면 
레벨 관계 없이 
그냥 약한 파티로 힘들게 힘들게 돌파해야됨

간단하게 능력치 요약 
힘=물리공격력,체력=방어력,
마력=마법공격,정신=마법방어력
인것 같고 255에 가까울수록 
최고수준의 공격력,방어력을 얻을수있음 

공략집&위키 등을 찾아보지 않으면 못얻거나 하는게 많음 
난 안보고 그냥 엔딩봄

column8:
I wanted to like this game, I really did. FF7 and 9 are some of my favorite games of all time, so I went into 8 thinking it would also be amazing. It had to be, right? It came out between two other classics I loved, everyone I've talked to has said it's amazing, and I'm also a big fan of the FF8 class that got added into FF14.

But no. This is one of the worst games I have ever played. I was absolutely shocked at how unenjoyable the game was.

I know this is a very subjective statement, but I found every character in the main cast to be a boring cardboard cutout emulation of the archetypes from earlier games. I say this having only completed less than a quarter of the game, but if none of the characters are interesting or likable after [i]10 hours[/i], something is wrong. The story itself was serviceable, but very hard to follow because of how disconnected the world felt - both between regions and individual screens. 
8 is also the first FF game where I [i]needed[/i] to consult walkthroughs to proceed. It's way too challenging to tell where you're supposed to go next and what parts of the environment are interactable. 

The new combat systems, Junction and GF, are extremely confusing and counter intuitive. They feel like systems created for the sake of complexity, while also over simplifying party compositions. You could use materia and skills in 7 and 9 to make characters fill certain roles, but it always felt purposeful, unlike in 8. 
Any character can draw any ability from an enemy, so you can easily make everyone into a jack of all trades with zero downsides. Want someone to be a healer? Just draw some heals and cleanses from enemies. Want them to deal damage? Add some elemental spells. Want them to be a tank? Slot in defensive abilities and GFs alongside your healing and damaging spells. As far as I know, there is zero downside to doing this on every character - besides the time it takes to draw spells.
At least materia took time to level, and you really had to work to get to the point where everyone could simultaneously fill every role. 

The remaster itself is also just ugly. I'm not a big fan of how the original looked either, but this version is just unpleasant to look at a lot of the time. 

If you're a big fan of Final Fantasy then it's probably worth the time and money to try the game just to experience it, but otherwise just don't bother. Go play 7 and 9.

2/10

Just play the original PC port. It looks better even without modding.

column8:
A thumbs up for a game I don't like? What is this madness.

The thing is, Final Fantasy is a series, I get captivated by some games, not others. This one doesn't do it for me, I like VII (obviously because I am not insane), IX is my favourite (obviously because I am insane), but you are investing in a story, quite a long time, and even though IX is probably the worst game of any final fantasy games for the first few hours, I am a fantasy genre nut, and that one is full fantasy genre, and I can easily get through that bit into the game.

This is my 4th failed attempt at VIII, but I can't give it a bad review, as I know my issues here are purely with me not getting into it. Probably because it starts in a school, which I did not enjoy in any way shape or form, so find it hard to invest past an hour or so. The game was designed to give that feel, so in that regard, it is 100% effective, just not something I want to invest in story wise.

But that tells you a lot about final fantasy games, especially as I dont actually like the game play mechanics, way too much faffing about in character screens which I am not keen for with turn based RPGs, I am there for the story, progression, investing into the characters, so I do all that other stuff quite eagerly to get the next part of the story.

But that is the review and why there is a thumbs up for a game I don't like, reviews are for helping other people make a decision to buy something, with Final Fantasy, I would be hugely surprised that given the drastic evolution of gameplay, that you would dislike all of them. But don't give up on the entire series, just because there is one you don't like.

column8:
[h1] 即使全世界都与你为敌,我也会做你的骑士----------------斯考尔 [/h1]

接触的第七款最终幻想。超级无敌牛逼棒的剧情，1999年的游戏居然可以写出如此超前的剧情，在我心目中简直比近年来的游戏的剧情不知道精彩多少倍！相信每一位通关ff8的玩家听见王菲演唱的Eyes On Me都会想起斯考尔和莉诺雅曲折的爱情故事，这是最终幻想第一首由中国人唱的主题曲，感谢植松伸夫，你的音乐总是能让我在游戏中听得入迷！

这一部是动态难度，角色等级越高敌人越强，越难打。千万不要闷头刷怪升级，以为只要不停的练级就能打赢这套传统的思维在这款游戏简直是地狱难度，好好看攻略！

Hysterically enough, I never beat it...Being a kid I would delete my save or overwrite it on the old memory card, cry, and start over. Well, here I am again, 25 years later and it still holds up! I am loving it and remembering all the memories and feeling super nostalgic. Highly recommend to any one who doesn't mind old gameplay graphics, all the while, the cinematic graphics were WAY ahead of their time! Awesome story, great hidden stuff to find and explore, and just overall, a great game. Cheers!

column8:
I've given this a thumbs down however if you, like me, played this when it first came out on PS1 then it is a great nostalgia trip. I played the game from start to finish on Steam Deck and encountered no issues. Overall I had a decent time reliving memories of first playing this but the game doesn't hold up.

As a game, FF8 is one of the weakest in the series. It's Junction system where you assign "Guardian Forces" and Magic ("GFs" - FF8 version of a summon) can be broken so much that it makes the game a cake walk before the end of disc 1 without much work. This remaster has updated a few things, especially the in-game character models but I would have liked to see more polish from a remaster.

Aside from Squall who has become iconic with his cool Gunblade, the other characters fail to make a mark on FF history and are largely forgetful (I had a actually forgotten Irvine was in this when I started my recent playthrough). The romance between Rinoa and Squall feels incredible forced. The story also takes some "convenient" turns that use concepts such as "memory loss" to push the plot along. The big bad in the game is also forgettable and you don't really get much time to understand her reasons or motivations. Gunblade aside, Seifer is also super lame.

Overall, this is still a decent JRPG and isn't the worst FF game, however when put alongside its other PS titles like 7 and 9, it really is a thorn between two roses.

I've recently replayed all of the main Final Fantasy titles for the 100% and have made my way through all of the sequels and prequels except Lightning Returns (which I do intend to play, but not the point), and I have to ask myself -- if I wanted to replay any FF title right now, which would it be?

The answer is undoubtedly Final Fantasy VIII.

[h3]Game Mechanics[/h3]

This game gets a lot of shit, and some of it is justified. The gameplay doesn't come across as intuitive, and the best way to improve your characters in this game is not to fight and engage in random battles like it is for other FF--nay, other JRPG--titles from a similar time frame, but rather to play... Cards?

But that, therein, holds the appeal and value in replayability. The first time I played FFVIII on release for PlayStation, I probably figured out the junction system before the last boss on Disc 1, and that's to say that the game is pretty forgiving if you don't "get it" at first. I probably had no spells junctioned on my characters by that point, only really drew from draw points, and used spells normally. The game still functioned just fine until that Disc 1 boss, and then I had to actually learn the mechanics.

The second time I played, I spent hours drawing from monsters manually and barely touched the card game. My characters still got insanely strong and breezed through.

Playing it again more recently, this game absolutely knew who the boss was (it was me, just to clarify).

Spending hours on cards in the first area, refining random items for stat maxing in optional dungeons, and making sure you don't kill anyone early so that you don't level up normally (using the handy Remaster no random encounters feature makes this way easier) are all ways you can break the ever loving hell out of this game. Is a game really fun if you can't break it? Don't answer that question.

When I think about playing it again, I think about making it as hard as possible: level early, restrict yourself to not playing cards, only junction certain stats, don't junction, etc.,. There are so many ways to play this game, far more ways to play this game, arguably, than any other Final Fantasy title.

I get that the entry level player experience is dautning. I recently watched a friend of mine stream the start of his first blind playthrough, and he closed the game after the first dungeon and resolved to never touch it again because he "didn't want to have to sit through tutorials to know what to do," and I think part of the difficulty of playing FFVIII for the first time in the 2020's comes from the fact that sitting through tutorials is so far from the current expectation of game design. The junction system could have been explained way more intuitively, anyway, and the original writers decided to overload the complexity like a Youtuber making 30 minutes of advanced analogies to media you haven't watched to make himself sound smarter.

But if you skip most of the tutorials and play through the game semi-casually figuring things out, you don't get punished that hard anyway, so the mechanics [i]are[/i] intuitive, actually.

I have way more fun playing FFVIII than running around in circles, fighting random battles and getting an arbitrary quantity of battles fought progression reward to leveling up (which should beg the question, why do I play old JRPGs, but that's for my therapist). I hope Square revives at least some of the elements of VIII's gameplay in future titles (at least give us monsters leveling up as we do again, please).

[h3]Story[/h3]

[b]Warning: Spoilers hidden in spoiler tags. Everything else is fine to read.[/b]

Yes, I am indeed one of those "FFVII's story is unparalleled" snobs, and when I went and replayed VII, I felt the same nuances that I remembered so well and came away satisfied that [i]yes, it is that good[/i]. But VIII hit me unexpectedly. As the ending closed, I actually cried. The resolution and progression made me ask "Is the VII story really that much better?"

Now, there is aplot twist that everyone justifiably complains about. The problem with that plot twist is not the plot twist itself, but that it has no payoff. If it didn't exist, the story is actually better. You don't [i]need[/i] [spoiler]the main cast to not remember growing up together[/spoiler] for the story to have an impact. In fact, imagine how much better the story would be if [spoiler]everyone had the memories from the orphanage in mind and had a built in relationship and dynamic together already. Squall gets nothing from not remembering his abandonment and loner childhood because [i]it already affects his character[/i]. They can still not realize that The Sorceress is Edea because her getup is frankly insane, and they were kids. If only Irvine recognizes her still, I don't think that comes off as implausible[/spoiler].

My frustration with the plot twist comes from the fact that the story could have so many more rich character moments without it, and it has absolutely no meaningful bearing on the plot in any way. [i]But[/i] if you ignore the plot twist, there's so much to meaningfully unpack in FFVIII. There's a reason that players have come up with countless interpretations of the story. So many hints exist that invite you to engage with the on a personal level, and struggling with human connection at its core should be an engaging and relatable subject matter for most people.

I could talk about the nuances of this story for many hours, and yes, it does [i]not[/i] have the best story in in the Final Fantasy franchise, but I was surprised that, by the end of my playthrough, I had it in my top three.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]

When VIII came out in 1998, it was very easy to be cool and say that the game was too confusing, the plot was too stupid. But having recently replayed every main FF title to 100% completion, I would play VIII again right now tomorrow (but I still have to play Lightning Returns), and I can't say that as easily about the others. Part of that could come from the impressions I had of it the first time contrasted with the impressions I had of it the most recent time I played it, but I already considered VIII pretty underrated when I went into it for the third time. Perhaps I also just like being the snob who said "Oh, well, actually, when you figure out the junction system it's really"--[i]pushes up glasses[/i]--"quite sophisticated and rewarding." 

Or maybe I just like media that requires you to immerse yourself, that wants you to come away with a feeling of "I definitely missed something, I'm going to go back and play it again." 

If you play VIII once, it's fine if you hate it. But if you play it a second time, you won't regret it.

column8:
I played the original back on PS1 and wanted to play again on PC. This game comes with three boosters ATB/Limit/HP Assist for battles, encounter none (which functions the same as diablos), and triple speed. I enjoyed playing through this game and experiencing the story again, but there are a few caveats you should know before purchasing:
- They really only updated the graphics (such as character models) to make the game look nicer
- There doesn't seem to be wide screen support so I played the whole game in 4:3
- It seems to be missing features exclusive to the JP PS1 version, but tries to make up for it via angelo search.
Other than these three things if you're looking to experience for the first time or want to play it again, this may be the best way to play it. This is among my favorite FF games, so I am a little biased giving it a thumbs up.

column8:
The game itself is ok. I only recommend this if you are already a fan of this series and you just want to experience this. It helps that the game is dirt cheap.

The story is maybe one of the more ridiculous in the series. Don't want to spoil anything.

The combat system is weird and probably the worst part of the game. Leveling is discouraged because the enemies sale with the player level. the draw system is cool, but also dog shit. It's cool that you can draw magic from enemies and use this to buff your stats, but the downside is that the stat boost is scaled to the number of magics you have. This means that casting any spell that is also attached to your stat is discouraged because this will decrease your stats and you'll have to find an enemy to draw more from (or craft) to replace the missing inventory.

The best part of the game is the mini card game Triple Triad. It's a really fun and simple card game that requires some strategy.

This "remaster" is barely a remaster. The character models look like they were given more polys and AI scaled textures. The backgrounds are just as pixelated as they were when this game came out. The only plus side is the ability to speed up time, avoid all encounters, and invincibility (kinda) features you can toggle.

column8: ok

Final Fantasy VIII occupies a peculiar space within the iconic franchise, often eliciting mixed reactions from fans and critics alike. Released in 1999, the game made significant strides in terms of graphics and storytelling but stumbled in several key areas that have left players divided.

One of the most polarizing aspects of FFVIII is its junction system. While innovative, allowing players to customize characters' abilities and stats by "junctioning" magic to them, it can also feel overly complex and unintuitive. The necessity of drawing spells from enemies to stockpile magic can become tedious and disrupt the flow of the game.

The story, centered around Squall Leonhart and his companions, has moments of brilliance but often suffers from uneven pacing and underdeveloped characters. The romance between Squall and Rinoa is central to the narrative, but it can feel forced and lacking in chemistry, leaving some players disengaged.

Graphically, FFVIII was a marvel for its time, with beautifully rendered cutscenes and detailed character models that pushed the original PlayStation to its limits. However, these visual achievements are sometimes undermined by the inconsistent art style and awkward character animations during gameplay.

Then there's Triple Triad, the in-game card mini-game that has gained a cult following. Its appeal is heavily subjective; for newcomers, it may seem like a distraction from the main story, with complex rules and a steep learning curve. However, for those who have experienced and grown to love Triple Triad through its resurgence in Final Fantasy XIV, the mini-game becomes a nostalgic and enjoyable diversion. It’s one of those elements that truly shines only if you’ve already built an appreciation for it through another entry in the series.

Final Fantasy VIII is neither a triumph nor a failure but rather a mixed bag that offers a unique experience within the franchise. Its ambitious systems and emotional highs are often balanced by its convoluted mechanics and narrative missteps. For every player who adores it, there’s another who finds it frustratingly flawed. Whether it's a hidden gem or a missed opportunity depends largely on individual player perspective and expectations.

I've never found it so painful to play a Final Fantasy game as this one. Initially, the game is impressive. We're shown a lot of directed moments, spectacular cutscenes, and the combat system initially seems interesting.

But after a few hours, you realize that Final Fantasy 8 is not a good game. And all the positives of this game, however significant they may seem, are overshadowed by its shortcomings:

The battles themselves are very sloooooooow because the combat system is based on summoning summons, and each of their attacks takes about 20-30 seconds to play out. This also applies to regular attacks. Maybe it was impressive in 1999, but today, without 3x speed, it's impossible to play.

The role-playing system is broken. Firstly, the game features auto-leveling, which makes leveling up pointless, but you'll still have to grind due to the magic system. Every spell in the game is a consumable that you draw from enemies. Before any tough storyline moment, you'll have to grind to max out spells for your characters.

The plot is rather silly, especially after Final Fantasy 7. It has a lot of deus ex machina moments and unremarkable characters. And Squall, as the main character, is downright annoying most of the time.

The only merit of this game is the Triple Triad card mini-game; it doesn't get boring, and collecting cards is interesting.

A few words about the remaster: it's pretty bad. All they did was add cheats to simplify the game and improve the character models. Instead of replacing or upscaling the game's backgrounds, they just applied a blurry filter, which looks awful.

When getting acquainted with the Final Fantasy series, you can easily skip this part and you won't miss anything
column9:
I've never found it so painful to play a Final Fantasy game as this one. Initially, the game is impressive. We're shown a lot of directed moments, spectacular cutscenes, and the combat system initially seems interesting.

But after a few hours, you realize that Final Fantasy 8 is not a good game. And all the positives of this game, however significant they may seem, are overshadowed by its shortcomings:

The battles themselves are very sloooooooow because the combat system is based on summoning summons, and each of their attacks takes about 20-30 seconds to play out. This also applies to regular attacks. Maybe it was impressive in 1999, but today, without 3x speed, it's impossible to play.

The role-playing system is broken. Firstly, the game features auto-leveling, which makes leveling up pointless, but you'll still have to grind due to the magic system. Every spell in the game is a consumable that you draw from enemies. Before any tough storyline moment, you'll have to grind to max out spells for your characters.

The plot is rather silly, especially after Final Fantasy 7. It has a lot of deus ex machina moments and unremarkable characters. And Squall, as the main character, is downright annoying most of the time.

The only merit of this game is the Triple Triad card mini-game; it doesn't get boring, and collecting cards is interesting.

A few words about the remaster: it's pretty bad. All they did was add cheats to simplify the game and improve the character models. Instead of replacing or upscaling the game's backgrounds, they just applied a blurry filter, which looks awful.

When getting acquainted with the Final Fantasy series, you can easily skip this part and you won't miss anything

리마스터의 최고 의의는 드디어 한글화 패치가 나오게 되었다는 것 그것도 높은 퀄리티로 만들어져서 놀라웠다. 한글화를 해주신 분들에게 감사드립니다.

1. 정션 시스템이 일견 어려워 보이지만 소환수가 스텟슬롯이며 거기에 마법이라는 아이템을 장비한다고 생각하면 쉽다. 리마스터 지원중에 인카운터 없음, 3배속을 이용하면 쾌적하게 저레벨 플레이가 가능하다. 저레벨 플레이의 이유는 저레벨로 플레이 하면서 정션만을 취할경우 적에 비해 스텟이득을 많이 누릴 수 있기 때문. 알테마웨폰도 저레벨 플레이어에겐 얄짤없다. 그렇다고 별의별 마법을 드로우하고 다녀야 하냐고 하면 그것도 아니다. 적당히 쓸만한 마법만 드로우 하고 다녀도 된다. 어차피 초중반에 넣을 스탯이 그다지 많지 않다. 더 설명충 빙의하고 싶지만, 공략본 찾으면 금방 나오니까 부담없이 플레이 해도 된다. 정션과 레밸개념에 대해 이해가 빠르면 시리즈 증 가장 쉬운 난이도를 가지고 있다. 

2. 저레벨 플레이시 카드게임이 반드시 언급되지만 그냥 레어카드만 수집하고 다녀도 된다. 막 상상이상의 과한 노가다를 요구하진 않지만 이데아나 특정 인물은 좀 난이도가 높은 편이긴 하다. 어느정도 레어카드를 수집하면 몬스터 카드들은 그때그때 갈아버려도 충분하다. 레어 아이템은 어차피 레벨업 레벨다운 어빌리티로 몬스터를 조절할 수 있으며 바하무트도 있기 때문에 바하무트 에덴을 수집하고 최종무기 노가다를 해도 늦지않다. 그래도 마을의 5000길로 알테마 드로우할 수 있는 시점부턴 알테마를 꾸준히 드로우 하는 걸 추천한다.

3. 요약하자면 정션이라는 시스템 때문에 거부감이 심하고 호불호가 강하지만 그만큼 이해하고 익숙해지면 시리즈 중 가장 쉬운 게임이다. 도전과제 100퍼도 1000마리 잡기가 제일 빡세다고 느낄정도. 그나마 3배속이 있기 망정이지

근데 난 왜 어릴때 얼티미시아 잡기가 그렇게 어려웠을까... 몇시간동안이나 트라이 했던 거 같은데

column8:
I've tried playing through this game multiple times but moved on to something else because of how weird the core gameplay is compared to other titles. While I don't think its as good as FFI, III, IV, V, VI, and VII as well as IX and X, it wasn't nearly as bad as I thought.

Basically you have to obtain magic spells. Whether you choose to play Triple Triad, draw spells from enemies, or refine magic through GF abilities, the point is the more spells you have stocked the better your stats will be once you junction your spells to them. The whole meta of this game is just obtaining spells and linking them to your stats to stand a chance against a boss. Another thing is that every enemy (with a few end game exceptions) scale with your level. The only reason why you would want to level grind is if you want to farm a specific enemy drop or draw a specific spell that only happens when they're at a certain level.

So no, you cannot play FFVIII like a JRPG that you're used to. Even if you enable cheats and try to God mode your way through, the 4th disc will punish you hard if you don't have any spells junctioned. You have to love the junctioning, hold the junctioning, take care of the junctioning, forfeit all your mortal possessions to the junctioning. Seriously. I had no idea how ill-prepared I was for Sorceress Adell, the final dungeon, and Ultimecia due to all the weaponized Autism they put me through. So if there's any tips I can give:

Make Multiple saves. Like between 10-20 across different save files.
Once you get to the third disc, just spend a session walking across the world map and draw magic from every enemy you find.
Do as many optional side quests as you can because once you fly your ship into the final area there's no going back.

The story is about a teenager named Squall, who's forced into a position of power that he never asked for, perpetuating a conflict that he doesn't actually care about, and has to tard wrangle a bunch of teamates who are all about as deep as a ballpit inside a Chuckie Cheeses. I know some people think Squall is just a 3edgy5me stereotype but I disagree. We've all felt like Squall at some point in our lives and I can't help but sympathize with him. Quistis is a slut, Rinoa is a slut, Irvine is just a pretty boy for the chicks to ogle at, Selphie is an idiot, Zell is Scrappy Doo, and Seifer is a jerkass for the sake of being a jerkass.

Overall though, the whole ff8 experience isn't nearly as bad as I thought it was going to be. 

It's like the JRPG equivalent of eating at a greasy restaurant in Ohio. It was tolerable in some aspects, horrible in others, and I wouldn't really want to experience it again.

As far as technical issues like crashing or bugs go, I never ran into anything so if you want to play FF8 on Steam this is the version to get since it has better character models and higher quality music.

Played the original in 1999 when it released. Was quite disappointed with it back then and considered it to be mediocre compared to the others entries in the series (specifically I, IV, VI, and VII, which were the publicly available ones in the USA at the time). 

The characters ranged from forgettable to unlikable. The plot was convoluted and poorly paced and poorly explained. The graphics were an eyesore (the PS1 couldn't handle the art direction they were going for) and I hated the junction system... On the positive side of things, I remembered the sound design was fantastic (as Final Fantasy games always are) and the setting was at least an interesting one. I found the flash-back stories of Laguna and co. to be intriguing... The FMVs were fantastic, and combining cut-scenes with gameplay was mind-blowing for the time. The svelte amount of time I spent engaging with the primary mini-game distraction - Triple Triad -  was enjoyable (I recently had started playing a relatively new game, "Magic: The Gathering" - you may have heard of it - just a few years prior). All-in-all, it was generally a let-down in my mind and I held a negative opinion of it over the decades.

Fast forward to 2024 and I finally give this game another chance with the 2013 Remastered version... Long story short, my complaints with the game are mostly still valid as I remember and the remaster job was very sloppy (even by the low standards of Sqeenix). However, doing a LLG (low-level game) and learning the junction system in far greater depth than my first playthrough, I came to enjoy it far more than in 1999. Its still a flawed system, but there is depth and fun to be had if you can approach it with the right mindset. 

I still don't like the characters (especially that annoying piece of furniture, Selphie... fight me). BUT, after reading opposing opinions and watching a couple retrospectives and opinions on YouTube, I can better appreciate what the developers were *trying* to achieve, and can take into consideration that some parts of the English translation were botched. Something that SHOULD HAVE be corrected in the 2013 version, but I digress...

This review could go on and on for a while longer, but I'll cut it short with a TL;DR:

Final Fantasy VIII is - to me - one of the weaker entries in the series. However, it is better than I remember it being. I can now better appreciate its highs and am somewhat less bothered by its lows. It had the potential to be another great, but some questionable decisions hold back its potential. Its well known amungst long-time Final Fantasy fans that VIII is a "you love it or you hate it" entry. I used to be part of the "I hate it" camp, but now, I would say I'm part of the less common, "mixed feelings" camp. 

Normally, I would have given this game a - just barely - thumbs up vote. However, due to the sloppy nature of this poorly done port, my review is going to be a thumbs down. If you enjoy the series and have never played FFVIII you still might want to pick it up. Just moderate your expectations, learn about the junction system (and the Queen of Cards non-sense when it comes to Triple Triad rules) *before* you start playing. Finally, if you are intending on grabbing this title, wait for a sale. They discount this and other FF titles at 50% off every few months.

... Thanks for reading and have a pleasant day.

On the positive side of things, I remembered the sound design was fantastic (as Final Fantasy games always are) and the setting was at least an interesting one. I found the flash-back stories of Laguna and co. to be intriguing... The FMVs were fantastic, and combining cut-scenes with gameplay was mind-blowing for the time. The svelte amount of time I spent engaging with the primary mini-game distraction - Triple Triad -  was enjoyable (I recently had started playing a relatively new game, "Magic: The Gathering" - you may have heard of it - just a few years prior). All-in-all, it was generally a let-down in my mind and I held a negative opinion of it over the decades.

Fast forward to 2024 and I finally give this game another chance with the 2013 Remastered version... Long story short, my complaints with the game are mostly still valid as I remember and the remaster job was very sloppy (even by the low standards of Sqeenix). However, doing a LLG (low-level game) and learning the junction system in far greater depth than my first playthrough, I came to enjoy it far more than in 1999. Its still a flawed system, but there is depth and fun to be had if you can approach it with the right mindset. 

I still don't like the characters (especially that annoying piece of furniture, Selphie... fight me). BUT, after reading opposing opinions and watching a couple retrospectives and opinions on YouTube, I can better appreciate what the developers were *trying* to achieve, and can take into consideration that some parts of the English translation were botched. Something that SHOULD HAVE be corrected in the 2013 version, but I digress...

This review could go on and on for a while longer, but I'll cut it short with a TL;DR:

Final Fantasy VIII is - to me - one of the weaker entries in the series. However, it is better than I remember it being. I can now better appreciate its highs and am somewhat less bothered by its lows. It had the potential to be another great, but some questionable decisions hold back its potential. Its well known amungst long-time Final Fantasy fans that VIII is a "you love it or you hate it" entry. I used to be part of the "I hate it" camp, but now, I would say I'm part of the less common, "mixed feelings" camp. 

Normally, I would have given this game a - just barely - thumbs up vote. However, due to the sloppy nature of this poorly done port, my review is going to be a thumbs down. If you enjoy the series and have never played FFVIII you still might want to pick it up. Just moderate your expectations, learn about the junction system (and the Queen of Cards non-sense when it comes to Triple Triad rules) *before* you start playing. Finally, if you are intending on grabbing this title, wait for a sale. They discount this and other FF titles at 50% off every few months.

... Thanks for reading and have a pleasant day.

玩家扮演的主角スコール，在garden成長
而garden是把學生培養成職業傭兵seed為目標的學校
這些16、7、8歲的少年少女們，雖然成為了職業傭兵，擁有了左右世界的實力
卻對這個世界懵懂無知，在一次次的任務途中，慢慢發現了世界的異樣之處
也慢慢學會了與人交往，表達自己情感的方式

玩完現在回顧整段劇情，我比我想像中的還喜歡這段故事
スコール從小時候和親(近的)人離異，變得不喜歡與人深交，最後慢慢打開心房
リノア算是大小姐家庭長大，空有熱情想改變世界，卻不知道實際該如何行動，最後學會了妥協
角色間的成長，絕對是我選擇玩RPG遊戲最大的理由

會影響人生最重要的青少年時期，難怪還是有很大部分RPG遊戲會選擇它作為主軸的理由
因為你最容易感受到角色們的成長

Just play the original port with mods, this version is missing Chocobo World, and also doesn't even have stretch widescreen support, much less actual widescreen support. The port is similarly trash, but only mildly less so. Supposedly you can even import saves, but what's the point when you can just play a version that can be modded to look even better?

With the Tonberry mod loader and the list of mods on PCGamingWiki, the original version, modded, actually looks better than this remaster. It's not as night and day as, say, Moguri Mod, but it's a huge step up from the original visuals.

Apparently this version is much harder to mod in general, so even if you're just interested in gameplay mods, it's the worse deal.

Also, needing to tediously use Angelo Search for the Chocobo World items is a pretty big downgrade over actually being able to play the minigame like in the original port. It's still on Steam, it's literally cheaper, just buy that instead. It's still a trash port but it's not much worse than this one.

神作无疑。在这之前也玩过一些号称“神作”的老游戏，平心而论，如果我是在它们刚发售的年代玩到它们，那大概我确实是会惊为天人。但如果是在今天玩到它们，我还是会觉得不过尔尔。时代在变迁，游戏在进步，好的创意会不断完善，好的点子会被滥用。老游戏毕竟是老游戏，光是克服那些现在早就已被抛弃的糟粕已经需要很大勇气了，还要忍受低质量的建模，受限的表现力和剧情表达，现代的玩家已经很难接受了。但FF8R说实话真的颠覆我的认知。这款只是接受了建模材质高清化（说实话也不怎么高清，傻逼SE）的游戏已经是25年前的老东西了，但设计、玩法、设定、剧情个人依然感觉十分超前，超前到哪怕我十年前玩到都觉得超前，现在玩着都不觉得过时，甚至能吊打现在90%以上的jrpg。

另外别等SE汉化了，等SE汉化都不如等FF8真 · 重制。B站搜传成君，可以找到FF8 RE高清计划，不仅有汉化，还有音乐替换、高清增强、金手指等一系列优化，就算SE真的良心发现整了汉化恐怕都没这个香，想玩FF8R的现在就可以入手了！

column8:
Bad review is for a bad remaster. The game itself? Eeeeeeeeh-

Final fantasy 8 is one of the most confusing things i have ever experienced. The writing is... good, actually. Id say its even great but the storyTELLING? Horrible. I had to stop what i was doing and google what the hell was happening a handful of times and all i found was tons of other people just... lost. The game spends a lot of time focusing on things it really doesnt need to while letting the important stuff on the side which really does hurt a blind playthrough. Story wise its a good story, i like Squal, Renoa and especially Laguna but christ almighty if they made a few of the important bits more obvious or not hidden in some random houses' notes it would really improve on the game. I dont wanna compare this to FF7 as thats a thing way too many people do, but FF7 built up its story block by block and it made a lot more sense while still having mysteries. At times it feels like FF8 does that but backwards, where you got this "Aha!" at the last tenth of the game but throughout it (and the large majority of the time you spend ACTUALLY playing the game) you are just confused and frustrated. Disc 1 and 2 were actually... fine.... ish. But 3? 3 just started going insane in ways that... arent that fun to play through. 1 really felt fine and kinda grounded but it really feels like throughout the development of the discs that 3 was the time the developers were going mad and writing messages on the walls in their blood

The gameplay is... fine. Its a step down from previous systems but i do like the concept of Junctioning. Not much else to say here honestly, its just a "fine" gameplay experience. Junction did not have to be so weirdly explained as honestly it does end up being very simple to use, levels being basically useless was a bit weird, GF's being easily missable at times was also a bit... weird but oh well. The upgrade and gear system is also... odd. Often FF8 seems to just be different to... be different. For example, why are rentable cars a thing? Like they hardly do anything. Why do party members have such tiny differences between eachother so you just "pick what you want" and still swaps them around the entire game meaning you gotta rejunction everyone every 5 minutes. Why in the love of god do animations stop the ATB? FF7 had this figured out and it feels the only reason are longer animations and Squal having to time his auto attack which just... would be really easy to fix conceptwise. The game feels WAY less fluid and more blocky then previous systems. If youre gonna go ATB, go ATB, not inbetween. Its just... frustrating at times. With its meh pacing and storytelling the game also throws in weirdly timed minigames and puzzles at really... weird and unfitting times. Like when ((spoiler for disc 3 second half)) you get to the Ragnarok and have to kill those monsters in a special order its a cool idea... but at that point im just wondering "wait wtf is this Lunar Cry, why wasnt it mentioned before?" "Wait how the hell did Renoa survive?" "Why is there this spaceship randomly in space?" "WHO THE FUCK JUNCTIONED MY IFRIT" (because again it forces you into a specific party which means having to swap around junctions...) When good, its really fun and works but when bad? ...ugh.

OST was a banger, as always, a few tracks were overplayed imo but besides that all gucci

Not too much else to talk about so if i had to rate it out of ten? 7.1 honestly. It has its good parts and those are genuinely cool and sick but you need some ENDURANCE to deal with this games bs at times.

Final Fantasy 8 is a serious exercise in tedium. Definitely the black sheep of the PS1 era of FFs. The story is full of contrivances albeit with some likeable characters. Gameplay is mind numbing. Either you're spending hours grinding magic draws for junctioning to then one-shot everything, or you're struggling through thanks to he unique levelling system for enemies. It just doesn't work in my opinion. Play VII or IX to scratch the itch instead.

column8:
Quel plaisir de pouvoir rejouer à l'un de mes jeux de mon enfance mais en remasterisé. Etant enfant, FF8 était mon FF préféré, j'ai adoré le 7 mais le 8 était mon préféré et encore aujourd'hui j'ai toujours des bons souvenir de ce jeu. Est ce que c'est la nostalgie qui parle ? Possible. Mais en redécouvrant ce jeu je me rend compte que j'aime encore plus ce jeu car là je peux le comprendre avec mon point de vue adulte. Ce FF était bien plus sérieux que les précédent même si parfois des répliques nous amuse. 
Il est vrai que quand on parle de FF, souvent on parlent de l'excellent FF7 mais perso pour avoir refait le FF7 original et ce FF8 c'est bien ce dernier qui m'a le plus marqué :D . 
Après le Remaster reste léger, il est un peu cher pour le peu de lissage que le jeu à eu. J'ai l'impression que le côté Remaster était que pour les personnages car le fond semble exactement le même. Pour moi un Remaster comme ça devrait coûté pas plus de 15 euro et encore. 
En conclusion le remaster est léger mais le jeu en lui même est une pépite :) .

Final Fantasy VIII è un capolavoro.
La storia è bella e profonda.
Le musiche stupende.
Il sistema di combattimento a turni vecchio stile fantastico (peccato non lo utilizzino più)
Trovo interessante anche il sistema junction, nonostante possa essere difficile all'inizio.
Il gioco di carte è un piacevole passatempo (ma mai mischiare le regole! :P (o quasi mai))

Perché allora il pollice verso? 
Ho messo a malincuore il pollice verso unicamente per protesta per l'edizione remastered qui su steam che trovo una presa in giro.

Di rimasterizzato ci sono solo i modelli poligonali dei personaggi e dei nemici.
Tutti quei bellissimi fondali in 2d non sono stati ritoccati.
Di conseguenza si vedranno dei bellissimi personaggi camminare su dei paesaggi in bassissima risoluzione.
I personaggi risultano essere totalmente incoerenti con i paesaggi.

Il 16:9?
Nemmeno per sogno. Il gioco è una specie di 4:3, ma con due micro bande nere sopra e sotto.
I combattimenti invece sono sempre 4:3, ma con due bande nere un pelino più grandi
I filmati, a parte il finale in 16:9, sono in 4:3, ma sono encodati malissimo!
Hanno una qualità visiva pessima con quadretti visibilissimi causati dall'eccessiva compressione.

Non è presente la vibrazione, funzione importantissima per le limit break.

Il gioco è bloccato a 30 fps nelle mappe e 15 fps nei combattimenti.
C'è pure un launcher che è SEMPRE una pessima cosa.

Inoltre alla square enix hanno pensato di inserire dei cheat per avere tutti gli oggetti, magie, limit, carte, HP al massimo etc.
Cheat che da fan delle serie trovo offensivi.
"basta non usarli" direte voi. E' vero, ma invece di dedicare tempo nella programmazione di questi cheat si poteva dedicare più tempo a fare un'edizione presentabile.

Invece perdono tempo in queste cose, e nel ridisegnare l'evocazione della G.F. di Siren, che in questa edizione è censurata.

Il gioco a volte si blocca anche al cambio schermata, soprattutto con il 3x attivo (sembra perché il gioco va in conflitto con onedrive)

Come sempre gruppi amatoriali hanno migliorato il gioco realizzando dei nuovi modelli ed addirittura dei fondali ad alta qualità. (cercate "qhimm lunatic pandora")
Se dei gruppi amatoriali sono riusciti ad avere dei buoni risultati sorprende che alla square enix non riescano a fare più di questo additando la colpa alla perdita del codice sorgente.

Tuttavia rimane Final Fantasy VIII.
E tutti i Final Fantasy prima del X sono sinonimo di capolavoro e vale la pena di giocarlo.
Pas de widescreen, je vais plutôt prendre l'original avec des mods

FF8 is an all time great. A great story, tons of great locations, top tier cinematics (for its time). A fantastic soundtrack. FF7, FF8 and FF9 are all pretty much interchangeable as the best FF game for me. 

I am overall disappointed with this remaster. I felt that Square was incredibly lazy here. I like what they did with the menu and character models - they just spruced them up. However, leaving everything else untouched was an awful, lazy mistake. Sure there are some mods that help a little but it just seems so dated trying to play this game now. The FPS is rough too. FF7 had mods to fix everything that felt dated, this game doesnt. Again it has some mods, but not nearly enough. 

Again, FF8 is a fantastic game, i just again wish Square wouldnt have been so dang lazy on the remaster. I made it about 4 hours in and im giving up. Its just too dated looking and them calling it a remaster is robbery.

column8:
Just finished the game today and I have to say, this game was very great and very unique 
as an experience. FF8 had a very rich cast of characters, and the story was very interesting even though it was confusing at certain points. The gameplay gets some time to getting used to but once you fully get to grasp the junction system it becomes amazing, as I've never experienced a JRPG with a more customizable system than FF8's. 

Some critiques I have to give though is not the game, but how the remaster itself was handled. While I think the player and enemy models look incredible, for a remaster, the backgrounds look muddy and leave a lot to be desired. 

My only critique for the gameplay itself is that the junction stats you've assigned discourage you to use the magic you've junctioned, as it'll alter your stats negatively.

Finally, do I recommend Final Fantasy VIII Remastered? Absolutely if you're a fan of JRPGs and especially if you're interested in the Final Fantasy franchise. People often critique this game unrighteously because it handles gameplay and story settings differently, but I believe this game stands out as one of the franchise's greatest and one of the most unique experiences a JRPG can offer.

People often critique this game unrighteously because it handles gameplay and story settings differently, but I believe this game stands out as one of the franchise's greatest and one of the most unique experiences a JRPG can offer.

column8:
TL;DR: This is the worst Final Fantasy game by far, please do not play this game.

Let's start with the positive:
+ Musics are great and enjoyable
+ Some FMVs and Videos are great to watch
+ Triad game is nice

That's it. Now, the negative:
- This port is a shame. It's 30fps, 15fps during fights, it's laggy, the only thing they've changed are the models of the main characters, and even at that they did a bad job. You're better off with the original game and a couple mods.
- Characters are not charismatic, they are the exact persona of all the cliché you could have back in that time (dark and solitary main character, sweet and foolish lover, fighter without a brain... those personas)
- The interface sxcks, really. It's bloated with menus, not easy to understand at all, with a lot of submenus hidden a bit everywhere
- ATB is even worse than before
- Limit Breaks are hidden now, like you don't have a clear view of when you'll have it
- Spells system is the worst. You either steal a spell from a monster or randomly find it on the map somewhere. That's bad.
- Invocation system is meh, you assign an invocation to someone and can use it during a fight, and this invocation can level-up and learn new passive or active abilities. That's okay I guess ?
- Equipment does not exist. The only thing you can do is: find magazines that'll tell you what components you need to reforge your weapon and thus increase its damage. You want to increase your stats ? Then you need to increase your affinity with GForces (the invocations) and assign some passives to your characters. No equipment, no accessory, nothing.
- The overworld map is awful. At first it felt good because for the first time you could see movable stuff on the overworld, but yeah nah, it's just a randomly animated train that goes from one town to the other and that's it. Other than that, the overworld is empty and too big for no reason at all. There's only a handful towns/cities, and they're spread for no reason.
- And the different screens you'll wander around are so, so bloated with useless details, you sometimes miss an exit or a door, or even an usable piece of equipment.
- And finally, the story is really bad. I won't spoil anything here, but it is really, really bad, and it does not make sense up until the very end, and EVEN THEN you're left with questions, and not the kind of questions you're happy to have at the end of a game.

I'll stop here because I've got so, so much to say about this game, and it's almost all bad. I've 100% this video game after ~30hrs of gameplay (using the x3 speed boost), and I've enjoyed it only when I was playing cards (Triad game) and at the very end watching the cinematic during the credits (I'm not even joking, the cinematic is really good). Other than that, I had an awful time.

I'm glad people consider this game a masterpiece and has great memories with it, I mean it, but it's not my case sadly. And I wanted to like this game so, so much, after hearing so many good things about Squall and the Gunblade and the SeeD and whatnot, but unfortunately, I cannot recommend this game to anyone.

column8:
My playthrough in 2024 is the first time that I've ever played FF8 in any way. I heard nothing but negative things about this game before I started playing it and they were all true. I had the entire plot explained to me by the amazing, beautiful and wonderful [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4nPOCkD32HM] EmptyHero [/url] and still don't really understand what happens in this game, who it's happening to or why any of it is happening. I criticized FF7 for taking the FF storyline into a weird direction but FF8 is just weird.

The gameplay is unbelievably slow and grueling. There was no way I would've been able to play through this game without the 3x game speed and no-encounter features of the remake. The remake was really well done, the game looks great for what it is and there's a lot of extra features that gives the player the ability to play the game how they want, however, that wasn't enough to make this game tolerable. I honestly think this game is less refined than FF7 and while I like the idea of the Junction/Magic system, it's too weird and complicated to be the main stat system in the game IMO. I love how exploitable it is because I love cheese in RPGs but it kind of trivializes the game.

Overall, I hate this game and really want to give it a negative review, but I'll treat this review as a review for the actual Steam product and not the 20yr video game and give it a positive review because I think the remake was well-done and both wish more games could've gotten this treatment and wonder why FF7 couldn't have gotten this treatment instead of taking 20 years to make a 3-part cinematic alternate-hybrid timeline.

The cheese this time around are the Junction and Ability Systems. I didn't mess with them too much but I looked up how crazy low-level runs are and had to use some of those tactics when I got stuck on hard fights. It took me back to FF2's stat system which I loved exploiting.

In Balamb Garden, where students train,
Zell's hunger is legendary, driving him insane.
Hot dogs, his obsession, his love and his bane,
Eating them fast, like a high-speed train.

In the cafeteria, he's always first in line,
His appetite voracious, nothing can confine.
But when it comes to cooking, oh what a sight,
Burnt toast and charred dishes, his culinary plight.

So here's to Zell, the martial arts ace,
With a hunger for hot dogs and a goofy face.
In Final Fantasy VIII, he'll make you grin,
With his antics and punches, he's bound to win!

The impossible follow up to an all time classic. There's a lot to like about Final Fantasy VIII, the music, character designs, setting, and unique combat system are all top notch. The way the game presents some of these different ideas are stilted and unengaging compared to the more straight forward previous titles. Playing the game today with a save editor and starter set of magic already drawn is a great way to enjoy the game without wasting time drawing magic/refining items. If you like Final Fantasy as a series, this game will most likely deliver on much of what you like about the series.
