Classic game that brings back old joy from childhood.

[h1]完璧ではないが、懐かしむには十分[/h1]

FF8って、偉大なFF7と原点回帰のFF9の間に挟まれていることもあって、
PS時代のファイナルファンタジーの中でも軽く見られがちな不遇な子なんですよ。
たぶん、主題歌の「Eyes On Me」や「[b]だったら壁とでも話してろよ[/b]」は知っている、くらいの方が多いのではないでしょうか。

でも私はFF8が大好きです。
[b]"美麗なプリレンダムービーの中でキャラを操作する"という衝撃[/b]、
[b](今の時代の方が寧ろ刺さりそうな程に)等身大に描かれたキャラクターたち[/b]、
[b]名も無いガーデン生や住人たちに用意された、世界観を補強するミニイベントの数々[/b]、
[b]ジャンクションとG.F.という、FFの中でも特異ながら世界観とゲーム性を両立したシステム[/b]、
[b]ゲーム開始時から縛りプレイやゲームバランス破壊などが可能と、様々な遊び方に対する懐の深さ[/b]etc...
全部好きです。


さて、そんなFF8を現行ハードとPCにリマスター移植したのが本作です。
3Dで描画されているキャラやオブジェクトが新規&高画質化して美麗になったり、
かつてのfor PC版と違ってMIDI音源ではなくオリジナル音源を搭載したり、
倍速モードやチート機能など、ゲームをスムーズにプレイする為の補助機能も導入されました。
んが…。
[h3]全体の完成度はそこそこです。[/h3]

誤解のないよう補足すると、プレイ自体は最後まで問題無くできました。
私はリマスター版リリース当時はSwitch版をプレイしており、このSteam版も紆余曲折あったようですが現在は同等であると感じます。
通常プレイ一周と実績解除用の常時倍速プレイだった二周目ともパフォーマンス低下やクラッシュには遭遇しませんでした。

ただリマスター版全体の問題として、一部オリジナルを再現できてない部分があり、しかもそれが2024年現在も放置されているのです。
ゲーム進行に直接影響がある部分ではないのですが、気になる人は永遠に気になる部分でもあり…。

とまあ多少の問題は抱えていますが、
令和の時代に「FINAL FANTASY VIII」をプレイする環境としてはこのHD版がオススメです。
(いやまあ、オリジナル版を遊ぶ環境はもうほぼ無いんですけどね)

とはいえパーフェクトな出来ではないので、許されるのであればちゃんと修正をかけてからプロジェクトを閉じて頂きたいものです。
スクエニも自社の看板IPに対してはもっと目を光らせて欲しい。協業する相手はよく選んでくれー！
[b]DOTEMU(開発)、もうやる気はないのか？ こんど会ったら……仕返ししてやる……[/b]


以下、
「[b]これから初めてFF8をプレイする方向けのネタバレなし情報[/b]」と、
「[b]HDリマスター固有の利点/問題点のネタバレあり詳細レビュー[/b]」です。

[hr][/hr]

[h1]これから初めてFF8をプレイする方へ(ネタバレなし)[/h1]

[h2]今更初めてFF8をプレイして楽しめるのか[/h2]
これに関して言えばどちらとも言えないかなー…というところです。
FF14からFF8に興味を持ってくれたヒカセンなどには是非プレイしていただきたいですが、
いかんせん25年前…1999年に発売された当時ほぼそのままなので、合う人合わない人は出てくるかと思います。

キャラクター描写には実在感があり感情移入もし易い類だと感じていますし、
前述のとおり、むしろ今の時勢の方がFF8(というより初期のスコールやリノアたち)に対する解像度を高くできるのではないかとすら思います。
サウンドは内蔵音源の時代の産物なので流石に古臭さはあるかとは思いますが、シンセ全開な"らしい"植松サウンドをこれでもかと堪能できますよ。

一方でゲームプレイの方は当然とはいえ現代のそれと比べて導線が不足しています。
それはG.F.(召喚獣)の入手であったり、アイテムだったり、イベントであったりと多岐にわたり、
当時の他のRPGと比べても[u]何かを取りこぼす可能性が常にどこかしらにあるゲーム[/u]と言っても過言ではないかもしれません。

また私自身、本作の魅力を早々に感じられるとは思っていなくて、
繰り返し遊んでキャラクターやストーリー、独自性の強いシステムやコンテンツの味を理解してからが本番な気がします。
この"[u]面白いと感じるまでの時間が遅い(かもしれない)[/u]"というのは現代のゲーム基準では致命的な気がしていて、人によっては堪えるかもしれません。
RPGということもあり腰を据えてじっくり遊ぶ時間を作った上でのプレイをオススメしたいですね。


[h2]FF8を楽しむ上でのコツは？[/h2]
ネタバレになるので多くは語りませんがとりあえず2つだけ。
「[b]ボス戦で一度はドローを試すクセをつける[/b]」
「[b]自由行動中は意外と行動範囲が広い[/b]」
この辺を意識すれば前述の取りこぼしを減らしながら遊べると思うので、是非お試しを。


これより下はHDリマスターの品質に焦点を当てたレビューです。
内容上、ネタバレ要素を多く含んでいますのでご注意ください。
[hr][/hr]

[h1]HDリマスター版の利点及び問題点(ネタバレあり)[/h1]

[h2]◯ 3倍速によるタイムパフォーマンスの向上[/h2]
シュミ族の村のエレベーターやF.H.の通路など、演出時間や移動時間が長いエリアも3倍速にすると超快適になります。
バトルでも特殊技使用時は自動で倍速化が無効化されるので、サボテンダー狩りやセントラ遺跡でトンベリをしばき回す時なんかは本当に便利。
トリプルトライアドも3倍速に対応しているので、初動のカード集めが滅茶苦茶捗ります。


[h2]△ 良くも悪くも高画質化の影響あり[/h2]
確かに3Dグラフィックはオリジナルと比べて美麗になりました。
テクスチャの品質は2世代くらい上がった感覚で、PSPのDFF時代のような"[b]ポリゴンを節約しながらテクスチャで美しく仕立てられた[/b]"スコールたちが拝めます。
プリレンダムービーもリマスターがかけられて見やすい部類です。

ただ、街やダンジョンの背景2Dは現代のHD環境に耐えられていないと感じます。
1600x900のウィンドウモードでプレイしていても結構ボケボケになっていて、これから新しく始める方は通路やドアなどが認識できないマップも多いのではないかと。
特にカーウェイ邸の下水道や3回目のルナティックパンドラ、ラストダンジョンのアルティミシア城はグラフィックの粗さもあって事前情報が無いと「えっ、そこ行けるの？」となるはず。
FF8はプレイヤーを意識的に或いは無意識的問わず誘導する導線が弱い時代のタイトルなので、視認性の悪さは割と影響が大きいと思います。

付随して当時の負荷軽減策だったのか、
"[b]3Dと見せかけて実は2Dで描き込まれた書き割りだった[/b]"キャラクターが悪目立ちしてしまっています。
例えば「SeeD実地試験前、候補生たちを送り出すシド学園長」なんかが特に顕著です。
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3200064401
他の学園長が登場するシーンではしっかり3Dモデルで出てきますし、全体がPS時代の粗いテクスチャなら問題なかったとは思いますが、
3Dモデルと背景の品質差が如実に顕れているリマスター版ではちょっと…いやかなりキツい。


[h2]X 再現力に乏しいサウンドまわり[/h2]
これが私としてはリマスター版一番の汚点とも言える部分だと思っています。具体的には、
「一部BGMのループがオリジナルと異なる」
「一部SEの発音タイミングが明らかにおかしい」
この2点です。

[h3]一部BGMのループがオリジナルと異なる[/h3]
ガルバディアガーデンで流れる「Galbadia Garden」やバラムガーデン起動時の「Movin'」、飛空艇ラグナロク搭乗中に流れる「Ride On」は、初回時のカットシーンやイベント以降はイントロをカットしたものが常時流れるようになるのがオリジナル版の挙動なんですが、リマスター版では常時イントロありで再生されます。
これがまたオリジナルに慣れ親しんだ身からすると違和感たっぷり。
どちらも初回イベントの尺を見て長めのイントロを取ってるのがわかる曲ですし、ちゃんとして欲しいものです。

[h3]一部SEの発音タイミングが明らかにおかしい[/h3]
いくつかありますが、繰り返し聴くことになる主にスコールの連続剣(4回攻撃版)とフィニッシュブローのブラスティングゾーンで起こる問題が特に辛いです。
連続剣はどういうわけか4回攻撃(上下段2連撃)を行うパターンだけ最初から全て音ズレしており、
ブラスティングゾーンは宇宙空間にビーム刃が伸び切る辺りからおかしくなります。
連続剣の音ゲー部分のタイミングはオリジナルのままなので余計に混乱してしまいます。
他の攻撃にサウンド面の問題は自分の触った限り見られないのですが、スコールの連続剣という一番触る部分に不具合が集中しているのが辛い。
ちゃんと修正してくれぇ…。


[h2]△ フィールド遷移時の暗転がない[/h2]
フィールドから街やダンジョンに入る時、あるはその逆で行われていた暗転処理がありません。
パッと瞬間的に画面が切り替わるので余韻がないというかシステマチックすぎるというか…。
オリジナル版ではその暗転でディスクの読み込みを行っていたので、それがほぼノータイムになったリマスター版ではそういう挙動になってしまうのは理解できますが…。
ダミーでもいいから一定時間の暗転は挿入して欲しかったですね。


[h2]△ ソフトリセット機能がない(代替機能あり)[/h2]
トリプルトライアドで負けた時などに重宝していたソフトリセットがSteam版では搭載されていません。
一応代替としてメニューから「しゅうりょう」を選ぶとタイトル画面まで戻る仕様を用意してくれているのですが…。
[hr][/hr]

以上です。

それはそうと、FF14も大好きなんだけどガンブレードから出る木刀みたいな打撃音辛くない…？
"...Whatever."

I remember waiting so long to purchase this on PSOne, Having to preorder it from a retailer, and watching it get pushed back and back again. After finally getting my hands on the game, I was thrilled. I purchased this with hopes that the game would bring back a little bit of that magic, and it did not fail in the least bit. I have been super excited putting in some time, this has been a great Remaster. The character models and some of the effects have been updated however the backgrounds in some areas are still a little choppy. I did buy the original, but quickly refunded it for this version as I realized there was a remaster. Definitely NOT upset about doing that as this one has better controller support. There are a few bugs (Typically your first GF Summon will Tab you out from time to time, and the game likes to restart itself after existing, not a big deal), but all in all a fantastic remaster. Thumbs up Square Enix.

column8:
!!!CASH GRAB!!!

The only thing remastered about this game is the character textures... that is all, literally everything else is the same and it makes the game look awkward as hell with the way the characters pop off screen. Had one crash and a constant glitch after the first boss where when i walk onto the elevator it wont go down and the controls lock up while sound is still playing. Also their is no wide screen support and it looks ridiculous. Really disappointed and SE should feel bad about the minimal effort that went into this. SHAME!!!

Also worth noting this game has some tedious flaws such as drawing/junction for magic (junction system is kinda cool) and the nontraditional reality of enemy level scaling. Enemies get stronger as you level up essentially punishing you for level grinding. I don't know about you folks but I like to wake up in the morning, have my coffee and grind out some levels, I find it fun and relaxing. In this game you are slapped on the wrist for doing so to the point where you may paint yourself into a corner. I love the story, world and characters but damn this is a departure from the OG formula and not in a good way imo.

column8: Really a "game you must play" if you like RPG games. Story and GamePlay are just amazing for a such old game.

Ah, como eu amo este jogo! Zerei-o no console na época em que as revistas ainda eram o principal meio de obter informações, e o jogo estava todo em japonês... Era algo absurdo de gráficos para a época! Recentemente, decidi reviver a nostalgia e comprei-o novamente para PC, após abandonar os consoles.

Este foi, sem dúvida, meu Final Fantasy preferido. Foi o primeiro da série a utilizar figuras realistas, em vez das tradicionais representações cartunescas, o que foi um marco no design artístico. A história e a trilha sonora são cativantes, as opções de guardian forces também são incríveis, e o mini game de cartas é sensacional... enfim, só tenho elogios. No entanto, citaria apenas um ponto negativo: a falta de sobrevida para o jogo após ser finalizado. Seria muito gratificante para os jogadores ter a chance de continuar a explorar o mundo do jogo após o término da história principal. Mas, como sabemos, nem tudo é perfeito, não é mesmo?

Se você curte RPGs por turnos e não se importa com a idade de um jogo, então recomendo muito este título.

column8:
I loved Final Fantasy VIII, but this remaster is pretty dull. FMV and background are pretty pixelated for a first - do we have to mod the game to have acceptable graphisms? 
Some achievement have disappeared between the classical FFVIII and this one. And of course, the Chocobo World have been ruled out of the game. Which mean that getting some of the most powerful items in the game is now a chore. Or you have to import a save from the old version of the game - but what the point then to have the new one ? Barely better 3D models ? Mild skin coverage for GF Shiva and Siren ? 

If you loved Final Fantasy VIII on Playstation, just stick to the classical version instead of the Remastered.

PS판, 삼성 정발 PC판, PS 클레식으로 PS3, PSP 등등 한 10번은 넘게 클리어한, 제 최애 파판입니다. 여러 이유로 많은 사람들에게 까이는 작품이긴 하나, 16편이 나왔어도 개인적으로 역대 파판중 연출은 단연 최고 였다고 생각합니다. 당시 프로듀서였던 콧수염 아저씨가 파판 영화화에 관심이 많았고 훗날 진짜로 실행했다 쫄딱 망햇지만, 그런저린 이유로 영화적 요소가 많이 들어갔습니다. 특히 라스트 보스 잡은뒤 나오는 인게임 이벤트씬과 대사, 이후 이어지는 앤딩 영상과 스텝롤 한쪽에 나오는 후일담 영상까지 하나도 버릴 것이 없이 멋지다고 생각합니다. 

 예전 구 PC판 소스를 작업해 리마스터로 나온거라 사실 구 PC판과 거의 같습니다. 새로 작업된건 케릭터 얼굴 모델링 정도고 배경 안티 얼리어싱 적용이 가능하도록 바뀌었습니다. 예전에는 게임에서 직접 지원하지 않아 엔비디아 제어판에서 강제로 켰었는데, 그 경우 대화 자막까지 AA가 먹어서 지저분해지는 문제가 있었습니다. 또 별도 설정 없이 패드가 제대로 작동하고 인게임내에서 액박패드 버튼 모양으로 잘 표시됩니다만 PC판 기반이라 진동이 없습니다. PS판에서 전투중 건블레이드로 때릴때 타이밍 맞춰 버튼 누르면 진동 오던 손맛을 즐길 수 없어 아쉽더군요.

원래 PC판에 있던 초코보월드는 본작에 포함이 안돼서 정상적으로 리본 얻기가 상당히 힘들어졌습니다. 없다고 게임에 지장이 있는건 아닌데 있는걸 빼버린건 좀 그렇네요. 하드 한켠에 전에 한거 따로 저정해놓은 2000년산 세이브 파일 있길래 본편에 적용해봤더니 완벽 호환되는걸 봐서는 구 PC판 초코보월드 실행파일 가져다가 약간 패치만 하면 여기도 적용할 수도 있을것 같긴 합니다.

 7편 리메이크 다 하고 나면 8편도 3부작까진 아니더라도 한편으로 리메이크 해줬으면 하는 바램입니다. 엔진 하나 만들어서 8이랑 9 리메이크 작업해서 내면 좋을 것 같아요. 유일하게 유저한글화조차 안된 파판인데 얼마전 한글화 초기단계 스샷을 봤습니다. 다음에 언제 할진 모르겠지만 그때는 한글화가 돼서 할 수 있길 바래봅니당.

column8:
GREETINGS FINAL FANTASY ENJOYERS, JRPG lovers, gamers from all over the world!

After battling schizophrenia and defeating my inner demons in FF7, it's high time to apply for a position as a SeeD in Final Fantasy VIII (FF8)!

The game opens with an ominous chanting and a battle, blood gets spilled and then... you arrive at the real game: you are [strike]a japanese student in a japanese high school[/strike] Squall, a student at Balamb Garden and a SeeD candidate. What the heck are SeeDs? Well, they're mercs. Sounds familiar?
In contrast to the previous entry, this entry focuses much more on our main character and his inner thoughts are often voiced. The cast is rather large as per FF tradition (~7 playable characters this time, 10 under some conditions), and their interactions are usually fun: Squall being teased by Quistis, Rinoa being a teenager girl, Selphie being a typical genki girl (or a ticking bomb for all I know). Laguna will always hold a special place in my heart with his goofyness. However, the characters feel a bit lackluster somehow and not very memorable when all is did and done.
Unfortunately, the plot suffers from the same issue, while it's going places and doing some crazy stuff (like dropping the most unexpected twists in the most unexpected places), it honestly feels very haphazardly put together and straight up incoherent at times. The ending particularly was a sequence weirder than multiple schizo moments from FF7 put together, lol.
So, plot and characters wise it was fine, but honestly it doesn't feel very memorable, maybe the Final Fantasy formula is starting to wear out? Maybe I'm just missing some greater piece here...

As far as gameplay goes this entry changes things up yet again! Materia is gone. The system seems to be more in place with FF6, where everyone can have a particular summon "junctioned" to them.
It honestly was the most mechanically dense game by far. At the beginning I was straight up put off by the sheer amount of jargon and stuff you could do with the junction system, but once you get the hang of it, it feels a lot like a system that really lets you experiment and abuse the game.
There's Triple Triad as well, but I didn't do it because I personally hate any card game minigame (screw you, Gwent!), dabbled only once or twice, but surely some people out there love this.
World map controls felt a bit wonky, especially in "free camera" mode, so I mostly stuck with the default.

Visually, the game is good. I checked out some clips and screenshots from the original. I appreciate the fact I can actually see characters' faces proper outside of combat in the remaster, haha. Compared to FF7, the FMVs in this one are tens if not hundred times better. Cutscenes were a real feast for the eyes!
Characters are also very animated, very amusing seeing various cast members also act in the background.

Musically, as per usual, it's very good. I certainly enjoyed the ominous chanting song (Liberi Fatali), town tunes and battle tunes. It's all great stuff, although I feel like there's less impactful pieces but maybe that's just because I'm comparing to FF7. My favourite ones after learning their names: The Man with the Machine Gun, My Mind, SeeD, Premonition.

Overall I think that it's a decent game, pretty mid I'd say. Maybe there's some deeper meaning I'm missing out, not sure. I wouldn't recommend this as a first Final Fantasy entry though, but well if you're a masochist like me and want to see what this Final Fantasy is all about you'll play through it anyway, play 4, 6 or 7 first and maybe visit this one after, or if you're the type that saves best for last, playing this ahead would be better.

Well, I'll see you in Final Fantasy IX, time compressor.
[junctions this review]

column8:
I have some issues with the remaster: the character models have lost some of their personality, the backgrounds can look pretty rough, and I'm not too keen on the new font. Not sure why, but SE always seems to use fonts that are too modern and clean in these remasters/re-released versions. I would rather have played the older PC version, but it seems to have audio issues on Steam Deck.

But as a game, this is so much better than a lot of people give it credit for. It tries so many things that are still new and weird today, and mostly successfully. The draw/junction system is odd, but if you restrain yourself from sitting and drawing for 20 turns in every random battle with a new magic available, it can be pretty fun to experiment with, especially if you have no memory of the best setups. The various side-systems (item refining, Triple Triad) all feed back into junction system, so pretty much everything you can do feeds back into mechanical progression. It's really satisfying, and incredibly rewarding to get right.

This game has awesome art direction (unfortunately I feel that some of this is lost in the new Kingdom Hearts-adjacent character models), and possibly Uematsu's finest soundtrack work. The plot that's set up is interesting, but it does take a bit of a backseat towards the end of the game. However, this gives a bit more space to explore some more thematic writing around love and (more importantly) loss. As such, I think the last act is more complete and compelling than a lot of people believe, if you're willing to meet it on its own terms.

Final Fantasy was at its peak in the 90s, both on the SNES and on the PS1, and I think VIII deserves to be a part of that conversation alongside the rest of IV-IX.

column8: This was the first Final Fantasy game that I ever played, and it is is my personal favorite and the best Final Fantasy in my eyes. I played this game as a kid, but could never get close to beating the game. Coming back YEARS later and being able to not only experience a huge hit of Nostalgia, but to be able to actually understand and finish this game was great. The combat system, Junction System, and everything else about this game is amazing. The ending hits you right in the feels, and seeing the main character (Squall) go through changes that a regular high school teenager would go through gives you something (hopefully) to relate to at some level. I absolutely recommend any fan of the Final Fantasy series to give this game a try, remaster or not, it is a great experience!

column8:
Half of my love for this game is pure nostalgia and the other half is because it is legitimately quite good. When I was a starry-eyed preteen I glommed onto Squall in Kingdom Hearts and he was my first husbando, long before I understood the concept; and so of course I'm incredibly biased when it comes to FF8. I'll just take it as a sign of the game's quality that I haven't yet been overcome with the urge to die of embarrassment remembering my crush on a fictional character. 

And yes, I recommend it. Highly. It is weird, it is experimental in both gameplay and story, it has an excellent soundtrack, it is funny, it has a fun character customization system. The junction system is so fun and intuitive and well-implemented. I know some people don't Get it but that's just kind of FF8 in a nutshell: you either Get It or you Don't. If you go into this game expecting it to be like the ones that came before it you're going to be disappointed. Especially if you go into it thinking it's going to be anything like FF7. 8 is its own beast and that's how you should think of it, and I am of the opinion that if it wasn't an FF game it would be some fondly-remembered oddity that would get some crowdfunding effort to restore or remaster it nowadays. (It is in fact a fondly-remembered oddity, and lucky enough to have been a best-seller and part of a popular series so no crowdfunding needed--but being popular, and coming after 7, attracted a lot of haters with, uh, questionable takes about it over the years, lmao.)

Anyway: it's a good game, and if you liked the original you'll like the remaster.

I remember renting this game from Blockbuster back in the day. 
It was the first FF game I ever played and still holds a special place in my gaming memories. I know this game will never have a full remake and that's understandable as it's not necessarily the fan favourite of the series. 
It's nice to at least see this remaster, it's given it a little bit of a refresh, I definitely recommend giving it a try for yourself. FFVIII has a fairly decent bit to offer, great music score, some really nice CGI cut-scenes (for it's day), the junction system was always a debate among the FF community, I do see why but I also enjoy it myself given I started on this game. The story itself is good if a little short, I think it's maybe one of if not THE shortest story in Final Fantasy (please do correct me if i'm wrong). 
Overall I say give it a go :)

일단 추천 박습니다.

1. 99년 출시 당시 하얀 바탕의 시디 케이스에 감동 먹고
 
2. I'll be here./ Why? / I'll be waiting here. / For what? / I'll be waiting here for you. / So... if you come here, you'll find me. I promise. 인트로 영상에 감동 먹고 

3. 다 깨고 감동 먹어서 3연타 콤보 얻어 맞고 100시간씩 5번 이상 클리어했습니다....만,

그래픽 보면서 하시려면 구입을 하지 않는 게 낫습니다.

옛 향수를 느끼시려고 하셔도 그 느낌 못 느끼실 가능성이 높습니다.

단, Eyes on me를 들으면서 리노아 보시려면 사셔야죠.

스퀄의 렌조쿠켄 E 타이밍 잡기 연습이나 젤의 펀치 러쉬(DX) + 부야(<- ->) 무한 콤보로 막보 원콤 연습하실 거라면 구매하셔도 괜찮아요. 단, 만 원 밑으로 할인할 때 구입하세요.

오리지널 버전도 소장하고 있어서 비교를 하자면 이 버전은 편의성을 올려서 클리어하기 훨씬 수월해졌습니다. 노가다하는 재미는 없다고 보셔도 됩니다.

쉽게 깨시려면 비공정 라그나로크 얻으신 후 사막 지역에서 선인장만 죽어라 사냥하셔서 AP만 올리시고 캐릭터는 저렙으로 깨시면 100렙으로 깨는 것보다 훨씬 수월해집니다.

column8:
Pontos positivos:
1) Todos os personagens principais são bem construídos e com uma psicologia bem definida, todos têm problemas e preocupações. Zell é muito explosivo, Irvine não consegue agir sob pressão, Rinoa tem problemas com o pai, Squall é antisocial, e por aí vai. Até mesmo personagens mais secundários possuem suas fraquezas e características bem definidas, como Laguna, Seifer e Edea.
A impressão que o jogo passa é que nenhum personagem está lá apenas por estar, todos cumprem um papel e são importantes em um momento ou outro do jogo. Convenhamos que não é todo rpg que consegue fazer isso com seu elenco.

2) O sistema de magia e suas junctions. Essa é a parte do jogo que mais divide opiniões, alguns odeiam, mas eu sou um admirador de sistemas alternativos, então gostei. FF8 trata as magias de uma forma que até hoje nunca vi igual em outro jogo: elas são como se fossem itens, você possui quantidades de determinada magia, e se usar tudo, elas vão acabar. Não apenas isso, com o junction system você atrela uma magia a um atributo do personagem, por exemplo: se fizer junction de Fire em Strength, sua força vai aumentar. Some isso com o fato de os inimigos serem sempre do seu level, e você tem um rpg que a questão não é "onde eu vou ficar upando level?", a questão é "onde eu vou achar haste pra junctionar em speed?" ou "onde eu acho thundaga pra usar em elemental defense contra um boss específico?". No mínimo interessante.

3) Eu sinto falta de mais rpgs com a "estética" de FF8. O que eu quero dizer com estética? Bom, o visual dos personagens é bem realista, parecem seres humanos de carne e osso, não é aquela estética "personagem de anime" ou "kawaii" que muitos jrpgs adotam. Também me agrada que em várias missões do jogo você tem que enfrentar soldados humanos que estão do lado inimigo, ou seja, não é só ficar batendo em monstros porque monstros = do mal e pronto. Ter que lutar contra o Seifer porque ele tomou algumas decisões bem questionáveis tem muito mais profundidade do que "olha, apareceu um dragão aleatório no final da caverna".

4) A trilha sonora é maravilhosa. Esse jogo nos rendeu a parceria inusitada de Nobuo Uematsu com a Faye Wong, e deu muito certo.

Pontos negativos:
1) A história é muito boa, mas tem algumas coisas que eu não entendi muito bem. Ainda tô na dúvida se eu que sou burro, ou o jogo que é confuso mesmo. Na missile base, você tem que aumentar o error ratio dos mísseis, mas aí depois eles vão pro alvo original igual. Eu achei que era pra colocar error ratio justamente pra desviar os mísseis, não? Se alguém entendeu essa parte, por favor me explica. Fora isso, algumas cenas me pareceram com problema de continuidade ou rushadas demais. No final do CD1, o Squall tem que entrar em um lugar que tá cercado por grades, e ele simplesmente aparece entrando lá, como se não tivessem as grades no meio do caminho. Ele cortou as grades com a espada? É tão magro que passou no meio delas? Não deu pra entender. É o tipo de erro que no cinema seria inaceitável, mas nos games parece que as pessoas não ligam muito (porém eu ligo). Também me incomodou um pouco que o Lunar Cry foi algo que apareceu DO NADA na história, sem foreshadow nenhum (se teve, eu não vi, nesse caso falha minha).

2) Algumas mecânicas do jogo levam a momentos de "AH NÃO, ESQUECI DE FAZER AQUILO LÁ", que são um saco, mesmo que as mecânicas em si não sejam ruins. Por exemplo, quando você muda de party, tem que fazer as junctions tudo de novo com os novos personagens. Lá se vão alguns minutos mexendo no menu só pra isso. A mecânica de ganhar dinheiro através de um salário pago de tempos em tempos também pode levar a isso. Gastou toda a grana? Vai ter que ficar andando pra lá e pra cá até receber salário, ou vender itens. Vou descontar um pouco de nota por causa desses pontos negativos, mas a verdade é que eles nem me incomodam tanto assim, não acho que atrapalhem muito o jogo.

Nota: 9/10

Final Fantasy 8 is a game with many flaws. First of all the graphics are horrendous for being a "remastered" version. The only thing that is "remastered" is the main characters so it looks like a ps3 character is stuck in a low-polygon ps2 environment. The game also is heavy on the introduction and mostly makes itself a lot more complex and difficult than it is irl. The simplest things require a cutscene of 10 minutes to press the arrow key up and down. There is also a bug in the game, I made it to a place with a big machine and Zell tells Squall to press a button only when you do this, nothing happens. You are stuck in that room and can't progress, that's at least how it was for me. So Steam essentially sold me and maybe even another player, a broken game with a bug that makes it unplayable.

I suppose being discouraged from grinding on the field is rewarding to some player but if you don't want your player to gain levels then what's the point of even having a battle system then? The story itself is interesting but it's no excuse. For a game to be good you need it to be functioning from beginning to end. Don't just add slight details and call it a "remastered" version, we know you can do better than that Square.

31小时通关，这么完美的前中期游戏体验，这么完美的感情线，这么有意思的世界观，全被老套的剧情架构还有烂到至极的后期体验给毁了！

一个小怪几万滴血，这就是后期的常态，1代和2代相比起来都算仁慈，看了人家贴吧老哥的东西，人家55级就8000血通关了，我都60级了才接近5000，第三部分才打完，第四部分已经打不动了，尼玛8代那byd动态难度我是真的服了，数值碾压放在本作都不在奏效了，怪会根据你的等级来，导致你如果前期就刷级的话，中期就开始坐牢，我都脱节了，怎么他打我一下几下就死，我打他几十下才死？这就是你游戏的后期体验

这代近战流是真不能玩，伤害太低，主力输出只有召唤兽，主力输出魔法就三个等级，低级，中级，高级，一样的后期不能用，然后就是要肝的东西有点多，BOSS还经常有多阶段，后期小怪都有多阶段

然后就是这代的特色玩法抽卡，我是真看不出来他有什么游戏性可言，后面该被虐还是被虐，也就前期玩玩那个抽卡，他那个抽卡玩法到中期就跟空气一样了，顶多用来抽个召唤兽就没啥用了，因为这代没MP，魔法只能从敌人身上抽过来，导致你玩法术流是不太可能玩的爽了，就得猛猛肝

支线设计补全剧情和世界观我是懒着做，我一路玩到后期，到后期发现真的玩不了，玩个游戏跟上班一样，不猛猛肝的话，不然主线过不去，还好这次重置版内置修改器，3倍加速，瞬间满血，不遇敌，我肝到60级的时候我召唤兽都7.80级了但到了后期一样撑不过几招，到了大后期（第三部分最后阶段）是真的难度直线上升，一点平缓都没有

我这刚到第4部分，刚进门就告诉我：不能用召唤兽了，不能用魔法了，请问你告诉我这款游戏好玩的点在哪里，就我上一秒还在看女主和男主打情骂俏呢，想看看接下来会发生什么剧情，然后下一秒你就拿个几万滴血的BOSS来当我的主线大门，就那种寸止的感觉，真给我恶心坏了

7代相比就完全没有这种情况，7代一口气打完难度曲线非常平滑，我可以说是目前难度曲线最平滑的，就8代这第三部分结尾这个难度曲线我真的，，，，，，就我真的有那么一点点理解了为什么最终幻想8他的评价是两极分化了，就傻逼到什么程度，就跟5代差不多了，就他明处给你的感觉就是你能按照你自己的节奏来玩这款游戏，但是你一旦真的按照你的节奏来玩这款游戏，那不好意思，游戏到了某一个阶段会故意教你去玩游戏，你不得不改变自己的游戏风格，不然将会寸步难行，8代就是这种情况

游戏前中期的体验真的很棒，几个CG名场面也是在游戏中期贡献的，后期随着剧情节奏的加快我本以为至此之后我会不断的继续走下去，直到某个BOSS把我从睡梦中打醒，5代6代都是这种鸟毛病，都改不掉那种教玩家玩游戏的坏毛病，这种垃圾设计不知道有没有延续到之后的FF，那种射精快要射出来然后突然给你寸止的感觉

然后就是这代大结局是真团圆，感情线真的没毛病，还是老问题，剧情架构太老套了，永远是拯救世界，就8代这么近现代的背景世界观到后期也要给你拯救个世界，然后就是老毛病，数值问题，难度曲线问题，正常玩的话标准50级你肯定通不了关（邪道玩法另说），还有大后期那糟糕的游戏节奏，非要学生化整个迷宫洋馆地形，我本以为这代会没有迷宫地形，结果还应征了这个系列某些地方永远改不掉吃屎的毛病

column8:
Of the original 9 Final Fantasy games, the “pre-voice acting” era, the “proper overworld” era, Final Fantasy II tends to be disliked most and Final Fantasy VIII tends to be most divisive. Pixel Remaster fixes a lot of issues of FF II and in that form, I’d say the game can be worth playing. But, sadly, there is no version of FF VIII that could fix its countless issues. This is a game I respect and adore a lot. It’s a game I want to love. A game that I’ve completed a few times before, both on PS1 and with the older PC port the Remastered version is based on. And also a game that I just do not enjoy playing at all.

The story and storytelling in Final Fantasy VIII is amazing. I forgot how genuinely well-written a lot of the game is and how much more nuance and detail for each character the developers attempted to add this time around. This is the deepest, at that point, the series has ever gone into trying to portray characters as well developed and almost real (if still very dramatized) people. A lot of quirks are well done, jokes are funny and still land, the idea to show the thoughts of the main character instead of just the spoken dialogue adds so much to each scene. There are moments that slightly fail in delivering an emotion that would still get high praise today just due to the lack of either voice acting or detailed little animations. But even there it’s easy to understand the intent and imagine it.

And how about the idea of revolutionizing the whole concept of equipment? You don’t get a traditional “equipment” screen in this game and the only thing that changes (visually too) is the equipped weapon if you upgrade it. Which is completely optional and is a bit more complicated than buying a new sword and equipping it. Instead of all that, you equip the GFs – the Guardian Forces (and yes this game being a love story has always made it a butt of “GirlFriend” jokes). GFs are your typical Summons from FF games, except when you equip them on a character, it allows you to also equip different magic spells to different stats, including adding elemental and status damage and defence. Since any character can equip any GF (and any number of them), it’s entirely up to you how you create your party as other than that the only real mechanical difference between the characters is their Limit Break. Which is returning from FF VII, however now again in a form that is closer to how it worked in FF VI, activating when character is in low health (although it can be forced with magic and items).

The world is absolutely amazingly cool too. This time around it’s a kind of a mid-20th century style world mixed with sci-fi elements and magic. The story you learn as you go is super interesting. There are lots of interesting details. The way the whole story is at first told with strange “dream sequences” where you play as people from a different generation is really cool and intriguing. And how it all comes together in the end is absolutely awesome and extremely well presented. This game pushed super hard on mixing CGI and real-time scenes as well and often the result looks great even today. The music is fantastic as well, as it tends to be with FF, and worth listening separately.

Oh and since you put magic as your equipment, you don’t get “mana” or “MP”, you get magic as limited number items – game calls it “Draw”. And… and… yeah, this is where the game starts falling apart, really. The idea is cool – you must manage these magic spells by drawing them from enemies or spots in locations. And if it’s from enemies in a fight, you can grab it to your stock or cast it right there and then – no limits for this at all. So, often times harder fights might have an enemy with a healing spell of some kind, thus serving as the main danger of the fight but also as your main source of healing. It’s a really cool idea in concept and I genuinely think that there’s potential for it to work.

It just doesn’t work in FF VIII well. Drawing magic is grindy and not doing it is doing yourself a disservice – it is beneficial to you to stock up on best magic spells and slot them into your stats, so you get ridiculously overpowered. Can get an unlimited and relatively safe way to grab Death spell? Do it, stick it to your status attack and one-shot a lot of enemies in the game, why wouldn’t you want that? But on top of this constant weird disbalance, game constantly wants you to micromanage this. Some fights work better with specific set ups, sometimes it’s better to not have status or element tied to attacks. And every time you go into the “dream world” any equipped GFs and magic gets unequipped from everyone but Squall (main character), leading to more of this really tedious micromanagement.

For how cool the world is, for how you can ride trains and rent a car, the overworld is basically pointless in this game. I think it’s rather weak in FF VII, but there, especially in comparison, it actually gets some use and some worldbuilding. In FF VIII it would’ve been simply better to cut it out and make the journey work like it does in FF X, so it’s linear until the end where you inevitably get some flying vehicle and there you could just select a destination and go there. Things are so dire with the overworld, in fact, that this game has probably worst side-quests involving it I ever saw in a Final Fantasy game. Some spots in the game overworld can be interacted with to get vague treasure hunt messages or hidden spots of magic you can draw. Just… because they wanted to sell guide books? It doesn’t add anything to the game and neither it is fun, so… I really don’t know why it’s done like this.

Though even in the linear cinematic story-driven sequences sometimes the game just expects you to guess that what you need to do is something that must be done to a specific pixel from a specific position and there’s no hint of any kind about what is it exactly the game wants you to do. Or it can give you a vague goal and then provide no further hints. Oh yeah, and a huge chunk of game items that are extremely useful, are entirely missable unless you guess that you need to talk to some particular character during a particular story beat. Even the GFs themselves are missable as some of them must be Drawn from bosses and they are not even marked in any special way – just a position in the list of things you can Draw. If you miss one, you can only get a second chance during the final dungeon. And yet, there are forced tutorials about things that are tied to those GFs, so if you miss one at the start the game will then tutorialize you about doing something you literally cannot do until hours later… Yes, I missed Drawing Siren again, just like I did 20 or so years ago, how did you guess?

There’s just so much cool potential in this game. And of all Final Fantasy titles, in my honest opinion, Final Fantasy VIII is the one that needs a remake. Everything for it being a beloved entry is already here, it just needs to be done better next time. Oh and the Remastered version is the same PC port from decades ago, but with higher detail models (that do look very nice), some slight balance changes due to the removal of Chocobo World as a separate mini-game and fixed music from the PlayStation version. It has some issues and in some spots looks and feels worse than the PS1 version, but, I suppose, for a modern player this might be the best option to get out of the available ones.

Issue is – I don’t think a lot of people will want to play FF VIII. Which is a shame, because there’s such a good cinematic story-driven RPG with cool ideas hidden beneath all of the horrible horrible execution of said ideas. Granted, with this Remastered version you can use modifiers (speed up is still such a blessing for people who dislike the slowness of these types of games) and actual cheats and just play it for the story. And maybe it’s worth it just for it. But it would be so much better to see a remake of this game.
column9:
Of the original 9 Final Fantasy games, the “pre-voice acting” era, the “proper overworld” era, Final Fantasy II tends to be disliked most and Final Fantasy VIII tends to be most divisive. Pixel Remaster fixes a lot of issues of FF II and in that form, I’d say the game can be worth playing. But, sadly, there is no version of FF VIII that could fix its countless issues. This is a game I respect and adore a lot. It’s a game I want to love. A game that I’ve completed a few times before, both on PS1 and with the older PC port the Remastered version is based on. And also a game that I just do not enjoy playing at all.

The story and storytelling in Final Fantasy VIII is amazing. I forgot how genuinely well-written a lot of the game is and how much more nuance and detail for each character the developers attempted to add this time around. This is the deepest, at that point, the series has ever gone into trying to portray characters as well developed and almost real (if still very dramatized) people. A lot of quirks are well done, jokes are funny and still land, the idea to show the thoughts of the main character instead of just the spoken dialogue adds so much to each scene. There are moments that slightly fail in delivering an emotion that would still get high praise today just due to the lack of either voice acting or detailed little animations. But even there it’s easy to understand the intent and imagine it.

And how about the idea of revolutionizing the whole concept of equipment? You don’t get a traditional “equipment” screen in this game and the only thing that changes (visually too) is the equipped weapon if you upgrade it. Which is completely optional and is a bit more complicated than buying a new sword and equipping it. Instead of all that, you equip the GFs – the Guardian Forces (and yes this game being a love story has always made it a butt of “GirlFriend” jokes). GFs are your typical Summons from FF games, except when you equip them on a character, it allows you to also equip different magic spells to different stats, including adding elemental and status damage and defence. Since any character can equip any GF (and any number of them), it’s entirely up to you how you create your party as other than that the only real mechanical difference between the characters is their Limit Break. Which is returning from FF VII, however now again in a form that is closer to how it worked in FF VI, activating when character is in low health (although it can be forced with magic and items).

The world is absolutely amazingly cool too. This time around it’s a kind of a mid-20th century style world mixed with sci-fi elements and magic. The story you learn as you go is super interesting. There are lots of interesting details. The way the whole story is at first told with strange “dream sequences” where you play as people from a different generation is really cool and intriguing. And how it all comes together in the end is absolutely awesome and extremely well presented. This game pushed super hard on mixing CGI and real-time scenes as well and often the result looks great even today. The music is fantastic as well, as it tends to be with FF, and worth listening separately.

Oh and since you put magic as your equipment, you don’t get “mana” or “MP”, you get magic as limited number items – game calls it “Draw”. And… and… yeah, this is where the game starts falling apart, really. The idea is cool – you must manage these magic spells by drawing them from enemies or spots in locations. And if it’s from enemies in a fight, you can grab it to your stock or cast it right there and then – no limits for this at all. So, often times harder fights might have an enemy with a healing spell of some kind, thus serving as the main danger of the fight but also as your main source of healing. It’s a really cool idea in concept and I genuinely think that there’s potential for it to work.

It just doesn’t work in FF VIII well. Drawing magic is grindy and not doing it is doing yourself a disservice – it is beneficial to you to stock up on best magic spells and slot them into your stats, so you get ridiculously overpowered. Can get an unlimited and relatively safe way to grab Death spell? Do it, stick it to your status attack and one-shot a lot of enemies in the game, why wouldn’t you want that? But on top of this constant weird disbalance, game constantly wants you to micromanage this. Some fights work better with specific set ups, sometimes it’s better to not have status or element tied to attacks. And every time you go into the “dream world” any equipped GFs and magic gets unequipped from everyone but Squall (main character), leading to more of this really tedious micromanagement.

For how cool the world is, for how you can ride trains and rent a car, the overworld is basically pointless in this game. I think it’s rather weak in FF VII, but there, especially in comparison, it actually gets some use and some worldbuilding. In FF VIII it would’ve been simply better to cut it out and make the journey work like it does in FF X, so it’s linear until the end where you inevitably get some flying vehicle and there you could just select a destination and go there. Things are so dire with the overworld, in fact, that this game has probably worst side-quests involving it I ever saw in a Final Fantasy game. Some spots in the game overworld can be interacted with to get vague treasure hunt messages or hidden spots of magic you can draw. Just… because they wanted to sell guide books? It doesn’t add anything to the game and neither it is fun, so… I really don’t know why it’s done like this.

Though even in the linear cinematic story-driven sequences sometimes the game just expects you to guess that what you need to do is something that must be done to a specific pixel from a specific position and there’s no hint of any kind about what is it exactly the game wants you to do. Or it can give you a vague goal and then provide no further hints. Oh yeah, and a huge chunk of game items that are extremely useful, are entirely missable unless you guess that you need to talk to some particular character during a particular story beat. Even the GFs themselves are missable as some of them must be Drawn from bosses and they are not even marked in any special way – just a position in the list of things you can Draw. If you miss one, you can only get a second chance during the final dungeon. And yet, there are forced tutorials about things that are tied to those GFs, so if you miss one at the start the game will then tutorialize you about doing something you literally cannot do until hours later… Yes, I missed Drawing Siren again, just like I did 20 or so years ago, how did you guess?

There’s just so much cool potential in this game. And of all Final Fantasy titles, in my honest opinion, Final Fantasy VIII is the one that needs a remake. Everything for it being a beloved entry is already here, it just needs to be done better next time. Oh and the Remastered version is the same PC port from decades ago, but with higher detail models (that do look very nice), some slight balance changes due to the removal of Chocobo World as a separate mini-game and fixed music from the PlayStation version. It has some issues and in some spots looks and feels worse than the PS1 version, but, I suppose, for a modern player this might be the best option to get out of the available ones.

Issue is – I don’t think a lot of people will want to play FF VIII. Which is a shame, because there’s such a good cinematic story-driven RPG with cool ideas hidden beneath all of the horrible horrible execution of said ideas. Granted, with this Remastered version you can use modifiers (speed up is still such a blessing for people who dislike the slowness of these types of games) and actual cheats and just play it for the story. And maybe it’s worth it just for it. But it would be so much better to see a remake of this game.

"Final Fantasy 8 Remastered" é uma versão atualizada e aprimorada do clássico JRPG lançado originalmente em 1999. eu zerei ele duas vezes, no ps1 e na versão normal. Aqui está uma análise abrangente dos principais aspectos do jogo:

Gráficos e Remasterização:
Os gráficos remasterizados representam uma melhoria significativa em relação ao original de 1999. Os modelos de personagens foram polidos, as texturas foram aprimoradas e a resolução foi ajustada para se adequar aos padrões contemporâneos. Esta atualização visual permitiu que os fãs antigos revivessem a experiência de jogo com uma estética mais moderna.

História e Personagens:
"Final Fantasy 8" é conhecido por sua trama complexa e personagens cativantes. A história acompanha Squall Leonhart e seu grupo de mercenários em um mundo onde a magia é uma força poderosa e as relações interpessoais desempenham um papel crucial. A remasterização manteve a narrativa envolvente que cativou os jogadores na época do lançamento original.

Mecânicas de Jogabilidade:
O sistema de Junção, que permite aos jogadores personalizar as habilidades dos personagens, permanece como uma característica distintiva. Embora alguns jogadores possam achar as mecânicas de junção inicialmente complexas, oferecem uma profundidade estratégica única ao jogo. O combate por turnos clássico da série "Final Fantasy" também está presente, proporcionando uma jogabilidade familiar aos fãs.

Música e Som:
A trilha sonora lendária de Nobuo Uematsu é uma parte integral do charme de "Final Fantasy 8". A remasterização preservou essas composições icônicas, oferecendo uma experiência auditiva nostálgica e envolvente. A qualidade sonora aprimorada contribui para a imersão na atmosfera do jogo.

**Interface do Usuário e Qualidade de Vida:**
A introdução de melhorias na qualidade de vida, como a opção de acelerar o jogo, é um toque bem-vindo. Essas adições permitem que os jogadores personalizem a experiência de jogo de acordo com suas preferências, tornando o jogo mais acessível para uma audiência contemporânea.

Recepção:
A remasterização foi geralmente bem recebida pelos fãs, principalmente pela oportunidade de reviver uma das entradas mais amadas da série "Final Fantasy" com melhorias gráficas e de qualidade de vida. No entanto, as opiniões sobre o sistema de junção e a complexidade da trama podem variar entre os jogadores.

Em resumo, "Final Fantasy 8 Remastered" continua a ser uma experiência cativante para os fãs de JRPGs, proporcionando uma combinação única de narrativa rica, mecânicas de jogo estratégicas e uma atmosfera sonora inesquecível.

column8:
Ich habe FF VIII seinerzeit noch auf der ersten PlayStation gezockt. Nach FF VII kam es sehr viel erwachsener daher, es war das erste Spiel mit ordentlich gerenderten Protagonisten. Die Handlung ist nach meinem Empfinden auch subtiler, nicht ganz so schwarz und weiß wie der Vorgänger und die einzelnen Charaktere sind größtenteils glaubhaft, man kann sich so richtig schön in die Story rein denken. Das Charakter-Entwicklungssystem ist (und war damals schon) sehr ungewöhnlich, da es eng an die verbundenen Esper gekoppelt ist (die üblichen Verdächtigen: Shiva, Ifrit...), aber es ist im Grunde intuitiv und man kommt schnell rein.
Grafisch ist dieses "Remaster" bestenfalls "OK". Ich spiele an einem 28" Monitor mit 4k Auflösung. Diese wird vom Spiel unterstützt und die Figuren und Cutscenes sehen im Spiel sehr ordentlich aus, aber die Hintergründe sind schlichtweg Matsch. Auch die Steuerung der Figuren ist manchmal etwas hakelig, auch da hat das  Remaster nichts verbessert. Größere technische Probleme hatte ich bisher noch nicht (Windows 11, AMD Ryzen 7, NVIDIA GForce RTX 3070), aber ich habe auch gerade mal zwei Stunden Spielzeit auf der Uhr. Einziges Manko ist, dass mein XBox Controller bei diesem Spiel immer wieder aussteigt, meist zum völlig unpassenden Zeitpunkt. Da er bei anderen Spielen (mit und ohne Steam) anstandslos funktioniert, sehe ich das Problem im Spiel, nicht in der Hardware.
Insgesamt kann ich das Spiel Nostalgikern und Liebhabern alter RPGs empfehlen. Aber ein echtes Remake wäre natürlich eine tolle Sache, da wäre ich sofort dabei.

column8: Final Fantasy VIII is a game that gives me nostalgia even when just starting out the game. Something about the dialogue, the whacky plot, and characters just meshes into that whacky rpg people think about when hearing the term JRPG. And I love this game for that. The plot is definitely all over the place, but what really gets the game is the characters and their relationships with each other and trust. They are all connected in some manner or another and all have to learn to overcome their past traumas. I really love the funny dialogue in this game. The music is also nostalgic as well. The characters get along well with each other and also go on their separate journeys. This game I'd have to say is very interesting, and I would probably have to play again, but there is something about it that I just really like that I cannot describe in words other than nostalgic feelings. The romance is cheesy, but it feels very heartfelt and warm so I do not mind it too much. It also helps that Eyes on Me is an amazing song that makes me feel.

[b]TLDR:[/b] [strike]Swords.[/strike] Gunblades. Magic. Monsters. Space-Travel. Witches. Romance. Love. Time-Travel. Truly, an [b]epic -[/b] [i]evocative, fascinating, unique & creative[/i] experience with gorgeous visuals & art direction, stunning CGI cutscenes, and beautiful music. The $19.99 I spent on this remaster is immeasurable to the fun, fulfilling, valuable, enrichening experience this game brought me. To any longtime fans curious about revisiting or any potential curious newcomers to the series, I highly recommend! 👌🏽

[b]Personal Anecdote:[/b] When I first discovered Final Fantasy VIII, twenty years ago at the age of twelve. I vividly remember discovering the box of the game, the PC port - a shiny, silver, holographic box. The cover art was so stunning, so gorgeous - [i]romanticized[/i] even - my brother & I had never seen anything like it, we were mesmerized. And that [i]feeling,[/i] perfectly encapsulates what Final Fantasy VIII means to me. Much like the box art, the opening FMV, the game itself - Final Fantasy VIII is a beautiful work of art, who's evocative imagery and beautiful music has never left my imagination.

[b]Music:[/b] Nobuo Uematsu is a legendary [strike]video-game[/strike] composer, and as a collective piece from start to finish, beginning to end - FF8 is his finest work in my opinion. It's the first time a game in the series would feature a theme song, and two at that. The Opening theme song of the game 'Liberi Fatali' would also be the first time in the series Uematsu would record with a live orchestra, and a chorus. It alone is a brilliant piece who's title Liberi Fatali 'Fated Children/Children of Fate' and lyrics tie into the core plot of the game - the words fithos lusec wecos vinosec while not latin, is an anagram of the words "Succession of Witches & Love". Then there's [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oUuuB51N2SM] Eyes On Me[/url], Uematsu's theme song of the game & collaboration with one of the 90's biggest pop stars in Asia - actress & singer Faye Wong - what a fucking ballad, a timeless beautiful classic - the first time a pop ballad was used in the series, and easily the most iconic. The in-game story behind the song Eyes On Me and the way it serves the narrative is beautifully realized in the game. Overall, what's remarkable to me about the music & score of Final Fantasy VIII is how effective it is used in the story-telling aspect of the game.

[b]Story Analysis:[/b] Essentially, FF8 is a coming of age story - it's focus is centered around youth (highschool kids) who are educated & trained at an elite military school. They're immediately forced into a geopolitical conflict, that spirals into an existential threat by the succession of witches, and by fate are destined to save the world. There's a bit of interesting social commentary and examination on the devastation of war (it's impact on society and over generations), conflict, & geopolitics. But, while that sets the stage of the events of the game - at it's core the game is examination on the positive impact of [b]LOVE -[/b] both through romance & friendship. The power of love and it's impact on an individual - more specifically the changes that happen once you fall in love, your personal growth, maturity, responsibility, selflessness, etc. Additionally, the game touches on the themes of TIME & GROWTH in a significant way. The game uses fantasy to explore abstract concepts (love) and "mystery-box" storytelling with a string of mysteries to try and hook the player in. The narrative is incredibly layered, and unfolds piece by piece with major revelations coming in the later half. Some of the payoffs are incredibly poignant and beautifully told, while others are much less so. The game does suffer from some poor setup, convenient writing, and tonal inconsistencies a handful of times - but despite these imperfections, much of the narrative is intact & sound and makes perfect sense in the world they've created. There are so many secrets hidden in the game that expand on the lore & characters too! The game is full of evocative imagery and symbolism too all throughout that is significant (think Rinoa's wings, the feather, Squall's Griever, etc.) - but it's meaning is never explicitly spelled out and is meant to be analyzed by the player...not everyone will understand or think on their meaning, etc. Personally, I concur with the sentiment that abstract concepts & story-telling are not inherently bad - it's subjective & a matter of preference. It either works for you or it doesn't - for me it [i]does.[/i]

[b]Squall:[/b] The game is essentially an intense character study of it's protagonist Squall.  Squall is described as a lone-wolf, cold, and withdrawn from others. Due to his introverted personality type, coupled with his trauma - this makes him even more distant as a character - he is definitely [i]weird,[/i] but misunderstood. Squall's psychological profile coupled with his actions in the game are incredibly realistic and does not get enough praise from the writers. The way he distances himself from everyone, his frustration at becoming the leader, his inability to express & communicate, his fears and anxiety of growing attachment to others, etc. But Squall is a bit more complex, he's also strong, capable and fierecely independent. If you look in-game, at the menu of Squall's stats - you'll see his hit Attack ratio is 255%. That's the highest of anyone in the game, and this piece of in-game story-telling (unique to the medium) proves that he is incredibly powerful. And so, the whole character arc for Squall is his personal growth, and his acceptance of letting others in his life in a profound and meaningful way. The game heightens this by the end, making it a matter of life or death - in order for the group to survive Time Compression they need to reaffirm their LOVE and belief in one another. The only reason Squall survives in the end is because of his personal growth, and acceptance of LOVE. In the game it's beautifully told and realized - he does not make the change alone, he had so much help, and support along the way from his friends. But, It's his love for Rinoa that sparked the change in him for his personal growth, to become a better person, a leader, and ultimately the legendary SeeD who traveled across time to kill the Sorceress. That is why Squall's arc is so satisfying and rewarding in the end - and the romance too, it serves a narrative purpose and thematically ties into the game.

I was going to write about Laguna & Sorceress Ultimecia but I am [i]compressed[/i] by [u]SPACE.[/u]

[b]✧THOUGHTS:[/b] If Final Fantasy VIII (1999) is widely considered to be the 'black sheep' of the early 3D Final Fantasy games then it's because it's an anomaly, an experiment. It's the product of a strong passionate creative force of young incredibly talented developers given the freedom to create whatever they wanted. They were pushing the boundaries in terms of realism in their characters & setting, quality of music, gorgeous pre-rendered backgrounds, and stunning CGI cutscenes. Much like the box art, the opening FMV, the game itself is a beautiful timeless work of art - and my personal favorite in the series. The highest compliment I can give a nearly 70 hour JRPG is that after it was over I immediately wanted to be immersed in that world & fun gameplay all over again. 👌🏽

Just as Final Fantasy VII had something meaningful to say about [b]LIFE.[/b] Final Fantasy VIII had something meaningful to say about [b]LOVE.[/b]

[b]Music:[/b] Nobuo Uematsu is a legendary [strike]video-game[/strike] composer, and as a collective piece from start to finish, beginning to end - FF8 is his finest work in my opinion. It's the first time a game in the series would feature a theme song, and two at that. The Opening theme song of the game 'Liberi Fatali' would also be the first time in the series Uematsu would record with a live orchestra, and a chorus. It alone is a brilliant piece who's title Liberi Fatali 'Fated Children/Children of Fate' and lyrics tie into the core plot of the game - the words fithos lusec wecos vinosec while not latin, is an anagram of the words "Succession of Witches & Love". Then there's [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oUuuB51N2SM] Eyes On Me[/url], Uematsu's theme song of the game & collaboration with one of the 90's biggest pop stars in Asia - actress & singer Faye Wong - what a fucking ballad, a timeless beautiful classic - the first time a pop ballad was used in the series, and easily the most iconic. The in-game story behind the song Eyes On Me and the way it serves the narrative is beautifully realized in the game. Overall, what's remarkable to me about the music & score of Final Fantasy VIII is how effective it is used in the story-telling aspect of the game.

[b]Story Analysis:[/b] Essentially, FF8 is a coming of age story - it's focus is centered around youth (highschool kids) who are educated & trained at an elite military school. They're immediately forced into a geopolitical conflict, that spirals into an existential threat by the succession of witches, and by fate are destined to save the world. There's a bit of interesting social commentary and examination on the devastation of war (it's impact on society and over generations), conflict, & geopolitics. But, while that sets the stage of the events of the game - at it's core the game is examination on the positive impact of [b]LOVE -[/b] both through romance & friendship. The power of love and it's impact on an individual - more specifically the changes that happen once you fall in love, your personal growth, maturity, responsibility, selflessness, etc. Additionally, the game touches on the themes of TIME & GROWTH in a significant way. The game uses fantasy to explore abstract concepts (love) and "mystery-box" storytelling with a string of mysteries to try and hook the player in. The narrative is incredibly layered, and unfolds piece by piece with major revelations coming in the later half. Some of the payoffs are incredibly poignant and beautifully told, while others are much less so. The game does suffer from some poor setup, convenient writing, and tonal inconsistencies a handful of times - but despite these imperfections, much of the narrative is intact & sound and makes perfect sense in the world they've created. There are so many secrets hidden in the game that expand on the lore & characters too! The game is full of evocative imagery and symbolism too all throughout that is significant (think Rinoa's wings, the feather, Squall's Griever, etc.) - but it's meaning is never explicitly spelled out and is meant to be analyzed by the player...not everyone will understand or think on their meaning, etc. Personally, I concur with the sentiment that abstract concepts & story-telling are not inherently bad - it's subjective & a matter of preference. It either works for you or it doesn't - for me it [i]does.[/i]

[b]Squall:[/b] The game is essentially an intense character study of it's protagonist Squall.  Squall is described as a lone-wolf, cold, and withdrawn from others. Due to his introverted personality type, coupled with his trauma - this makes him even more distant as a character - he is definitely [i]weird,[/i] but misunderstood. Squall's psychological profile coupled with his actions in the game are incredibly realistic and does not get enough praise from the writers. The way he distances himself from everyone, his frustration at becoming the leader, his inability to express & communicate, his fears and anxiety of growing attachment to others, etc. But Squall is a bit more complex, he's also strong, capable and fierecely independent. If you look in-game, at the menu of Squall's stats - you'll see his hit Attack ratio is 255%. That's the highest of anyone in the game, and this piece of in-game story-telling (unique to the medium) proves that he is incredibly powerful. And so, the whole character arc for Squall is his personal growth, and his acceptance of letting others in his life in a profound and meaningful way. The game heightens this by the end, making it a matter of life or death - in order for the group to survive Time Compression they need to reaffirm their LOVE and belief in one another. The only reason Squall survives in the end is because of his personal growth, and acceptance of LOVE. In the game it's beautifully told and realized - he does not make the change alone, he had so much help, and support along the way from his friends. But, It's his love for Rinoa that sparked the change in him for his personal growth, to become a better person, a leader, and ultimately the legendary SeeD who traveled across time to kill the Sorceress. That is why Squall's arc is so satisfying and rewarding in the end - and the romance too, it serves a narrative purpose and thematically ties into the game.

I was going to write about Laguna & Sorceress Ultimecia but I am [i]compressed[/i] by [u]SPACE.[/u]

[b]✧THOUGHTS:[/b] If Final Fantasy VIII (1999) is widely considered to be the 'black sheep' of the early 3D Final Fantasy games then it's because it's an anomaly, an experiment. It's the product of a strong passionate creative force of young incredibly talented developers given the freedom to create whatever they wanted. They were pushing the boundaries in terms of realism in their characters & setting, quality of music, gorgeous pre-rendered backgrounds, and stunning CGI cutscenes. Much like the box art, the opening FMV, the game itself is a beautiful timeless work of art - and my personal favorite in the series. The highest compliment I can give a nearly 70 hour JRPG is that after it was over I immediately wanted to be immersed in that world & fun gameplay all over again. 👌🏽

Just as Final Fantasy VII had something meaningful to say about [b]LIFE.[/b] Final Fantasy VIII had something meaningful to say about [b]LOVE.[/b]

column8:
想想过了差不多有半年了，忽然想来评价半年前玩的ff8，从几个方面着手浅谈一下square的在ps1上的ff第二作

故事的前半段讲述孤儿男主的佣兵校园生活，到刺杀魔女失败为止，营造出的那股校园佣兵味非常之纯正，我也只能给非常之好评，从夺回电波塔到劫持火车，基本把前面的气氛推到了最高潮（有谁能拒绝面瘫男主耍帅呢），中期开始味道就开始不对了，从佣兵剧一转穿越剧，学园被炮击，galbadia全国和seifer也是不知道为什么莫名其妙就被魔女洗脑当了魔女的跟班，第二条线开始引出全游戏关键人物，而后唯一可圈可点的地方就是在当时看来相当震撼的学园大战（尤其是和两年前发售的ff7杠铃人比），最后草草去到esta城，上太空当了一回真正的“太空战士“，最后莫名蹦出的esta的新魔女（男）以及最后的穿越未来击败魔女也只能用草率来形容，（不过魔女宅邸这张地图很有意思，而且ff8的最终boss bgm也在ff14的伊甸零式再生4层本体得到了复用，而且4层门神的联线也有致敬junction系统的意图在），而且后半段的剧本明显有可以打磨的空间

战斗方面上，ff8的junction系统无疑是个毁誉参半的系统（甚至毁更多），junction系统颠覆了传统rpg的练级体验，取而代之的是动态化等级，不过说是这么说，升级对于敌人的数值提升远远超于玩家的数值提升，魔法和召唤兽变成了可以贴在角色身上加强属性的道具，魔法也从前作的消耗mp释放变成了类似道具的一次性用品（魔法数量，等级越高加成越大），换言之就是魔法得囤着，哪怕摸到了究极，也得存着不能用，一用角色的属性就掉，但是魔法和召唤兽的最快速获取方法就是从敌人身上抽取，这下又面临两难问题了，进战斗会升级，不进战斗角色属性过于弱鸡，系统的深度是有，但是具体落实到游戏里面很多东西还是相当灾难性的

小游戏方面，这代和七代的赛鸟塔防比显然有不少差距，唯一能玩的小游戏可能就是幻卡了（

总评ff8是一款前期极其优秀但是中后期发力不足的作品，同时具有着十分具有争议性的战斗系统，不过总体来说，ff8的变革也属于ff系列的老传统，总体还是属于瑕不掩瑜的一作，推荐喜欢古早jrpg的人试试

column8:
Final Fantasy 7 & 9 are two of my favorite games of all time, so it was inevitable I would play this "middle" chapter. And I was not disappointed.
I had purchased the regular version off Steam, but due to its impartial controller support, I decided to play this version instead, despite many reviews mentioning performance issues. While there were definitely some lags early on and even consistent crashing after the second dream sequence (which I guess was due to the x3 speed feature), I found that the lagging stopped when I switched to a lower resolution -- 400 x 300 -- which wasn't optimal and even strained my eyes before too long, but the lagging stopped, plus I upped the resolution a little later on and there was no more eye strain.
This game is definitely different than 7 and 9, and while it took a while to get into it, I can say this is a solid 8-8.5/10 for me. It's a very immersive world and engaging story, even with the curveball near the end of Disc 2. The final boss is *very* challenging* but after having beat it about a month ago, I still feel a great sense of accomplishment. And the music, of course, is top notch, especially the "Love Grows" theme. A month removed from beating it and I find myself still missing the characters and overall world, but having not really delved into any of the sidequests or fully optimizing the Junction system (which I thought was great), this will certainly deserve a re-visit.

Okay, I normally don't even review games because you probably already know if you like/want them or not. But something here has to be said:

All the people claiming "the game is broken, fuck Square/Enix" are full of shit. The game is NOT broken. They have something wrong in their computers. The game works PERFECTLY. No crashes, no getting locked out of the settings, nothing like that. I am playing the remaster for the first time right now (started yesterday, 29 NOV 2023) and everything works fine. They're doing something wrong, have some setting in their PC screwed up, something.

I'm a PC technician/programmer/network administrator, so I'm very used to customers thinking "the program is bad!" when it's something THEY did, even if when it's a customer you never tell them that and just pretend they were right all along when nine times out of ten it's "user error".

Again, yes, it still works, no special computer knowledge necessary. I just installed and ran it out the box like every other steam game. No special programming know how needed to fix it.

column8:
I have been telling myself I would play this game for nearly 20 years. It was the first FF I was introduced to, and it's now the first one I have finished.

It's a beautiful, charming, funny, crazy, and even convoluted/confusing game at times with parts of its story and the Junction system. But if you are patient and spend some time learning the systems, story, and world, it's a wonderful game. The music, characters, world-building, art, cutscenes, dungeons, boss fights, and environment are top notch imo. Although it is a divisive FF game, I highly recommend trying it out.

In regards to the "remaster", I had no issues with it. No crashes on my end, even with abusing the 3x speed boost.

p.s. plz remake this game

[h1]A Depressing Yet Semi-Realistic Story of Teenage Love and Feelings of Loneliness[/h1]

[h2]DISCLAIMER:[/h2] 
I modded the shit out of this game to upscale the backgrounds, models, basically fix 99% of the disappointing graphical bullshit in this "remaster" (my ass). As such, I'll only be taking about the actual game and not how awful this remaster is. I really only got the remastered version because I saw the "Kill 10.000 Enemies" achievement in the original and I was like "man fuck that shit lol" and got the remaster. Sue me.
[h2]DISCLAIMER OVER[/h2]

Only recently did I get into the golden era of the Final Fantasy franchise, and this game didn't disappoint. I know there are many criticisms directed at the junction system, and the story, and so on, but I genuinely love this game.

For me, the most important part of an RPG is the context and the story. Having the knowledge of fighting for something bigger than myself, something more important than my own dreams and wishes, is the recipe for a great story imo.

Squall's struggle to [spoiler]reject his twisted sense of pride[/spoiler] and finally accept the [spoiler]unconditional warmth and love his friends offer to him[/spoiler] is such a great character arc that I just can't help but question people who hate this game's story.

As we play through the story, we learn that Squall acts like a total jackass towards his friends/peers/superiors [spoiler]on purpose; he desperately wants to keep people away so that he doesn't get attached, and subsequently suffer when they inevitably leave his life for one reason or another.[/spoiler]

We also learn that Squall has [spoiler]a ring that depicts an image of a prideful, powerful lion that he refers to as Griever; Griever being[/spoiler] Squall's manifestation of his desire to [spoiler]never feel the pain of loss or loneliness ever again, and to remain safe and alone (in his eyes, at least).[/spoiler]

Rinoa, his [spoiler]developing love interest[/spoiler] throughout the course of the game, nails it into his head over and over that life is worth living specifically for the beautiful moments, even knowing that they don't last forever. In her eyes, losing your love is better than never having loved at all.

The final boss, [spoiler]Ultimecia[/spoiler], is not only a struggle for the sake of the world, but Squall confronting [spoiler]his toxic mindset and his insecurities in the form of Griever. Ultimecia summons Griever as a Guardian Force to junction, and Squall is able to defeat her in part because of his acceptance of himself and letting other people into his heart, and being able to appreciate temporary beauty.[/spoiler]

All in all, this game is nothing short of a masterpiece, and should be hailed as one of the greatest video games of the Final Fantasy franchise, instead of being the weird, black sheep of the series.

[h2]10/10[/h2]

This game's achievements were way less obnoxious than Final Fantasy 7's. So it's got that going for it, if you think nothing else.

column8:
First time player, here to dispute some of the negative reviews.
- No crashes or frame rate issues on my end, despite abusing the 3x speed boost frequently
- Runs perfect on a Steam Deck, with my playtime being split between that and a PC (but mostly the Deck)
- No issues with the launcher, on my end
- The improved character models on the old backgrounds does look goofy at times, but you get used to it. The backgrounds are gorgeous.

The ending was absolutely incredible, possibly best of the franchise. Some of the best CG scenes throughout the game, too. Everything else wasn't bad, but was fairly standard. I will say that this game does not deserve the hate it gets amongst the FF community.

La historia esta hecha con una ia de 1999 porque es mas genérica que un isekai de magia y fantasía, ni siquiera se entiende, Squall muere con el cacho de hielo en el pecho? Rinoa muere en el espacio? la bruja no puede morir sin transferir sus poderes, controla el tiempo y el espacio, por lo tanto no puede morir nunca y se repetiria el ciclo en bucle? no se, nada tiene sentido.

Los personajes son 3, Squall, la bruja, y el único que por su historia vale la pena Laguna, todos los demás son relleno, Rinoa solo existe para complementar a Squall.

El juego de cartas es una ##### cuanto mas jugas y avanzas te toca todo al azar y manéjate.

Si sos fan de la saga FF compralo de oferta nomas si queres completar los logros de steam, porque divertirte no te vas a divertir

column8:
Le début est un peu indigeste, j'ai commencé par le Mystic Quest, puis le IX et divers, j'ai fais quasi la totalité des FF sans avoir fait le VIII, car il est beaucoup plus différent des autres FF.
Heureusement qu'il n'y a pas d’ordre précis à respecter pour jouer à Final Fantasy, chacun à sa propre histoire
Bien que j'ai eu beaucoup de mal avec le VIII au départ, j'ai fini par grandement apprécier le milieu et la fin du jeu, j'ai une autre vision de cet opus.
La bande sonore est tout bonnement excellente, les cinématiques sont assez folles pour l'époque, pour l'heure, je remercie les devs d'avoir intégré le X3, car oui, je l'ai trouvé trop lent en normal, les combats tours par tours, sont un des éléments que j'adore, mais la progression des GF et des personnages m'aurait pris des dizaines d'heures supplémentaires s'il n'y avait pas ces assistances.
Je ne regrette finalement pas d'avoir compléter ce jeu, il y a du bon, du moins bon, mais globalement je le recommanderai à ceux qui n'ont pas essayé et de persévérer un tout petit peu plus. Les choses deviennent beaucoup intéressantes dès le milieu du CD2 voir début du CD3.
Il y a quelques bugs de sons par contre, dès fois quand vous rentrez dans une ville et que vous en sortez, il n'y a pas de musique de la WorldMaps, elle revient seulement si un combat dans la Worldmap a été lancé.

I can't believe they didn't even bothered to update the backgrounds with Waifu 2X. Believe me, I have a 24" monitor and it looks HORRIBLE, if you have a bigger screen you might get eye cancer with this one.

Can't speak for the quality of the game as I'll play it on PSP, but stay away from this port; only give it a go if you have nowhere else to play it (or you have a Deck, in that case it should look kinda decent, bearable, at least).

column8:
Primeiramente sobre o Port: Meu PC não é uma máquina gamer, tampouco tenho placa de vídeo, mas ele roda sim travado a 30 FPS nos mapas/15 FPS nas batalhas, porém você deve apertar ESC e desabilitar o Anti-Aliasing (que ao meu ver não fez nenhuma diferença). Essa opção não aparece no launcher do jogo, ou seja, passa despercebida até você descobrir que existe esse menu dentro do jogo. O jogo tem quedas em algumas telas onde possui transparência de elementos transparentes dos cenários pré-renderizados com os modelos, mas é uma limitação do próprio jogo e não atrapalha em nada. É um port melhor que o Chrono Cross the Radical Dreamers Edition, porém inferior ao port do IX e do X por exemplo.
Quanto as melhorias e funcionalidades dessa versão, eu achei excelente, a melhor maneira de jogar o jogo hoje em dia. Você pode acelerar o tempo para farmar magias dos inimigos, algo que no jogo original era bem  massante. Os modelos novos são bonitos, porém é bem claro que destoam com o cenário em algumas partes, mas na minha opinião na maioria das partes o jogo é bem bonito. A opção de Trapaças eu não usei, visto que já dá para acelerar o tempo para farmar as magias, dito isto, seria bem melhor se colocassem uma opção aonde você poderia mudar as regras chatas e aleatórias do Triple Triad, isso sim seria ótimo.
E quanto ao jogo, é ótimo, a história é confusa, mas prestando atenção até que faz sentido, começa num ambiente de "escola" e termina envolvendo viagem no tempo, só jogando pra entender. O minigame de Triple Triad é muito legal e o sistema de Junction é muito bacana, o jogo recompensa você farmar magias, refinar cartas em troca de itens que são refinados em magias novas equipar essas magias nos Status dos seus personagens para que eles fiquem mais fortes, e não em derrotar os inimigos e ganhar experiência (eles evoluem conforme você evolui), a propósito zerei o jogo com o Squall no Level 16, o que é bem bacana, cada pessoa vai ter uma experiência diferente conforme o level do seu personagem, possibilitando walkthroughs e runs diferentes, dependendo da sua estratégia. O ponto mais forte desse Final Fantasy é a liberdade que você tem logo de início em montar seu personagem.
Final Fantasy VIII tem seus defeitos, não é meu Final Fantasy da época do PS1 favorito, mas é um excelente JRPG.

[h1]A Fantasy About Love, Succession, Fate... and TRIPLE TRIAD[/h1]

Final Fantasy VIII Remastered is a fun school romp about the best-looking guy in Balamb Garden named Squall. He suffers from childhood trauma, is anti-social, very lonely... and has a sick habit of taking valuable cards. The game is a heavily contentious title among the fandom and I'm here to give my honest thoughts and feelings after finishing the game in 2023

[hr][/hr] 
[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Junction, Draw, and Card Mod is broken af. It scratches that itch to collect everything and it's fun to feel powerful throughout the game.
+ Characters are charming as hell and feels alive. Talking to the NPCs are fun, they're very animated and I took all their cards. The same can be said about our main party. They all have an interesting backstory (IYKYK) which puts focus on in-the-moment interaction and reaction for character development. It works in making them feel like a real group of friends. Lastly, Laguna. That's enough of a reason to make this journey worth it. How can a fictional character be so likable?!
+ The humor is on point. Zell and his hotdog arc, Laguna getting the cramps, Rinoa's handmade train model, Squall's serious tone in contrast to every hijinks going around him, (... ya know) etc. So many memorable moments that made me laugh and enjoy the vibe of the game.
+ OST is, as always, amazing. Nobuo Uematsu doesn't miss.
+ TRIPLE TRIAD. More than half of my playtime is burnt on Triple Triad. I collected everything and grinded for the good items. This is just Tetra Master w/o the bs RNG. 10/10. I'm so glad I played this game.
+ Boosters actually helps tremendously with the slog of the Draw system (and a certain airship being way too slow). Without the boosters, I would probably hate the combat because collecting magic is a huge part of the junction. Also, I always lose HP when switching junctions so the God Mode booster is a God send.

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Some of the convoluted plot and world-building are hinged on talking to the right NPCs and reading the "tutorials" section. I wish they're implemented on the plot rather than around it. Thankfully I enjoy talking to everybody but also not knowing which is important muddles the info.
- Summons and Magic are kinda useless for most of the game. With the right junction, you can just hold the attack button and watch Squall one-hit 90% of the enemies. Using Magic reduces the stat as well so there's barely any use for it in my playthrough outside of something like Aura or Meltdown. Summons, I personally just use for status effects like reflect/triple etc. Most cases, junctioning elem/stat-atk beats summoning.
- Character dynamic seems to take a backseat due to the plot and focuses more on Squall and Rinoa's relationship. A bit SaaaD because I love Quistis in the first disc and Irvine has potential with his relationship to Edea and us. But nah he's just the plot guy. After he served his role to the story, there's nothing outside of generic lines when they're in the party during scenes. His relationship with Selphie is an afterthought as well. We barely saw development outside of the Festival and the credits iirc.
- Oh Garden is being attacked and many are dying? B-but Rinoa needs to get together with Squall guys! Rinoa is unconscious? Let's joke around each other etc. Those moments just bothered me a bit and makes the tone all over the place in some big story moments.
- The reason why it took me this long to play the game was the fact that people say "grinding is bad and will mess you up". I love grinding in RPGs. Well, It wasn't THAT bad but for most of the game I was tiptoeing around because Squall doesn't leave your party, making grinding a hassle for other underleveled party members. I'm just the type that gets bothered when someone is 5 levels ahead or something so this is on me.
- HP doesn't adjust when junctioning. Using Auto will fuck you over sometimes. Just in general navigating through the magic/junction/item is a hassle especially in a game where there's a lot of items/magic being made.
- World Map and its traversal pre-Ragnarok is pretty disappointing. There's barely anything interesting on the world map. I guess it makes sense lore-wise but I wish there's more to do and places to go.
- I wish we delve more into Ultimecia as a character. Sure we can assume her tragic story of being ostracized as a sorceress and her effort to break away from her fate from the lore and her dialog but wish they were told in-game in some way. Her final scene at the orphanage would've hit
- I wish the story was segmented better. I don't mind the convoluted story as much but I wish we get more of the school and mission-based stuff on the first disc. I just enjoy the unique vibe of it and being graded at the end. Also more Laguna sections. There's some confusion for me at the start with his timeline because most of it gets skipped around.

[hr][/hr] 
All in all, I think Final Fantasy VIII is an excellent RPG and Final Fantasy game. It has its ups and downs but overall, a positive experience. It helps that I play each title and look at them as a separate entity rather than a sequel/prequel to this and that. I think Final Fantasy VIII deserves a second look and consider me a new fan.

[h3][i]82 hours (40+ of which was spent playing Triple Triad) and 100% Achievement later, I give [strike]Triple Triad[/strike] Final Fantasy VII Remastered a 8/10[/i][/h3]

column8: Uno de los mejores FF que he jugado

No recomiendo este Remastered y mis motivos es sobretodo que no entiendo que cobren el precio  de 20€ por este juego.

Las cinemáticas están capadas a 15 FPS, en un monitor QHD se ven los PIXELES en las mismas es horrible, creo que en la versión de PS1 se veían mejor. Así cómo el Gameplay que está capado a 30FPS en 4:3 (ni si quiera en 16:9). 

Sólo lo recomiendo sí nunca jugaste al juego, si te es IMPOSIBLE conseguir el de PSX o si lo encuentras ultra barato.

El único "añadido" que eso es un punto a favor, es el X3. Puedes el triple de rápido en el Gameplay, por lo tanto puedes pasártelo más rápido. Y el Autoguardado, que te puede salvar de alguna cagada.

Así que sí, estamos ante el maravilloso FFVIII de 1999, tal cual pero con esas 3-4 opciones nuevas que no justifican el precio.

I just love the world depicted here, I enjoy the characters, the storytelling, the mini game, everything.
I wish they would do a remake of this with modern standards.
