column8: Mejor Juego RPG de la época de PS1, tiene algo único e insuperable a diferencia de otros RPG de esta época...

Octava entrega de la rama principal de la saga Final Fantasy y en versión 'remastered' con unos cuantos añadidos como velocidad X3, modo sin encuentros y unas cuantas herramientas más que hacen la experiencia bastante más amena para los que ya se conocen la historia y simplemente quieren volver a experimentarla sin tener que invertir tanto tiempo entre las animaciones lentas y el grindeo.

Es un juego divisivo para los fans: está ciertamente roto si sabes exactamente cómo romperlo, pero personalmente creo que poder hacerlo tiene su gracia.

[h2]Lo bueno[/h2]
[list][*] Historia con un comienzo muy fuerte, que te atrapa casi al instante
[*] Una banda sonora brutal: temas como [i]The Landing[/i], [i]The Guy With The Machine Gun[/i] o  [i]Liberi Fatali[/i] son muy memorables
[*] Esta versión incluye herramientas de QoL para hacer que el juego vaya a X3 de velocidad o tener autoguardado, entre otras cosas
[*] Si te gusta sentirte poderoso, en este juego es muy fácil hacerlo con su sistema de Enlaces
[*] No he llegado a probarlo, pero tiene soporte a mods
[*] Funciona perfectamente en Steam Deck
[*] Unos cuantos super-jefes que probarán lo bien que entiendes el juego
[/list] 

[h2]Lo malo[/h2]
[list][*] Sin la velocidad al X3 el juego es horriblemente lento
[*] Al poder romperse el juego al principio, hace que la sensación de progresión se pierda
[*] Los modelos están remasterizados, pero los mapas no, lo que hace que haya una diferencia muy notoria y no se disfrute igual
[*] Las misiones secundarias son una movida para encontrarlas y completarlas
[/list]

Personalmente lo recomiendo porque pese a que el remaster deja un poco que desear en cuanto a remasterizaciones de juegos se trata, creo que es actualmente la mejor manera de jugar a Final Fantasy 8, especialmente por el soporte a mods que tiene y lo bien que funciona con la Steam Deck sin ninguna configuración adicional.

If you're an achievement person who wants an easy 100%, take a look at this version of Final Fantasy VIII.

It's a bit like the Pixel Remasters of Final Fantasy 1 - 6; this is a fine version of a game that I really enjoy, it's why I recommend this version of this game anyway, but the Lunatic Pandora mod for the original version is probably the better choice.

column8:
Premetto: non ho ancora giocato la remastered, ma ho visto ciò che doveva essere visto, ovvero un """"miglioramento"""", per usare un eufemismo, grafico di un gioco vecchio di quasi 30 anni, invecchiato davvero molto male. Detto ciò passiamo alla recensione: FF VIII è un gioco leggendario, secondo me il miglior Final Fantasy mai creato. Storia matura, gameplay strutturato e interessante, anche se di difficile comprensione, specie se lo si gioca ora, nel 2023, anno in cui i JRPG e RPG hanno una comprensione estremamente più semplicistica ed immediata dei comandi di gioco. Ma nel complesso parliamo di un'opera veramente meravigliosa, Io ho acquistato questa remastered per l'amore che ho per il titolo, un mix di nostalgici  ricordi d'infanzia. Ormai vecchio sia nel gameplay che antiquato nella resa grafica, rimane un titolo per boomer come il sottoscritto, che ha passato i 35.
Spero un giorno svilupperanno un remake di questo capolavoro, sarebbe uno dei pochissimi giochi che prenderei al lancio.

He leído varias veces que tu primer Final Fantasy va a ser siempre tu favorito, y creo que en mi caso es verdad. Final Fantasy VIII fue el primer juego de la franquicia con el que me crucé y desde entonces suelo jugarlo cada cierto tiempo, primero en mi fallecida PS1, luego la primera versión que existió en PC, mucho antes de que Steam fuera algo, luego PS3 y finalmente, en Steam, tanto la versión original como el Remaster. Y aunque puedo decir con propiedad que lo he jugado unas ocho o nueve veces, sé que volveré a tomar este juego una vez más en el futuro y que voy a disfrutarlo como la primera vez. Pero ¿sólo me atrae el juego por nostalgia? En parte, admito que sí. Pero Final Fantasy VIII va mucho más allá de eso.

Partamos diciendo que el juego dista mucho de ser perfecto y que cuando salió a la venta la primera vez, en el lejano 1999, decepcionó a todos los que esperaban que superara al ya mítico Final Fantasy VII (algo que visto en retrospectiva da algo de risa, pues casi veinte años después Square continúa intentando desarrollar un FF que 'supere' a FFVII y los usuarios siguen decepcionándose porque no lo logra; FFVIII no tenía oportunidad) y eso impidió que pudiera ser considerado cavalmente por sus propios méritos. Y es que considerado por sí solo, FFVIII ofrece muchas cosas, tanto buenas como malas. Partamos por las malas:

Una de las cosas que siempre me han gustado de Square es su vocación por la experimentación, algo que a veces funciona muy bien (FFVI), otras veces funciona mal (FFXIII) y cuando no se hace, les estalla en la cara de forma estrepitosa (FFXIV 1.0), pero ¿eliminar el maná y convertir la magia en un ítem más? Fue una experimentación audaz en su momento, lo admito, pero hizo que el juego se volviera tedioso de utilizar, al menos al comienzo de la aventura y cuando no sabías usar bien ni los GFs ni el sistema de Junction, y esto le jugo muy en contra al título. Tanto que no han vuelto a utilizar este modo en ningún otro FF ni spin-off hasta la fecha (a lo más, algo similar se vio en FFXV, pero no a este nivel).

Otro aspecto negativo, aunque admito que una vez que aprendí a usarlo me enamoró, fue el sistema Junction -o de Vínculo. En este, tienes que utilizar las magias que extraes de los enemigos (o de artefactos o que creas con ayuda de GFs) para potencias los stats de tu personaje, incluyendo fuerza, agilidad, resistencias y fortalezas elementales, etc. El sistema no es sencillo de usar a la primera, lo que también provocó mucho daño a la reputación del juego en su momento, y por eso lo considero negativo. Pero no puedo dejar de repetir que una vez que se aprende a usar se convierte en uno de los modos más versátiles que esta serie ha visto alguna vez. Es tan bueno, que incluso puede ayudarte a romper el juego y volverlo facilísimo, otra cosa que no puedo considerar positiva.

Pasado eso, sólo puedo hablar de cosas buenas sobre este título: la historia es genial, si bien algo simplona, adolescente (Squall es el adolescente emo típico del JRPG) y bien cliché, como suelen ser las de los Final Fantasy. Pero es la única historia de la franquicia que hasta ahora se ha enfocado en un romance, algo que si bien puede alejar a muchos, a mí me atrajo bastante. Nunca esperé, ni lo hago ahora, una trama digna de un best-seller, pero dentro de lo que se puede, no es una mala historia para nada. Y va más allá del romance: ¿guerras entre naciones? ¿Un secuestro? ¿Estudiantes enfrentándose colegio vs. colegio, pero a cañonazos? FFVIII tiene mucho que ofrecer en este apartado.

Acerca de los gráficos, fue durante la producción de FFVIII en que Square logró encontrar el diseño visual que ahora utiliza en gran parte de sus títulos, y es que FFVIII fue el primero en presentar una estética más realista, con personajes con proporciones reales y con expresiones faciales más humanas (para una PS1). FFVIII visualmente relucía entonces y ahora, con el lavado de cara de este Remaster, lo vuelve hacer... al menos para los personajes principales, ya que los fondos y los personajes no importantes, si bien han recibido algo de cariño, se quedaron en los noventa. No es raro en estos remasters de Square Enix, pero no deja de ser una pena cuando los mismos usuarios han demostrado que es posible realizar estas modificaciones a través de mods.

Por último, y lo mejor que tiene este juego para mí, es la música. Nobuo Uematsu, que por entonces era el único compositor de la franquicia, ya había creado grandes composiciones antes, pero en FFVIII alcanzó lo que para muchos, entre los que me incluyo, es el mejor soundtrack de toda la serie. Grandes melodías como 'Blue Fields', 'Fisherman's Horizon', 'Balamb Garden', 'Maybe I'm a Lion' o la genial 'Eyes on Me' (la primera canción cantada en algún FF), hacen que este soundtrack sea un deleite para los oídos. ¿Lo mejor? A diferencia de la versión original que salió para Steam, este Remaster no necesita de mods para poder apreciar la música de forma decente, lo que es un tremendo punto a favor. Espero que, tal como lo he hecho yo en estos 24 años, ustedes también puedan enamorarse de este soundtrack.

En fin. Final Fantasy VIII fue el primer juego que dividió a los fans de la franquicia y eso es algo que no ha disminuido hasta ahora. Continúa siendo un título al que o amas u odias, y en mi caso, puedo decir que es mi favorito, a pesar de sus errores y de todos los mejorables que tiene. Continúo disfrutándolo como el primer día, si bien considero que no es el mejor (es un cliché, pero FFVI es el mejor). Lo recomiendo para todo fanático de la serie, a pesar de lo que puedan escuchar de él, y también le diría a los amantes de los JRPG y de los RPG en general que le den una oportunidad. Después me dicen si terminaron amándolo o si lo odian con el corazón.

Pros:
- Trama entretenida y con varios recovecos. No es un best-seller, y tampoco planeó serlo, pero sí es una buena trama de RPG.
- Gráficos mejorados que permiten apreciar de mejor manera cuál era el objetivo que se planteó el equipo diseñador en cuanto a gráficas, animaciones, expresiones faciales, etc.... Al menos en los modelos de los personajes principales.
- Una banda sonora que sólo puedo describir como espectacular y mi favorita de toda la franquicia (Pro-Tip: La canción del Ending está cortada en Spotify. Recomiendo escucharla en otros lugares para apreciarla completa).
- Ya no se necesita el mod Roses & Wine para disfrutar de la música.
- Extensión de juego de RPG clásico. Nada de 20 horas, acá puedes sacar fácilmente 100. Para los que gustan de eso (más de esto en las contras).
- Posibilidad de usar trucos que facilitan la experiencia de juego. Aunque recomiendo no usar ninguno, para disfrutar de este título tal como estaba diseñado.

Contras:
- Sistema de batalla complicado en demasía al principio, con eso de que las magias ahora son ítems que se consumen y que tienes que extraer ya no te dan ganas de usarlas, especialmente porque con el sistema de vínculo, puedes empezar a debilitar a tu personaje si lo usas. Aunque con el tiempo, una vez aprendido, se convierte en un elemento estratégico bien entretenido.
- El juego es largo, como todo JRPG clásico (y uno que otro moderno). Lo digo en los pros, pero también puede ser un contra si estás sometido a los rigores de la vida adulta.
- El juego tiene 'precio de Square Enix', y eso siempre es caro. Y no va a bajar pronto.

Dale una chance.
Es un buen Final Fantasy que te gustará.
O que odiarás.
Un classique qu'on redécouvre à chaque fois qu'on joue.

I loved this game as a kid growing up so I maybe have nostalgia glasses on but it's still one of my favourites, this remaster is a 3/10 game, and those 3 points go into it being a good platform to mod from. 

Once modded though it has been an excellent game and I've sunk 80 hours in to it already and am looking forward to more, the best mods are available on the forum QHIMM after a quick google and I'd recommend the Ragnarok mod as it completely changes the game.

In terms of it crashing, I had it constantly crashing until I disabled OneDrive, after that I haven't had a single crash.

* Disable OneDrive, either entirely or just on the game folder, it locks the files during uploading and will crash the game everytime. I had to exclude my folder C:\Users\%USER%\OneDrive\Documents\My Games\FINAL FANTASY VIII Remastered to get it to work.

column8:
一部以“爱情”为主题的最终幻想，充满着浪漫，科幻，唯美，悲伤气息的最终幻想。
距离最终幻想8的问世已经过了20余年，当时熬夜查阅各种资料通关的少年已成为家庭里的中流砥柱，而吸引我的也只是起唯美而哀伤的剧情，然而接触之后才发现游戏整个系统其实是前无古人后无来者的，放至22年的今日也是很新颖的。
游戏整体质量相对于7代有了明显提升，cg，建模有了大幅度改善，现在看也是一种观影的感受。然而整体游戏系统相对于7代以及以前的RPG有了大幅度革新，然而对于我来说因为没有仔细研究系统，甚至没有去打牌，所以这一部成了我玩过最难的一代最终幻想，最终boss也是靠了游戏内置工具才打过去，只能说是一件憾事了吧。
游戏剧情丝毫不逊色于7代，Quistis那明丽的出场笑容，华丽唯美的庆祝舞会，命中注定的舞蹈，性格迥异的同伴，诡谲怪异的魔女游行，梦中的前辈，魔女的骑士，至死不渝的爱恋，太空中的互诉衷肠，穿越时空的旅行，感人的重逢，最终的宴会，月夜下的相拥，宛如一场唯美的梦境。看似大团圆的结局下或许也是陷入循环的悲剧。
在时间的尽头，或许squall因为使用GF而失忆死去，只留下几乎遗忘了一切的Rinoa成为魔女，但在记忆深处，她任然渴望和心中的那个他于花海中重逢。
No matter whether Rinoa turn into Ultimecia in the.end，at least in the limited life of squall，they can have eyes on each other.

column8:
I've played Final Fantasy games since I was young...starting with the first one on NES. I stopped with X-2, because the series went downhill rocketship speed. So, I am very familiar with 1 - 10 and the side games too. To this day, Final Fantasy VIII is the only one I have not beaten...and there is a reason for this:

I WOULD NEVER EVER EVER RECOMMEND THIS GAME TO ANYONE!

Remastered (is it really?) or not....this game is still not worth playing. There is a reason for this, which I will get to. But lets start with why this game is bad but could have been good.

FF8 is good...on paper, but poor in execution. What I mean by this is if this was a pen and paper rpg, the junction system would work great. Perhaps if this was the first of the series, with classes, it would work ok. However, here...it is a monumental disaster. Connecting magic to your stats with a stack count of spells just makes the series garbage. It will prevent you from using your good magic from not wanting to lower your stats, and get the missing spells back (more on this coming...oh trust me on that!). So it becomes either a slogfest for physically attacking everything outright, or constantly weakening your guys to put out good magic damage, only to have to re-aquire spells. And the fact the game spits out so much junction info in the beginning at first is the sign the disaster is assured.

The characters suck and are uninteresting and annoying.

The game scales to your levels. So grinders beware.....as you get stronger, so does that little bug you faced in the beginning of the game. But yet you have to grind to raise your guardian forces (aka summons).

But now lets get to the real reason why this game is a complete turd....because it has always been a turd even back to the PSX days. See I remember getting this game the day it came out for PSX. I remember being at the front of the line with my full paid reserve ticket at Gamestop. And back then I even dreaded this command:

Draw

Draw is singlehandedly the stupidest idea in any RPG that I have ever experienced. If you don't know draw...this is how the magic system works:

You want fire, then good..go get it from certain enemies. But you have to "Draw" it out of them using the Draw command during the battle. However magic is limited in your inventory per character, and each has to draw separately. You can hold 100 of each spell. 

Big deal right? Just draw 100 out of each at once.

it doesn't work that way. When you draw you can either stock the spells for that character or instantly cast them. When you stock them...you will pull on average of everything about 4 at a time. The lower the spell, the more likely you will pull more. But something like Ultima...get ready for like 1 at a time. And these spells are used to adjust your stats...so you will want to draw out 100. And it takes forever.

And the fact that cheats are built into the game to fix this boring drawfest....that says a lot.

So, like I said...the idea is good. But the execution is flawed to crap. FF2 remaster fixed the issues with how that played....this remaster fixed nothing.

Don't play this one.

i think you'd probably have to be a masochist to enjoy this game. I literally had to use cheats to beat the final boss, and it was hard even with cheats. Somehow it one hit killed me when i had infinite HP. The final boss took me like 4 hours (with cheats on), even though i had little difficulty going through the rest of the game.

the user experience is abhorrent. the game will actively mess your builds so you'll be in the menues rearranging stuff most of the time. it's not a fun experience. i don't know why i play these games, to be honest.

it runs at 12 FPS in slow motion if you don't use the 3x boost.

the story is good. it has great action scenes with great cinematics.

it has interesting game mechanics, different from all other Final Fantasy games. But it's ruined by all the rest.

so just watch a let's play or cutscene video. whatever. i'm so done.

column8:
Short answer: It's good.
Long answer: This is the greatest game of all time to me. I've been playing FF8 since I was 4 and I'm 25 now so that goes to show that even after all the other games I've played, this is still #1 for me. Sure: the story is a bit confusing, there's so much stuff you wouldn't find without a guide, the main character is a downer (most of the time), the junctioning system is overpowering, you'll spend a huge chunk of time drawing magic, and if you learn the card game and spend hours and hours grinding, you go from overpowered to autonomous ultra instinct Goku killing 95% of enemies with one single hit no matter how many hit points they have. 
All that to say that this game is an experience. You learn to understand the main character. You see why he is the way that he is. You enjoy seeing side character's personalty's and the bond between them all. The love story portrayed between Squall and Rinoa showing opposites attracting. The satisfaction of defeating anything in your path because you grinded cards and manipulated the junction system to become basically unstoppable. The absolute thrill of getting that one card you spent multiple hours and dozens and dozens of restarts to try and get (there's a lot). The story can be a bit odd with plot holes but it creates discussion between what you think happened at a certain point and what someone else thinks. Every time you start a new game, you learn something new even after multiple play throughs. There's always different ways you can play certain characters because of the junctioning system so it never feels like the same game twice.
Is this game everybody's cup of tea? No, I completely understand that it's not for everyone. That being said, it's a game I'd recommend to someone if they're interested in spending a little time looking up how certain things work and what does what; then seeing them eliminate every enemy in their path with extreme prejudice and destroying people in card games while the world ends.

column8: It's a "good" game. The worst part about it are it's battle systems that try to ruin it. The drawing mechanic incentives to not use, but stockpile mass amounts of spells that the use of lower your stats through the junction system, which replaces equipment/accessories from earlier titles. Guardian forces are a good mechanic, a great step up from FF6's espers, but it does make all the playable party feel the same other than their limit moves. Guardian forces is how your party will use/learn abilities such as mug, encounter-none, etc. which again is hindered by the draw mechanic to fully open up their potential. You know a game has missed it's mark when the optional card game within itself is the best part of the whole experience. 8 is a great time, if not a tad monotonous by the 15-20 hour mark, especially if going for all achievements. FF7 and 9 are more worth your time for the PS1 era games.

column8:
Final Fantasy VIII Remastered para PC es una versión remasterizada del juego de rol clásico de Square Enix. Esta versión mejorada incluye una mejoría significativa en la calidad de los gráficos, así como una nueva interfaz de usuario y controles optimizados para una mejor experiencia de juego. Además, se incluyen nuevas funciones como el modo de velocidad ajustable, el modo de batalla mejorado y la eliminación de la limitación de los puntos de habilidad.

La jugabilidad es fluida y divertida. Los controles se han optimizado para una experiencia de juego mucho más intuitiva, y el nuevo modo de velocidad ajustable permite a los jugadores acelerar o ralentizar el juego según sus preferencias. El modo de batalla mejorado también ofrece una mayor profundidad en las estrategias de combate.

La dificultad es moderada. La IA de los enemigos es inteligente y desafiante, pero no es imposible de superar. La dificultad también se puede ajustar para adaptarse a los niveles de habilidad de los jugadores.

Final Fantasy VIII Remastered ofrece una cantidad impresionante de contenido. El juego cuenta con una campaña principal de más de 40 horas y una gran variedad de misiones secundarias y minijuegos. Además, hay una amplia gama de personajes y armas y una gran cantidad de contenido adicional para descubrir.

La calidad de los gráficos de la versión remasterizada es excelente si tienes un PC con bajas especificaciones. Los gráficos han sido mejorados significativamente para ofrecer una experiencia visual de primera clase. Los entornos y los personajes están detallados y vibrantes, y los efectos de luz y sombras son impresionantes .... pero se realista no son del nivel de los juegos de ultima generación.

La historia es profunda y emocionante. El juego sigue a Squall Leonhart, un estudiante de la Academia Balamb Garden, mientras lucha para salvar el mundo de la destrucción. El juego ofrece una narrativa interesante y una trama llena de giros y vueltas.

Final Fantasy VIII Remastered ofrece una ambientación emocionante. El juego se desarrolla en un mundo colorido y variado, con entornos vibrantes y una variedad de personajes interesantes. El diseño de los escenarios es impresionante y ofrece una sensación de realismo.

Los efectos son impresionantes. Los efectos de sonido y luz son ricos y vibrantes, y los efectos de batalla son emocionantes. Los efectos especiales también son impresionantes, y contribuyen a la atmósfera del juego.

La banda sonora es magnífica (siempre lo ha sido y espero que siempre lo sea). La música es variada y emocionante, y se adapta perfectamente a los entornos y situaciones del juego. La música también ayuda a crear una atmósfera intensa y emocionante.

Las voces son convincentes y expresivas. Los actores de doblaje han hecho un trabajo excelente al interpretar los personajes, y los diálogos están bien escritos.

    [*]Dificultad / IA: 6.5/10
    [*]Contenido: 7.0/10

column8:
There's a lot to like about FF8 Remastered. The differences between versions feel so minute that if you all ready have the original game I really don't see the reason to buy this. though. It's the same game, just some models look better. Lots of models, including ones you're supposed to talk to for moving the plot along, were just taken from the original game, and that can be jarring when they're standing right next to the new ones. 

It's hard to recommend one way or the other, without knowing if you're into in-depth micromanagement of stats, magic, summons, items, and cards. The story is okay, and the battles are okay. Most of the playable cast is kinda bland, honestly. But if you don't like micromanagement you're probably not going to enjoy Final Fantasy 8, no matter what the models look like or what version you play. You'll be spending plenty of time in the menus setting up. Most of the fun for battles is seeing how your builds play out in different scenarios with different boss challenges. FF7's Materia is much easier to understand, at least. There is a learning curve, and the tutorials this game is infamous for really do not explain the real depths of the system.

That being said, I think I prefer the original FF8 to the remaster. I like FF8's base gameplay, and I feel like I'm the one solitary fan of the junction system some days. I give it a thumbs up only because exploiting junctioning to rule the battlefield is fun for me. <3

column8:
The most unique and most underrated Final Fantasy. 

FF8 is built different on every front. The junction system is unlike anything before or since. The setting is modern mixed with futuristic. It does not go out of its way to explain every detail to the player. Some things just are because they are. The world feels less like a backdrop for the game to take place in. The characters are teenagers, and generally act like it. Not stereotypes like on TV, but young adults figuring it out. it has always been refreshing when compared to the other series. The music also plays a role, most of it being slower paced with some high flying music for the big action events. The game's vocal track exist within the game world, and carries some narrative weight. Which sets it apart from the other titles. 

The Remaster updates the game, and makes it very playable. There is full native controller support inside steam. Which is very welcome after the nightmare of FF7. There's also a full set of boosts, and cheats, but it is mostly unneeded. This was never a challenging game. Its core systems have always lent themselves to breaking whatever difficulty the game may have. 

The most improved part are the character models. They more than make up for the slightly fuzzy backgrounds. The improved models made me appreciate just how much work went into the games animations.  Characters are packed full of small moments. Flailing their hands. Stamping their feet. Primping for a hug that'll never come. 

Overall, while FF7 took the series forward and FF9 tried to recapture the series roots, FF8 was always did its own thing. Yet looking at the series as a whole, one could argue FF8 distilled the overall essence of the series down to its core namesake.

THIS is how you make a remaster! Final Fantasy VIII is a modern classic, hailing from one of the JRPG golden ages of the late 90s. The remaster gives the original PS1 game a fresh coat of paint and a bevy of quality of life upgrades and boosters, making it much more accessible to modern gamers. The game has never looked better, and as someone who has been playing Final Fantasy VIII on-and-off for the past 20+ years since its original release, I can definitively say that this remaster is the BEST version of the game. 

How much you enjoy Final Fantasy VIII will largely depend on how much you like JRPGs, specifically: complex systems, menus upon menus upon menus of stat and item modifications, melodramatic teenagers, an off-beat sense of humor, well-developed characters, oodles of side quests, and an unapologetically difficult barrage of boss battles with very little in the way of hand-holding. This game was made during an era when RPGs were infuriatingly hard and strategy guides were basically essential. Many players either love or hate Final Fantasy VIII. I'm firmly in the love camp, and I'm confident that those who are up for the challenge will love it too. Others may find it too intimidating - the game's Junction system is famously one of the franchise's most complicated - but the remaster does a lot to provide quality of life perks that reduce both grind and frustration. Even if you already played FFVIII the first time around, it's worth it giving this remaster a go. Squall never looked so good, and the 3x speed boost is a godsend. I power-leveled my characters to LV 100 in less than an hour (try doing that in the original PS1 version!). 

For me, the game's sometimes tedious grind is well worth it. Final Fantasy VIII is epic in a way that few games are. There are so many standout moments - the amphibious attack on Dollet, the Timber train mission, the battle of the mobile gardens, launching yourself into SPACE to revive your comatose girlfriend, the jaw-dropping final dungeon that sets the standard for spooky final boss showdowns. The campaign is hard, but it is never boring and always FUN. It's a superb game that pushed the PS1 to its limit but never took itself too seriously. It's grand, it's weird, it's sometimes confusing, but above all it's fun, and isn't that why we play games?

On a technical level, the game runs like quicksilver. I played it on the Steam Deck and encountered no problems - a pleasant surprise given Square-Enix's shaky track record of successfully porting console games to PC. I'm happy to report that the Final Fantasy VIII remaster plays beautifully and never crashed once. (I wish all FF remasters were like this!)   

I grew up with this game, and I recognize I'm biased. But I honestly think that the remaster also has something to offer to new gamers with fresh eyes. If any of the above piques your interest, then give it a go. There are worse ways to spend $20 (even less if you get it on sale!). Final Fantasy VIII is the FF I remember most fondly. I think you will too.

column8:
I want to recommend this because it's one of my all-time favorite games, but this version is plagued with crash issues. I was able to muster through the majority of them, but now that I've reached Esthar on disc 3, I can't seem to make it through the city without it crashing no matter what I do, so I guess that's it for my adventure for now.

If you want an idea of how much I struggled with crashes, check this: Steam says I have played it for 41.7 hours so far. The in-game save clock says 31:31, and there's no way I spent more than an hour total reloading for RNG / card reasons.

Play ANY other version except this one!

FOLLOW UP: I bought a Steam Deck and decided to try it once more on that rather than a PC, and I'll be damned, it has run amazingly without any issues on the Steam Deck, so I'm actually finishing the game. Though it still hasn't changed my mind regarding this review; not like everyone can just drop their PC for a while to buy a Steam Deck just to complete this game. All I know is that because of this, it's likely either a Windows issue in general, Windows 11 issue specifically, or AMD Windows driver issue. Who knows...

column8: 高中时候玩的游戏，怀旧一下，非常推荐，王菲最高
ミサイル基地のBGH251F2等の戦闘後、エラーが出て強制終了されます。

※ 파판8 게임 자체에 대한 평가는 일절 배제하고 리마스터에 대한 평가만 씁니다.

외주 줘서 만들어서 그런지는 모르겠는데, 리마스터 퀄리티가 매우 처참함
캐릭터 3D 폴리곤은 나름 업스케일링이 되어 그럭저럭 봐줄만 하지만, 내가 노안이 온건가 의심하며 눈을 비비게 만드는 배경이 문제.

인게임 CG 동영상도, 배경 그림도 죄다 옛날 PS1 시절 그대로라 거의 산업재해 수준의 눈뽕을 주는데 그와중에 애매하게 업스케일링 된 캐릭들이 자글자글한 맵을 뛰어댕기는걸 보고 있으면 참을수 없는 괴리감과 기괴함에 모니터에서 눈을 돌리게 만든다.

이래놓고 20년전 게임을 정가 25,900원이나 받아쳐먹다니 양심이 없는 놈들이다.

I had an INCREDIBLE amount of hesitation about this version after combing through the reviews. To say I was on the fence about this is an incredible understatement. I have fond memories of this game, I absolutely love the story and the unique battle mechanics. Once you get the hang of things it becomes incredibly addictive. 

But this remaster is positively bogged down by negative reviews. I have to say, after putting the game through its paces, those negative reviews are hardly accurate. Most seem to echo the same sentiments they got from other reviews and barely give the game a chance. 

For the time the game came out, the backgrounds and cut scenes truly shine. On modern hardware their age is certainly more noticeable but that does not take away from their charm. It is still a style that still stands out on its own and coupled with an appropriate dose of imagination, brings a vivid and unique world to life. 

One of the most common critiques I see about this version is "ThE NEW MoDels cLaSh wITh ThE OlD BaCkGrouNDS!" which is just plain silly in my opinion. It sounds like people who lack a creative way to accurately critique something...just feeling sour the developers did not put something NEW that THEY wanted in their product. 

Here's the thing, if you polish up the backgrounds you take away even more of the style of the original. A REMASTER does not always need to redo everything. In fact, that can often be a bad idea. Because then you are truly just making something new from the groundup. A lot of Final Fantasy games have gone this route, and while it can be cool and stand out on their own, it is often a COMPLETELY redone product, just recycling a script and dialogue at that point.

Or you come out with a case like the recent FF7 re-imagining. Which again, while cool, becomes its own beast. Not EXACTLY scratching the same itch as the original, but definitely still cashing in on nostalgia. 

This Remaster keeps the charm of the old game by sticking with the older backgrounds. And I do not believe it takes away either the "Wow" factor of the updated models, nor tarnish the art style of the backgrounds. They do go together rather well. It certainly is noticeable but y'know what? Even with the older models it was OBVIOUS when the background was of a different caliber and when a 3D video went into motion. It wasn't a seamless blend then, and it still isn't a seamless blend BUT THAT HAS A LOVELY FEELING TO IT! 

It takes you back to the older days, in much the same way that we all adore and love pixel art. The era FF8 originally came out in had a beautiful renaissance and growth, a deep evolution that sprung fast, as all technology was at the time. When you compare FF7, FF8, and FF9 on a graphical standpoint, they are all deeply different. And having grown up through that era, I have a sentimental attachment that just pushes my nostalgia high to a dizzying height. 

Especially if you snag the game while it is on sale, it is well worth every penny. I enjoy having a way to play this on my PC. That alone is worth the money ((Yeah yeah, emulators are a thing, but this is just handy and cool to show my friends what I am playing, post in discussions about it, and chat while I play with them, getting achievements for my collection is also always a plus)) 

I don't need a complete redo to make this a worth while product, because it is what it is, a polished Remaster. You don't need to rewrite the wheel here. 

It has fantastic additions that speed up the more monotonous aspects, and help get those of us that have already gone toe to toe with the beginning get into some of the more meatier bits faster. The music still hits hard, sounds great, and puts me into my happy place. I've heard this soundtrack way too many times to count, and nothing sounds off or peculiar. 

The cut scenes still play accurately, still look gorgeous, and I have not run into A SINGLE BUG that has been mentioned in some reviews. Some of these nightmare bugs were reported to start as soon as the Fire Cave where you get Ifrit. But I am happy to say I am far deeper in than that and have not had a single crash, a single horrible FPS moment, or honestly anything that has slowed down my enjoyment or immersion. 

Take this game for a spin, relive the magic, junction up and "Don't be Afraid" to join the fight!

column8: El Squall pixelado molaba más, por lo demás está bien, tal vez algún que otro logro más hubiese estado bien.

Imagine being Square after making FFVII. You've just made what many consider to be the greatest game of all time. You could probably coast off of the success of that game for decades. So what do you do?

Make something completely fucking different.

For this reason alone, I respect the hell out of this game. Mechanically, it's like no turn-based RPG I've ever played. Story-wise, it's a batshit insane mess of ideas baked anywhere from fully to barely at all. Graphically, it's stunning for its time. It's a hell of a follow-up to FFVII, even if it doesn't pull everything it tries to do off.

The junction system takes a while to understand, and the magic system takes a lot of getting used to. Combat can be tedious due to the need to draw magic from enemies, and the lack of guidance makes it easy to end up building your party like shit. But if you put the time in, the mechanics of this game are really engaging. I had a blast trying to figure out what kind of party I wanted to build with the GFs I had, and it was like Christmas every time I got a new one.

The story isn't as good as FFVII, but it's charming. There are a lot of poignant moments, and the main cast is fun. It's not the best RPG story out there, but it's a weird, ambitious adventure.

Give this one a try. It takes a while to get going, but if you give it a chance, there's nothing else truly like it.

Pensaba escribir esta reseña en Inglés para que le llegue a más gente, pero estoy tan indignado, que te lo voy a escribir en perfecto Español Latino. Más precisamente en Argento: 	[i]"Este Remastered es una bazofia, un rejunté putrefacto de basura que da asco de sólo verlo y de horrorizarte de como se puede llegar a este punto (y ser vendido). Más preocupante aún la gente que lo defiende".	[/i]

Así es, este intento de Remaster es un insulto al título en cuestión (un clásico), a tu billetera y tu inteligencia. Es así nomas, lo quieras reconocer o no.

[b]Paso a explicarte: [/b]
[h1]1:[/h1] Primero que nada que absolutamente toda la totalidad del juego (Cinemáticas y Gameplay) están en 4:3, así que vas a disfrutar del efecto pantalla cubo en todo su esplendor. Y antes de que empiecen a llorar "p-pero es normal porque el j-juego es viejo y antes.. "Silencio ignorante!"
No hay ningún motivo valido para semejante vagancia de parte de Square Enix y Dotemu para largar el juego así. Te digo más, La versión del 2013 (acá en steam) tiene una opción oficial para "Estirar" la imagen y dejar de lado esas 2 columnas negras horripilantes que tanto defienden algunos. Te repito, la versión del 2013 tiene una opción para que sea "verdadera" pantalla completa. No es perfecta, pero es muchísimo a no tener nada.

Continuó. Fue la misma comunidad la que también desarrollo la forma con programas e inyectores, poder lograr un efecto verdadero pantalla completa de todo lo que ves. Nuevamente, no es perfecto por qué aún quedan algunas líneas oscuras en los contornos. PERO es ALGO! Y lo hizo la comunidad. ¿Y vos me vas a decir que estos sin vergüenza no van a poder siquiera hacer algo para que se justifique el precio de esta "Remaster". 

No tienen perdón. Incluso no les costaba nada poner al menos imagenes (a modo arcade de calle) para tapar las barras negras. Aunque sea ahí, podría decir bueno, algo hicieron. Que sería, lo básico. 

[h1]2:[/h1] Cinematicas (FMVs) de identica calidad al original, mejor dicho, sin ninguna mejora realmente notable. Actualmente existen cantidad de usuarios en Youtube que se dedican de forma gratuita -y amor al material con el que trabajan- con videos super detallados en 60fps 4k y en alta definición, con ayuda de IA. Y de vuelta.. ¿Me vas a decir que estos imbéciles no pueden hacer lo mismo? 

Te dejo un ejemplo así te caes de culo: https://youtu.be/rL3Zvyrvk4w

[h1]3:[/h1] Fondos y escenarios de combate estropeados. Sí, no solo porque lo único que hicieron fue aplicar un "Filtro" del tipo bilinear para interpolar la imagen (lo único que hace es que se vea borroso) sino que al hacerlo se ven de forma peor que los originales. Simplemente porque si bien los otros están pixeleados, le daba cierto cariño visual, pero acá queda todo borroneado. 
De nuevo. Una remaster que ni tocaron las texturas de escenarios y fondos. PERO se tiraron un filtrazo! Unos genios! Habrán estado 4 años buscando el filtro adecuado.

O sea, flaco! ¿Modificaron las texturas de los modelos de personajes pero fueron incapaces de trabajar el resto de las texturas? Claro, pobrecitos se quedaron seguro sin tiempo, pero tranqui, les dejamos este filtrazo que existe desde 1997. 

[h1]4:[/h1] Fps bajos en combate. Y por las dudas antes les digo: "CALLATE!". No empiecen a llorar de nuevo con "p-pero Águila, el juego es viejo y andaba así en su versión original de PSX!" ¿Y? ¿Qué pasa no le da el cerebro o la actitud para al menos boostear el gameplay a 30 fps?. Sin vergüenzas. 
Y antes que nieguen la efectividad de mayores cuadros por segundo los invito a ver lo que sería el juego andando a 60 fps. Link: https://youtu.be/8ryH9-BBQqM

¿Una hermosura verdad? Y les digo más. La excusa de "no pero el juego es viejo y...blabla" se les cae. Ya fueron cantidad de veces que fue la misma comunidad la que tuvo que salir a laburar, investigar y hacer ingeniería interna para demostrar que si se puede correr juegos viejos a 60 FPS (más cuadros por segundo), cuando del otro lado dicen imposible (usuarios y desarrolladores).
Algunos ejemplos que me vienen a la mente ahora son Command & Conquer Tiberian Sun, C&C Generals. Ah, y adivinen cuál otro ejemplo: El Final Fantasy IX de la mano del MEMORIA ENGINE. ¿Increíble verdad?

[u]Nota:[/u] Y si me vienen con el cuento de "Ah, pero Squarenosoft perdió el acceso al código del engine original entonces..". Escuchame, si vos sos empleado mío y me decís que perdiste o eliminaste el código fuente del juego, te pego tal patada en el orto (ida y vuelta) que cuando volvés me hiciste un FAN MADE REMASTER como el que hicieron con FFIX llamado "MOGURI MOD". 

[i]El MOD en cuestión trae excelentes texturas, soporte para widescreen, modos de combate, banda sonora mejorada, fixes y cantidad de cosas de calidad.. GRATIS.	[/i]

Y si no estás conforme como en tu cara te muestran la importancia que le dan a tu juego o franquicia favorita, te digo, que con la guita que tienen no hay nada que les impida hacer ingeniería inversa para lograrlo. Por favor, dejen de creerles todo y defender lo indefendible. 

[b]Dato util: [/b]El juego anda bajo una interfaz de 60 fps, Gameplay en Mundo a 30 fps y combates a 15/16fps.



[h1]Conclusión Final: 	[/h1]
Lo único que tiene de bueno (hasta ahí nomas) son los modelos apeeeenas twekeados para que se vean más "redonditos" y las texturas de personajes y GF's (guardian forces). Pero son súper simples, cumplen y nada más. De ninguna manera esto puede llegar a valer X3 o X4 el precio que piden. 
Como siempre, es la Comunidad la que sale a sacar texturas mejores y cantidad de mos para intentar salvar un título, y en este caso, ni así fue suficiente. 

Háganse un favor propio y a la comunidad de su juego, no compren esta bazofia e insulto a todo lo bueno. Mejor vayan con el FF8 del 2013 que tiene cantidad de mods ya establecidos para mejorar la fidelidad visual y encima con mejores prestaciones de fábrica.

FF8 is such a weird one to me. Up to this point, I've enjoyed the FF games that are not well-regarded within the community (FF2, 3, and 5). But unfortunately it seems FF8 won't be joining the "I actually enjoyed it camp" for me. Far from it actually.

[h1]Likes:[/h1]
If FF7 showcases how cinematic video games can be, FF8 took that idea and cranks it up to 11. This is reflected in its gameplay, with Squall's basic attack and some Limit Breaks being real-time, reminiscent of Sabin's Blitz in FF6.

The visual is simply amazing for the time, I can't believe this was made in the span of 2 years after FF7 was released. The Remaster did botch the backgrounds but the art direction, character model fidelity and FMV is miles ahead better than FF7 did 2 years prior. The idea of blending real-time gameplay with FMV is also pretty novel. The technology to render a lot of busy things in the background wasn't quite there yet, so it's pretty clever how they could overcome the technology limitations. This came at the side effect of locking the frame rates to 15 FPS, but it's a fair trade off I'd say.

If there's anything I like the most about FF8, it's the music. I'm not the biggest Uematsu fan out there, but FF8 is easily my most favourite work I've heard from him. The Extreme in particular, while I still prefer Soken's arrangement in XIV, is simply amazing.

[h1]Dislikes:[/h1]
Boy, I don't know where to actually begin.

The story is a complete mess, if I have to summarise it in one word: it's Nomura weird, the kind you see in Kingdom Hearts. There's a lot of plot holes and weirdness that makes it hard for me to like FF8. But I think the biggest problem for me is Squall himself. Him and his angst one liners might be relatable when I was younger, but now I see him as insensitive. He has a very unlikeable personality for me to be able to connect to him, and by extension the game's story as a whole. For a game being about love, I don't buy Rinoa and Squall's romance story.  One positive point for FF8 despite its tendency to throw bizarre terminologies at you though, is unlike XIII, the majority of the story is told on a chronological order.

Despite many people hating on the enemy level scaling, I actually think it's pretty interesting. I also love how you can break the game from the start with the Triple Triad cards. My biggest problem though is how the Junction system creeps over the loot and equipment aspect of the game. Equipment is completely replaced with Magic and Triple Triad cards, which I think is a complete mistake. My second biggest problem though, is how you are essentially leveling up and building Guardian Forces instead of your character. This makes it a huge chore whenever you have to switch party members. 

This should be fairly obvious by now, but the fact the game has so many gameplay elements tied to the frame rate is horrible. While I enjoy the real time elements especially Squall's Limit Break, having to do it in 15 FPS feels terrible.

----------

I think the highs of FF8 are really high. But the lows drag the game so much that prevents me from liking FF8. There's a lot of good ideas here marred with terrible execution. I think more than anything, FF8 needs a complete remake.

There's a lot of plot holes and weirdness that makes it hard for me to like FF8. But I think the biggest problem for me is Squall himself. Him and his angst one liners might be relatable when I was younger, but now I see him as insensitive. He has a very unlikeable personality for me to be able to connect to him, and by extension the game's story as a whole. For a game being about love, I don't buy Rinoa and Squall's romance story.  One positive point for FF8 despite its tendency to throw bizarre terminologies at you though, is unlike XIII, the majority of the story is told on a chronological order.

Despite many people hating on the enemy level scaling, I actually think it's pretty interesting. I also love how you can break the game from the start with the Triple Triad cards. My biggest problem though is how the Junction system creeps over the loot and equipment aspect of the game. Equipment is completely replaced with Magic and Triple Triad cards, which I think is a complete mistake. My second biggest problem though, is how you are essentially leveling up and building Guardian Forces instead of your character. This makes it a huge chore whenever you have to switch party members. 

This should be fairly obvious by now, but the fact the game has so many gameplay elements tied to the frame rate is horrible. While I enjoy the real time elements especially Squall's Limit Break, having to do it in 15 FPS feels terrible.

----------

I think the highs of FF8 are really high. But the lows drag the game so much that prevents me from liking FF8. There's a lot of good ideas here marred with terrible execution. I think more than anything, FF8 needs a complete remake.

column8:
Un bon remasteur, très proche du jeu d'origine.

En effet, peu changement excepté pour les personnages qui sont maintenant en HD. Les menus sont bien plus jolies et plus lisibles que ceux de la Playstation tout en gardant leur style d'origine. Bref, le jeu ne vieillit pas grâce à tout ces petits plus.

Cependant, quelques censures visuelles inutiles font leurs apparitions mais on n'y prête pas vraiment compte. On peut aussi ajouter que certaines cartes du Triple Triad ont vu leur design revu. À noter que les arrières plans ont pris un petit coup de ride et l'anti-aliasing n'a malheureusement pas pu faire de miracle mais cela reste, dans l'ensemble, bien plus beau que le titre d'origine.

Au final, si vous voulez découvrir ou redécouvrir ce final fantasy tel qu'il était, c'est pour vous. De plus, vous pourrez toujours activer des cheats pour vous aider et vous simplifiez la vie ou les ignorer totalement pour faire le jeu normalement, et honnêtement ce n'est pas une mauvaise idée car cela ne ruine en rien l'immersion. En revanche, dommage que la combinaison de touche qui vous permettent de modifier les commandes de la manette s'affichent continuellement sur l'écran titre. Cela encombre inutilement le menu principal et casse un peu le sentiment de nostalgie...

column8:
[code]Final Fantasy VIII might be a bit rough around the edges, partially thanks to this suboptimal “Remaster” version, but it still has a lot of heart and quite a few memorable moments[/code]

Following up one of [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/dreamylotus/recommended/39140/]the most iconic JRPGs ever created[/url]? Definitely not an easy task - and it’s fair to say that [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] didn’t succeed at it. However, that doesn’t mean that it should be entirely disregarded – even if its own publisher seems to think so: While [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] is set for an entire trilogy (!) of high-budget remakes, [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] only got this one remaster, which is somehow even worse in parts than the original 1999 PS1 game.

Before I’ll move on to the various problems of the “Remaster” itself though, let’s talk about the game at its core. [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] continues a development that started with [i]Final Fantasy VI[/i] and brings a lot of technical progress to its world of fantasy: trains, space ships, TV stations, gunblades – you name it. There are still quite a few fantasy elements present, from sorceresses to various monsters, mind you. But we’re far from earlier [i]Final Fantasy[/i] settings, which – technology-wise - offered an airship at most.

The protagonist of [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] is Squall Leonhart, a 17-year-old lone wolf and mercenary.  Yes, this does sound a lot like the previous protagonist Cloud Strife, anti-hero and also mercenary. But while Cloud is still a beloved hero to this day, Squall should prove to be more of a more divisive character, a fine example for a “love him or hate him”-protagonist. The reason for that would be his anti-social “lone wolf” attitude, which is turned up to 11. Be it treating his party members coldly, reacting cynically or not reacting at all, Squall sure comes across like a jerk in many situations – his catchphrase isn’t “whatever” for nothing.

Unsurprisingly, Squall does undergo a character arc throughout the game. Most of it is part of a romantic subplot, which might even be the core of [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i]’s story. This alone must be acknowledged already, considering this is the first time [i]Final Fantasy[/i] really focusses on a love story (and in 1999 no less!). It’s a bold choice for the time and it certainly paved the way for later (love) stories like [i]Final Fantasy X[/i]. Unfortunately, though, while I approve of the attempt itself, the romantic subplot turns out to be as underwhelming as Squall’s character arc.

This can mostly be attributed to the fact that neither the relationship nor Squall’s character develop naturally. Instead, it feels more forced than anything, as if someone suddenly flipped a switch to make characters behave differently. Considering the length of [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] and the huge amount of story-related scenes, it’s disappointing to see how abrupt and unnatural some developments are introduced in this regard. [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] handled the character arc of its protagonist a lot better (partially because Cloud actually had some character development) and even gave him a (traumatic) reason as to why he behaved the way he did.

That said, Squall’s attitude and the forced love story aren’t the only problems concerning [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i]’s plot. I can only describe it as a plot that’s consistently trying to sabotage itself thanks to various story decisions. Most of the party members don’t have any real backstory ([spoiler]as they all (!) grew up in the same orphanage[/spoiler]) which is explained by a poor plot device [spoiler]selective memory loss[/spoiler], the villain’s only characterization amounts to “is evil” ([spoiler]because the game suddenly switches villains[/spoiler]) and some developments are just abandoned ([spoiler]NORG turning into a cocoon, that’s it[/spoiler]) or barely explained ([spoiler]Why are monsters falling from the moon?[/spoiler]). 

That said, beyond all these criticisms, I do have to point out that [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] features quite a few memorable scenes. They might not all fit together due to the mess that the plot ultimately becomes, but although rarely, [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] does offer some great story moments – partially thanks to it’s mix of real-time gameplay and FMV backgrounds. Scenes like fighting on a rope while swinging across a raging battleground are great and memorable. The pressure of saving innocent lives while under a time limit as missiles are about to be fired. Hijacking a personal train to fight an empire. Those are great – I just wished the overarching plot didn’t drag them down.

Moving on, let’s talk about the gameplay. [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] introduces one of the best virtual card games with “Triple Triad”. Thank you [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i]!

…okay, there’s a bit more than that.  [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] once again features the usual: an explorable world map with dungeons and towns, boss fights and a lot of random encounters. The ATB system makes a return as well as Limit Breaks– although they sometimes offer QTEs for higher damage this time around. The biggest gameplay change of [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] is the so-called “Junction System” however, which is simultaneously overtutorialized and underexplained. Basically, your character gets stronger by equipping GFs (unfortunate abbreviation for “Guardian Forces”, basically summons from earlier [i]Final Fantasy[/i] games) and magic spells (which have to be “drawn” from enemies and can’t be bought) in order to raise individual stats.

This Junction System is as divisive as the plot of [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] – some people love the amount of customization it offers, others think it’s too complicated. Considering how in-depth the system goes, I can’t offer a write-up here, so let me just say this: I got by fine by just letting the game auto-equip my characters for the most part. I do find it questionable that most of the Guardian Forces, the heart of the Junction System, are missable – only three out of sixteen (!) Guardian Forces are obtained as part of the story. I also feel the constant need to draw magic & switch Junctions between party member swas quite a hassle.

Lastly, as you might I recall, I previously mentioned that this remaster of [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] is somehow even worse in parts than the original 1999 PS1 game. There’s an entire [url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ch_xNzDk6aY]12 minute Digital Foundry analysis[/url] out there if you prefer more details, but here's the short version: Menus that used to run at 60fps are running at 16fps in this remaster, making some of the Limit Break QTEs harder to perform. Character and enemy models received an HD makeover but the (battle) backgrounds and world map did not – they merely got a smoothing filter applied. This leads to an ugly mix of HD characters running around in front of a blurry, pixelized PS1 background, as the two levels of detail clash. Upscaled backgrounds would’ve been the solution here. And lastly, the original graphics mode from the 2013 PC port is missing. In order to fix some of these issues, try some of these mods mentioned in the [url= https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Final_Fantasy_VIII_Remastered#Graphical_Enhancement_Mods]PcGamingWiki[/url].

However, there is one reason why this remaster is probably still the best version of [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] to play today: the boosters. With just one button press, you can speed up the game, disable random encounters or temporarily enable combat buffs – all of which greatly improved my gameplay experience and saved me from some possible frustrations.

Concluding, if you’re a fan interested in trying out one of the more divisive [i]Final Fantasy[/i] titles, this is the way to go. [i]Final Fantasy VIII[/i] might be a rough experience at times, but it still offers some memorable moments and - even better- [url=https://youtu.be/vuB5NSuF2U8]another fantastic soundtrack[/url].

This was my main game for 10 years! Took me 10 years to beat it, because my final disc was completely scratched. A well rounded turn-based game that deserved a real Re-Master. This isn't bad if its your 1st time or collecting. Once you've figure out the mechanics of the game, you'll be given a group of characters with a great story. 

Plenty of bosses to challenge. Loads of magic and limit-break moves to use. Even a card game built-in for a change of pace. After you beat it once, you might find a reason to go back more than twice. Give FFVIII a real REMASTER.

I've done multiple rounds of troubleshooting - I'll change my review if I can find a way to fix it, but it's footwork on my part. So far: restarting, adjusting to different resolution settings, updating drivers.

I was getting into it at this point as some plot points started to connect, so it's a big let down for a long-time fan, and I truly wanted to continue this game.

Not worth your money, find another way to play FFVIII.

column8: War schon immer mein liebster Teil, die Umsetzung ist einfach der Hammer

(SPOILERS BELLOW)

One of the wackiest stories in FF, if not in JRPG's in general, if you like to play games for the story you will probably love it or hate it, I personally really liked the story, the characters are also great speacially Squall, seeing him mature as a person and growing from someone who is very closed off towards other people to learning that he isn't alone and that he can count on others is really satisfying, although his character development is a slow burn, so he may be really annoying towards the begning of the game.

The best way I can describe  the overall story is that it is a coming of age story but with a lot of wacky stuff going on,  like soceress planning world domination and other sorceress from the future planning to compress time and stuff. 

As for the gameplay, the Junction system really isn't for everyone,   I didn't like it very much and it took a long time for me to get it, and I still think I don't understand it 100%. That being said the animations are great for a PS1 game, I really liked the Limit Breaks specifically, some of them were really funny (Like Rinoa's with Angelo) and others were really badass and cool looking (Like Squall's Lion Heart specifically). 

You have to grind a lot in this game, specially for the spells, but it is possible to get them without a lot of grinding, but I only learned that towards the end of disc 3 lol.

Overall,  if you don't mind the junction system, I really recommend it, it isn't the best FF game out there, but it is special in its own crazy way ... whatever.

If you are looking for a typical JRPG, this is not your game, but if you enjoy JRPGs and appreciate fresh approaches to the genre, play this game. The remastered version has made only minor changes to the overall experience.

The story in this game has incredible depth, and the main characters are all memorable.

Final Fantasy VIII is not the best Final Fantasy there is, and it doesn't have to be. It's true that there are lot of weird things in this game; the plot, the design, junction system, characters... And yet... It has it's own charm. 
FFVIII has it own nostalgic value. Following VII, it had some big shoes to fill, and in some areas, it did. Mostly on the looks departement. It looked sooooo much prettier than VII did, and the character's were much more expressive with their movements. Summoning animations are gorgeous, and the monster designs are great.
The gmaeplay itself is basic turn based RPG, with the weirdest equipment system ever. Junction system is something you either love or hate. I personally hate it. Being sucker for old school RPG's, and job system, I want my character's to get better with leveling and fancy new gear, not sucking up magic over and over and over again. And because of the junction system, there really isn't any variability with the characters.
The story is... Weird. Still to this day I'm really not sure, WHAT it is about. The only interesting story we actually get, [spoiler] is from a magical flashbacks of this random guy, who is actually the best character in the game, and you only get to play as him for like, three or four times?!?!?[/spoiler]
Completing this game was an okay ride. The achievements weren't that hard, but it's not a bad thing. Sometimes more casual achievement hunt is refreshing. Yet I'm surprised that some of the stuff in this game didn't get their own achievements, yet they'd be achievement worthy.
If you grew up with the original FFVIII, Remastered is a good quick hop on the nostalgia train. If you're new to the game series, I'd say, try it, if you're really curious. Otherwise, check out the older titles.
...
...
...
Oh yeah, this game gave us the Triple Triad... Forget everything I said, perfect 5/7, masterpiece!

Fresh off of Final Fantasy VII's tail, I knew I had to play the follow up. I had to know how this next entry would build on top of the masterclass piece of work that was VII. So, after finishing it, is it any good? ...Yeah.

I say that a bit reluctantly because this game has a lot of misses. The junctioning system (at least to me) just felt unnecessarily deep, and the magic system was tedious, having magic act as consumable items rather than a permanent spell that could be cast. The main party other than the protagonist Squall, have no worthwhile backstories and development. They're just kinda there because they're simply part of Squall's posse. I hate to say it, but even their given backstories feel like the writers said "this is convenient, lets have it be this way." Not to get into spoilers, but the antagonist(s?) aren't all that great either. Not as compelling as Sephiroth, where you understand his motives and backstory (because he actually has one...).

With that being said, there are things about VIII that I really do like! Cloud from VII is a fantastic protagonist, and his growth was great. Squall was just like Cloud, but a bit better to me. Yeah, he's brooding and not very likable, he slowly changes and evolves into a character who is able to shed some bad habits. The music as per usual with Nobuo Uematsu is superb. "Liberi Fatali", the opening song, has easily become one of my favorite video game arrangements. I also enjoyed the story, although I feel VII had some more epic moments.

I would recommend this game, however it is NOT perfect. Like, really not perfect... but I still enjoyed it's climaxes and story. The entire journey rounds out handsomely, but a good ending doesn't justify a mediocre journey at some points. It's a 8/10 for me. Not a perfect game, but a pretty damn good one still.

column8: 7, 9 and 10 are better but still good

Okay. Es la primera vez que concluyo este FF,  y tengo en cuenta que es un juego del 99 con mecánicas en su mayoría, que si bien están bien planteadas, a lo largo se me hicieron súper pesadas. He amado y odiado este juego. La historia es buena y profunda, como acostumbran a hacer los FF, pero a mí personalmente el sistema de enlaces y extracciones me pareció una santísima basura.

Como nota general le doy un 6/10.
Puedes dejarlo aquí porque este es mi resumen.
Ahora se viene la parrafada innecesaria, nene.
Vete cogiendo un cafesito que va para largo.

Historia - 7/10: Si te gusta Evangelion, este es tu juego. Vale, no, ahora en serio. Tiene una buena premisa, no obstante, la trama da varios vuelcos inesperados y el objetivo principal cambia varias veces, con una serie de giros de guion tremendamente convenientes. De un DVD a otro, la historia cambia tanto que casi sentí por un momento que estaban improvisando sobre la marcha. Hay que estar muy atento a todo lo que te están contando (bloc de notas en mano y el workbú también, de paso), que llega a ser de locos debido a la complejidad de la historia. Creo que se podría haber contado de forma más sencilla. Luego del final me tuve que ver 3 videos-análisis de YouTube, fumarme cuatro porros para abrir los chakras, y finalmente decir, sí, he entendido la trama.

Personajes - 6/10: Sé que es una nota baja, pero voy a explicarlo largo y tendido porque no tengo nada mejor que hacer. Se cumple con el estándar de personajes secundarios de los FF, lo he visto en todos los que he jugado y no puedo quejarme. Squall tiene un buen desarrollo y como personaje principal me ha gustado. Creo que es evidente la influencia que tiene Cloud (FF7) en la creación de este, aunque hay diferencias, claro. Squall es gélido, muestra su indiferencia y frialdad allá a donde va. Puede llegar a resultar cruel con su forma de actuar con los demás (DVD1). Con el paso del juego, su evolución es correcta y coherente, diría que orgánica y bastante creíble. Los personajes secundarios cumplen con su rol; aunque he echado de menos algún que otro diálogo extra en el grupo, también entre ellos, así como con el protagonista. Por ejemplo, Quistis (lo suyo con Squall pierde atención muy rápido, y creo que le daba un salseo extra). También la relación que parece tener un tono romántico entre Selphie y Irvine. Solo algunas escenas más, tampoco tanto. En cuanto a Rinoa, como co-protagonista, no está mal, aunque al principio el rollo niña mimada, alegre y atrevida me estaba desencajando. Debo decir que después su personaje se asienta y actúa de forma más natural, menos forzada y mucho más agradable. El romance es muy ligero pero va cogiendo protagonismo, deja algunas escenas bastante épicas y bonitas que quedarán en mi memoria.

Ahora vamos con Seifer y Artemisa, la gran decepción de este juego.

Empecemos: Seifer es un bully de turno que es malo porque equisdé (1. gilipollas de manual. 2. está semi-controlado, ¿influenciado? por la bruja/las brujas). Venga ya, tío. Podía haber tenido una motivación mucho más personal e íntima con Squall, por ejemplo, algo que le afectase profundamente cuando eran más pequeños; una relación de amistad rota; una traición, o lo que él considerase como tal; y luego una rivalidad desproporcionada que surge posteriormente como consecuencia de esto. ¿Pillas por donde voy? Hubiese ganado mucho. Pero el personaje es más plano que el posa-vasos que tengo en mi mesa. Es artificial. Está ahí, plantado, siendo un tremendo HDP en todo momento y a todo el mundo casi que le da igual. Seifer no tiene ninguna motivación real. Ninguna, en serio. Rinoa y él habían tenido un rollo romántico en el pasado y ni siquiera aprovecharon el dramatismo del asunto cuando él mismo la agarra para (...no spoiler). Sentí que Seifer era el planteamiento de algo que se olvidaron desarrollar porque la trama estaba siendo demasiado transcendental y no les apeteció pulir lo demás. Fue una oportunidad perdida. Una lástima.

Y ya, para acabar, la bruja antagonista principal (Artemisa) me ha decepcionado bastante. Por Dios, me encantan las historias que le dan al opio y he entendido la trama perfectamente. Todo el asunto de posesiones, poderes, conciencias, viajes en el tiempo, y la compresión del tiempo en sí. Simplemente, la [motivación] de Artemisa es reduccionista (hago esto porque quiero que me adoréis, ajjia) que me ha parecido insulsa y súper falsa. El que es malo, es malo, sí, pero comprimir el jodido universo entero y quedarte tú sola no es demasiado aburrido?????? No tiene ninguna motivación real que la incite a hacerlo; un trauma, un evento que la marcó, o un motivo divino o algo así. Por ejemplo, que al realizar la compresión, después iba a descomprimir (winrar) e iniciar los tiempos de nuevo para tener una segunda oportunidad o qué se yo. En definitiva, me pareció poco coherente y casi diría que infantil para la complejidad y el peso de esta historia. No me gustó nada.

Venga, que ya casi termino esto.

Jugabilidad: 3/10. Lo siento, he odiado el combate. El peor sistema con diferencia de todos los FF a los que he jugado. El sistema de Enlaces y Extracciones es un coñazo. He detestado estar cambiando de grupo y tener que estar a cada poco cambiando los enlaces, en el menú, asignando las magias a las estadísticas de cada personaje, y pocas horas después, o incluso minutos, anulando todo eso para volver a enlazarlo a otro personaje de la misma manera. Es aburrido, ortopédico, se hace pesado con el tiempo. Entiendo que el juego quiere que te impliques en la personalización de los personajes y cómo quieres que sus estadísticas se vean potenciadas, pero es tan poco fluido, y te hace estar tanto tiempo en el menú, que llegué a aborrecerlo con ganas.
Además, el combate es mega fácil de romper y puedes abusar de las invocaciones de G.F. todo lo que te apetezca. Me he pasado el 95% del juego spameando a Shiva, Ifrit, y cuatro o cinco más. No necesitaba plantear una estrategia de ataque y/o defensa si podía lanzar invocaciones gratuitamente y sin ningún tipo de coste o consecuencia negativa. Las magias no sirven para nada más que bindeartelas. Lo siento por el que le guste, pero para mí este es el gran defecto del juego.


Misiones secundarias y grindeos: 7/10. No hay secundarias como tal, son cosas que puedes sacar explorando mucho o tirando de guía para que sea algo más rápido. Que no os engañen, la mayoría jugamos a esto porque La Triple Tríada es el mini-juego más absurdamente adictivo que he visto en un FF. Simplemente, no puedes parar. Te quieres farmear todas las cartas y te pones como un psicótico cuando la norma Suma + cadena entra en todas las regiones. Quería cargarme a alguien en la vida real, y hasta me habría dado satisfacción hacerlo.
El grinding te puede dar un montón de horas de contenido extra (yo no hice mucho), sacándote los G.F. opcionales, desbloqueándote las armas finales de los personajes y sus mejores límites. Tiene muchas cosas por hacer.

Una cosa más. Esta es la versión remasterizada que salió en 2019.

Remasterización: 2/10. Ni siquiera voy a tenerlo en cuenta, porque esto ya es asunto de Square Enix. Aquí no puede haber existido un trabajo de remasterización de más de una semana si es que llega. El juego no tiene culpa de haber salido en 1999; consta de gráficos antiguos de PS1, poligonales, fondos borrosos y la cámara no es de lo mejorcito, pero en la remasterización NO HAN TOCADO NADA más allá de los modelos de los personajes principales y algún boss importante. El mapamundi es tan feo que duele mirarlo. He visto Mods de la comunidad con filtros de texturas que le dan un lavado de cara impresionante y queda chulísimo. No entiendo por qué no han hecho algo similar, hablamos de una compañía multimillonaria y uno de los títulos dentro de la franquicia que más pasta les ha traído en su historia.
No sé, Square Enix, un poquito de amor a este juego no le habría venido mal.

Excelente juego, con este inicie en el mundo de los FF

I personally LOVE FFVIII, with it being my personal favorite of the PS1 Final Fantasies. Its gameplay systems are clunky, the story is a mess, and by all means could be considered the black sheep of the entire franchise... But I still love it. I don't exactly know why I love this game so much, but I just do. There's just... something about this game that draws me to it more than VII or IX. Something about the world that fascinates me. Something about the characters that draws me into their struggles, into their relationships, into their stories. I do with this game got more love because I really do feel like it deserves it. However, Final Fantasy VIII Remastered is a terrible port of what is a misunderstood game. It doesn't really do anything outside of updating *some* models. No QOL changes (that this game desperately needs), no upscaled backdrops, no remastered music... I still recommend it because it is super easy to mod those things in. Lunatic Pandora fixes a lot of these issues and more. I really can't recommend FFVIII enough to anyone who even has a fringe enjoyment of this franchise. It should absolutely be experienced despite its inherent flaws and the flaws of this terrible port.

column8: Un vero e proprio tuffo nel passato. Con questa versione remastered sono stato in grado di rivivere le emozioni di un gioco che purtroppo in tenera età non sono mai stato in grado di finire a causa di un disco difettoso. La remastered offre una qualità degna, senza tuttavia snaturare l’originale concept della versione ps1, inoltre offre anche la possibilità di velocizzare alcune parti noiose del gioco grazie ai “cheat” di velocizzazione del game play (che si attivano con L3 R3 ed L3+R3). Sono presenti anche altri cheat che tuttavia precludono la possibilità di ottenere achievents dal momento stesso che si procede con un salvataggio su cui sono stati utilizzati e che sconsiglio a prescindere per evitare un gameplay che altrimenti potrebbe risultare noioso (si trovano nel menù premendo ESC sulla tastiera o rimappando un tasto personalizzato sul controller con quello in questione). Su Final Fantasy VIII c’è poco da dire come titolo, c’è chi lo ama e chi lo odia, io sono uno tra i primi in quanto l’ho sempre trovata una storia molto piú “matura” rispetto al 7 ed al 9 che tuttavia portavano con se uno storytelling eccellente in cui questo titolo invece zoppica un po (ho potuto notarlo solo adesso con qualche anno in piú sulle spalle). In linea generale è un gioco che consiglio comunque a tutti gli amanti del genere e per coloro che hanno una steam deck che con qualche piccolissimo accorgimento garantisce un gameplay di oltre 4 ore senza la necessità di una ricarica nel mezzo dell’azione. column8: molto bell
Meu jogo favorita da vida!

POSITIVOS:

- A direção de arte é ótima, os personagens, as cidades, as naves e os monstros, tudo é muito estiloso.
- Músicas ótimas como sempre, acho que nunca ouve um FF com músicas ruins, e aqui claro Nobuo Uematsu sempre preciso, apesar de eu achar que não é seu melhor trabalho.
- Graficamente pra época era um jogão, a mescla de cenas de 3d com as cenas CGI faziam o playstation suar.

NEGATIVOS:

- TODO o sistema de batalha é ruim, as "junctions" que ditam seus atributos são baseados nos GFs, sem eles nem tem o personagem, e ainda tem as magias que funcionam como o recurso base pra esse sistema que já é ruim, você precisa de magias que são retiradas de monstros tornando as batalhas arrastadas demais e bem chatas, e evoluir de nível é algo ruim já que existe um sistema secundário de scaling nos monstros que aumentam a resistência com base no seu nível fazendo com que você nunca atinja aquele hit de 9999 mesmo sendo nível máximo, com a junction certa, usando a arma mais forte.

- Apesar de estilosos os personagens são rasos, não tem desenvolvimento algum, estão lá porque convenientemente o plot fez eles estarem lá, e acredito que o romance de adolescente de 12 anos seja o culpado.

- O romance que existe entre Squall e Rinoa é forçado, sem sal, ocupa espaço que poderia ter sido usado pra desenvolver outros personagens, e no final nem fede e nem cheira.

- O plot principal é confuso, com plot twists, cansado, com viagens no tempo tanto pra trás quanto pra frente, cheio de conveniências porque sim e é de longe uma das piores histórias de FF, A Squaresoft na época devia estar chapada quando aprovou isso.

Resumindo, é um FF esquecível, história fraca, combate ruim porém com muito estilo nos personagens e nas ideias artísticas, eu diria que o visual da Gunblade é a única coisa que se salva do jogo.
One of the best FF's

column8:
Disclaimer: This is better than the original. It has better graphics and some small negligible changes. The game guides and guidebooks will still work with this version. (I recommend Bover_87's)

Like the other guy said, This game is not for stupid people or people who are not willing to take a little time to learn the systems.

I'll keep it short:

Soundtrack: this game has the best soundtrack in the series. For real. (I don't count FF14 as a real mainline entry)

Story: The story is amazing, you 100% end up getting attached to most of the party members by the end but some complain about a "twist" towards the end but it is not really that much of a twist if you think about it.

Progress system/gear/junction thing: The system being complicated isn't necessarily bad for the game. It just makes it harder. People like to cry about it but then praise other "hard" games like Dark Souls. The difference is that the difficulty here lies in you having the willingness to research how junctions work using the in-game tutorial menu option or the internet. The system is amazing, it provides customization I have not seen in any other Final Fantasy game so far.

So basically this is the best  mainline Final Fantasy game.

column8:
DO NOT GET ODIN UNTIL THE LAST MOMENT POSSIBLE. Also do minimal levelling until you get all GFs and status-up abilities. You can turn off random encounters in this remastered version with F2

---{ Story }---
Child soldiers save the world from a time travelling sorceress, and on the way, discover the power of friendship and love. 
The storytelling is a little choppy, i feel like the localisation wasn't the best, but i still really enjoyed it. So, off the bat, using child soldiers to perform a political assassination, not the best subplot ever, but everything involving time-compression and the Lunatic Pandora is just so weird and awesome. Reminds me of weird mid 90s anime. 

---{ Gameplay }---
Battles in this game, the setting up and forming strategies is very fun. There are also moments when it's really frustrating. There is a very steep learning curve, and there's a lot of trial and error. There are some mini-games which have not aged well. My only real gripes are that fades between scenes should have been shortened for this remaster, even with the speed boost they add up, and angles in some locations are so weird that it makes moving in the right direction completely un-intuitive. 

---{ Graphics }---
Dated as heck. The updated character sprites look ok, but they really do make everything else look worse by comparison. The artstyle and design is so beautiful though. 

---{ Audio }---
Very late 90s vibes, but it's great. The sound effects are really creative and complement the action nicely. The music in this game is phenomenal. More jazz/funk influence than previous FFs. 

---{ Difficulty }---
It's all very do-able if you play correctly. If you don't play correctly, you'll be in for a world of frustration. 

---{ Grind }---
It's a JRPG, so... yep. Mostly grinding for magic, and items, or you can grind Triad and refine it into items. Either way there's grinding. 

---{ Bugs }---
One bug in the entire playthrough. A character got stuck on a chair in Esthar and i had to reset. 

---{ PC Requirements }---
Max settings on an i5-9600K and an RTX 2070 = constant 60fps.

---{ 8 / 10 }---
