column8:
I agonized over whether to get the original Final Fantasy 8 listing on Steam or the Remastered version, because I read a lot of horror stories about the FF8 remaster just not working very well.
Having completed the game, I think the bug fixing updates Square Enix has made since the game's launch have ironed out a lot of the serious problems. I think most people should be capable of running this game with only minor technical issues, but I would suggest refunding it if you have any serious issues within the first couple hours of playing the game.
Anyway, here are the technical issues I ran into:
1. The most annoying by far was constant visual tearing when playing in borderless windowed mode. I ended up playing the game entirely in full screen, which I basically never do, because I like being able to click away to do something else or take a screen snip without the game freaking out. (I just paused the game and checked stuff on my phone instead, lol.)
2. Any time my computer went to sleep while the game was still open, it crashed. I'm not talking about deep sleep, but just, like, the regular sleep your computer goes into after maybe 30 minutes or so away from it. Honestly? You might consider changing your power saving settings if you're going to step away from the game and can't find a save point. *Don't* rely on the autosave, because sometimes it can be hours -- if not *an entire disc* -- behind. I don't have a clue what triggers the autosave aside from some story events.
3. After defeating Sphinxaur (the first mid-boss of Ultimecia Castle on Disc 4) using Battle Assist mode and 3x speed, the game crashed. Thankfully, it's right before a save point, but it's worth mentioning because that was the only crash I encountered while actively playing the game.
4. Once, upon launching the game, I noticed all of the sound effects were gone. I had to restart the game to get them back.

As for the game itself: wow! Fresh off of the success of the beloved Final Fantasy 7, it looks like the folks at Square Enix decided to get a little weird with this one. The game starts with the main character taking his exam to become a member of a mercenary force for hire, and then goes completely and totally off the rails.
The turn-based combat with ATB is pretty much standard, so I appreciated the remaster's 3x speed and battle assist modes that allowed me to break the game wide open and make random encounters and most early to mid-game bosses trivial. That said, it doesn't entirely override all of the gameplay, and you'll spend plenty of time learning about the Junction feature used to modify your character's stats, abilities, strengths, and weaknesses, which becomes crucial later in the game.
Something worth noting is that the game uses level scaling to determine how hard enemies should be based on your party members' levels. As such, you really, really do not want to grind at all until you have unlocked all six main party members and are in a position to swap them out so you can level them up equally. I ran into some trouble in the late game because the main character was level 70-something while my other party members were somewhere between level 50 and level 20. I ended up toggling on the cheat codes and giving up the 'you beat the game' achievement after losing to the final boss because it was going to be extremely difficult to win otherwise, even with Battle Assist turned on.
Unrelated, but you might consider looking up a guide to find side quests and where to get the optional Guardian Forces. A lot of that stuff isn't really obvious without sinking a lot of time into exploring the world map, and even then it isn't always easy to find.

column9:
I agonized over whether to get the original Final Fantasy 8 listing on Steam or the Remastered version, because I read a lot of horror stories about the FF8 remaster just not working very well.
Having completed the game, I think the bug fixing updates Square Enix has made since the game's launch have ironed out a lot of the serious problems. I think most people should be capable of running this game with only minor technical issues, but I would suggest refunding it if you have any serious issues within the first couple hours of playing the game.
Anyway, here are the technical issues I ran into:
1. The most annoying by far was constant visual tearing when playing in borderless windowed mode. I ended up playing the game entirely in full screen, which I basically never do, because I like being able to click away to do something else or take a screen snip without the game freaking out. (I just paused the game and checked stuff on my phone instead, lol.)
2. Any time my computer went to sleep while the game was still open, it crashed. I'm not talking about deep sleep, but just, like, the regular sleep your computer goes into after maybe 30 minutes or so away from it. Honestly? You might consider changing your power saving settings if you're going to step away from the game and can't find a save point. *Don't* rely on the autosave, because sometimes it can be hours -- if not *an entire disc* -- behind. I don't have a clue what triggers the autosave aside from some story events.
3. After defeating Sphinxaur (the first mid-boss of Ultimecia Castle on Disc 4) using Battle Assist mode and 3x speed, the game crashed. Thankfully, it's right before a save point, but it's worth mentioning because that was the only crash I encountered while actively playing the game.
4. Once, upon launching the game, I noticed all of the sound effects were gone. I had to restart the game to get them back.

As for the game itself: wow! Fresh off of the success of the beloved Final Fantasy 7, it looks like the folks at Square Enix decided to get a little weird with this one. The game starts with the main character taking his exam to become a member of a mercenary force for hire, and then goes completely and totally off the rails.
The turn-based combat with ATB is pretty much standard, so I appreciated the remaster's 3x speed and battle assist modes that allowed me to break the game wide open and make random encounters and most early to mid-game bosses trivial. That said, it doesn't entirely override all of the gameplay, and you'll spend plenty of time learning about the Junction feature used to modify your character's stats, abilities, strengths, and weaknesses, which becomes crucial later in the game.
Something worth noting is that the game uses level scaling to determine how hard enemies should be based on your party members' levels. As such, you really, really do not want to grind at all until you have unlocked all six main party members and are in a position to swap them out so you can level them up equally. I ran into some trouble in the late game because the main character was level 70-something while my other party members were somewhere between level 50 and level 20. I ended up toggling on the cheat codes and giving up the 'you beat the game' achievement after losing to the final boss because it was going to be extremely difficult to win otherwise, even with Battle Assist turned on.
Unrelated, but you might consider looking up a guide to find side quests and where to get the optional Guardian Forces. A lot of that stuff isn't really obvious without sinking a lot of time into exploring the world map, and even then it isn't always easy to find.

All in all, I think it's totally worth playing if you're a fan of JRPGs or other Final Fantasy games, and the Remaster adds those quality of life features that make me glad I picked it over the original PC release.
It's one of the wilder mainline entries in the series for sure!

column8: Maravilloso juego, un clasico +++

A card game with an RPG in the way.

This game was a roller coaster for me, but I think we ended on a high. For context -- I rented this game as a kid when I had a PS2, but never got super far (I believe I got as far as unlocking Irvine in your party), so anything beyond that is new (this is like maybe 4 hours into the game). My review and opinion will be coming from someone who's essentially done a first play-through.

So first and foremost, "remastered" means they made character's faces look a bit nicer while keeping with the PS1 polygon graphics. Backgrounds are still mostly static images that may or may not be animated, so there are several points where it is hard to tell where to go because things don't look like you can interact with them. Cutscenes are also 1999 CGI, which I've heard is a turnoff for some people -- I am neutral about it and don't mind the Y2K feel, but if that is a sticking point for you I'd want you to know now rather than later.

In terms of gameplay, the junction system is extremely unique. You can gather magic from enemies, items, the environment, and from your Guardian Forces (what summons are called in this world) and assign them to specific stats to increase them. Some work better for buffing physical attack, others defense or speed -- you have to play around and see how that changes your character. This means you can acquire super powerful magic and be a walking juggernaut if you plan correctly. It does make fights way easier, but the grind to get this way from early game is no joke and is definitely a time sink. 

The other unique thing about this game is the battle system. Unlike any other Final Fantasy game that I know, FF8 is unique in that enemies get stronger as you get stronger. They gain more HP, do more damage, and l earn way better spells ever 10-15 levels. That means you do NOT want to grind in the traditional way, lest you want a final boss with like 1,500,000 HP for each phase. Grinding, instead, looks like gathering the right spells and figuring out a way to "kill" enemies without getting experience points (*cough* use the Card ability and turn them into a Magic, The Gathering playing card *cough*). This aspect of the game can be a little tedious and it takes way more foresight than I thought going into it, especially as there are a number of fixed encounters that you cannot escape from, and some that force you to gain experience as the enemies are immune to the normal means of EXP avoidance. There is an achievement for beating the game and keeping Squall at level 1 the whole time, but like...love yourself. Don't.

My biggest frustrations with this game were mostly around PS1 jank. Menus are very dated, maps are sometimes hard to navigate, the over-world is very bleak and muddy. For the time, these game features were  iconique, but looking back it definitely has aspects that did not age well. I also wasn't enamoured with the story -- it has a bit of Kingdom Hearts-style ~timey-wimey~ mess where you need to go into the future to fix the past to save the present that you just need to nod and be like "ok, werk" as it happens. The biggest thing that bugged me is that it is super often that you'll hit a major story point and the game will shuffle your party, often in a way where all their stats are unequipped. You will have to make sure you go back in and fix it before you stumble into a fight you can't handle because 2/3 of your party members are essentially naked. This happened at least 5 times and I was tilted on stream each time.

A lot of the characters are also a bit flat and their "growth" is forced or underplayed -- Squall can't express his emotions, Rinoa wants to be his manic pixy dream girl but will only drop hints about it instead of being direct, Irvine is h-word, Quistis is mature but also not mature but is also a role model but is also jealous and a bit jaded? They all felt like abstract ideas of a person that, had this game gotten the full FF7 remake treatment, could have been way better fleshed out so I felt like I *cared* about them, rather than *tolerated* them.

Lastly, the best aspect of the game is Triple Triad. A super fun mini-game where you battle with cards and then potentially steal them from your opponent if you win. These cards can then be refined in to super important items and spells and is worth the grind to collect. They brought this back in FF14 and it is hands down the best mini-game Square has ever made. Hence why I declared this game "A card game with an RPG in the way." 

All in all, this isn't my favorite Final Fantasy and I had my quarrels with it, but I am happy I got to experience it. If you're a fan of the franchise, I also recommend taking the plunge and seeing it for yourself.

column8:
This is a great remaster of my favorite 3D Final Fantasy game of all time. To this day, I have many fond memories of receiving the original PS1 game for my birthday and playing it for the first time during the summer of 2000. Even now, I cannot help but reminisce on how amazing that summer was with pouring hours into FF8, going swimming at the local swimming pool with a friend, and then returning home to play more FF8.

As a longtime fan of the franchise, I consider this installment to be very underrated and it (sadly) does not receive as much praise compared to other 3D entries like FF7, FF9, and FF10, and it's truly a shame. Granted, the Junction/Drawing system can feel a bit monotonous at first, but once you get the hang of it, it is actually pretty neat and makes the battles with regular enemies and bosses more interesting at times. Animations for Guardian Forces (or "GFs", for short) are absolutely amazing and even surpass the animations for Summon Materias used in battles in FF7. The plot is also one of the most engaging (albeit complex, to some degree) in the series and the whole love story between the main protagonist, Squall, and his significant other, Rinoa, captivated me, especially in later portions. Nobou Uematsu's soundtrack is also among his very best work and, like its predecessors, truly gives the story an incredibly epic feel!

Regarding this remaster, most main character, font, GF, and enemy sprites have received a high-definition makeover and FMV sequences look much better than they originally did on their PS1 and PC counterparts. My only gripe is that some of the backgrounds and NPCs still look blurry and don't always mesh too well with the HD characters (not a deal-breaker since backgrounds and NPCs at least look slightly better than they originally did on PS1). Aside from that, this is now my favorite version of FF8 of all time (though the original PS1 version will always hold a special place in my heart) not only due to the updated visuals, but also the quality-of-life improvements, especially the 3x toggle speed feature (which makes battling enemies and traveling in towns and on the world map much more convenient now). Therefore, I HIGHLY recommend this port!

column8:
Ok so I am just gonna open up and say that this is my favorite Final Fantasy game that I have played. People have their problems with and I understand but I also think that strengths of this game are often ignored because of these problems.

So first is the gameplay. Most Final Fantasies have notable differences from each other gameplay wise and in this game is the introduction of Junctions and GFs. Junctions are ways you can customize your character stats with summons you find granting you abilities and letting you use magic to buff your stats up. Some people find this easy to exploit while others find it too difficult to learn. I think the junction system is easy to learn after an hour or so and then after that if you learn what enemies and locations and items give out what spells then you should be fine for the rest of the game. After that fights should be easily manageable for the most part.

Next is the story [b] NO SPOILERS [/b] but it's really a story about accepting love and help from others and I think the game does a fantastic job at conveying that story. Most elements of the story lead up to this without much of important side stories happening. I think The only down side this has is that much less of the side characters get many moments themselves. That being said the main story thread is the best in the series up to this point. 

Last but not least that I want to talk about is the music. The PSX mainline games all have fantastic soundtracks, but this game blows the other two out of the water. I find the soundtrack among some of the most memorable in the series. It's hard to find many songs I dislike from this game. Every single one is so memorable and fits in so well in this game. I think people who dislike this game even agree on the soundtrack  being one of the best.

Anyway that was my overview of the game I have. I can't really put into words how much this game means to me. I would be happy to see more people enjoy it.

Just finished my second playthrough of this masterpiece. I just got into the Final Fantasy series and have ZERO nastalgia for it, despite being almost 40 years old. Like I've mentioned in other reviews, I have played and finished 1-15 (except 11 and 14) and absolutely LOVE them all.  I was a little intimidated with the junctioning system at first, but once you just play the game and use common sense, it's a  pretty straight-forward and engaging experience. I think  the story and music are incredible and I enjoyed my time with the game the whole time. The hate that #2 and #8 get are not warranted at all- and are definitely worthy of a playthrough. Ignore the bandwagon "reviewers" and try them for yourselves. Use a guide though, because admittedly there are some cryptic moments where you won't know what to do or where to go, but I find that to be true with most RPG's if you play them in small chunks like I do (adult responsibilities). If you dismiss this game in the first few hours, you are missing out on one of the best in the whole series!

[h1]色褪せても名作。[/h1]
中二病真っ盛りの頃にプレイし、自分の人生観に致命的な影響を受けてしまい[b]未だに中二病が抜けません。[/b]10年ぶりくらいのプレイです。
やはり当時ほどの感動はありませんでしたが、それでも楽しめました。
同時にFFXも進めていましたが、利便性やストーリーのつくりなどはあちらが上に感じました。ストーリーのボリュームはこちらが長いかな。

[b][i]ブーストプレイが非常に快適[/i][/b]で、エンカウントなしや3倍速等によりサクサクと思い出を掘り返しながらプレイできました。当時PARなどに手を出していた私としては全てのRPGに搭載してほしい機能ですね。

[b][i]HDグラフィックは良かった[/i][/b]ですね。初見プレイだと物足りなく感じるかもしれませんが、リマスター前を知る者からするとみんなずっと顔が良いです。セルフィ可愛い。アーヴァイン？悪いな、おぼえてない。

低評価にあるエラーの類はいずれも起こりませんでした。同様のエラーが起きてたら私も低評価にしてたかもしれませんね。

今後フルボイスつきでリメイクしてくれたらまた印象が変わる作品になると思います。してくれないかな～。

以下、[h1]ストーリーの感想(ネタバレ[/h1]です。
当時から言われていましたが、[b][i]スコールの心理描写が少ない[/i][/b]ため、突然リノアを好きになったような感じは若干否めません。(特にブーストプレイでサクサク進めていたため。)
ですが、[b][i]スコールは17歳[/i][/b]と考えるとまあまあ納得できるとは思います。
たまたま超絶顔が良いだけの、元々依存体質で根暗、学業に注力してきたカードゲーム廃人の高２男子と考えると、陽キャの可愛い女の子にすきになーるされたらコロっといくのはしゃーねーなー？

その他、トラビアでのアーヴァインの独白のシーンや、EDでのハンドカメラの演出は今見ても神がかっていると感じました。
反面、宇宙でラグナロクが都合よく出てきたり、時間圧縮以降のシナリオはちょっと強引すぎるような気がしました。

[b][i]アルティミシアについて、[/i][/b]様々な説がありますが、個人的にはアルティミシアは他ならぬアルティミシアという未来の魔女だとしか思ってません。ハッピーエンドのストーリーであってほしいですし、オダインから数世代?先までリノアが継承もせず孤独なのはあんまり考えにくいなあ。あとラスボスが哲学的なことを言うのは過去のFFやこの時代の作品(エクスデスとかケフカやムジュラの子供たち等)ならままあることなので、そんなに気にすることではないような。カッコイイですけどね。

というように、本作の醍醐味は、あえて語られない部分について、考察が楽しめる点にもあると思います。
ブーストプレイにより、既プレイでも未プレイでも比較的お手軽に硬派なRPGを楽しめる素晴らしいリマスターだと思います。

So-so remaster of an underappreciated Final Fantasy game that is a wild ride of madness even by JRPG/FF standards. It's worth trying if you like other Final Fantasy games, although it's a little crash prone and not very polished for a remaster (better character models but not making higher resolution backgrounds is a shame), so if you have the game somewhere else, I would pass on this.

The game itself is great, albeit easy to cheese with the junction system (and keeping your levels low!) and it has some of the worst side quests and optional content of any FF game. But it does have a great story and is a lot of fun!

column8:
It's great, people have had mixed feelings about the battle system. Basically it's more complex, gives a lot more options to build your characters however you want, there's multiple ways to victory - but it can be confusing until you finally take the time to learn it all.

You're basically drawing magic from enemies, then taking that magic and "junctioning" it to your stats like strength, magic (dmg)... melee attack element... melee attack status (blind, silenced etc.) and defenses of the same sort.

Then there's the pokemons ie. the Guardian Forces which are huge elemental creatures you can summon to dish out a lot of damage to the enemy, while you're summoning you're "protected" behind the elementals health points so you will not take damage, a sort of one dimensional but a valid strategy for newer players.

According to the story, I would say the story is mature. Yes the main character at times can be seen as emo/angsty but part of this is because of the translation. Looking past the minor issues I've found the game engaging for tens of hours, the graphic or more - the artstyle is beautiful with sceneries and landscapes that strecth far to the horizon.

I would recommend the Remastered version because it allows you to use 3x time skip which basically eliminates de facto all the grinding (there is a bit of Draw grinding but it happens so fast that it's basically a sort of it's own minigame where your pushing buttons as fast as you can since the battles are so fast.)

It's not as cartoony or straightforward as previous and future versions of the game series, although you can junction 99x magics to strength, speed, hitrate and put on some elemental damage and just auto attack your way to heaven. But all in all i really like the complex ways in which you can build and engage battles, there's a LOT of variety.

Also the tone of the game isn't as cartoony as mentioned above, but sort of mature and this comes in all aspects of the game I think. There's many beautiful games where they have different art directors, music directors, animation directors and so forth... I think here it all comes together nicely as in "it's a one whole experience" instead of a sillisalaatti of different experiences. 

+ Remastered allows for skipping of the grindy parts of the game
+ I think to get the best of this experience you have to truly "be there with the characters" as in, there is slower parts of the game but if you try to zone out and just rush through them you won't get the experience. I think it all needs to be experienced as a 1 whole.

I thought it was fun. 
( this is the end of the review. )

column8:
This is going to be a pretty in depth review, prepare thyself. 

Story: the story was definitely a thing, for final fantasy. It was interesting with ideas that it had implemented and fell flat with the romance and time compression. However, something to keep in mind is that this had to attempt to outdo its predecessor, FF7. As we all know, good luck with that it isn't happening in this series. 
With that aside, the story was alright. But it is not comparable to 7, i felt 8 even had brain melting make sense of stuff moments. Like when they make sense of Ultimecia, Adel, Rinoa, and Edea. That sorceress schtick was brain achingly lame.

Mechanics: this is not your typical final fantasy game. You have Guardian Forces that you have to attach to a character known as junctioning. When doing so based on what you have unlocked for that guardian will allow you to junction different magics to your characters to make them more powerful. GF are required and needed built up to even get to the point of being able to make your character more powerful. It is a mess! 
This is probably why it is not seen in any other FF game. Bc basically you want the best magics with as much possible junctioned or your not going to have a strong character. For reference if I junction 100 curaga to my health, it may not max out. Now junction even 80 ultima to it and wham, 9999. This also means you are discouraged from using those awesome magics as by doing so you will be losing the amount that buffs your character. Silly stuff.
Now, the next mechanic that is absolutely not good for FF: If you think well, I WILL JUST LEVEL UP! Jokes on you, the monsters and bosses scale in this game. Thats right, no matter how you level, the enemy will have an equation that takes there health by level compared to yours and multiplies it to make it comparable to your characters. This means that you will never have that "I grinded to not get my butt kicked in feeling." Some may like that, others may hate it. I personally do not care for it bc it makes some fights insane. I.E. diablos GF, fight him sooner than later or he destroy you in damage when you go to try for him. 
Triple triad, the card game, was annoying bc of how the rules would get out of hand, based on the last regions cards you played in, have fun in space. All rules apply at once. 
The damned...ultima weapon. Omg that boss fight was a mess based on said games mechanics. 

For a remaster, its not at all. All you did Square was upscale the textures in character models and that is it. No background sets were upscaled so they are a blur mess. If you know you know, just like you did on your 90s tv. 

Also, Squall is Lagunas illegitimate kid. So remember that if you play.

Hmm....well with all that said,
It made some wonderful memories and fun times with my wife while playing through this. It was definitely different, definitely tough at times and almost needed a walkthrough, but it was that in its essence that made it fun for us.

Buy it if you like FF and on sale.

One lat thing, this was when FMV was a huge deal, be ready for long fights, long cutscenes, etc.

Have fun with your fantasy! Hope it ain't final!

column8: 한글화 해줘잉 제발 ㅠㅠ

One of the most polarizing games in the series, perhaps only surpassed by XIII or XV. I've definitely been polarized. 

It feels like for everything FFVIII does well, it does something else poorly. The junction system is a fantastic new way to determine builds and difficulty; drawing for magic is a drag. Triple Triad is incredibly fun and helpful; regional rules make it easy to infect your whole map with major handicaps in utilizing it. The characters are lovable and memorable; but the plot is erratic and paced inconsistently. This might be the ultimate game to look up tips for before one plays! A blind playthrough sounds infuriating.

If you know what FFVIII is and what its reputation is and you want to play it, then you should. A lot of aspects of it are middling to poor, but the characters, the Junction System, Triple Triad, and the excellent final fights in the game make it more than worth the time for anyone looking to explore the Final

column8:
I'll start by saying this remaster is the bare minimum of the bare minimum and you should only buy it if you want to consolidate the final fantasy series on your steam account.

That being said models look very nice and your eyes won't bleed. So I guess this is "good enough" if you lower your standard that low.

Now the game by itself .... it's ... complicated.

It has a lot of good in it. It's basically an upgrade on FF7 when it comes to production value.

- Cut-scene, fight and musics are great.
- Card game is really good.
- The Junction system with Magic and GF allows a lot of versatility and can get you OP at lvl 20 or 30 if done right.

But everything else is cringe, borderline unbearable. The story is good until end of disc 2 then it gives up on taking itself or anything that happens seriously. The disc 4 is a joke.

- To this day I still do not understand what are Seifer and Ultimecia motivation. Why are they doing what they are doing ?
- Why is Squall a 17 years old emo boy suddenly the leader of an entire army. Where are the adults ? The guy is clearly struggling with teen crisis and probably discovered how to pleasure himself not even a couple of months ago.
- Squall/Rinoa relationship is so cringe. Everything they say about their struggles, their doubt and general group dynamics becomes comical. I can't help but seeing a group of teenagers doing some deviant art poster with "deep" quote while wondering "how their life got so messed up at 17 because when I was 16 and half I was totally fine. What happened ? How is time affecting my life like this ?". The game does a very good job at re-creating 16 years old inner struggles.
- Characters (including Squall and Rinoa) To be honest  I did not care about any characters. Special mention to Irvine and Selphie who are there just ... to be there I guess. Every body is so uni-dimensional and empty. It's like they have 1 scene in the entire game to justify their personality and behavior but these scene are so random they are not enough.
- The game is an "exp trap". The most powerfull you will ever get is between lvl 10 to 30. Leveling more than that is a mistake and will only make the game harder as enemies level up with you. The junction system will allow you to get close to max stats while being low level.


Overall, my personal theory based on nothing is that SE felt they had to make a 4 CD game to be "better" than FF7. So they had their story wrapped up by end of 2nd CD but they had to fill up additional 10 to 15 hours of gameplay/story to get to 4th CD. And even then the 4th CD is a joke in terms of content.

From beginning of Disc 3, the story goes in every direction, character motivations evolve a the speed of light, we get twist over twist over twist just for the sake of adding extra couple of hours here and there.

Anyway it might contradict what I wrote above (mostly negative) but I like this game very much. First half up to en of CD 2, magic/GF system and card game do the trick for me. Everything else is subpar and cringe.

Edit: SE in the very unlikely event you read this review when you will start pre-production on your ff8 rebirth/remake. Please stop the story at end of CD 2 this was enought. Save yourself the pain of last third of the game.

column8: Buien recuerdo de infancia lo unico malo los bugs del x3 pero recomendado

Ich möchte euch mitteilen, ob sich das Upgrade vom Standard auf Remaster lohnt.

Pro: 
- Charakäre sehen sehr hübsch aus, nicht mit 2022 zu vergleichen aber ok.
- 4K Einstellungen sind möglich 
- Randlos Fenster Modus ist möglich, super wenn man mit Anleitung auf einem 2ten Bildschirm spielt.
- Karten wurden überarbeitet
- Für Controller Spieler wird jetzt A,B,X,Y angezeigt (nicht mehr B1-B4)
- Laden klappt jetzt ach besser, es wurde ein Beenden Butten hinzugefügt
- Für Leute die gern mal Cheaten es wurden welche direkt integriert, allerdings gibt es dann keine Erfolge mehr, lohnt sich also nur für Leute die sie schon haben oder dennen es egal ist.

Contra:
- Grafisch wurden leider nur die Charaktäre und die Karten überarbeitet
- Die Videos wurden leider nicht überabeitet, das ist das was ich mir gewünscht hätte was sie auch anpassen können.  
Wenn man die neuen Charaktäre sieht und dazu die alten Videos, sieht man den unterschied schon deutlich. Finde es aber nicht so tragisch.

Fazit:
Für 10€ habe ich es mir gekauft, für 20€ wäre es mir persönlich zu teuer.
Was mich dazu entschlossen hat, das Spiel nicht zurück zu geben waren 2 Sachen
Die bessere Controller unterstützung und der Beenden Button.
Ich habe es erst in der alten Version bis Ende CD 3 gespielt und habe mir dann die neue Version gekauft, 
nach 30 min war ich überzeugt das es besser war die 10€ aus zugeben, um ein besseres Spiel Erlebnis zu haben.
Die neuerungen wurden an die heutige Zeit angepasst.

Jeder muss für sich selbst entscheiden, ob es ihm das Geld wert ist, ich kann nur ne Kaufempfehlung geben weil die Verbesserungen überwiegen.

column8:
Final Fantasy 8 is an extremely mixed game for me. The game is controversial and for good reason. Lets first get the good out of the way:

- Presentation is a huge step up from FF 7. There are many more cutscenes and the models and animations look a lot more high quality. The Remaster doesn't really touch much on the way the game looks (besides the character models) but thats perfectly fine because the game still looks pretty good even more then 20 years later. Music is fantastic but that can be said for pretty much all of the FF games up to this point.

- Story has some real heartfelt moments and has some of the best character progression out of all the FF games up to this point. It feels like the problems people deal with here are much simpler but much more grounded compared to anything before it. Coming to terms with death, discussing the future, finding your own place in the world, accepting love. There is a LOT to be said about FF 8's story but if there is one positive thing I have to mention it has to be those personal stories.

- Triple Triad, this is an in game card game that you can access extremely early and play throughout the entire game against most of the main characters. It is super simple to pick up but has some serious depth to it. Its really fun and is a nice change of pace from the main game. It isn't just fun but has huge impact on the main gameplay as well as you can turn cards into items which can then be turned into spells. And as I will mention later in this review, spells are insanely important in this game. So playing the card game isn't just a fun side diversion but also a serious way to progress throughout the game. My only complaint about this mode is that there are rules which get added as you progress throughout the game, these rules are not fun and in my opinion defeat a lot of the cool things the card game does right. You can technically turn the rules off but its not very well explained how.

- Locations, the game has a really unique feel to it, its exciting to see new locations and to explore the world. The game is super linear for the first like 10 hours but after that there is a lot to see in the world. One noteworthy location I wanna name is the 'Shumi village' this location has a side quest that isn't easily found but its a huge highlight from the game to me, it combines all the things I love about FF 8, the personal stories, the fun locations, a sense of adventure. Its this location that made me change my mind about the game and made me see why people love it.

Now for the negatives/controversial stuff...

- Story. Yes you just heard me praise the story. But if we look at the overall story then the story makes no sense and is honestly embarrassing. There is so much going wrong here that I could write an entire review purely on how nonsensical and convoluted the story is. Just some stuff that pops up in my head without going into heavy spoilers: The main character is treated like the ultimate leader with 0 explanation or development as to why. There is a whole bunch of weird time related stuff that just makes no sense. There is an insane amount of lore that you can miss extremely easily, for example who or what the main villain is. There are a lot of plot devices that have to be made up on the spot to explain incredibly important plot developments. The list goes on and on, there is so much I would like to say but I am intentionally avoiding to say because of spoilers. It can be a ton of fun but most of the time I am just in awe of how ridiculous the story is even for final fantasy standards.

- Combat, this might be the most controversial thing in this entire game. Some people REALLY love it and some people despise it. I'm in the despise side. Just like the story you can probably write an entire review just on the combat. So lets get to it, why is combat controversial? The entire games combat is based on 1 thing: Magic. Magic has been turned into an equipable and that together with your equipable  Guardian force (the summons of this game) make up a huge majority of a characters strength. You can also still use magic but magic is also a consumable and has to be gained from draining enemies or turning items/cards into magic. Did that sound confusing? Yes? That's because it is, the game barely explains this system properly and only after hours of messing around with it did I actually understand what was going on. 

My problem with it isn't just that its confusing, its the fact that its just straight up broken. In the first 10 hours or so you can practically get so strong that nothing in the game matters anymore besides the hardest content. But wait it gets better, the game automatically levels up enemies to your level, do you understand what that means? It means that leveling doesn't matter and getting exp is almost actively discouraged. Instead you just try to get powerful magic, material to craft new weapons and level up your Guardian forces through battles that give a lot of AP (experience points for Guardian forces) and not a lot of normal exp. If you actually understand how the system works you just break the game, it almost feels like the entire difficulty of the game is built around players not understanding those systems, its ridiculous. The game is either way too easy or overly grindy and complex.

- Characters, technically I could put this in story and combat but I think there is too much going on here to just have it get a quick mention. You end up having selectable party members but it doesn't matter. First of all these characters are so painfully shallow, they all get like 1 story moment and after that they don't matter 90 % of the time for the story. The only exceptions to this are like the main character and 3 other characters. There are side quests and side characters that somehow feel more fleshed out then like 4 main cast characters. Just ridiculous. Not only that but gameplay wise they also don't matter, pretty much you just care about their limits and thats it, FF 7 also had that problem but there was a lot more going on with equipment and progression that at least somewhat made each character stand out gameplay wise. In FF 8 you can literally swap the Guardian forces and magic and you will probably not even notice you switched characters.

I can't talk much about what the remaster adds because I haven't played the original version of FF 8. But the most noteworthy thing I can talk about is the 'boosts' these are features that allow you to speed the game up by 3X, turn on what is practically god mode as long as you have enough HP and lastly allows you to turn off random encounters. None of these are necessary to beat the game but I appreciated them greatly at times, especially the 3 x speed feature and the no encounter feature. The things that are really missing from this remaster are more FPS (especially for the battles) as well as proper resolution scaling and Playstation controller support (For some reason it shows Xbox inputs, funnily I had the opposite issues when playing FF 7 on steam).

So that's that, should you play FF 8 and should you buy the remastered version? If you don't want to think about modding then the remaster is probably the better version, especially with the addition of the boosts I mentioned earlier. As for FF 8, that's up to you, I went into this game thinking I would be able to think positively about it, but the main issues with the game are too glaring for me. There are moments in both the gameplay and story that are fantastic and seriously fun to play, but for each moment I had fun there would be some random annoyance that would pop up within 30 minutes. I won't recommend this game because the annoyances were too much for me but somewhere in here there is a real gem of a game. As it stands I only recommend this to people who wanna experience FF 8 specifically or to those like me who are trying to go through gaming history and playing each FF game chronologically.

There is a LOT to be said about FF 8's story but if there is one positive thing I have to mention it has to be those personal stories.

- Triple Triad, this is an in game card game that you can access extremely early and play throughout the entire game against most of the main characters. It is super simple to pick up but has some serious depth to it. Its really fun and is a nice change of pace from the main game. It isn't just fun but has huge impact on the main gameplay as well as you can turn cards into items which can then be turned into spells. And as I will mention later in this review, spells are insanely important in this game. So playing the card game isn't just a fun side diversion but also a serious way to progress throughout the game. My only complaint about this mode is that there are rules which get added as you progress throughout the game, these rules are not fun and in my opinion defeat a lot of the cool things the card game does right. You can technically turn the rules off but its not very well explained how.

- Locations, the game has a really unique feel to it, its exciting to see new locations and to explore the world. The game is super linear for the first like 10 hours but after that there is a lot to see in the world. One noteworthy location I wanna name is the 'Shumi village' this location has a side quest that isn't easily found but its a huge highlight from the game to me, it combines all the things I love about FF 8, the personal stories, the fun locations, a sense of adventure. Its this location that made me change my mind about the game and made me see why people love it.

Now for the negatives/controversial stuff...

- Story. Yes you just heard me praise the story. But if we look at the overall story then the story makes no sense and is honestly embarrassing. There is so much going wrong here that I could write an entire review purely on how nonsensical and convoluted the story is. Just some stuff that pops up in my head without going into heavy spoilers: The main character is treated like the ultimate leader with 0 explanation or development as to why. There is a whole bunch of weird time related stuff that just makes no sense. There is an insane amount of lore that you can miss extremely easily, for example who or what the main villain is. There are a lot of plot devices that have to be made up on the spot to explain incredibly important plot developments. The list goes on and on, there is so much I would like to say but I am intentionally avoiding to say because of spoilers. It can be a ton of fun but most of the time I am just in awe of how ridiculous the story is even for final fantasy standards.

- Combat, this might be the most controversial thing in this entire game. Some people REALLY love it and some people despise it. I'm in the despise side. Just like the story you can probably write an entire review just on the combat. So lets get to it, why is combat controversial? The entire games combat is based on 1 thing: Magic. Magic has been turned into an equipable and that together with your equipable  Guardian force (the summons of this game) make up a huge majority of a characters strength. You can also still use magic but magic is also a consumable and has to be gained from draining enemies or turning items/cards into magic. Did that sound confusing? Yes? That's because it is, the game barely explains this system properly and only after hours of messing around with it did I actually understand what was going on. 

My problem with it isn't just that its confusing, its the fact that its just straight up broken. In the first 10 hours or so you can practically get so strong that nothing in the game matters anymore besides the hardest content. But wait it gets better, the game automatically levels up enemies to your level, do you understand what that means? It means that leveling doesn't matter and getting exp is almost actively discouraged. Instead you just try to get powerful magic, material to craft new weapons and level up your Guardian forces through battles that give a lot of AP (experience points for Guardian forces) and not a lot of normal exp. If you actually understand how the system works you just break the game, it almost feels like the entire difficulty of the game is built around players not understanding those systems, its ridiculous. The game is either way too easy or overly grindy and complex.

- Characters, technically I could put this in story and combat but I think there is too much going on here to just have it get a quick mention. You end up having selectable party members but it doesn't matter. First of all these characters are so painfully shallow, they all get like 1 story moment and after that they don't matter 90 % of the time for the story. The only exceptions to this are like the main character and 3 other characters. There are side quests and side characters that somehow feel more fleshed out then like 4 main cast characters. Just ridiculous. Not only that but gameplay wise they also don't matter, pretty much you just care about their limits and thats it, FF 7 also had that problem but there was a lot more going on with equipment and progression that at least somewhat made each character stand out gameplay wise. In FF 8 you can literally swap the Guardian forces and magic and you will probably not even notice you switched characters.

I can't talk much about what the remaster adds because I haven't played the original version of FF 8. But the most noteworthy thing I can talk about is the 'boosts' these are features that allow you to speed the game up by 3X, turn on what is practically god mode as long as you have enough HP and lastly allows you to turn off random encounters. None of these are necessary to beat the game but I appreciated them greatly at times, especially the 3 x speed feature and the no encounter feature. The things that are really missing from this remaster are more FPS (especially for the battles) as well as proper resolution scaling and Playstation controller support (For some reason it shows Xbox inputs, funnily I had the opposite issues when playing FF 7 on steam).

So that's that, should you play FF 8 and should you buy the remastered version? If you don't want to think about modding then the remaster is probably the better version, especially with the addition of the boosts I mentioned earlier. As for FF 8, that's up to you, I went into this game thinking I would be able to think positively about it, but the main issues with the game are too glaring for me. There are moments in both the gameplay and story that are fantastic and seriously fun to play, but for each moment I had fun there would be some random annoyance that would pop up within 30 minutes. I won't recommend this game because the annoyances were too much for me but somewhere in here there is a real gem of a game. As it stands I only recommend this to people who wanna experience FF 8 specifically or to those like me who are trying to go through gaming history and playing each FF game chronologically.

Embarrassing remaster and one of the laziest I have played in a while. 

On top of that: crashes every 2nd or 3rd screen transition when changing areas, for me. Had 10!!! crashes during the first hour of the game. 
ALL of them while leaving the Ifrit cave post kill and entering Balamb garden afterwards. 

Not even worth it during sale. Refunded.

EDIT:  After going through my system logs and finding one of several potential culprits for the crashes I gave it another shot and it seems to be stable now. Won't change the *thumb down* though, since the amount of effort that was needed to get it to work has just been ........

For those of you with the same issue, here is what I did:
- Check the Event viewer > Windows logs > Application for any error OTHER then FF VIII related
 + in my case "Parsec" seemed to be messing with my graphics drivers
- then check the logs for FF VIII related errors
 + in my case I got the exception code: 0xc0000005 for the FFVIII.exe
 + this error code is related to memory access errors that usually can be fixed "easy-ish"
- After that I downloaded the .net repair tool from microsoft and then, in an elevated cmd / powershell, I executed "sfc /scannow"
 + that command found compromised files and repaired them
- to be on the save side I followed that up with "DISM /online /cleanup-image /scanhealth" which showed no errors or corrupted files and then (bcs I am paranoid) I executed "DISM /online /cleanup-image /restorehealth"
- since then I had several screen transitions with x3 speed activated and no crashes since
- if the above mentioned steps did not work for you, another step I skipped (bcs lazy) is to delete the .net framework and re-install it

Going into this game from FINAL FANTASY VII, I didn't know what to expect. FF7 was my first Final Fantasy experience, and I knew that the games were not really connected in terms of story or even gameplay. Let me tell you, however, that FINAL FANTASY VIII is probably right up there, very close behind--if not tied--with VII.

The classic Final Fantasy charm is all here: great characters, iconic music, gameplay and visuals that pushed innovation, and even the sometimes confusing yet lovable story. The party of FF8 is one of my favorite in any JRPG, and their journey is unforgettable.

In terms of gameplay, FF8 plays quite differently from most of the other FF games. Of course, your simple turn-based RPG mechanics along with ATB system are here, but it's the junctions and draw system that really change things up. Although frustrating at times, I found it quite satisfying to find spells that slotted well with my stats and gave them great boosts, although I could see why someone would find this and the draw system to be annoying or tedious. 

The remaster also adds wonderful graphics updates, as well as some options to speed up the game, make random encounters easier, or turn them off entirely. I did need to install a mod to get the graphics to work smoothly (I got the mod because I read about it online, not because I had any initial problems). All-in-all, I highly recommend you at least give FINAL FANTASY VIII a try. 9/10

column8: This is by far the weirdest, most bizarre FF game ever made. At first I thought "Ok this is gonna be some anime tropey weeb tripe isn't it?" and then it throws you for a loop, and then it does it again. Curveball after curveball with the most insane, ridiculous, over the top sh!t that after a certain point I couldn't tell if it was terrible or genius. This game has more twists than a fat kids nipples, none of which anyone will see coming. And that kept me hooked, along with the brilliant FMV cutscenes that aged like fine wine and the killer soundtrack that always sets the perfect tone. The setting is also super cool and big departure from previous FF titles. This game covers the entire David Lynch spectrum from cheesy dialogue, surreal unexplained stupid sh1t, schizophrenic pacing, to creepy and unsettling moments that come out of left field. It really has it all. The whole game feels like one big fever dream. The ending is crazy and raises more questions than answers, and leaves a lot up to interpretation. This game isn't without it's flaws though, some of the side characters never really get fleshed out because the game is focused on a few central main characters, and also the level scaling on enemies and bosses can sometimes be petarded,  menus and UI can be clunky and finicky at times as well. Overall it probably isn't on my top 4 favorite FF titles but I appreciate how unique it is and how much they shake up the formula and do something different from other RPGs

王菲是最适合这首歌的演绎者，空灵且柔情，美妙到令人落泪。
游戏方面，超脱时代的实时画面、顶级的cg动画、繁杂且精妙的系统，还有打牌，今天的jrpg，依然在像ff8取经。
这个版本只是优化了cg分辨率，说炒冷饭都是在侮辱卡普空，人家生化4至少每次还能优化一下子贴图精细度，如果想打汉化建议玩原版。
对se这种无底线圈钱的行为表示谴责。
[spoiler] 但是看在《巴比伦陨落》锁了国区的份上还是给你好评，你se关键时刻还真是不坑中国人。 [/spoiler]

** PREMESSA : Non intendo discutere sulla gestione della remaster, sono un novizio dei JRPG e sopratutto dei FF quindi mi è del tutto indifferente.**

La storia di Final Fantasy VIII rimane impressa per i suoi momenti incredibili che ti rimangono nel cuore, però non è esente da difetti anche gravi, soprattutto verso la fine.
Il Junction system, cioè la gestione dei Guardian Force (le evocazioni di questo FF) per potenziare i propri personaggi oltre alla consueta funzione di levelling, aveva sicuramente del potenziale. E' interessante poter capire come funziona e quanto si possa rompere il gioco sapendo ciò che si fa. Però ovviamente questo porta a dei difetti gravissimi, come il fatto che non ci sia bisogno di utilizzare magie (anzi si tende ad accumularle in modo da non intaccare le statistiche) e che il gioco sia, appunto, "rotto" dopo poco tempo, quindi facile per chi sa usare il sistema. Inoltre le abilità in battaglia sono LEGATE alle Junction, quindi ogni personaggio perde la sua "unicità" e può diventare uguale ad un altro se non per le statistiche base all'inizio del gioco.
I personaggi secondari sono stati poco interessanti, soprattutto alcuni che non mi sono andati proprio giù, ma comunque il cast rimane simpatico e ci si affeziona facilmente a Squall, Rinoa e compagnia.
Nonostante tutti questi problemi mi sento di consigliarlo a pieni voti, perché ritengo che sia una bella esperienza nel suo complesso e non si meriti del tutto i difetti che gli vengono sempre attribuiti.
Un Final Fantasy in tutto e per tutto, anche nelle sue lacune.

this game is just objectively boring, it just is.  Its a fact.  The characters are basically the same, they look like a clothing mag from the late 90s.  I still don't know what Quistis's personality is.  She barely speaks after disk one.  Every character has the same backstory except one.  They all grew up in the same location, have the same abilities besides their limit breaks, 4 of the characters have interchangeable dialogue who never affect the plot, and they look like are all attractive teenagers with late 90s attire.  They don't explain the main conflict: its just go here, then here, then here, then a character near the end gives you a wall of text that doesn't make sense.   

THen there's the battle system.  Its a mess and tedious.  You're better off just leaving squall nearly dead and using his limit break to kill everything.  Use the card mod ability to refine a bunch of items near the end of the game, watch the long ending, then try not to ever think about this again.

Some of the art design is cool.  Music is good.  Triple Triad is fun but the rules get out of hand.

column8:
Final Fantasy VIII has some of the worst combat in any FF game I've ever played. The framerate is terrible, locked at 15 fps and everything is time based, so going through the laggy ass menu while a live fight is happening is annoying. Sometimes it pauses the fight so you have time to choose, sometimes it doesn't. I couldn't quite figure out when it would pause and when it wouldn't, since it would seemingly flip whenever I figured it out..

Basically, the combat sucks. But the story, holy fuck. Am I playing a horror game? A love story? A story about time and space? A story about military students getting caught up in an ancient evil? Imagery everywhere hinting at things but never quite telling you?

It's an insanely bizarre final fantasy game, probably the most bizarre out of all of them and I think it's why it's now my favourite Final Fantasy. Maybe not my favourite in terms of gameplay, or final boss (my fucking god how many phases do you need to put on a final boss, it just doesn't seem to fuckin' end.) Eventually, I had to use a bunch of Hero's I had saved up, which is an item that makes you invulnerable for a while and depending on your speed you can basically become invulnerable the whole fight given you have enough hero and enough damage.

Squall basically carried my entire party but somehow Quistis & Rinoa at like, level 20 or 30 something managed to survive, I was pretty confused but whatever, I beat that annoying ass boss after re-adjusting my gameplay style like 52 times. Basically hero omega-op.

There's so much nostalgia in it, and honestly I never planned to beat it. It's one of the least liked FF's and it's like that for a reason. 95% of the game, you can just spam your summon. Yep, legitimately just spam your summons. They do ridiculous damage and your characters still get xp. The 3x speed up genuinely makes the game a lot better as well. Since the game engine is dependant on FPS, I guess they figured if they set fps to like 45, triple of the original frames it'll speed the game up and it does. It also makes the game look a lot smoother.

It was such an experience, it was so wacky, so tense, so romantic and at times completely fucking non-sensical, or so it seems. If you pay attention, you notice things and your brain comes up with all sorts of theories as to what the ever-living fuck is going on.

It's one helluva ride and I'm glad I beat it. It took me 24 hours almost exactly, but I was using 3x speed up and there was probably a lot of times where I was in the menu doing nothing, so I think my last save file had about 15-16 hours? I purely focused on the main story and didn't really explore. If combat was less scuffed I'd probably would've, but it's horrible. It was not fun when I was a kid, and it's still not fun now, but at least I'm old enough to understand stuff so that's cool.

TL;DR - Insane, wacky, amazing story. Lots of cutscenes, interesting gameplay elements, absolutely terrible combat, terrible framerate. Game can be a straight up horror game half the time, and a sweet wholesome romance story the other half. 100% worth my time playing through this. Definitely one of my favourite FF's now.

column8:
Classic Squall: "...I dreamt I was a moron."
  23 years later and it's still as compelling as the day it was released. Final Fantasy VIII will forever be my favourite in the series, and to me, is unmatched in story and music. I know the Junction System is very controversial within the fan-base, but I believe disliking it is mainly a lack of understanding; it is - without question - a highly enjoyable and unique levelling system, which I'm still extremely grateful for. It doesn't play the same as every other JRPG, so it made it more interesting.
  Seriously, I implore anyone who is yet to give it a chance, or has passed up on it in the past, to take the time to learn this levelling and battle system. It's one of the best, if not, best.
  From the epic opening of Liberi Fatali, to the final and satisfying showdown to The Extreme, it's pure magic.

column8:
Whose idea was it to make triple triad have rules where you can't choose which cards you play, you always go second and also cannot see what cards sorceress edea is even playing.  What does the same and plus rule even mean?
"When a card is placed touching two or more other cards (one or both of them have to be the opposite color), and the touching sides of each card is the same (8 touching 8 for example), then the other two cards are flipped. Combo rule applies."

This is indecipherable, but what about plus?

"Similar to the Same rule. When one card is placed touching two others and the ranks touching the cards plus the opposing rank equal the same sum, then both cards are captured. Combo rule applies."

I'm not even entirely sure this is written in english. I recognize most of the words, but it may as well be a 1978 manual for a 2-cycle honda lawn mower repair.

Over all Triple triad is a very bad game and the final fantasy game that comes with it is only just OK. Please stay away if you have any expensive electronics that you don't want to break in a fit of rage when some loser drops low level catcherpillar card and flips the entire board causing you to lose the game and your Squall card and also your entire sanity and self respect and now the neighbors' suspicions that you are a complete lunatic are TOTALLY founded when they hear you screaming about bitebugs and glacialeyes at 8 in the morning.

7/10

column8:
初めて遊んだFFシリーズということもあってPS版はかなりやり込みました。
レビューが芳しくないので買おうか迷っていたのですが、久しぶりにカード遊びをしたくなったのでついに購入。

■背景がぼやけているとかは思っていたより気にならなかった。すぐに慣れるレベルだった。
強制終了みたいなエラーは一度も起こりませんでした。ただゲームをウインドウのXマークで終了していたからかクラウド同期に失敗することは何度かありました。

■ブースト機能と言う名のチート機能はありますが、ブーストを使うと実績が解除できないため、そういうのを気にする人はブーストをOFFにしなければなりません。ただしバトル強化・エンカなし・３倍速の使用は実績に影響しません。
３倍速がめちゃくちゃ便利でした。このゲームは全体的にテンポが悪いので移動やら戦闘モーションやらダルいんです。
しかしこの倍速機能でそれらをスピーディーにできるので、快適なプレイができました。
倍速にしてもBGMはそのまま等速なので、良曲揃いのBGMをゆったり聞きながら３倍速で走り回れます。

そんな感じです。
Steam版のレビューであり、FF8自体のレビューではないのでご注意ください。

column8:
Worth it for Triple Triad and the soundtrack alone. 

The game is very guide-dang-it-y with the achievements, I had several exception errors/crashes which caused me to have to retread certain areas, and being able to lose rare cards in Triple Triad - even sometimes when you win a game- was very irking and caused several reloads. 

However, the characters were fun and Squall in particular gets some nice development. The world is interesting. While the story lost me at a couple of points, I overall found it to be a great ride with a lot of depth and field for analysis (aka, listening to smarter people than me do YouTube vids after the fact xD) . And while I do complain about the crashes, the 3x speed + power boosters makes getting back to where I was a non-issue. And while I prefer the combat in most other turn-based Final Fantasies, I do like that we got to see some variety here. 

So overall, a good time :) I would recommend starting with Final Fantasy IX + the Moguri Mod if you were only going to play one PS1 Final Fantasy but otherwise, yeah; a good time. :)

It is a great game in the FF franchise. We have a more paranoid Cloud but with fewer personality problems.
The remastering is not bad, except that the drawn backgrounds have not been treated and the difference is very noticeable. 
The addition of being able to pass the time x3 is a great success.
As always I've spent more time on the cards (Triple Triad) than on the game itself, but this great mechanic allows you to pass the game at level 1 with all the items and magics at maximum.
A great game from a great era.

column8:
L'avevo già giocato per psx1 senza mai finirlo (i dischi di ogni ff per psx si rovinavano sempre, obbligandoti a comprarne un altro).
Riprovandolo a distanza di anni, posso sentire frustrazione giocandolo, abbandonando il gioco per l'ennesima volta.. Ma questa volta non per i cd danneggiati (evviva il digital T_T).
La trama è sempre splendida, ma la frustrazione è dovuta alle meccaniche di gioco (troppo vecchie) che penalizzano chi usa le magie (assorbimento... c'è da chiedersi chi abbia mai inventato questa idea assurda) e il metodo junction che è un fastidio assurdo.
Ma ovviamente, sebbene le meccaniche di gioco siano rimaste quelle dell'originale, il danno peggiore l'hanno subito gli occhi degli utenti.. Quale perverso capo progettazione ha deciso di usare gli sfondi originali per sfocarli e poi fare mettere in alta risoluzione i personaggi? 
Carina l'idea dei cheat incorporati (probabilmente sempre per la merda di meccanica di gioco), che facilità l'esperienza e permette di godersi la storia senza diventare pazzo ad assorbire magie qua e magie la.
Per chi volesse migliorare l'effetto visivo.. dovrebbero esserci alcuni sfondi in hd sul web, fatti da appassionati delusi.
Nel caso decideste di comprarlo, prendetelo solo a prezzo di saldo.

If you must have it, buy it on sale, because it definitely isn't worth the full price when you could just buy the original for cheaper and it is literally the same game. No gameplay changes or anything, just a lazy copy and paste job in most areas.

column8:
This is my first time ever playing through FF8. 
I put it off and played the rest of the franchise due to this games reputation with the junction system.  

Having now played through the game...heavily influenced by the in game cheats...I'd have to say the game play here sucks.  I also found it surprisingly difficult to figure out what the game wanted from me.  Whether it was something as simple as what part of the backgrounds I can navigate through or who/what I need to interact with in order to progress the plot. 

The up side of this experience was the story and character development.  I completely understand why this game is beloved and hated.  It is a prime contender for a remake.  One that brings the game play to the modern world while keeping and deepening its already solid story.  

The story is what kept me with the game.  From the end of disc1 to the end of disc 3 is where I had the most fun with this game.  They through a lot at you in the final act and I admittedly got a bit lost.  

4/10. 

The story is good and some of the sequences here are memorable.  I actually loved the use of character thoughts as a narrative device and it was used to great effect here.  But the experience just isn't worth recommending.  I don't see myself ever playing this again unless it gets a proper remake.

You should just download the PS1 ISOs and play for free. All this really does is add some new character models which clash with the unaltered lower-resolution backgrounds.
 
I also hear that you could download the non-"remaster" version of FF8 on Steam and then install an "HD upscale" mod.
There is a similar mod in the works for this "remaster" version, but the creator of that mod has been working on it for quite some time, and he has a Patreon account associated with the project which incentivizes perpetual development, so please be careful. I am not accusing the person who is working on the mod, I am only encouraging potential purchasers to be cautious. As such, I can't recommend this version of the game, not for $19.99 USD at the time of writing this review.

column8:
Even if you like the Final Fantasy series, this game is not really worth it.
The story is all over the place and the characters aren't the most interesting either, not even the main villain, who basically ins't in the game until the very end.
Coupled with some atrocious minigames/quick time events I was close to not finishing the game a lot of times because I was either bored or just frustrated.

The good thing is this remastered version features built in boost and cheats so you can at least breeze through a lot of the content of the game without much grinding.

Other than that is a basic FF game.

column8:
(Primera parte de la reseña)

[h1]Otro Remake Faltando al Respeto a los Fans [/h1]

Creo que es más falta de respeto la propuesta de configuración en sí que el hecho de que no hayan remodelado a todos los personajes. Dicho esto, es cierto que es insultante que solo remodelen a los 6 personajes principales, dejando pixelados el resto. Así, nos encontramos con planos donde Cid no está rimeikeado, y Squall sí lo está, siendo bastante cantoso. Aun con todo, parece una propuesta orientada a que te pases el juego lo más rápido posible, con tal de revivir la historia. Vayamos por partes. 

[b]Alcance del remake:[/b] No esperes ver todo reformado. Cuando lo hacen, corren el riesgo de "cambiarle la cara" a los protagonistas. Pero, al menos, lo que han reeditado creo que lo han hecho bien. Igual no te imaginabas a Squall con esa cara, pero no es algo muy cantoso. Le han metido filtros a muchas texturas, pero no han remodelado todos los escenarios, lo cual significa que si bien podrás ver a los personajes e invocaciones en pantalla mucho mejor, las demás texturas serán peores que las que podrías ver con el emulador Epsxe. Dicho esto, si deseas volver a pasarte el juego, sigue siendo una buena opción. Una buena opción que te recuerda lo poco que importas para los que lo han creado, en un insulto constante cuando veas personajes originales pixelados y otros que no lo están. En mi opinión: o los remodelan todos, o que no hubieran hecho el remake. Pero ya conocemos como funciona esto: hacen juegos A MEDIAS, con prisas, con tal de vender por un módico precio. Se marcan un Netflix con un videojuego exprimiendo algo, con la Ley del mínimo esfuerzo, y saben que va a vender. 

[b]Qué incluye realmente:[/b] Hay que acudir al Youtube para conocer realmente lo que incluye esta caja de sorpresas. De entrada, puedes obtener 100 unidades de magia. Creo que es lo único "útil" del remake. En el original tenías que pasar horas extrayendo magias en bloques de un máximo de 9 unidades por extracción. Cuando tenías que pillar 600 unidades para cada personaje te podías morir de asco. Ahora mismo el remake te permite una vez tienes una magia, aumentarla hasta tener 100 unidades por personaje. Eso es útil y no vicia el juego porque simplemente te ahorras las horas extrayendo Piros, o la magia que sea. ¿Dónde está el problema? Que no parece tener límite la ayuda propuesta. 

Lo otro que yo he utilizado ha sido el de usar las armas finales. ¿Por qué? porque así puedo lanzar todos los especiales desde el principio. Una de las críticas al original FF VIII ha sido el hecho de que no hubiera economía, (y lógicamente en este remake sigue sin haber), y no existir armas nuevas para comprar. Por eso activé esta opción, para gozar más con los especiales. El problema es que cuando lo haces, te dan automáticamente todos los objetos necesarios para obtener esas armas, que no son pocos, con lo que implícitamente te están dando material para fabricar magias. Deberás de evitar hacerlo. Por supuesto, también te pueden dar todas las habilidades posibles de GFs desde el inicio. Y ya el colmo: puedes tirar siempre que quieras especiales. Se les ha ido un poco de las manos. Jugar al juego así tiene su gracia los primeros minutos, después no le encuentras mucho el sentido. Me recuerda a esos juegos de rol online trucados donde matas a un zorro y subes del nivel 1 al 30 directamente. 

También puedes meter el máximo nivel a los GFs. Y otra mejora que a mi me parecía interesante: Puedes ir a x3 con solo pulsar una tecla. Es gracioso, y hace que Squall corra más, pero el problema es que llega un punto que ya no sabes como gestionar esas mejoras, si jugar con ellas o sin ellas y acabas por dejarlo. Porque no sabes marcar el límite. Hay magias que extraes de puntos y no de enemigos, (por ejemplo en principio la magia Aura), y no sabes si multiplicarla o no. No sabes cuando moverte en x3 ni la utilidad que tiene. Al final parece que juegas con prisas, como para "no perder el tiempo", y la historia los fans ya nos la sabemos de memoria y no tenemos prisa por vivirla tan rápido. Al final, terminar por leer texto, por avanzar en un juego que puedes revivir creo de una manera más digna y disfrutando. También te dan todas las cartas, por cierto. 

Todas estas mejoras las puedes desactivar y jugar al juego original, pero pudiéndolas activar siempre a golpe de click, es muy tentador no hacerlo. Si mantienes el juego original te encontrarás con un remake a medias, con escenarios pixelados y personajes bien cuidados en otras escenas. Cuando tengas que matar a 20 Tomberis te plantearás el x3, y creo que va a ser difícil que seas capaz de jugarlo sin sentirte tentado de aplicar algún truco propuesto en algún momento. En conclusión: que esas mejoras estarían bien si te las proponen una vez te pasas el juego, pero así de primeras lo vician mucho y lo convierten en un absurdo insulto a los Fans. 

[u]FOV:[/u]Donde el 1 es vomitar tras 10 minutos (Fallout) y el 10 es un prerenderizado. Aquí como sabemos son prerenderizados, pero no los han modificado. Les debía de suponer mucho trabajo modificar los innumerables escenarios. Es alucinante cómo no hay termino medio: O se cargan el juego de principio a fin con el Final Fantasy VII Remake pasándose tres pueblos de frenada, o hacen un remake completamente a medias como con este FF VIII. Es como si hubieran empezado el remake y al mes de trabajo hubieran abandonado el proyecto y en vez de tirarlo por la basura alguien haya dicho: "bueno, acabamos de remodelar a Edén y tíralo para adelante, alguien lo comprará". Es lamentable. Aun con todo ello le voy a dar un 8 a FOV. 

[u]JUGABILIDAD:[/u] Es complicado de valorar porque los trucos propuestos inciden de lleno en el desarrollo del juego. Realmente, lo hacen "más jugable", insultantemente fácil para poder avanzar. Por ello la nota debería de ser alta, si bien la ejecución de estas mejoras no me acaba de convencer. El x3 lo puedo entender, lo de las magias también porque era una queja de mucha gente, (extraer durante horas), pero hay otras cosas que rozan el ridículo. Aun con ello, debo de darle un 8.

[u]DIVERSIÓN:[/u] Es muy difícil de valorar un juego que es un remake, porque no sabes si valorar el original, o aplicarle un criterio individual y separado a "lo que han hecho" con el juego. Porque, si valoramos el FF VIII como juego, sin duda su nota sería próxima a un 10. Pero, ¿ha aportado algo realmente lo que han hecho? ¿Ha empeorado el juego? ¿Cometer tal sacrilegio es merecedor de suspender a todo un FF VIII? Mi criterio va a ser combinado, y yo creo que las mejoras ayudan al juego si pasamos por alto la desidia para no haber retocado todos los personajes y escenarios. Puedes volver a jugar a este juego con gráficos mejorados y si no te aguantas y quieres aplicar mejoras, es tu problema. Por otro lado, las mejoras divierten, porque te permiten explotar el juego desde otros puntos de vista, jugarlo en x3, obtener todas las magias, todos los especiales, etc...  Yo soy un gran fan y la verdad es que me ha cansado... Puedes guardar en cualquier momento, eso ayuda, pero no me ha apetecido jugarlo con estos trucos y por otro lado la mejora gráfica no es tan grande como para que me anime a pasármelo por enésima vez. Le pongo un 7. 

[u]DURABILIDAD:[/u] Ya sabemos lo que dura el juego. Unas 100 horas en condiciones normales leyendo todos los textos posibles y haciendo todas y cada una de las opciones secundarias y explotándolo al 100% consiguiendo todas las cartas y GFs posibles. Ahora bien, aplicando estas mejoras, la duración del juego podría variar sustancialmente entre un gameplay y otro, (por no decir que una de las mejoras es de andar a velocidad triple). Es complicado de valorar, nuevamente. Yo he jugado unas 10 horas, puede que menos. Me he cansado de obtener todas las magias.

column8:
What I liked:

I enjoyed that the cast felt like actual friends.

Squall's character development was interesting. He isn't an on-off switch. Sometimes he recluses back to being his old self, even after a major part of his development. He felt real for that reason. Yet even when he'd recluse, I never felt like what we had just went through was meaningless, because in the end he really felt like he'd opened up finally.


What I feel neutral about:

The story. It's not amazing, but it definitely isn't bad. Some of the plot points felt pushed to the side, which I mainly took issue in with the villain.

The battle system. NOT including the junction system. Aside from magic feeling a bit weak (except for stuff like Meteor), I felt pretty happy with my setup. Squall as the main physical damage-dealer, Rinoa as your typical white mage, and Quistis as my magic attacker. My only issue is that since magic didn't feel strong, my Quistis kind of just resorted to being a Card/Draw spammer.

Magic system. Again, NOT including the junction system. I enjoyed not worrying about MP, instead having to keep track of how much of each spell I have. This is dampened, however, by the junction system, as I'll get into below.


What I disliked:

Junction system. Probably a no-brainer for most people, including people who *do* enjoy it, should understand why it's controversial. While I wouldn't go as far as saying it dissuades me from using spells (it's so easy to restock), it never felt great. Again, this might be due to magic feeling weak? I at least appreciate that they tried something different.

The villain - majorly underrepresented and unexplained in their motive.

A must have for any fan of one of the best titles in the series.
Final Fantasy VIII - Remastered gives us high quality textures and character models which both serve as a great improvement compared to the original.
If you loved this game as a kid and would like to revisit it after years of contemporary gaming, you'll find soon enough that your nostalgia has conceled some really annoying memories from you. Lo-ong pauses in dialogues, Guardian Force animations that take forever to play, random encounters that pop-up in the least wanted moments. With Remastered edition those inconveniences are fixed with a single press of a hot-key, so lacking in the original.

Overall, this product is dozens of hours of joy, a decent tribute to the classic.

Em minha opinião, este foi o FF mais fraco e por que?

Apesar de ser um Remastered, envelheceu mal, tanto em gráfico com um 3D de fotos, tanto em jogabilidade. Tem uma história genérica e que demora muito para engrenar e mesmo assim ainda está longe do padrão de um Final Fantasy, até seus personagens possuem pouco ou nenhum carisma. Já a exploração dos mapas, no mundo livre é muito espaço para quase nada à se explorar e nas masmorras e cidades muito pouco se tem para explorar e coletar.

Mas o jogo tentou inovar na questão das magias ao qual você precisa extrair para usá-las, mas com o GF's são praticamente inúteis.


Este é um Final Fantasy em que apenas os fãs da franquia irão querer ter e jogar! E como todo fã, irão tentar tirar o máximo que o jogo pode proporcionar!
