column8:
Talk about an underrated game. For the supposed "black sheep" of the series this entry in the Final Fantasy franchise sure has a lot going for it.

I gotta say, a ton of the complaints about this game seem very overblown and facetious after I replayed this game more recently. It gets hated for a crazy story, the junction system, and a myriad of other issues. This feels very unfair to the game, and I see these flaws as the core strengths of this game compared to many of its' contemporaries.

At first glance the story is about you becoming and filling the role of a SeeD troop. An elite mercenary that takes contracts all around the world using their fighting prowess to get the contracts done. While this is the backdrop for the story the whole game, the actual meat goes into a more personal direction for Squall. Over the course of the game Squall develops character wise in a very touching way. The inner voice we get for the protag in this game is very unique. It lets us see a side of Squall that normally a JRPG would leave out and not bother telling us. Trying to be as spoiler free as possible, but the game contains flashback scenes where you control a different party. These are a great way to do flashbacks in my opinion and give the player control instead of just showing things in cut scenes. As you play the game you'll come to learn what these mean and I think this is one of those things that's pretty cool in this game. 

The game play is at its' core standard JRPG fare for the time, but they did try a few things to spice it up for you. Let's start with the extremely polarizing junction system. Basically you take the magic you have accrued and slot it to a stat. The magic increases the stat by x amount and this is how you want to power up the party through the game instead of relying on simply leveling up. The enemies in this one scale with your party and their levels, so you can't just grind to beat everything without thinking. Personally, I love the junction system. Sure, it's incredibly easy to break it even if you are going in blind, but for me half the fun of games is trying to break them and make them bend to your will. They've also expanded on limit breaks in this game. Instead of having a bar filled as you get attacked, your character has a chance to get a limit break when they are in low health. Not only that, but they made the limit breaks very interactive now instead of just something cool you watch. Don't get me wrong, they're still very cool to watch, but they now require some input from you. I think this is a great mechanic and makes the limit break system feel a lot more like you as the player doing the move instead of a get out of jail free card. There is a problem though. This system and the way they designed it makes it incredibly easy to spam limit breaks and render any difficulty in the game null and void. It takes some self control from the player to not abuse it, and I think that is a huge flaw in the balance of the game. For example, during my fight with the game's super boss, I had 2 party members at low health and spamming their limits, with a third staying topped off and ready to revive the other 2 if they should ever go down. It's way more effective to take care of the challenge in this game in this way and it shouldn't be up to the player to have to nerf himself to account for the game.

This game has a lot less mini-games than the previous installment in the series. Personally, I like that. I always felt FFVII had too many mini games, so this was great to see. While it doesn't have many, it does have Triple Triad. This is the mini-game that a ton of fans will say is the best mini-game in FF and possibly JRPG history. With some help from my brother this time around I was able to get into this game and I have to say it is addicting in a strange sort of way. Trying to get all the unique cards and then using said cards to help you break the game incredibly early is very fun and it makes the game a lot more enjoyable for me. You can do crazy stuff with the card game and become godly even before you're out of disc 1, if you're willing to put in the time that is.

The music and presentation of this game are honestly my favorite in the series so far I think. It's crazy to go from VII to VIII and see how huge the graphical leap was. Every track in this game feels perfect for the area they put it in, and honestly I wish there were more areas just so we could have heard more of this type of music from the composer. It has a very unique sound that none of the other games in the series really get close to unfortunately. The CGI cut scenes are still pretty amazing to this day if you ask me. i might just have a soft spot for those CGI type of cut scenes but I still get excited when I see those play, and this game has a ton of them to shock and awe you.

If you're on the fence about this game after hearing everything about it online, I think you owe it at least a play through to make your own opinion on it. For all its' flaws and quirks you'll find a very enjoyable and memorable game that lends itself to a ton of different play styles.

An elite mercenary that takes contracts all around the world using their fighting prowess to get the contracts done. While this is the backdrop for the story the whole game, the actual meat goes into a more personal direction for Squall. Over the course of the game Squall develops character wise in a very touching way. The inner voice we get for the protag in this game is very unique. It lets us see a side of Squall that normally a JRPG would leave out and not bother telling us. Trying to be as spoiler free as possible, but the game contains flashback scenes where you control a different party. These are a great way to do flashbacks in my opinion and give the player control instead of just showing things in cut scenes. As you play the game you'll come to learn what these mean and I think this is one of those things that's pretty cool in this game. 

The game play is at its' core standard JRPG fare for the time, but they did try a few things to spice it up for you. Let's start with the extremely polarizing junction system. Basically you take the magic you have accrued and slot it to a stat. The magic increases the stat by x amount and this is how you want to power up the party through the game instead of relying on simply leveling up. The enemies in this one scale with your party and their levels, so you can't just grind to beat everything without thinking. Personally, I love the junction system. Sure, it's incredibly easy to break it even if you are going in blind, but for me half the fun of games is trying to break them and make them bend to your will. They've also expanded on limit breaks in this game. Instead of having a bar filled as you get attacked, your character has a chance to get a limit break when they are in low health. Not only that, but they made the limit breaks very interactive now instead of just something cool you watch. Don't get me wrong, they're still very cool to watch, but they now require some input from you. I think this is a great mechanic and makes the limit break system feel a lot more like you as the player doing the move instead of a get out of jail free card. There is a problem though. This system and the way they designed it makes it incredibly easy to spam limit breaks and render any difficulty in the game null and void. It takes some self control from the player to not abuse it, and I think that is a huge flaw in the balance of the game. For example, during my fight with the game's super boss, I had 2 party members at low health and spamming their limits, with a third staying topped off and ready to revive the other 2 if they should ever go down. It's way more effective to take care of the challenge in this game in this way and it shouldn't be up to the player to have to nerf himself to account for the game.

This game has a lot less mini-games than the previous installment in the series. Personally, I like that. I always felt FFVII had too many mini games, so this was great to see. While it doesn't have many, it does have Triple Triad. This is the mini-game that a ton of fans will say is the best mini-game in FF and possibly JRPG history. With some help from my brother this time around I was able to get into this game and I have to say it is addicting in a strange sort of way. Trying to get all the unique cards and then using said cards to help you break the game incredibly early is very fun and it makes the game a lot more enjoyable for me. You can do crazy stuff with the card game and become godly even before you're out of disc 1, if you're willing to put in the time that is.

The music and presentation of this game are honestly my favorite in the series so far I think. It's crazy to go from VII to VIII and see how huge the graphical leap was. Every track in this game feels perfect for the area they put it in, and honestly I wish there were more areas just so we could have heard more of this type of music from the composer. It has a very unique sound that none of the other games in the series really get close to unfortunately. The CGI cut scenes are still pretty amazing to this day if you ask me. i might just have a soft spot for those CGI type of cut scenes but I still get excited when I see those play, and this game has a ton of them to shock and awe you.

If you're on the fence about this game after hearing everything about it online, I think you owe it at least a play through to make your own opinion on it. For all its' flaws and quirks you'll find a very enjoyable and memorable game that lends itself to a ton of different play styles.

column8:
Qualche parola per un titolo che oramai conoscono tutti e che comunque commentai nella sua versione originale qui su Steam.

È l’episodio a cui sono legato maggiormente dal punto di vista emozionale, il mio secondo Final Fantasy dopo avere messo le mani sulla prima Playstation.
Come in tanti sottolineano, dal punto di vista della trama sono presenti problematiche importanti, ma questo è uno di quei giochi in cui il racconto e il suo significato sembrano belli lo stesso, basta non pensarci più di tanto. E in cui i protagonisti sono meravigliosi, sebbene con gli occhi di un adulto di oggi facciano un po’ ridere. Prendendo questo gioco come una fiaba le emozioni rimangono ed è questo ciò che conta. Emozioni, sensazioni.
Final Fantasy VIII per me è un titolo a cui si perdona tanto, in cui il tutto è molto più della somma delle parti, e ci sono pochi titoli che riesco a paragonargli e che mi danno la sensazione di aver viaggiato in un altro mondo (i primi Tomb Raider, ad esempio).

Ricordo la prima volta che lo finii sulla mia Play modificata (sebbene lo acquistai originale e ne conservo ancora una copia). Dopo averlo terminato (anno 2000), all’epoca era una impresa improba andare in rete e rivivere le fasi più emozionanti del gioco, perché su Internet si trovava quasi nulla. Addirittura mi scaricai un software che permetteva di estrarre i video dai CD del gioco, cosicché potessi rivedermeli senza dover per forza rigiocarci (la sequenza finale a quei tempi la potevi rivivere solo riaffrontando Artemisia…). Oggi è tutto a così poca distanza di un click: si può giocare guardando direttamente un walk su YT… però all’epoca era anche tutto così frustrante, anche il solo riascoltare quei bellissimi brani musicali di sottofondo.

Per quanto riguarda il discorso gameplay, nulla è cambiato naturalmente, il cuore del gioco è sempre il sistema Junction, che per me di base rimane ancora oggi interessantissimo, anche se qualcuno dopo averlo rotto ha trovato in esso una giusta critica per affondare, ingiustamente, il gioco (sebbene all’epoca molti di noi nemmeno immaginavano tutti quei trucchetti per fare soldi facili o livellare a potenza i personaggi in poco tempo. Cosa che io continuo a evitare ogni volta che lo rigioco, perché non riesco a giocare mentre guardo una guida sotto gli occhi…).
Per me il voto base di FF VIII è un 9/10 pieno, ma qui si dovrebbe valutare anche l’operazione di Remastered.

Non saprei se con questo termine ci si dovrebbe aspettare anche un intervento sulla grafica in bitmap. Immagino di sì, anche se, data la quantità spropositata di luoghi di questo titolo, sarebbe stato una faticaccia rifare ogni schermata in altissima risoluzione e adattarla al formato 16:9 o addirittura 21:9. Certo, con i particolari filtri neurali che oggi si usano si poteva fare… ma non è stato fatto. Così come si poteva rifare tutto a mano (ma in questo caso tecnicamente non saprei se ciò avrebbe inficiato parti di codice, come quando lo si fa sbloccando gli fps in titoli che erano nati per 30 andando a rompere la tempistica della fisica del gioco).
Però, ecco, se remastered deve essere, allora la devi fare a 360 gradi, anche prendendoti più tempo, anche facendo pagare di più il prodotto. Ma sappiamo tutti come ragionano in quel di Square-Enix. Per cui, dal mio punto di vista, questa operazione, è da bocciare. Semplicemente perché rispetto l’originale non è stato aggiunto molto.
Sì, ci sono le texture ad alta risoluzione, ma qui c’è il mio gusto personale: non mi piacciono i volti dei personaggi. Rispetto l’originale, ad esempio, per me Squall e Rinoa in questa versione si presentano anonimi, senza particolari segni identificativi di riconoscimento. Che per fortuna sono rimasti nelle scene di intermezzo. Anch’esse, però, assolutamente non ritoccate: bassa risoluzione, uguali all’originale.
Il passo avanti sostanziale è quello dei tasti a schermo, finalmente rispondenti a quelli del controller utilizzato (almeno per quello XBOX, non so se è possibile che le icone cambino attaccandoci un pad della PS), laddove nell’originale per PC su schermo apparivano lettere a caso. Certo, con la versione originale si potevano usare delle mod, ma quelle dei tasti per me erano disastrose: non funzionavano. Quindi inesistenti.
Altra aggiunta interessante è un menù (richiamabile mediante L2+L3) che permette l’uso di qualche opzione aggiuntiva (opzioni grafiche e modifica dei comandi) e alcuni tasti che permettono l’abilitazione dei cheat e, SOPRATTUTTO, di velocizzare le fasi di gioco, utile durante gli scontri più noiosi, inutili o le evocazioni. La velocizzazione però non funziona per le scene animate, anche quelle che si sovrappongono alle fasi di interazione.

Lo consiglio?
Beh, diciamo che per chi non possiede il primo su Steam, allora tra le due versioni la Remastered è quella che ha senso acquistare (a meno che non si voglia giocare con le texture dei personaggi originali).
In caso si possedesse l’originale, il consiglio di acquisto della Remastered è inutile verso chi ama il gioco, perché sarà automatico spenderci i soldi a prescindere (Square-Enix conosce i suoi chocobo). Negli altri casi, la spesa la consiglierei nei periodi di sconti (in genere a 9.99 euro).

6/10

column8:
Final Fantasy 8 Remastered - definitely the black sheep of the family - but does have some high spots!

------------

The main draw of this entry in the classic final fantasy anthology, for me, has always been the awesome set pieces and classic CGI cutscenes - which this version of the game does plenty well enough. And true to form for Final Fantasy, the characters and environments you get to explore are second to none.

But this is also a very flawed game. The "Draw" system is needlessly time consuming, character progression feels very flaky (with some characters having their abilities hidden behind a wall of menus), and the story starts to go in a really weird direction through the second half of the game all the way to the ending.

Fortunately the Remaster has built in Boosts and Cheats which can help to either speed up or skip entirely some of the slower bits. I appreciate that might be a turn off to some of you, but in the case of FF8 it's all surprisingly welcome (having a 3x speed boost toggle on a simple button press is a godsend for drawing magic and overly long combat animations!).

So yes, worth a play if you're into JRPGs or the Final Fantasy mythos, for sure, but try to walk softly and enjoy it for what it is, lest you get bogged down in all the nonsense.

Balamb Garden and "disc 1" is definitely worth remembering.

column8:
FFVIII was the first JRPG I played as a kid and perhaps because of that it's one of my all-time-favourites to play despite its many flaws. 

The story is just perfect for FF fans. It's very melodramatic and you won't see most of the twists coming because of how ridiculous they are. I know that sounds like I'm talking negatively, but if you like JRPGs I'm sure you understand that these are endearing traits. The full-motion cutscenes are just insane - the graphics are very dated but the art style and fast-paced action of the scenes are a joy to watch.

The battle system is based on old-fashioned Final Fantasy ATB, a turn-based system. Wait for your character's attack bar to fill up over time and select an attack from a menu when it's full. There's no real-time combat, no moving your characters around, just plain menu-based attacks. If you've played a lot of older JRPGs you'll feel right at home here.

The Junction System, used to empower your characters, is easily exploitable but a great concept. Spells you collect from your enemies can be used to increase your stats or add a status effect to your attacks. There's a lot of fun to be had in playing around with this system.

This Remastered version does have some annoyances. 8-direction movement in a game like this is just sucky and takes away from my immersion somewhat when my character can't walk in a straight line on angled scenery. The FPS issues weren't really a big issue for me. In all, while they could've put a bit more work into the technical aspects of this remaster, my enjoyment wasn't impacted in a major way.

I love this game. It doesn't take the crown in any particular aspect - gameplay, setting, story  have all been done better by one FF game or another. But altogether this game is fun and memorable. I give it a strong recommendation.

The full-motion cutscenes are just insane - the graphics are very dated but the art style and fast-paced action of the scenes are a joy to watch.

The battle system is based on old-fashioned Final Fantasy ATB, a turn-based system. Wait for your character's attack bar to fill up over time and select an attack from a menu when it's full. There's no real-time combat, no moving your characters around, just plain menu-based attacks. If you've played a lot of older JRPGs you'll feel right at home here.

The Junction System, used to empower your characters, is easily exploitable but a great concept. Spells you collect from your enemies can be used to increase your stats or add a status effect to your attacks. There's a lot of fun to be had in playing around with this system.

This Remastered version does have some annoyances. 8-direction movement in a game like this is just sucky and takes away from my immersion somewhat when my character can't walk in a straight line on angled scenery. The FPS issues weren't really a big issue for me. In all, while they could've put a bit more work into the technical aspects of this remaster, my enjoyment wasn't impacted in a major way.

I love this game. It doesn't take the crown in any particular aspect - gameplay, setting, story  have all been done better by one FF game or another. But altogether this game is fun and memorable. I give it a strong recommendation.

column8:
Full disclosure. I always thought it was one of the more underappreciated FFs. The system is simple, but powerful once you understand it. Tutorial is better integrated into gameplay ( the game makes you take an actual test to show you know the game works ). The story.. is more grim ( I am replaying it now as an old fart ) than I remember. Frankly, it feels a lot sadder than I remember. There are still moments of teenage amusements, but they are spaced between real impending war themes.

All that said, odds are.. if you are reading this, you already know all this. So what is new in the remastered version? Well, you can cheat your way through the game for the story ( though that nullifies achievements ), you can speed up the game ( really useful for summons early on ), you can change keyboard/pad bindings from overlay.. small little comforts. Resolution can be adjusted to meet modern monitors and proton works very well for it ( running it now on PopOS ).

If you are new to it or want to replay for nostalgia factor, it is a good choice. Unlike FF9, you don't need extra mods to enjoy it.

I can safely recommend it.

column8:
tl dr; Only buy this if you really love FF8 or have never played it and really want to try it, can deal with how horrible most of the game looks in contrast to the updated character models, or if you're willing to mod the game (*starred information on that below*), or if you can deal with how fucking stupid Selphie is. 

I can't recommend this game because it's probably the poorest excuse for a remaster I've ever seen. Modders have done more work to remaster this game than Square Enix did. All they really did was update the character models and some art for the GF's, cards, and stuff like that. The UI is nothing special and pretty boring. The new character models are decent, but pretty much nothing else was updated in the game and it's really jarring seeing the contrast between the models and everything else clash. All the pre-rendered backgrounds are like 160p, and some of them are so blurry you can't really tell what was supposed to be there in certain spots. The rest of the game is the same ol' FF8 Final Fantasy fans either hate with a passion or adore. There are a few QoL features that are mostly welcome. The 3x fast forward makes the draw system a little less crappy, and you can turn off random encounters. There's also basically a god mode you can turn off and on at any moment where your characters go to full health, and always have their LB, but that's obviously for complete cowards.

With that being said, you can make this game actually look like a remaster with some nice mods, although at some points in the game, they can cause it to crash and you'll have to disable them to proceed. You can turn them back on after very easily.

*********************************************************************************************
To find out how to mod look up mcindus ff8 remastered mods. There will be a qhimm forum page link. The instructions under each mod are pretty straightforward, but if you have issues there's a number of youtube vids that will show you how to mod the game. You'll also have to download something called the FF8 Demaster, which is basically just a mod tool that unpacks the game's files so they can be modded. There should be a github page to download it. That also has straightforward instructions to install and use.

Unfortunately to update the pre-rendered backgrounds you will have to pay $2 on McIndus' patreon and download the files from there, which might be a turnoff for some. He said it will be free whenever he finishes it in the future. You can just pay $2 to download it and unsub if you want to. The only bug I've encountered so far is some white tiles on the screen during some of the train travel scenes in the game because some of them were probably missing from the mod files. In my opinion paying the extra $2 for the backgrounds is 100% worth it if you're actually going to get mileage out of the game and don't want to wait because they are leaps and bounds better than the old ones.
*********************************************************************************************

column8:
The ending sequence for this video game was like the scene in the final act of Princess Mononoke where the barren hills are slowly restored to life but stretched out across 15 minutes. Pure distilled catharsis. 

The writers poured in so much love into this  game. One of the marks of a classic work of art is how well it overcomes the technical limitations of its time. Final Fantasy VIII delivers a theatrical experience that few other video games can hope to aspire too. I feel blessed to have my mind furnished with the beauty of this story.

column8:
I played this game when it came out and I was in high school and I loved it then and I love it now. It was my first final fantasy game and holds a special place for me. I am really enjoying the remastered version. Now when Rinoa tells him that he's the best looking guy here it isn't a funny joke because his pixelly face is pretty much like everyone else's, now he really is handsome. 

It is a love story, first and foremost, and a deep and charming one. The characters don't seem at first all that deep, just teenagers raised to be warriors, but there is a great deal more to each of them, especially Squall.  It is one of the few Final Fantasy games I've played that I did not hate at least one of the characters that you play (here's looking at you pre-Intergrade Yuffie and that sack of flour, Quina). The junction system is both frustrating and satisfying in equal measure. It makes you careful about what you use and which characters have which magics and Guardian Forces.

Overall I love the game. I recommend it strongly because the story is good, the gameplay is solid if different, and it is worth playing at least once.

column8:
DO NOT BUY!  A joke of a port. The game somehow manages to look WORSE than how it looked on PSX. They only "remastered" literally 10 character models and that's it (by "remastering" I mean adding 20 or so more triangles into them - they still look like they're from 1990s). The textures are low-res, all 3D models (except the 10 "remastered" ones) are low-res (which now clashes badly with the rest of the original models), the 2D field backgrounds are low-res, the overworld map is low-res, the pre-rendered cutscenes are simply copied from the 20-year old PC port (read: low-res, low FPS). The field backgrounds actually look even WORSE than 20 years ago, because they're still low-res and on top of that they are now blurred by some BS filter applied to the whole screen.  Oh, and have I mentioned already that the battles are running at 16 FPS. Yes, you see it right - no need to clean your screen - it's 16 as in SIXTEEN. I'd like to remind the younger audience here that the original game 20 years ago, on a hardware 1000 times weaker, was running at 30 FPS. Now we're in 2021 and we get basically the same game from 20 years ago, but somehow in a worse state than 20 years ago. 

To play this game correctly do as follows: 1. Do NOT buy this BS joke of a port. 2. Obtain (through any means) the original PC version. 3. Download the graphics mods, the FPS mods, the music mods.  Then you'll have a 60 FPS Full HD experience with the excellent PSX music for virtually zero money.

Do NOT buy this crap. You've been warned!

column8: É um jogo que adoro. Joguei no ps1 em inglês na minha adolescência. Estava com esperanças de jogar esse remaster em Japonês já que na descrição diz que tem o idioma, mas depois que comprei e instalei, vi que não tem como trocar.

Final Fantasy VIII, pour moi, c'est bien plus qu'un jeu : c'est un véritable morceau de mon enfance, un éternel refuge dans lequel je me suis plongé des heures durant, sans vraiment comprendre, à l’époque, toutes les subtilités de son histoire ou les détails de son univers. Mais qui a dit que j'avais besoin de tout saisir pour en être profondément captivé ?

Mes souvenirs sont tellement nombreux : les couloirs de la BGU où je m'imaginais étudier, la silhouette  tellement classe de Squall qui me donnait un modèle, Linoa qui était vraiment l'idéale que je me faisais de celle qui pourrait partager ma vie, Zell qui incarnait cet ami sur qui je pourrai toujours compter, le groupe d'amis qui vit des aventures tout en se découvrant au fur et à mesure, absolument tout me faisait rêver. Sans parler des villes : de la mystérieuse Timber en passant par la majestueuse Deling City (où l'on pouvait prendre le bus), sans oublier les missions des Seed qui m'ont marqué et qui le font encore aujourd'hui.
Finalement, l'univers était si riche, un mélange unique entre la vie étudiante, les amitiés naissantes, les responsabilités qui nous tombent dessus, même lorsque nous ne sommes pas prêts. Avec le recul, et à mon âge aujourd'hui, n'étant plus un enfant comme à l'époque, je réalise à quel point FFVIII était, malgré son ambiance fantastique, incroyablement réaliste dans sa manière de nous confronter aux enjeux de la vie.


Lorsque j'ai appris la sortie d'une version "remasterisée", je n'ai pas hésité une seconde. Peu importe les critiques, peu importe ce que disaient les autres (FFVIII est le moins bon etc),  pour moi, ce voyage en valait chaque instant et je ne me suis pas trompé. 

La première chose qui frappe, ce sont les graphismes. On ne parle pas ici d’une transformation totale, mais d’une belle mise à jour des personnages. Les décors, eux, n'ont pas changé, conservant leur charme originel. D'ailleurs, ce contraste entre les personnages modernisés et les environnements d’antan pourrait sembler déroutant au début, mais au bout d'une heure, tout devient fluide, naturel, comme si ce monde était resté en attente, attendant simplement que nous, joueurs devenus adultes, revenions pour le revisiter. A chaque scène, chaque panorama, c'est comme un vieil ami que l’on retrouve, inchangé, fidèle, prêt à nous accueillir encore une fois. 

Quelles émotions !

Ajout vraiment sympa sur la version R : les options de confort. Des aides, comme la vitesse x3 ou les Limit Breaks toujours disponibles, sont là pour ceux qui veulent redécouvrir l’histoire sans forcément affronter toutes les épreuves du passé. Oui, ces options peuvent déséquilibrer l’expérience pour les puristes, mais elles ne sont jamais imposées. Ce sont des choix, tout comme la vie nous offre des chemins différents selon les moments. Parfois, on a juste envie de se replonger dans un souvenir, sans en revivre toutes les épreuves.
Et que dire de l’OST...qui mériterait une review juste pour en faire l'éloge. Ces mélodies qui m'ont bercé, ces notes qui, dès qu’elles résonnent, parviennent à réveiller des émotions enfouies. Elles agissent comme des ponts vers le passé, vers ces instants où tout semblait plus simple et où chaque minute passée dans le jeu était une échappatoire. C’est vraiment comme si, en réécoutant ces musiques, je pouvais sentir de nouveau l’excitation de mes premières heures à la BGU, cette impression de vivre une aventure qui allait me marquer pour toujours. 


Mais, le plus beau, dans ce remaster, c’est peut-être ce parallèle entre nous et les personnages. Eux aussi ont changé, évolué graphiquement, mais ils évoluent dans un monde qui, lui, est resté le même. Et n’est-ce pas ce que nous, joueurs, ressentons aussi ? Nous avons grandi, nous avons changé, mais en revenant à FFVIII, nous retrouvons un univers figé dans le temps, fidèle à nos souvenirs, comme un cocon prêt à nous envelopper à nouveau. C’est une leçon sur le passage du temps, sur l’évolution, mais aussi sur la persistance de certaines choses qui nous rappellent d’où nous venons et ce que nous faisons.

Alors, si vous avez aimé FFVIII autrefois, ne craignez pas d’y revenir. Ce remaster est un hommage subtil, un rappel que, bien que nous ayons changé, certains mondes et certains souvenirs demeurent intacts, prêts à nous accueillir comme au premier jour. Et si vous êtes nouveaux joueurs, vous ne pouvez pas faire l'impasse sur une aventure qui à le pouvoir de véritablement vous changer.

column8: recordar viejos tiempos...

A story of love, separation and reunion

  

Everyone will have a unique view of a certain game. I don't know about everyone, but for me Final Fantasy VIII is about separation and reunion. Above all is the timeless love story of Squall and Rinoa. It can be said that Final Fantasy VIII is the most special part of the series for me right from the game's logo. Normally, the logo of the Series will only let one main character of the game or a big event affect the whole game. But the logo of VIII is the first time we see both the male and female protagonists depicted on the game's logo. Thereby we can guess that this game will focus on the story of the two main characters instead of just letting the love story of the male and female protagonists be just secondary compared to the main plot of saving the world. of other Final Fantasy titles. And of course it is. Final Fantasy VIII takes the love story of Balamb Garden SEED member Squall and the captain of the resistance against the Galbadian government, Rinoa Heartilly, as the theme revolving around the game. We can joke that the story that saves the world just accidentally gets caught up in their love story and they have to deal with it on their way to finding true love for each other.

  

  

FVIII is a long story with a lot of characters being dragged into it, so there are a lot of details and characters, so it's normal to forget a few characters and details, so I'll go into the details. A little detail to help people remember the details of the game because the game has been out for a long time anyway, so many people will not remember the game well. I just finished playing the Remastered version, so I just updated the game, so I remember a lot of the details.

  

Why do I say FFVIII is a story about separation and convergence? I wonder if everyone remembers the singer that Laguna met at the beginning of the game? Everyone must remember that Laguna has a crush on this girl and has always spent a lot of time going to her shows. She knows Laguna's feelings for her and she also loves him, even though the two don't talk much, but the fact that he often comes to listen to her sing is enough to prove his love for her. And their first and last conversation gave her hope that this was the person she was looking for. Unfortunately the army called him to the front lines so he had to say goodbye (and also goodbye because she died shortly after and Laguna didn't get a chance to see her again). This is the first separation in the love story of FFVIII. This singer's name is Julia Heartilly, do you think they look familiar? Because she is Rinoa Heartilly's mother. She married an officer of Galbadia while waiting for Laguna and gave birth to Rinoa. Then she died in an accident. She once said that she wanted to write a song for Laguna but she was bad at writing lyrics because she didn't know what to write. Soon after marrying the officer (named Carroway) she released a song called Eyes on Me and the song became a global phenomenon. This song is dedicated to Laguna and the lyrics are simply the advice Laguna gave her: "Write down what's on your mind" and the lyrics are about her feelings for him. She wrote this song as a final gift for Laguna so she can rest in peace and move on with her new family.

  

Eyes on me is also the theme song throughout Final Fantasy VIII. The lyrics talk about her last night with Laguna and tell him not to see her as a beautiful singer but instead to see her as a normal girl and if he treats her normally. Will he realize that she is more than simply singing well and dressing well. Although the song is Julia's for Laguna, it also uses Squall and Rinoa, is Squall related to Laguna??

  

The second separation was between Laguna and Raine, the girl he met while recovering in Winhill with Ellone. Both expressed their feelings for each other, but because Ellone was kidnapped, he had to set out to save her and when he saved Ellone, Raine died giving birth to Squall (ie Squall is Laguna's child). ) . He then sent Ellone back to Raine. However, because Raine died, both (Squall and Ellone) were sent to an orphanage.

  

The third separation is the one that affects our main character the most, making it difficult for him to open up to others because he doesn't want to be close to a person and then becomes miserable when he loses them. That was Ellone and the orphanage. Because Ellone was a sorceress, she had to hide, making Squall very sad.

  

A few other side separations such as : Cid Kramer and his wife Edea ( the sorceress controlled by Ultimecia ) , members of the orphanage . Seifer's gang.

And the reunion everyone is sure to recognize. That is the reunion of the Orphanage and Squall, Rinoa. Although everyone in the orphanage doesn't remember each other due to the side effects of Guardian Force, their relationship at the orphanage accidentally pulls them together.

 

As for Squall and Rinoa, we know that Squall is Laguna's child and Rinoa's Julia's child. Laguna and Julia's love affair did not work out, but their two children came together and accidentally healed their parent's love and turned it into a timeless love story.

 

Final Fantasy VIII is not one of my favorites because its gameplay is too weird compared to other games in the series, the content is also quite small but the music and the plot of VIII really made me see a story. Such a beautiful love.

column8:
[h1]This is the definitive version of this game as long as you can mod the backgrounds for higher resolution.[/h1] Check out mods by McIndus and others to accomplish that.

The boosters in this game are REALLY good and remove a lot of the tedium / deadends from the base game. Don't like the card game rules in the final areas? Just cheat and give yourself all the cards. Don't want a bunch of random battle spam during grindy story bits? Just turn on encounter-none.

This game is also fairly easy to 100% achievement hunt in as long as you do the sidequest ones before disc 4.

column8:
El título remastered está muy de más. Lo único remasterizado son los modelos de los personajes. Aún así es la mejor versión del juego y uno de los mejores Final Fantasy.

Lo recomiendo porque es la mejor forma de jugar FF8 a día de hoy y el juego de por sí es bruto juegazo.

El sistema de combate es el más balanceado de la saga (luego de FFXIV). No es necesario farmear niveles, al contrario vuelve el juego más difícil. Con el sistema de junction necesitas armarte de una build y estrategia para ir superando cada jefe. Farmear niveles se penaliza ya que los enemigos se ajustan a tu nivel. 

La historia es muy buena; no hay tanto enfoque en los personajes como FFVII salvo por Squall y Rinoa. La OST sigue siendo maravillosa, obra de Nobuo Uematsu. 

Gráficamente es un juego de PS1. Lastimosamente salvo los modelos de los personajes el resto se dejó intacto, por eso el nombre remastered le queda grande.

Técnicamente, 60fps en los menús, 30fps en el mundo abierto y pueblos y 15fps en combate. Los FPS están ligados a las animaciones y velocidad del juego. Pedir 60fps en todos los aspectos es un sinsentido y desconocimiento de desarrollo de videojuegos. Para eso tendrían que rehacer casi todo desde 0.

Edit: desde 17/10/2021 no es necesario usar plugins ni mods para estabilizar los FPS.

I have mixed feelings about Final Fantasy VIII, and I think it's towards the lower end of my rankings of the Final Fantasy series. The plot is alright, the gameplay is pretty fun, the music is great, and the characters are pretty interesting/fun. I definitely recommend FF8 as a game because I generally really like the Final Fantasy series, but I wouldn't necessarily rush to play it.

As far as graphics go, the original version of FF8 is very similar to FF7, but with improved character models (not amazing, but better than the Lego-esque ones in FF7). When I first tried FF8 on the PSX, I was really impressed with the jump in visuals with respect to FF7, but they certainly look pretty dated now (understandably so). However, I was not very impressed with the FF8 Remastered graphics compared to the regular FF8 graphics. From what I can tell, the main difference is that character models, UI elements, backgrounds, and FMVs have been improved, but in my opinion, not significantly enough to constitute a new release. Maybe I'm biased because of how amazing the FF7 modding scene is, but the "Remastered" enhancements in this release look like something the modding scene could come up with (to be honest, the FF7 fan mods are better than this official FF8 "Remaster"). I even checked out some videos of people playing the original PSX FF8 release using emulators with various visual enhancement features, and those honestly look just as good, if not better, than this release.

In short, I definitely recommend playing some version of Final Fantasy VIII at some point, as it's a decent game (though not the most amazing Final Fantasy in my opinion), but I can't recommend this specific release, which honestly feels like a cheap money grab

column8:
My favourite game (not just my fave Final Fantasy title). I played this game for the first time during the COVID-19 pandemic, so that is probably why I am so attached to it. I'll try to be unbiased here. The soundtrack of FFVIII is probably the best aspect of the game, and I would dare say the best in the franchise, just solid tracks all around. The world is also very good, although in the Remastered version, somehow the backdrops became so blurry, making the game almost looking ugly. 

Gameplay - the Junction system is quite fun, and I love the "novelty" that Magic is considered as an consumable item rather than the more common use of MP. I also love the concept of enemies leveling up with the player. HOWEVER, this was not so well executed as the Junction system became so exploitable that the whole game became just so easy. The biggest offender of this is the Limit Breaks, where you only have to be in critical HP and you can unleash unlimited LBs. That's why I would really wish for a Remake, where the Junction system is refined to be less expoitable.

TLDR: I LOVE FFVIII!

column8:
On first load this is legitimately appalling. I played the original on PS1 and the only criticisms I had for it then were a surfeit of bishounen character models and a quite linear, short and forgettable story. That said, I did like how Disc 4 was one long epic boss battle. It's weird how a game that on first purchase represented 'cutting-edge' graphics now looks like it's been roughed up in a piss-stained alleyway. Time is cruel I guess.

Picked this up in the current sales alongside 7 and 9 and thought I'd better check it on seeing the bad reviews after - I usually imagine bad reviews are being overly histrionic with this kind of thing- but the complaints about framerate are very real. I've never cared about what framerate I'm getting in a game as long as it looks right, but this runs like the rabbit in Švankmajer's 'Alice' or for more modern kids, the jerky horror of 'Mama'. You know when The Simpsons, back when it was good, would have a videogame like 'Bonestorm' that moved a step above cave drawings and you thought, even in 1992, well games aren't that basic, they're exaggerating for comic effect? This moves like that.

There's a free patch online that somewhat addresses this slightly so that at least you see animation inbetweens - see the forum - but that's the fan community trying to paper over the cracks and not any credit to SquareEnix or DotEmu. Even with this it's still... bad. Windowed even in 4:3 resolution, blurry pixelated backgrounds. Vaguely insulting built in cheat options to trivialise the whole thing even further. I guess some people want to play for just the story but experience that story as a spasmic flickbook? 

Only reason I've not refunded it is that I bought my key from an aftermarket seller, so I can't. Perhaps there'll be an official patch in four years time like Nier Automata got, but I don't suggest holding your breath.

column8:
Final Fantasy 8 was a stunningly good game when it came out for the Playstation back in the late 90s. It was an absolute gem - on a personal level its my favourite of the Final Fantasy games from the 90s / early 2000s era.

I found the idea of a remaster quite exciting at the time but was left feeling a little disillusioned after seeing some of the remastered screenshots and vowed not to play it over the original.

I was wrong - I managed to find this in a Humble Bundle sale so purchased it to give it a whirl. It was cheap for a fiver but it was a fiver well spent!

Pros

- The textures are a LOT better - visually the graphics do the game justice with the re-skinning of the character models and the fact that you can play this in full HD alone is a bonus.

- There are some nice little bonuses like boosts that allow you to speed up the game significantly - skipping some of the long winded GF and battle cutscenes. I always felt they were a bit too long and with the speed boost it makes the game a lot more playable.

- There are cheats to make the game easier (personally not a fan of cheats but if it floats your boat then they're available).

- The music and game sound is still excellent - not sure how you can improve on the original to be honest and I think it was a case of - if it aint broke don't fix it. It's still awesome.

- The story is as good and as epic as ever (its seriously long without ever feeling like a real grind) and the game controls are a lot easier to manage with modern gamepads supported and the ability to re-map keyboard controls.

If you're unlucky enough to have never played this game then I urge you to try it out - it's truly an incredible experience and a lot of fun!

Wadup  world. Here's a review n stuff. 

This final fantasy, in my opinion, is underrated. If you haven't played it and looking to play some old school RPG's I highly recomend. Though the graphics aren't modern, I believe the story and gameplay to be very compelling. The Junction system was potentially too complicated for casual gamers at the time, but is an amazingly rewarding system that I believe can make this game stand out in a very positive way. 

good: much better port than the other version that I had originally had on steam. My controller is much more functional without needing to modify anything. 

good or bad: it isn't a massive upgrade from the PS version, so remaster is a strong word, though the character models, seemingly one of the only upgrades, are great in my opinion. 

Bad: I guess my graphics card can't handle the intense graphics of this 23 year old game? cause the framerate, when I'm not in X3 mode, drops well below 15 fps. I cannot fathom why that's a thing, but luckily that's not a huge problem for getting to relive one of the best Turn based RPG's of all time.

column8:
Drawing magic is fucking boring and tedious, and the alternatives are almost as bad, with the addition of being needlessly convoluted. Like oh yeah, if you want to stock up on GLOB magic, challange random NPC  #5542 to like a thousand games of poker until you win one hundred of his pokemon cards, then use the GF skill SK - MED RARE, to turn the cards into ten FluShots, then use GF skill BN - FORBIDDEN MAG to turn the FluShots into one GLOB magic. Now just do that one hundred more times, and you'll have one character fully stocked with that spell. 

THERE YOU GO! THAT'S LIKE HALF THE FUCKING GAME!

The game has great music, and beautiful cutscenes, but it's so fucking tedious to play, and the writing ranges from bad to average. I'm on a FF Marathon. So far I've played 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8, 7-remake, and 15. And 8 is easily the worst so far. I'd take 2s individual stat leveling over Drawing/junctioning any day.

column8:
I have very fond memories of FFVIII on the original Playstation.  I won't give them too much crap about the remaster, since I prefer to play it as close to original as I can.  The updated models look nice, and the nifty add-ins are fun. 

That said, the game is basically unplayable. The overworld maps never get frame rates higher than 20fps, and when I'm in a zone/on a mission it gets about 23 fps. This would be bad enough, but how fast the game moves is directly tied to frame rate, which means you're playing the game in slow motion. It's not my setup either, since I can run other AAA games at or around 60fps, the issue has to be with the way the game is produced and coded. 

If i didn't already suffer through 20 hours of this I'd ask for my money back.

column8: FINAL FANTASY VIII is a game that tells the story of an avid triple triad player who traverses not only the entire planet but also outer space to complete his card collection. In his journey to become the ultimate triple triad player, he meets many skilled players such as the CC-Group and people who play with the Plus rule. My favorite part about this game is when Squall wins his character card, which is the last card needed to complete the collection, from his [spoiler] father [/spoiler]. However, my main gripe about this game is how hard it is to progress the main quest. I needed to resort to some RNG manipulation to make the Queen of Cards go to her father. There's also this sidequest about love and stopping an evil sorceress but I didn't really pay attention to it.

column8:
FF8 is an awesome game, and this isn't so much a "remaster" in earnest as much as it's just kinda touched up. You'd mostly be paying for an accessible port with cheat options for 3x speed/no encounters/etc.
That said, a Windows 10 update in May 2020 ended up fucking with the performance and framerate of this game, making it feel like sandpaper on your eyes. Over a year later and it's still like this. The only "solution" is to use awkward third party tools that I shouldn't have to install to just play a game properly, but I doubt Square Enix gives enough of a shit to actually come back and update their game.
Tried to get a refund but the pigfuckers at Steam rejected it because I owned the game longer than 2 weeks despite the fact that I played for under an hour.

If you're gonna get it, just get it on a console. They run fine there.

column8:
What a wonderful game. Played it the first time early 2000 on my Playstation 1 when I was 7 years old. At that point I did not understand how the game mechanic works and didnt rly care for the story. Stopped right before the end of CD1. Every like 2-3 years since then I wanted to finish the game, just cause I hate playing a game and not finish it. But didnt make it past end CD2/beginning CD3.

Now, like 1 week ago, I saw that there is a "REMASTERED"-Version on Steam. Didnt think twice and got it. In my opinion, it doesnt matter if you go for "Remastered" or the regular one. There are small benefits here like "Cheats", "Speed X3" and "FULL ATB". Only Speed X3 is recommended, the others just fuck up the experience and fun.

Tried to get in touch with the story, understand everything and get everything in this game done on my playthrough. Well, to be honest, if i wouldve played the game till end like 20 years ago, there is no way i couldve understood the connections between the characters. 

Now, like 6 days later and around 50h gameplay, I beat the game with everything done (went for the "Low-Level-Playthrough). Without my earlier knowledge of the game, it wouldve taken me around 80hours I guess. At least if I wanted to experience everything.

This game with its battle theme, soundtracks and music (for those of you who already played the game CARE MAYBE SPOILERS!! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HNefNLOHVYk), is captivating and worth every cent I payed for it this week, and same counts for the first version I bought in 2000.

I recommend this game to everyone who likes round-based / turn-based RPG, and not just "Monster-Slaughter-Games".

Final Fantasy 8 is the most underrated of the Final Fantasy franchise. 
That said, the graphics and soundtrack do not hold up in comparison to the FF games to have come since. There are some problems with the leveling mechanics due to enemies scaling to your grind so you can end up failing from success in this game. 

It's old and dated but I still recommend a full playthrough for any fan of the genre.

column8:
[h1]A Worthy Successor[/h1]

Now I'll admit I'm a sucker for these kinds of stories but FFVIII easily takes first place for story out of all the FF games I've played so far, I only wish it had MORE; [spoiler]while it does get its happy ending I can't help but want to see the characters lives after the events of the game à la Advent Children for FFVII (but way less fucking weird).[/spoiler]

But on the gameplay side of things a lot is left to be desired, the system is indeed great and has the start of something  fantastic but falls flat as it's hilariously abusable. You can practically accidentally break the first 20 hours of gameplay by drawing just a little to much magic from enemies early on giving yourself way too much damage and health, the game also pushes you towards doing this; I honestly don't now how they managed it in development it's an impressive fuckup.

but with that point aside it is still a lot of fun regardless of the lack of difficulty. The ending hour or so however does pick up the slack even if it's in an annoying way in that enemies drain your spell stacks leaving you fucking helpless depending on your luck.

So in the end I'd say the gameplay is about on-par or a little below FFVII but the story is the best in the franchise; and that's my opinion.

highly recommend, [i]bring tissues[/i].
column9:
[h1]A Worthy Successor[/h1]

Now I'll admit I'm a sucker for these kinds of stories but FFVIII easily takes first place for story out of all the FF games I've played so far, I only wish it had MORE; [spoiler]while it does get its happy ending I can't help but want to see the characters lives after the events of the game à la Advent Children for FFVII (but way less fucking weird).[/spoiler]

But on the gameplay side of things a lot is left to be desired, the system is indeed great and has the start of something  fantastic but falls flat as it's hilariously abusable. You can practically accidentally break the first 20 hours of gameplay by drawing just a little to much magic from enemies early on giving yourself way too much damage and health, the game also pushes you towards doing this; I honestly don't now how they managed it in development it's an impressive fuckup.

but with that point aside it is still a lot of fun regardless of the lack of difficulty. The ending hour or so however does pick up the slack even if it's in an annoying way in that enemies drain your spell stacks leaving you fucking helpless depending on your luck.

So in the end I'd say the gameplay is about on-par or a little below FFVII but the story is the best in the franchise; and that's my opinion.

highly recommend, [i]bring tissues[/i].

column8:
Being the first Final Fantasy I've ever played, Final Fantasy VIII was my first foray into the Final Fantasy series and JRPG genre in general. I spent countless hours and multiple playthroughs going through the expansive world and finding all the little secrets from one side of the map to the other. When I found out that they are going to be remastering my first and favorite Final Fantasy, I was ecstatic on going through it again with much better graphics and getting to experience the wonderful story again and for the first couple of hours, it was amazing. 

I loved experiencing the game over again and re-finding all the secrets I found as a kid. But after about 10 hours, an update to either the game or driver/Windows caused massive framerate issues. While it's still playable, playing at 22 fps just isn't the experience I wanted nor something I want to put up with for a 40-50 hour playthrough. It seems like SE is no longer supporting this title with updates so  I am unfortunately either stuck with a game that has framerate issues, or download an unofficial patch that requires me to turn off my antivirus (which I'm not willing to do). 

I did end up buying the remaster on Switch which doesn't appear to have the issue so it seems to be isolated solely on the PC version. I definitely recommend not purchasing this on PC and picking up on a console. I like the remaster and feel that it is worth the price asked but am disappointed with SE's support on their PC port and hope they treat the pixel remasters with better support than they did with the FFVIII Remaster.

I don't get much of the critique of this remaster. There are a lot of things that have been vastly improved compared to the original Steam version.

Pros
+ Auto Save
+ Included trainer (not much for me though except the "no random encounters" at times, i like to play legit and honestly the game is pretty easy anyway for the most part, like finishing the storyline)
+ More options
+ OST
+ Xbox controller support with actual prompts too
+ Improved models
+ Improved backgrounds (a bit better than the mod for the original version and without its bugs)

Cons
- FPS drops (rarely)
- No chocobo world idle game (but since you can get all items with the trainer it doesn't matter much, but of course it would be nice if it was included)
- The horrible 4 way movement is still there

I have played the original version for more than 300 hours and have killed most bosses and got the majority of game cards too. So i have some experience of that version and for the modern era it feels very lacking. This is funny since FF7 got better treatment even earlier (maybe cause it is more famous and popular, this is the underdog of later FFs after all).

column8:
ATROPELADO PELA NOSTALGIA COMO UMA MANADA DE RINOCERONTES RAIVOSOS.

[Terminado em 100% faltando apenas uma conquista com 83h]

Chego ao fim da trilogia em 3D de Final Fantasys do PSOne. Comecei com o 7, passei pelo 9 e agora finalizo o 8, que continua sendo o meu favorito da trilogia.

Eu gostei muito da versão remaster, apesar de ir na contra-mão da opinião geral. Achei que ficou charmosa, com os modelos melhorados e texturas mais nítidas, mesmo que destoem bastante dos backgrounds ou dos FMVs. Nada disso me incomodou pois estou acostumado a jogar jogos velhos, então aproveitei ao máximo a experiência.

Vale ressaltar que quem já havia jogado a versão de PC antes, os erros de DirectX foram corrigidos mas o Squall ainda se movimenta em apenas 8 eixos com o analógico, e não em 16 como no original do PSOne.

Bom, eu não vou me alongar muito nessa resenha pois o jogo é batido, mas vou dividir minha experiência pessoal.

A história é maravilhosa, apesar de não estar livre de furos no roteiro. A jogabilidade acho que é a mais sólida de todas, com o sistema de junções que pode deixar o personagem absurdamente forte mesmo em níveis mais baixos se você souber usar com maestria. A apresentação dos Summons é a melhor da série, na minha opinião, pois é a mais cinematográfica dos três, cheia de efeitos visuais e sonoros. A Shiva está maravilhosa. O jogo em si não é muito difícil e o "grind" é baixo. A evolução do personagem se dá quase que naturalmente se você não correr de nenhuma luta. Mais no final você "grinda" um pouco nas "Island Closest to Hell" pra pegar nível caso queira detonar com a Ômega Weapon, o chefe mais difícil do jogo.

Eu simplesmente adoro todos os personagens do nosso grupo. O Squall, com seu jeito estoico de ser, mas que no fim se importa com todo mundo. A Quistis, com ar de superioridade de instrutora mas com um coração de manteiga. O Zell, alegria do grupo, enérgico e sempre pronto pra sair no braço pelos amigos. A Selphie, coisinha fofa, decidida e corajosa, com o maior coração da trupe. O Irvine, com seu jeito galanteador de pistoleiro norte-americano, mas frágil e sensível por debaixo dessa carapaça. E claro, da Rinoa, que é a princesinha meio chatinha que você tem vontade de torcer o pescoço no começo, mas acaba se apaixonando pela firmeza de caráter dela junto do Squall. Menção honrosa para o trio coadjuvante Laguna, que é atrapalhado por demais  mas de enorme coração que, mesmo sem querer, acaba derrubando um regime ditatorial e se tornando um herói. Ao Ward e o Kiros, companheiros inseparáveis do Laguna, amigos leais e grandes guerreiros que ajudaram (e muito, diga-se de passagem) o Laguna a se manter vivo.

Eu terminei esse jogo em 100% trocentas vezes já, então eu me permiti usar o boost de limitbreak infinito e a aceleração x3 em alguns momentos como para adquirir item pra forjar armas, mas eu passei o jogo todo praticamente na raça. As cartas do Triple Triad (que é um mini-game alá trading cards) eu conquistei todas no suor, sangue e frustração até quase quebrar o controle de raiva por perder uma carta rara, mas no fim completei a coleção.

Eu segui o detonado da Gamestation lá de de 1900 e bola, publicado pela ProGames com editoração da JBC. Fiz um PDF a zilhões de anos atrás antes de perder a revista. Ainda bem, pois cá estou eu, 20 anos depois terminado o Final 8 pela enésima vez. O legal é que no detonado tem as estratégias pra enfrentar os chefões, e isso dá um adianto danado na hora de se preparar com as junções.

Então é isso galera. Recomendo a todos os fãs de FInal Fantasy e aqueles que buscam entrar na série. Marcou minha infância e estará para sempre gravado no meu coração com carinho.

Lionhart classifica 10/10 na escala leomaníaca pois a gente não escolhe os prediletos.
Um dos melhores remastered de jrpg. Recomendo.

Yes, I would suggest playing it, but this was the first Final Fantasy I ever played as a kid so I am definitely biased in my recommendation! I'm not sure how it plays without nostalgia, but here is what I've found most noticeable in this decades later replay:
- The angst! So much more than I remember, chill out Squall!
- The updated sprites overlaid with the original backdrops really makes you notice just how incredibly low the resolution was back in the day. Not sure how much I like the new high-def characters as the combination is quite jarring.
- The environment interaction can be difficult at times: half because of the age of the mechanics and half because of the low-def backgrounds being stretched across a 60" screen makes it hard to identify what's being displayed sometimes. I wish there was an indicator when I'm up against something I can select.
 - The movement (character and vehicles) is sluggish and imprecise. Again, this is just a fact of age, but thank goodness for the 3x speed multiplier option! It makes all the difference when you are making some of the many long treks in this game.

And that's all the detractors that have stood out for me so far (I'm about halfway through), and that said you get used to all this pretty quickly. This still unquestionably gets a thumbs up from me!

column8: Seria bom apenas que tivesse uma tradução Pt-Br, mas no geral o jogo é muito bom

First, getting the technical stuff out of the way. The game itself is stable, but runs at a reduced framerate without a certain version of a third party program. There's a popular guide on it so I won't go into detail. It's a relatively simple fix but nonetheless it's one I shouldn't have had to do myself.

From a purely visual standpoint, it's my favorite FF game so far. The game has a futuristic setting but doesn't fall into being dystopic, samey or utilitarian like most of its peers. Every city setting is grand and ornate, weird and colorful skyscrapers and transportation systems line the streets and even the "backwoods hick town" has these immaculate structures that tower over the prerendered backgrounds. It's to the point where generic caves or ruins feel completely alien in this world, and those rare moments of quiet scenery help to bolster the game's more emotional moments.

I've heard mostly negative things about Squall, and while I can definitely see where these people come from, I ended up liking him quite a bit by the end. Sure, he's mopey and distant in the first half, but it's not without reason and never to the point where it feels unrealistic. I've met people like Squall in real life, who turn people away so they don't risk having to lose them later. The only gripe I have for his arc is that he seems to fall for Rinoa very suddenly a little over halfway through the game. Maybe it's because I didn't have her in my party unless I had to (Square can't expect me to not use Irvine, god bless) but I can't really recall the exact time where Squall's feelings started to change, it just sorta happened.

The rest of the story is pretty hit or miss. This is one of those games where you literally don't get to see the main villain until the very end. Ultimecia is a huge step down from your Sephiroths or your Kefkas. She doesn't have any real reason for what she's doing and she's not doing it in a way that's fun. Laguna and his gang are fun (and they'd probably be my favorite parts if i didnt have to dread redoing my setup) but their story wraps up really hastily via some optional dialogue.

Truly this game loses most of its points with its gameplay mechanics. I can genuinely appreciate Square's desire to innovate on the turn based jrpg format, especially how sterile and samey they can get nowadays, but for every fun decision they make they screw it up with an equally bad one.
-The game has a ton of freedom with how your characters progress, letting them become incredibly overpowered extremely early on if you have the knowhow and the time (think Morrowind), but the level scaling system they implemented just means you get weaker and weaker as you progress unless you do extremely tedious exp avoidance strats (Card literally every enemy you can't run away from). It's really not fun to have all this power and not be able to use it.
-GFs were a great concept I would like to see refined in future entries. Think of a more involved version of VI's Espers that change your characters on an extremely fundamental level (IE, replacing your ability to use items in battles with a free revive command). Even though I wish the GF abilities were more unique and tied to the respective monster, I still had fun with it and really digged the summon animations (especially for that end game one, which was the one of the most flashy and absurd JRPG spells I've ever seen. If you know you know). Junctioning spells to stats was a complete failure though. Since all your best moves are tied to your strength it never feels good having to waste a rare spell on an enemy. The only good move is just to not bother and just use healing items and special commands, pretty much defeating the whole point of magic in the first place.

The issues I was having with the progression started to grow bigger as the game went on and about 3/4 of the way through I was just completely done with this game's antics. I broke my rule of not using the combat booster cheat and just powered through the last few hours and optional dungeons with Renzokuken. Some people would argue that you didn't beat a game if you cheated to win, but if that's the case I don't want to beat this game. I was tired of constantly restocking life and cure spells to keep my stats up, I was tired of trying to balance farming for materials and keeping my exp gain low, I was tired of the constant lingering status effects that seemingly every enemy had, I was tired of the slow ass 15fps random encounters where you had to keep turning the speedup off to time Squall's crit, I just wanted to see the story to the end and be done with it already. Keep in mind I didn't enable any of the boost features for FF7, not even the speedup, So it's really just this game that broke me, not long JRPGs in general.

Despite all my nagging, I still recommend checking it out - the version really doesn't matter. Go with the original if you want to see more Siren cootch i guess. This game is famously divisive within FF circles and the only way you can come to a conclusion about FF8's merits is just to play it yourself. If you want this Duck's opinion though, I give it a 5/10. Good ideas, good visuals, good characters bogged down with a reckless need to "innovate".

column8:
If you're thinking about buying Final Fantasy VIII on Steam, buy this port! (Not the other one). Also, this version has remastered the characters and looks sharper than the original version. This port has the original PS1 music in it, which to me makes a big difference in the games atmosphere (as opposed to the other one that has MIDI). 

Onto the game itself. It is one of my favourites in the series, and has been since it came out in 1999. It has a good story to it and good character development. This instalment is more Sci-Fi than traditional "fantasy" than some of the other instalments. But I don't mind that as I enjoy Sci-Fi just as much as the traditional fantasy of IX, VI and IV. 

I also really like the Junction system because there are all sorts of ways to work magic to different stats and also to different situations. Once you have got your head around how that works, it's really good. 

Also, the soundtrack and the FMV cut scenes <3

column8:
This may be the eleventh time I've played FFVIII since its release in 1999; it's gameplay suits me well. I'm among those weirdos who enjoy the grinding-ness of Drawing magics, the persnickety experimentation allowed by this game's Junction system, and the that-don't-make-no-sense-ness of its story that makes it less coherent even than the story of FFVII.

Harry and Draco -- I mean -- Squall and Seifer (I'm not the first to make that comparison) aren't as compelling as Cloud and Sephiroth but their [spoilers withheld] helps to make their rivalry/mutual admiration feel equally as personal. The revelations about the relationships between all of the main characters are fun to review and I get caught-up in all the sci-fi, supernatural melodrama.

The world-design, character-design, monster-design, music, and sense of humor are also important to my repeated enjoyment of Final Fantasy VIII.

column8: This is a review of the port. Square Enix is a s**t company. So many terrible FF ports and this one is one of the worst. Clear HD character models with extremely blurry backgrounds is real jarring and makes the game look terrible. Removed analog controls so talking to certain NPCs is a pain in the a$$. This is an awful remaster, but luckily modders have saved a terrible FF port once again.

Love the game, hate this "remaster". Long story short: pretty much anything you'll look at in this game hasn't been updated at all. There are a couple of new models and a couple of new textures, but they still have the old animations which usually means that they end up pretty strange.

But the real issue here is that movies and backgrounds haven't been updated AT ALL. Movies are still 15fps, they still have the compression artifacts from the first PC release. Just using SVP on the original PSX movies would have resulted in better quality.

Backgrounds have bilinear filtering enabled and that's it. There's no advanced upscaling neither in real-time nor are there are updated backgrounds included. It's just the same as on PSX.

I have to say, I usually don't rant about game releases, but this one is a disgrace. DotEmu, SquareEnix: Get your act together. This is no way to treat your customers. This isn't even close to a remaster.

At least have the decency to run the assets through a low-cost image-enhancement tool... would cost your half a day's work and we could at least PRETEND this was a decent update.

Final Fantasy przeżywa od kilku lat złoty wiek na Steam. Od wydań siódemki czy ósemki po remaster X/X2 czy XII Zodiac Age. Niestety z tą ilością (każdy numeryczny FF od 3 wzwyż jest tutaj wydany) nie idzie w parze jakość i zdarzają się koszmarki w stylu FF6 słabo zportowanego wprost z urządzeń mobilnych, czy wychodząc poza „Fajnale” Chrono Trigger będący bodaj najgorszym portem z androida od Square, tę ostatnią grę na szczęście poprawili po masywnym bombardingu w reckach. No ale miałem pisać o remasterze FF8, więc już kończę dygresję i zapraszam do właściwego tekstu.

FF8 Remastered został wydany w 2019 roku, można rzec na fali zbliżającego się remake’u Siódemki. Mieliśmy dostać 8-mkę w grafice HD i z nowymi modelami postaci. No i cóż – dostaliśmy, ale czy wprowadzone zmiany warte są ponownego zakupu, lub kupienia tej konkretnej wersji? Na to pytanie najlepiej odpowiedzieć sobie samemu porównując Remastered z wydaną na Steam w 2013 klasyczną wersją. Do wymienionej wersji będę też robił porównania.

Zacznijmy od samej grafiki, bo tutaj moim zdaniem „kwadratowi” polegli. Odpaliłem sobie niedawno obie wersje gry, żeby mieć na świeżo w pamięci to, co widziałem. Nie wiem, co kierowało developerami, gdy wybierali metodę odświeżenia grafiki świata, po którym się poruszamy. Użycie rozmycia czy też wygładzenia krawędzi dało taki efekt, że tak zwane „backgroundy” wyglądają jak zamglony wid osoby z krótkowzrocznością przerastającą moją. Jeśli dodamy do tego fakt, iż lwia część modeli 3d a zwłaszcza główni bohaterowie i npc dostali nowiutkie, ostre jak żyleta tekstury stworzone zresztą przez twórców oryginału, to dostajemy swoisty graficzny dysonans, który może razić w oczy. Osobiście wolę wersję 2013 dla której powstały mody poprawiające grafiki tła w o wiele lepszy sposób. Dodam, że GFy (Summony) także doczekały się liftingu. Poprawiono też wygląd karcianki Tripple Triad, karty wyglądają teraz całkiem ładnie. Tak więc na tle graficznym dostaliśmy swoisty half remaster i polecam zobaczyć sobie na YouTube porównanie obu wersji (2013 i 2019).

Dźwiękowo jest z kolei zdecydowanie na plus. W końcu mamy oryginalną ścieżkę dźwiękową z PSX zamiast midówek, które trafiały do poprzednich pecetowych wersji gry. Tylko, że mając wersję 2013 można sobie modem przywrócić tą muzykę.

Z innych zmian największą jest usunięcie minigry Chocobo World obecnej w każdej poprzedniej edycji FF8 w tym tej z 2013. Itemki z CW dostajemy teraz w trakcie wykonywania limitu Angelo Search.

Powracają znane już z pierwszej steamowej edycji cheaty i boostery pozwalające ułatwić sobie tą już i tak łatwą grę. Dodano też funkcje trzykrotnego przyspieszenia gry i wyłączenia losowych walk (losowe walki i tak mógł nam od zawsze wyłączać Diablos).

Łowcy trofeów powinni być zadowoleni, że zniknęły niektóre achievementy, zwłaszcza 10k walk, pamiętajcie, że cheaty aktywowane w menu gry wyłączają osiągnięcia, ale już te odpalane padem jak wyłączenie walk czy przyspieszacz nie mają na nie wpływu.

Z różnych opinii graczy docierają też niepokojące doniesienia o craschach gry, jednak ja przez 70 godzin grania nie uświadczyłem żadnego nagłego wyjścia z gry czy innych anomalii.

Podsumowując. Nie będę ani zachęcał, ani odradzał zakupu tej konkretnej wersji FF8. Popatrzcie sobie na YouTube na porównania i zdecydujcie, co przypada Wam bardziej do gustu. Jednak ocenić ten szumnie zapowiadany remaster muszę na szkolną tróję. Jako odświeżenie gry wypada po prostu przeciętnie, popatrzcie na remaster FFX dla przykładu, tam wyszło to o wiele lepiej. Jeśli najdzie mnie ponownie ochota na zagranie w FF8 to wrócę do wersji z 2013 z modami. Oczywiście to tylko moja opinia i Wam przyjęty styl graficzny może nie przeszkadzać. Łapka leci w górę, ale tylko z braku opcji łapki neutralnej.

column8:
[h1] I want to live in Balamb Garden.[/h1]

I'm a hardcore fan with FF8, so many times I would even try to escape reality with lucid dreaming, I would be in Balamb Garden where I would often train with Zell in the training center and help Selphie with the Garden Festival, but one day as I was talking to Selphie, we went to my dormitory for a private talk. She immediately said, "You know you could live with us forever.." I gave her a confused look and she continued, "We understand that you live on earth and you REALLY wish to live here". I then said "How..How did you know?" She then giggled and said "Because we've been watching you, silly!"

This was a dream come true and I almost cried right there. She then said, "I talked with Headmaster Cid and he agreed that you would be PERFECT for SeeD, you just have to do...one thing". She then held my hand and looked deep into my eyes and said "...You have to kill yourself for the transfer to work correctly." I then gave her some questions, "How long do I have before the deal expires?" She then said "Cid said 3 months.." I added by saying "What's the most painless way?..." She giggled again, "Suicide will require pain buuut...if you want it quick...Get a gun and a nice shot to the head works.

I then agreed and she gave me a kiss on the forehead, "I know this will be tough but once it's over and done, you'll get to live here!" I then woke up and this was last week and i purchased a gun. I might actually kill myself because that dream just felt too real to be fake and my life isn't doing so grand.

[h1]NON CREDEVO POTESSE SUCCEDERE[/h1]

Ho cominciato la mia run di recupero della saga ad inizio anno, con FF7 che ho finito in un mesetto, poi sono passato a FF8...

[b]QUESTO GIOCO È FANTASTICO[/b]

Sono venuto a conoscenza del fatto che è considerato uno dei FF più scadenti sotto alcuni punti di vista, e che non so ancora quali, ma questo gioco mi ha regalato delle emozioni.
La storia tra Rinoa e Squall è semplicemente perfetta, bellissima non so che altro dire.
[spoiler]Tra l'altro la scena nello spazio è bellissima, tra cui anche il finale, dove credo che Squall sia ancora vivo[/spoiler]

L'unico punto debole del gioco secondo me è il boss finale, [spoiler]Sinceramente quattro fasi sono troppe, considerando questa boss fight. Mi ci sono voluti molti tentativi, tanti, tanti, tanti. Poi a caso provo un try come tutti gli altri e nessun personaggio è mai morto, ok. Ho capito che se non hai le magie precise come un miliardo di aura e haste allora non è fattibile.[/spoiler]

Veramente un bel gioco.


                                                                        -  [b]The End[/b]  -

One of my guilty pleasure games. I personally would have preferred this to be remade

Pros 
Slow burn leveling up system due to junction and draw system where stats rely on GF and Junction and it increases slowly per chapter if you won't over level in an area
Amazing music as always
Beautiful fight sequences for a turn based RPG like summons and limit breaks 
Beautifully directed set pieces
Tons of enemy designs that are unique and not reused
Amazing and probably the most memorable card mini game in FF history
Unique and different story

Cons
Busted Leveling System If you really over level
Complicated Card Rule Removal and Passing System
Yes and No Tests to Increase Gil
You can get Ga- magic before even getting Ifrit (First mission / boss) if you have patience
Progression problems like near impossible to perfect without guide with so many missables

Play this if you are a Final Fantasy Buff who haven't played it yet, if you're looking for a new RPG or also looking for something new and updated from the past

Don't play if you have a notion that it's FF7 or FF9 in terms of overall likeness and balance,
