column8:
I love this game. And playing it again makes me love the story once more. But I hate *playing* this game, and this remaster does almost nothing to alleviate that. 

Is it really a remaster? They added some cheats, which is nice I suppose, but core mechanics still don't work right on modern computers. (Boosting GF's is way harder than on an old console, presumably due to the framerate/input-lag issues that existed in previous PC ports of the game which apparently still haven't been corrected.)

It's a grind. A long painful tedious grind. But it's a great nostalgia hit, and if you have any memory at all of how amazing it was when it came out it might just be worth it.
If you never played it the first time though, hooo boy are you in for some fun. Maybe go watch a highlights/overview on YouTube instead.

column8: I see so many poor reviews and while everyone got different opinions and expect different things from remasters I am more than happy with this game, given I didnt have this game for pc prior to this and maybe thats why. It must have been 10 years since I played FF VIII from the beginning again, Its in my top 3 FF games together with VII and XV from a personal enjoyment view only. There's some background characters forever pixelated but im weird enough to have this give me a "homey" feeling as FF VIII wouldnt be VIII without some pixelated faces. If it was more expensive maybe I wouldnt recommend it but 20 to play one of my favorite games again has definitely been worth it for me and I have many more hours to go.

I really wanted this to be more... I wanted this to be THE version of FF8 to play... but really, it's the same game. I already own the barely-less-expensive PC version and the blocky models -- of which I'm well accustomed to, having played the good ol' PS1 version on release -- just don't bother me.

The back grounds have an anti aliasing filter; but it just manages to make them smooth and blurry. It all seemed to be kinda cleaner until right after the first scene where you enter the classroom... and there it was.

Crisp, clean, HD models next to jagged, ugly, 2D sprites baked into the background just like on the PS1. THERE it was forgivable. THERE the hardware limitations made this make sense. On modern hardware with plenty of NPC models to have chosen from to populate the world? There really isn't an excuse. This isn't a remaster... this is a mod pack.

Speaking of, Roses and Wine is all I really need with my original copy to get the music in line. The models? Well, they aren't the prettiest in the world; but, as models on the RPG board that tell me where I'm at and who I'm playing? They work just fine. 

Sorry, Squeenix. I'm pumped for VII and I feel like one of the few who would say that VIII is one of my favorites; but, I just can't spend $20 for table scraps when I know I have the game I spent $15 for already sitting there waiting for me to play it.

Regretfully, this'll actually be my first refund on Steam... and I hate that it's something I was so hype for. I hate that this wasn't something more for one of the more underrated (draw system excluded. All complaints are justified there.) FF games. I'm off to play the original 2013 port with naught but a few mods to get the buttons looking right (A, B, X, etc rather than the [SELECT] [CANCEL] [MENU], etc labels) and the music back to ps1 style.

If you'd have done more, squeenix, I'd have been happy to pay $20 for a nice, pretty game... but all I got was a slight modification to a game I already own.

This is hard to write because I absolutely love FFVIII. This review will assume you are familiar with the game and are considering purchasing the remastered version to re-play the game you love.

Unfortunately for us PC gamers, *this* is the best legal version we can get unmodded. 

I have dumped the .ISO file from my original PS1 game and emulated it on ePSXe and it is glorious, but I'm not certain of the legality (it should totally be legal to play my own game).

So this is what we get - a half hearted remake.

ADDED:

I haven't read any specs or anytning, so this is just what it appears to me to be new.

-All main characters have new HD models and they look nice, though Squall's hair is a bit off.
  -It must be said that all prerendered backgrounds have *not* been upgraded. You're getting cool new character models on top of blurry backgrounds
-All Tetra Master cards have new HD models
-Monsters have new HD models
-The original PS1 score is included, but it's buggy as heck. The game has twice randomly dropped all sound effects and reverted to the awful original PC MIDI score for no darn reason
-Guardian Forces have new FANTASTIC HD scenes
-Cheats and 3X speedup

TLDR; You're getting a port of the FFVIII PC version with new HD models and the same old blurry backgrounds. You're getting some cheats and a speed-up.

This should've been $9.99 DLC for the original rather than a $19.99 stand alone.

Try harder, please, Squeenix.
column9:
This is hard to write because I absolutely love FFVIII. This review will assume you are familiar with the game and are considering purchasing the remastered version to re-play the game you love.

Unfortunately for us PC gamers, *this* is the best legal version we can get unmodded. 

I have dumped the .ISO file from my original PS1 game and emulated it on ePSXe and it is glorious, but I'm not certain of the legality (it should totally be legal to play my own game).

So this is what we get - a half hearted remake.

ADDED:

I haven't read any specs or anytning, so this is just what it appears to me to be new.

-All main characters have new HD models and they look nice, though Squall's hair is a bit off.
  -It must be said that all prerendered backgrounds have *not* been upgraded. You're getting cool new character models on top of blurry backgrounds
-All Tetra Master cards have new HD models
-Monsters have new HD models
-The original PS1 score is included, but it's buggy as heck. The game has twice randomly dropped all sound effects and reverted to the awful original PC MIDI score for no darn reason
-Guardian Forces have new FANTASTIC HD scenes
-Cheats and 3X speedup

TLDR; You're getting a port of the FFVIII PC version with new HD models and the same old blurry backgrounds. You're getting some cheats and a speed-up.

This should've been $9.99 DLC for the original rather than a $19.99 stand alone.

Try harder, please, Squeenix.

column8: The redone character models are a nice touch, and the fact that it doesn't use the MIDI music is good (except for some glitch that I've heard about but haven't seen for myself yet). There's some people online claiming that the change to Siren's model is a bad move, but the real problems in this game are the backgrounds and the wonky framerates. The field backgrounds aren't upscaled at all. it looks like the only thing that was done with them is they were put through a smoothing filter. And the world map and battleground backgrounds don't look like they were touched up at all. And that ties nicely in with my "Wonky Framerates" comment - battle is locked at 15FPS for non-turbo. I can't boost the GFs to insane power - like I do ALL THE TIME on PlayStation - with the framerate like that. I wish I could recommend this game... I really do - but I can't. Not in this state. Here's hoping Square-Enix figures this one out and fixes at least a couple of these issues.

Sempre quis jogar esse titulo da série FF, mas nunca tive a oportunidade, quando descobri que tinha sido lançada uma versão na Steam em 2013 com certeza quis comprar, só que foi bem na época da E3 desse ano, e não é que a Saquere Enix anunciou justo um Remaster dele, então resolvi esperar ser lançado, e valeu muito a pena!

 FF8 já se tornou meu FF favorito, e depois de ter jogado também o FFX/X2, me pergunto porque mais titulos da franquia não tem foco em romance, Squall e Rinoa são perfeitos!
Agora é torcer para um dia a Square Enix fazer um Remake, e com certeza FF8 merece!

8: There are people around who are happy with this "remaster" 

9: They charging money for this, it would have been much better as a patch for the 2013 release 

 

My conclusion = don’t buy yet wait for mods to polish this turd into a diamond

column8:
Sadly, cannot give this a positive review in its current state :(

Aside from weird inconsistencies (the soundtrack for instance - why is it made up of a mix of both CD versions AND MIDIs? What is that all about?) and now-missing previous features (incomplete analog controls - no 360 degree movement or rumble; less achievements than the old version), the game has clearly not had all of its bugs squashed (one of which has made me put off playing it entirely until the issue is fixed - the flashing hand cursor that doesn't go away once it shows up and is incredibly distracting).

The backgrounds have been blurred far too heavily in my opinion; would at the very least like to have the option to switch to the original unfiltered backgrounds (not to mention the missed opportunity about potentially having the backgrounds AI upscaled, which, as we've have seen from fan renders, can produce some amazing results).

Another underwhelming, half-baked SE port... Please fix this, FF8 deserves better.

Okay, when I bought this Remastered version in Steam, the game had a Mostly Negative review for it citing HD Models isn't in full and I agree with majority of them (my biggest trigger would be the before the Dollet mission where Cid somehow blended in with the environment, leaving other characters visible but not Cid) but bombing them for that sake alone is childish at most.

Don't take the negative reviews too seriously because of that aspect. Final Fantasy 8 is the best Final Fantasy, yes, it is different than the normal formula of the other Final Fantasy franchise but it is still good.

The game launcher itself is way easier to navigate as oppose to the older version which Steam also has but the only advantage to the older version is that you can mod, provided you know the know-how.

For new players who wanted to know who Squall and the gang is, give 8 a try, be it the older version or the Remastered, other than the HD models and the awful midi soundtrack on the old version, both version gave the same great experience.

Another note as of 2023/03/11 I finally buckled down and finished this game... All that to 100% completion pretty much. All i have left to do is finish the game and beat omega weapon. 
My opinion still stands... Great game terrible port. 

Note as of 2022/10/30 The game is finally in a playable state but i won't change my stance on this port  / remaster whatever you call it being pure garbage. You are better off buying the older version while you still can. 

Words cannot properly describe how annoyed i am at this port. While staying with in steams terms of service and well as being respectful to the devs who did ...work on this. What i see here is a changed up font and new characters models slapped on older character models which are still present in the game seen in a few of the starting areas. 

It's almost laughable that this got approved and shipped... did they learn anything from chrono trigger? Clearly not. I do like final fantasy 8 this is not a rant on the game what so ever. This is a rant on squares constant disappointment when it comes to porting things over to pc. Fans have proven time and time again that they can do a better job then they can with mods and such. 

Sqaure enix as a company i do like them and there games but you guys gotta get better at your pc stuff. It can be done correctly with time and effort. This ... barely any effort got put into lets be honest here... Sure they can say they didn't have the original code but once again fans have done better.

Ce remaster aurait dû sortir il y a des années, mais la déception est encore plus grande lorsqu'on voit ce que SquareEnix en a fait. Les modèles de personnages sont une grande réussite, ainsi que ceux des GF (je salue d'ailleurs le travail qui a été fait sur Shiva, dont le visage est extrêmement réaliste). Les options de confort ainsi que la mise à disposition des objets du Chocobo World sont les bienvenus également.
Voilà on a fini pour les points positifs. Les arrières plans sont une honte. SquareEnix a pris pour excuse que ça n'a pas été fait en raison de la perte de code source (?). Les moddeurs nous montrent bien que ça n'a aucune importance. J'ai remarqué aussi des changements sur les illustrations des cartes et d'autres petites modifications ici et là. Pourtant du travail était dû sur d'autres points (que les fans ont demandé), mais plutôt ils ont décidé de faire ces modifications dont personne ne se soucie... Voilà, Final Fantasy VIII est un excellent jeu, mais le Remaster mérite à peine cette dénomination.

I bonus aggiuntivi, potenzialmente chiamati "cheat", sono certamente interessanti per chi ne fa uso, altrimenti, dopo essere trascorsi anni, e dopo che un fan ha realizzato una mod in HD con una grafica generale migliorata, ci si aspetta che anche Square Enix possa farcela. Forse avevano bisogno di più tempo, molto probabilmente la questione tempistica li ha presi alla sprovvista, ma rimane un lavoro fatto a metà dal punto di vista grafico, e da un titolo definito remastered non è esattamente ciò che si aspetta. C'est, blindé de bandes noires...
Les persos sont jolis et c'est tout...
Sur la map pour se balader c'est juste dégueulasse, du 32 bits classique. 
Déçue. Et les décors sont à peine lisser (et je suis sympa). Les scènes cinématique en image de synthèse sont celles de la PS1, sans amélioration, bande noire, et pixelisé.

C'est un foutage de tronche, dommage. Remboursement.

Highly recommend as this is the definitive version to play Final Fantasy VIII. There is definitely issues with the Remaster(which I will go over) but not enough that it makes any previous version better.

The character models are fully redone. This means the jagged angles and squished faces no longer happen and this applies to NPC's with the exception of any character baked into the background. The only designs that could have been updated a little better is Squalls hair and face which contrast poorly with his CG design and Rinoa's hair seems too flat and lacking volume otherwise the rest have never looked better. These weren't the only ones to receive redone models. All boss enemies and Guardian Force have received new and detailed models. Regular enemies has also been touched up but some received the full Remaster treatment while others are just cleaned up a bit which is okay because they still look quite good.

The boosters are the best quality of life feature added to this. The x3 boost makes any parts that would normally drag on(repeat Triple Triad matches and Draw) move faster and smoother than regular play. The rest of the boosters allow anyone wanting to take it easy and just revisit the game for story purposes simple with the No-Encounter option right from the beginning rather than learning the ability with Diablos.

The FMV's were touched up compared to the original release and the backgrounds were cleaned up but given a blur affect that unfortunately causes a contrast between the new models and background. Thankfully the blur is easy to adjust to so while some areas definitely look bad others are completely easy to ignore. The game also uses the PS1 soundtrack which sounds even better. 

This version is using the PC port from 2013 which lacked Analogue Controls and Vibration Rumble which means it's not in this version either. Neither of these are game breaking features but definitely would have smoothed out some of the movement and added that tiny extra bit of fun when doing Triggers. The other problem is battle menu's running at 15FPS due to the PC version having this problem. 

Achievements are in all versions now except Switch and are just as fun to unlock. None are particularly difficult to do which makes for stress free run for any new or returning players.

There is some bugs that will hopefully get fixed but most seem to be avoidable. The Landing seems to be the only track with an issue where it will switch to midi. This ONLY happens once in the game towards the end of Disc 2 while the other time is a bug you need to trigger in Dollet and doesn't happen normally. 

Overall this a gorgeous Remaster that makes the experience fresh and exciting to be able to properly see faces and details in designs you might have missed before due to the horrid pixelation of the original. The original soundtrack being back in without modding is fantastic. Anyone recommending the 2013 version is offering a downgrade on almost every level considering it's the version the Remaster started with and upgraded from. If you need to suggest something while also telling everyone they need mods to fix it then you're just making your suggestion look redundant especially since mods will eventually be made for the Remaster fixing some of the problems people currently have. 

9/10 is my rating. It would have been higher if they smoothed out the bugs and battle FPS.

column8:
About half a remaster, if you ask me. Graphically, the animated models and the FMVs are updated to HD resolution (so you can finally see details like Griever in the game itself), but the game itself is still in 4:3, the models and textures for backgrounds are at their original resolution (so it looks like a game where characters from a 2014 AAA title are running around in a blurry Playstation 1 environment), and the 3D animations themselves are at their original state so some actions (like Cid's speech in the first part of the game) look choppy. Some in-game menus like the school terminal are also at their original resolutions, so this makes for a rather painful experience trying to read menus originally rendered at 640x480. This last one should have been a slam dunk, but whether due to technical difficulties or oversight, it's now an air ball.

This remaster makes many languages available, so I picked Japanese since (a) I can mostly read it, and (b) I heard there were some liberties taken with the English translation (and the FF7 Switch port's original Japanese indicates this as well). Kudos to Square Enix for not limiting the language selections. This is accessible from the launcher's "config" dialog.

The soundtrack and SFX got a bit of a makeover. Some tracks are "boomier" for lack of a better word, and Quezalcoatl's summoning now has different SFX from what I remember, for example. The overworld and battle tracks, however, are largely untouched.

The controls were previously a hot mess, with you having to remember which number is mapped to which key or button rather than the game using unique names for each button (FF7 Eidos PC port) or, ideally, telling you which buttons to press in the dialogue based on your key mapping. This made the "punch the password" minigame a nightmare to play, because they would call out a sequence of numbers which wouldn't make any sense even with a standard controller. Now there's a button mapping "abstraction layer" if you would, which is accessible at all times from the in-game system menu by pressing Esc. Yup, instead of putting this stuff in the game's config screen, they made an entire second menu system. This is probably to make future game configurations more consistent, but it's shoddily documented. But this should eliminate nearly all issues related to custom keyboard/controller configs.

The game itself is unchanged from the previous PC port, so there's no new content, unfortunately. This also means that stupid control schemes like for cars remain in effect. Unlike the previous port, however, the Chocobo minigame app originally for the PS Pocket is not part of the package, which is unfortunate because it was a bit of a reliable way to get some exotic items for the main game including weapon upgrade parts. Maybe a smartphone app will become available in the future, but I'm not holding my breath.

So, to recap, nicer graphics, backgrounds and in-game displays that now make me want to puke, FPS issues, and no Chocobo minigame (though to be honest, there's an official "all items" cheat that obviates grinding or hex editing through the minigame). They might go back and update the remaining parts of the remaster, but for now, I can only recommend getting this on sale.

column8:
I went into this totally excited and ready to play FFVIII again after so long...and promptly found myself refunding it with less than an hour played. (And this was the first time I've ever requested a refund from Steam.)

I could have played the original again and have been happy with it, even dated as it is. The fact that they called this a 'Remaster' is what I take issue with, as literally all they did was update character skins. (This looks hilariously off at times, such as an early scene in Quistis' classroom in Garden where half the students have new models, and half have old models.) Square-Enix has done some really good Remasters as of late, with Secret of Mana, FFX/X-2, and FFXII as examples. This one is false advertising. This one is just...lazy. And a shame, because the core game is very good.

I'll hold off, though. I'll wait for the sales and see what the mod community has together by then.

column8:
Everyone. Please. This is the game I grew up with, far flung from the basic train everyone was on with VII. And it was a black sheep from the start. When the original on Steam emerged, I was surprised. To think that Square cared between all the other greats. And now suddenly we have this.

The music fixed to the perfection it was in olden days.
The entire game is set for a controller from the start, down to the cheat options on sticks (clicking the left speeds the jam up, almost like a sprint button on the long corridors).
They thought ahead and removed the crazy achievements like beating it without leveling Squall and killing 10000 enemies (in ONE playthrough).
And then, guess what? We got upgraded characters. Sure, Squall's the anime pretty boy they made him in Dissidia (goodbye, strong chin...), but dang. Even the other games being ported over didn't get love like this, save for IV.

Square cares. Maybe not enough, but they do. And we care even more. The community. The modders will have this spiffed up in like a week.

I love this game. And we don't need to attack it for "not doing anything" if we want Square to know that.

我懷疑根本是 SE 社為了省中文化成本吧，反正華人玩家都會自己想辦法處理

說真的，如果我是日本人、美國人，FF8 一款遊戲冷飯炒了那麼多次，我還真的不會買單一個沒誠意的 REMASTERED 版
今天因為我是台灣人，基本上已經沒有什麼管道可以玩正版的、中文的 FF8 了，只能夠巴望 STEAM 版還有沒有機會
結果 SE 社又再次毫不意外的辜負台灣玩家的期待了，所以我給負評也是毫無懸念
我很喜歡 FF8 這遊戲，但 SE 社無誠意的作為實在讓我非常不喜歡

Estuve dudando si recomendar este juego o no, ya que es mi Final Fantasy preferido. 

Básicamente lo único que mejoraron (enormemente) son los diseños de los personajes principales. De ahí se nota demasiado el mal trato hacia otros secundarios (Zone, Watts, etc). 

El juego está en 4:3, lo cual es entendible al tratarse de escenarios cuya imagen originalmente estaba en este formato, pero creo que podrían haberlo mejorado, al igual que la calidad de los mismos (tiene un blur que disfraza el pixelado).

Tiene un par de bugs, como desfasaje en la música cuando se activa la velocidad x3.

El mapamundi es inmirable.

Dentro de los "pro" además de la mejora en los personajes principales, están los trucos que incorpora, que para los que jugaron el juego en su día como yo (allá por 1999) y le metieron cientos de horas en PSX, más 70 en Steam, y sacaron casi el 100% del juego, puedan rejugarlo rápido para revivir la historia (que es para mi hoy en día, el único motivo para volver a adentrarme).

En fin, lo recomiendo para nostálgicos como yo. Si no lo jugaron antes, la versión original está mucho más barata y con mods se acerca bastante a ésta y la supera en otros aspectos, sumando que sacan la tentación de los trucos y te incita a exprimir el juego para conseguir todas las habilidades, G.F., armas, etc.

Habia hecho una review bastante positiva sobre el juego (o por lo menos diciendo la verdad sobre sus virtudes y carencias). Pero saben que? a medida de que avance en la trama (pasando el cd1) me di cuenta de que tiene mas bug de los que creia, esta rotisimo!!! el peor de todo es que crashea cada tanto. 
Eviten comprarlo si pueden, no cometan el mismo error que yo!
De todas formas si se solucionan estos problemas con un parche, lo cual dudo, cambiare mi recomendacion, por ahora la dejo en negativo.

ACTUALIZACION :

Square sorprendentemente saco un parche. Hasta donde pude probar soluciona el gran problema que muchos teniamos. El crasheo del juego al usar magias como espejo o coraza.

Final Fantasy VIII was my very first game in the series and thus I was hyped on buying the remaster on PC...until I played it that is.

If you want to play FFVIII don't bother with this version as the devs were extremelly lazy with this version. It's not worth being named a remaster if you ask me, you really don't need to play alot to notice how poor the changes are. Even the new character models don't look right.

The world map is also a total mess which is one of the most important things to get right in my opinion.

Hopefully Square does something about this version because the game really deserves a much much better "remaster".

column8:
Je laisse pour le moment une évaluation négative, je la changerai quand le bug sera corrigé. En reprenant ma partie sur la mission de Dollet, la musique du niveau (the landing) est repassée en MIDI... la blague. Après quelques recherches j'ai vu que le bug apparaissait à plusieurs moments du jeu. Je le laisse donc de côté pour le moment (en espérant qu'ils ne mettent pas 3 ans à corriger ça).

Pour le reste, le remaster est un peu plus propre que les précédents, les nouveaux modèles et effets 3d rendent plutôt pas mal.  Les décors sont hélas toujours aussi flous, eux qui regorgent de tellement de détails, c'est vraiment dommage. J'espère que des mods arriveront pour corriger ça.

Final Fantasy 8 reste, même abîmé, la tuerie qu'il était à l'époque.

Damals wie heute ist FF8 ein fantastisches Spiel. Die überarbeiteten Charakter- und Waffenmodelle sehen fantastisch aus. Schade natürlich, dass die Hintergründe und Zwischensequenzen keine ebensolche Behandlung erhalten haben, aber das lag anscheinend außerhalb technischer Möglichkeiten. Das sind allerdings nur Luxusprobleme, die sich evtl sogar mit Mods beheben lassen.

column8:
Oh boy, How do I dig into this; As a game it's completely functional... but the very same could be said of the cheaper 2013 release.

The corrected controls are nice for Xinput users, but still Dual Analog is a no-show, and the lack of smooth rotation and movement does make the very act of talking to an NPC a bit of a learning curve at best, a chore at worst.

The updated models... they are pretty much the ONLY selling point, and this is back-dropped by 2 pixel radius Guassian blurred pre-rendered backgrounds which shows the cracks within the first 5 minutes of gameplay, in fact, you'll see the lack of effort immediately before you'll actually start playing. The full 3D sections unfortunately have no significant touch-ups in the textures and in worst-case completely broken in certain areas.

I guess I should mention the PSX Music, it's fine... other than the bug in Dollet that plays midi, yet again, showing cracks.

Achievements are... Completionist's basic. a few challenging ones are removed and, honestly, more should have been added given the amount of content this game has, it really would entice a newcomer to get curious and explore.

For 2013 players, you can port saves, this COULD have been a nice selling point but, yet again, shows cracks.

Modding is in the works as of writing the review.

There is absolutely no Widescreen support on any level, after Chrono Trigger, It would have been a safe assumption to see a few updates in some regards.

But I must state that the community should NOT have to fix the game for you, It's important to learn from your modding community and take the general "essentials" and simply integrate them to bolster a step up in quality as well as learning from other ports' issues and creative solutions to keep a standard. Maybe add some options and manual touch-ups to backgrounds.

As I stand, This is a functional game, but as a remaster, I feel like all the effort went into Models and nothing else, there are still missing elements from the original PSX release, It fails as a proper emulation of the original and it really does feel like a beta build of a proper remaster. Since 2013 has more to offer in modding, I can only recommend that version unless Square-Enix can turn this one around like Chrono Trigger.

Coming from someone who loved this game in his teens on the ole playstation this was an amazing experience. I love the story and being able to enjoy the game without grinding for hours on end was very nice indeed with the 3x speed. I also enjoyed being able to use the limit breaks whenever i wanted. The upgrades to the character models i thought wer very well done and running through the game seeing all the wee tweaks made the journey all the more enjoyable. Highly recommend to any ff8 fans who wish to experience the game again but dont want to give up a massive amount of time to do so. 
One down side i feel i should mention was that dropping the 3x speed in battle would slow the game down slightly beyond the norm which was a tad annoying but didnt stop my enjoyment of the game.

column8: I'm going to start out by taking you through the first part of this game step by step. You begin with Squall, an anti-social Garden military trainee who's yet to meet the love of his life. First off if this story line is truly to meet epic levels, then I hope one of the lovers dies. From Shakespeare to The English Patient to Titanic, death has proven to be the most effective instrument of high romantic drama. As you can see the full-motion videos impressive, but sometimes the characters feel dead inside...THEY'RE TOO MECHANICAL!!! Rinoa's eyes aren't lively enough and Squall's face shows no character. He's over idealized and the emptiness he feels inside isn't quite captured in his eyes and facial expression, perhaps that will change. If you think Squall looks young check out Zell, the ultimate Geekazoid! Look how he smiles right into the camera, can you get any cheesier than that!? Oh well! When you're in class go to the tutorial study panel on your desk, here you can download your first two Guardian Forces or GFs. A Guardian Force is a powerful mythical creature or spirit which casts and defends against certain types of magic. Shiva's elemental magic is ice so she's effective against fire enemies. Once you download the GFs leave the classroom when you run into Selphie tell her that you don't have the time to give her a tour, then head into the direction from which she came. Notice the guy on the right, he'll give you seven magic cards for later use. Take the cards and go down the elevator, on the next floor keep walking out towards the screen until you find Quistis you teacher. Talk to her and then leave the irritating music of the Balamb Garden. Welcome to the overworld, home of dated Playstation graphics! If you look at the ocean and face left you'll spot a cave behind a small forest area. Go there to fight Ifrit the fire boss, if you beat him you can equip him as a GF. You'll quickly learn the only way to cast non-GF magic spells is to draw the spells from your enemies while in battle. Personally I like this system a lot, it gives weaker characters something productive to do while you wait for the impending doom of your character's GF. Sometimes only one GF will be effective on a larger enemy. In Final Fantasy 8 once you draw a magic spell you can either store it or cast it. Therefore, enemies with cure spells can actually help you heal yourself! The Junction System is confusing at first, but you should get the hang of it in about thirty minutes. The menu system could be much more organized especially the sub-menus which are opened by pressing X while on another screen. If you don't read the mandatory in-game tutorials you'll never know they exist. For every con there is a pro however, one con is that the status screen does not show which GFs are equipped one pro is that magic inventory lists are now composed of pages. No more endlessly scrolling item lists! For extended critical analysis of this game visit flightsoffantasy.com where we discuss the pros and cons of the Junction System, the pacing problems of the battle system leftover from Final Fantasy 7, and some minor story quirks. Final Fantasy 8 is a must-buy it's not perfect and as of yet the story is more plot driven than character driven but this game is perhaps the most engaging RPG of all time. The easy difficulty level allows you to freely enjoy the momentum of the story above all else. While traditional RPG elements like armor and money are less apparent in this title, it's a nice change of pace without them. That doesn't mean we don't want to see them again. Look for continued coverage of this game soon, oh by the way if Square doesn't add voice-overs to Final Fantasy 9 I'm committing suicide. I hate Taxi!

column8:
Really enjoying this release so far. There are enough upgrades for people who played through the original PlayStation version and the game is more approachable for new players.

The new character models look great and the Guardian Force cut scenes are nicer overall. The backgrounds are the original but up-scaled to a higher video resolution so they do have a bit of grain. I do wish they upgraded the backgrounds for new players but honestly I forgot all about it until writing this review. Although I'm a classic console fan and enjoy the style of 8-bit console graphics like the 2600 etc. The text fonts also look great and I'm so glad they cleaned them up so nice.

Though the real upgrades to this release are not the graphics, the graphics are more of a bonus. It runs really well on my PC and haven't experienced any crashes or slowdowns. It's awesome that this will run on the new generation of consoles and keep the game alive for both old and new players. The controls are smooth and I'm able to use a controller on the PC perfectly without any manual configuration. You can also now access the controls and main game settings from a new overlay menu they added. It's really handy to have that.

The fast-forward feature they added though really shines. Rather funny concept but I could not live without it at this point. It's a much better experience for stat building, stocking magic, and traveling. When I played through the original I liked the slow pace as it brought more immersion and investment, but nowadays I don't have time for all that. The fast-forward feature in this game is so well done. I was expecting it to be like an emulator where you skip frames to make it go faster, but its not that at all. Not sure what was done technically but it feels super smooth and doesn't interrupt the normal game play at all.

That's it for this review for now. I'm going to keep playing! [EDIT: on the PS4 now! lol]

column8:
I'll start by saying that I did not buy the previous version of FF8 available on Steam.

I bought this game back on the original PSX. It is one of my favorite Final Fantasy games.

I was definitely looking forward to the remaster. I bought the FF7 remaster and liked some of the features they had added to it.
If you're a purist, good for you. However, I am an adult with precious little time to devote to gaming. Not like I did when playing this back in the 90's.

The cheats available are a god send. I can run through the game without having to grind for hours drawing magic or killing 3 fish for that sweet sweet AP.

I've done my time already. I farmed out the Mug ability as soon as I left Balamb Garden. I had the Lion Heart in Disc One. I spend untold hours on the island closest to Hell grabbing invisible draw points and leveling up. Hell, I even got that damn random rule for triple triad eliminated.

Is this an amazing HD remake? No. But then it sure as hell looks better than the original. Fire up your PSX and see if you can tell the expressions on the faces of the character models.

I am having a blast with this. The remaster doesn't make my eyes bleed and I seem to have kept all my limbs.

I'm only recommending for Nostalagia purposes.

They only touched up the characters(most) which is nice, and I do like the story of this game. $20 today compared to how much we paid during first release, I'm okay with.

However, as most of the negative reviews say, this was truly a lazy remaster. They touched up a lot of the characters, but none of the backgrounds, and if you pay attention, you can notice sometimes, High quality redesigned characters, and then some original low res characters in the blurry fashion of the original game. 

IF you already own the original on PC, just mod it, do not spend your money on this. If you don't have it on PC, then yes, get this, you should play through. It's still a great game that has a great story.

column8:
Le Remaster est cool, je prend autant de plaisir à jouer que sur la version playstation (voir plus avec les nouveaux design).
Seul critique, c'est dommage que les décors n'aient pas été refait en HD, et 20euro c'est pas cher (j'ai eu ma version playstation pour 30 euro sans le livret dans un megagame à l'époque). Et le Cid caca au début pendant le briefing ça m'a plus fait rire qu'autre chose. ^^

    Ce serai tellement bien un Remake, mais bon vu le temps passé sur celui du 7 (qui a été étendu sur plusieurs plateformes avec des histoires différente, contrairement au 8 qui n'a qu'un jeu, mais reste tout de même mon FF préféré) je doute qu'il y en ai un un jour, mais gardons espoir.

    Bon après 12h de jeu je suis rendu à l'Université de Galbadia, déjà quelques cartes rare du Triple Triad en poche et 5 G-Forces. Ah et je m'interdit formellement d'utiliser les codes de triche (c'est vraiment trop simple si on les active), sauf si on désir juste voir l'histoire, mais bon quel intérêt à jouer au jeu.

    Enfin bref, je prend mon pied à jouer, et j'ai pas que ça à faire de critiquer un jeu qui n'est pas si cher, et qui n'est qu'un remaster des persos et montres, certains décors sont caca mais bon sur la playstation c'était caca aussi (les visages moins travaillé qu'un perso minecraft, franchement ça change ce lissage) un peu déçu que les cinématique n'ai pas non plus été retravaillé niveau qualité, mais apparemment ils ont perdu le code source du jeu, donc beau travail en ayant perdu ça.

PS : J'y ai joué sur Playstation et je ne suis pas fan des mods dans les jeux en général (même si certains sont très beaux), et puis sur steam il y a des mises à jours des fois sur les jeux, alors peut-être qu'un jour il y aura la mise à jour des décors (mais encore je n'espère rien du tout pour l'instant)

Bon allé j'ai fini ma critique, et retourne jouer au jeu, prenez soin de vous, bye

column8: Retour dans le monde de final fantasy 8. J'aime beaucoup les final fantasy,et les rpg en général. Final fantasy 8 m'a laissé un excellent souvenir et n'a pas à rougir devant les autres épisodes. Malgré tout plusieurs fois j'ai essayé de recommencer ce jeu. Mais à chaque fois je laissais tomber par manque de temps,par lassitude ou par découragement. En effet,final fantasy 8 dispose d'un système où la force des personnages dépend des capacités apprises par les invocations et de magie associée aux différents paramétres comme l'attaque ou la défense. Il faut donc passer beaucoup de temps à voler la magie aux adversaires pour gonfler ses stats, et entrainer ses invocations comme on entrainerait ses pokemon. Et c'est LONG. Aujourd'hui les rpg ont presque tous éliminé ou fortement réduit cette partie farm. Aussi retourner à un jeu avec ce genre de pratique peut sembler pénible pour certains joueurs. Et bien rassurez vous,cette version remastered rend les choses beaucoup moins pénible en donnant la possibilité d'accélerer les combats et même vous rendre totalement invincible pendant vos petites séances de farm. En fait vous pouvez le faire pendant tout le jeu mais je vous le déconseille et vous encourage à utiliser cette fonctionnalité uniquement pour zapper l'entrainement. Et ça change beaucoup le ressentis du jeu. Je prend plaisir à le redécouvrir et cette fois j'irai jusqu'au bout. Les personnages sont plus joli,les décors,cinématiques,n'ont eux pas changé. Les musiques sont celles de la version ps1. Certaines cartes du mini jeu triple triad ont été également retravaillées,sinon je n'ai pas noté d'autres changements pour l'instant. Vous pouvez également utiliser plusieurs cheat pour vous débloquer tous les objets,cartes,et autres fonctionnalité qui rendent le jeu beaucoup plus facile. Pour ceux qui ont connu le jeu avant, ce remaster apporte une expérience de jeu plus confortable,pour les nouveaux c'est l'occasion de découvrir un très bon rpg et un monde à explorer avec des quêtes annexes sympathiques.

column8:
This game is EXACTLY WHAT WAS PROMISED with its announcement. It's a re-release of the previous HD version of the game with crisp, clean character models and some built in game boosters. If you liked FF8 before, you should enjoy this new version just fine. If you didn't enjoy FF8 before for whatever reason, this remaster likely isn't going to change your mind.

It's safe to disregard most negative reviews you see here. Almost every negative review of this game can be broken down into one of three basic categories:

1) Graphics.

Anyone who was expecting this game to look like FF15 was just deluding themselves. This game is exactly what was promised with its announcement: a re-release of FF8 with sexy new character models and some built in cheats. Which is, ironically, exactly what the FF9 and FF7 re-releases got with them.

2) Errors.

Can't say I've seen any myself, but I'm also not very far in yet. But since almost every error seems to be unique, it's probably more based on individual setups than the game itself. All the same, gamebreaking errors are bad and devs should acknowledge and deal with whatever compatibility issues are causing them.

3) Censorship.

This doesn't even deserve to be a thing, let's be honest, and there's no way I can even talk about this without insulting anyone who brought it up as part of their reviews. Anyone who thinks Siren's feather skirt is worth starting a crusade over should probably rethink their life choices.

column8:
This is the best OFFICIAL version of Final Fanstasy VIII to date. Its the best game ever made by Square. I'll fight you! Triple Triad forever.

Fight me...Yes, the backgrounds are very prominent when laid against the crisp new character models and beautiful interface (it WOULD have been great to have them completely redo the backgrounds - but did you guys really believe they would, considering what they did with FFXV and alllllllllll the issues they are having with FF7 Remake?) 

Honestly, Square Enix doesn't want to spend money on final fantasy 8, they want to make money off of it. Square hasn't ever celebrated this title, not even on its 20th anniversary. Many "final fantasy fans" don't appreciate it. And.. well, I'm just glad to have something I cherish back in my life and able to experience it in a way I haven't before without having to pay for mods and install a bunch of crap on my computer. If square had released a remaster that had completely redone everything and altered the general look and feel of the original game, that would have literally RUINED the game for a lot of people. What they did was allow it to reach a modern audience by and upgrading the models and a few textures here and there. Is it lazy? Absolutely. But again - WHAT DID YOU EXPECT?

The negative reviewers are obviously nitpicky brats who either are spoiled into thinking graphics mean something (nah, story is what matters) or - with the way some people are complaining about the price - can't spare $20 without it burning a hole in their wallets, causing them to choose between wiping their butts and living off of ramen for two weeks or playing this game. So - if that's the case, then yeah, if you're broke don't buy the game or anything else for that matter except necessities in the first place, save your money. 

If you ONLY give a crap about "cool graphics" then obviously this isn't a game you'll enjoy - go play FFXV. This was never going to look as good as FF10's remaster. $20 is nothing for a game of this caliber so for people complaining about the price... Uh... What?

This is my favourite game of all time, one that helped me through the worst period in my childhood and means more than I can say, honestly, reliving it all is has been nothing short of magical. I don't understand the complaints or what people expected. The new characters look beautiful, the story is just as riveting as ever, and having the OST is nostalgic.

For anyone who hasn't played a final fantasy, or people who've played them all - this game is amazingly good to this day. It stood the test of time. Do I wish there were more beautiful high quality backgrounds? Yes, I do. But FF8 has always been the one final fantasy that Square Enix never seemed to care too much about, and I'm just grateful to have this. 

FF8 has always been bashed and critiqued for numerous things and I just think it's kinda horseshit. Who CARES if the game is in 16:9? Remember when they "remastered" Buffy the vampire slayer to 16:9 and Joss Whedon was horrified because it was never meant to be upscaled? Same thing here. This game was MADE to be 4:3, and I like it that way too. It's nostalgic. There are mods for people who really want widescreen but.. I mean... why? This is a title from TWENTY YEARS AGO! Get over it.

The game is worth $20, the game is wonderful, and in my opinion the best final fantasy to date.

column8:
FF8 is a solid game. I prefer it to FF7 (though nothing beats FF6), and the meddling of CGI cinematics with game-play is incredible and ambitious. FF8 is an underrated Final Fantasy, and it holds up extremely well 20 years since its initial release, especially with the updated sprites from their primitive and pixelated form to something more modern and smooth.

You might see plenty of bad reviews, which is unfortunate because FF8 already gets bashed in the franchise for things like its complicated junction system and long GF/esper battle animations, which might turn even more people off this classic game. But note that most people are attacking the "remaster", not FF8 itself. This is understandable, because if you already own FF8 on steam you're only paying for upgraded sprites. And the sprites look good, they were literally reworked from the ground up for not only characters but all the bosses and encounters. Even the world map was smoothed somewhat. But the location background looks blurry, and it's disappointing that Square-Enix with all its resources couldn't sharpen them up a bit, something that amateur mods were able to easily do. The text is also smoothed out, and I'm happy that they didn't tamper with the music or sounds, because it retains that retro-FF feel [that is it uses original PSX sounds, not the crappy MIDI ones from other PC versions, and not re-orchestrated]. Other minor disappointments are no rumble support and 8-direction control (the PS version had rumble, and 360 analog directions so you could turn more smoothly). There is also a 3x-fast-forward mode (useful for skipping GF animations and grinding), the option to turn random encounters on/off, and cheats.

So in summary, a lazy remaster. I feel if the backgrounds were sharpened most of the fan hate would die off, and if the PS controller features were added it would be the definitive version. If you don't own FF8 yet I still recommend this version because it's still the core game with the option to skip the grindy and boring parts. If you already own FF8 on steam skip this one, because you can get better backgrounds with mods.

column8:
So... We have a bit of a mixed bag, here. 

I was hyped when the remastered version of FF8. Like 7 and 9, it does have its issues, though. I have both versions on Steam so, I'll draw some comparisons here. The original steam version came out in 2013, nearly 6 years ago. That one has its own issues which can be fixed via mods (i.e. the soundtrack runs at a higher pitch in that version due to it being MIDI and not the original PSX version). The modding community for the original release is pretty massive and you can even apply mods that clean up the backgrounds and clearer textures for the character models. 

In FF8R's case, the models are entirely updated. Most of them look great. Siren sadly was censored. I don't count Rinoa's new model as censorship though like others have insisted since the model itself is closer to her CG + artwork counterparts. I find that these prove that there was no censorship at play here. I also believe they wanted to base her model off of her Dissidia NT model like they did with Squall. Her original model made it look like her chest was more exposed than it actually was. 

The drawback of the updated models isn't really just the censorship of Siren, however... It's the backgrounds. Yes, the backgrounds. They are not very clear, and stick out like a sore thumb to the otherwise amazing models. I was hoping that they'd be cleaned up especially with the fact that as I mentioned, modders have cleaned the backgrounds up themselves. A pro here is that the game uses the original soundtrack from the PSX version. It's not orchestrated nor remastered, but I'm fine with this. I don't want the original music to be tampered with if it's going to end up like the FF10 fiasco. 

The game is also in a 4:9 ratio with no way to change this as of the time I am writing this. I don't entirely mind it, but I wish it was an option anyhow because it could make viewing experience much better. Of course, this would mean that the CG cutscenes would be in 4:9 ratio, unfortunately. If this is a deal breaker for you, I'd stick with the original FF8 release on Steam. Just keep in mind that you'll need to mod the game in order to get the PSX Soundtrack. 

I feel like a lot of things could have been done to make this game more of a remaster such as upscaling the backgrounds and updating the textures of the world map as this creates an uncomfortable contrast between the updated visuals of the game itself. Do I feel like this was a rushed release? Kind of? I feel as though that Square wanted this out before 2020. FF8 isn't the only one with issues though as there appears to be some issues with various ports/versions of FF7 and FF9. There just seems to be a bit more at hand. 

Also, about the framerate, the game runs at 30 fps in game with battles and CG cutscenes running at 15fps, sometimes going to 16-17 fps. It's the same even on the original release, actually and it's not that noticeable. Is that to say 60 fps universally would be noticeable and even a big improvement? Yes, but this game doesn't lag when running under 20 fps or 30 fps. I know games nowadays (mainly on PC) run at 60 fps or more. But this is a game from 20 years ago and from the 5th generation. The upscale in fps shouldn't have been expected in the first place.

Other than that, I do enjoy playing this remastered, even though it's only remastered to an extent. I wish steam had a "mixed" option as opposed to just recommended and not recommended.

I'm not as skeptical as some others regarding this release, but I understand some of the more general negative sentiments. Especially the fact that Square could easily have used available tools to perform high quality upgrades to the backgrounds in this game. However, this is (if just barely) a worthwhile addition to the catalog. 

Let me break it down as to why you should buy Remastered if you're thinking about playing VIII again:

0) Excellent controller support
1) 3x Speed Boost (hot switchable with L3 on the gamepad)
2) Autosave
3) Excellent menu upgrades
4) Enhanced models
5) Somewhat enhanced backgrounds
6) Some small audio quality improvements



Though disappointing at first, I've come to a different conclusion after thirty hours playing it. That conclusion is... it's good. This is certainly the version I'd recommend to first time players (or those that had not played the original in 20 years). Advantageously, I can use saves with my old Steam version of VIII, and can mod that to my heart's content. Yes, I had higher expectations, but I'm happy with the end product here... and promptly got sucked in to the game again while testing VIII Remastered. I think the problem is that SE calls it Remastered, which it really isn't. 

It should be called [B]Final Fantasy VIII - Marginally Improved[/B] . But the new controller support, autosave, speed boost and menus are worth the price of admission to me... and likely to most others playing this game today.

column8:
It's Final Fantasy VIII! Just with updated character models. Like, seriously, that's it. If you like FF8, but wish the characters didn't look like inexpert papercraft models, this is great. If you wanted something more updated (insert former film major rant about the word "remaster" here,) you won't be getting that here.

Personally, I've always thought this game was criminally underrated, and have run through it a few times since it came out. I'm happy to have an out of the box solution to wanting to play my favorite entry in the Final Fantasy franchise without having to look at late 90s era character models.

For those unfamiliar, the game itself, then and now, is a pretty interesting experiment in "what if we made a giant, complex RPG with, like, exactly one system?" Magic? Meet the Draw system! Stats? Draw system! Summons? Draw system!!! Elemental resistance and damage types? Yup, it's your old buddy the Draw system!

The story is a bit soap opera (even by this series' standards) but keeps itself held together well enough with decent characters and fun set pieces. There's a lot more angsty interpersonal stuff that accompanies saving the world in this universe than other Final Fantasy worlds, apparently. Either you'll be here for that or you won't.

Oh, and there is a narrative reward for petting the dog. Pet the dog.

The game runs perfectly. In fact, I've had less trouble running this version that the old version. The cheat features are really nice since I've already finished the game multiple times before. I know I could just use cheat engine or something similar for the same or even better effects, but it's cool to see it implemented right into the game itself. The controls are fine, I've had no problems navigating the menus, and it's stupidly easy to view the controls any time you need to, if you've somehow forgotten.

The new models look nice, and while it's a bummer the backgrounds look a little muddy in contrast, I don't really mind it. I think it's a good release, and I look forward to playing through FF8 again.

Se c'è qualcosa che Square non è mai riuscita a fare è accontentare tutti, ricordo ancora quando nel 2014 venne portato FF8 su steam, e tutti esaltati da una conversione PESSIMA del gioco originale, solo per averlo su questo piattaforma, niente poco di meno che l'edizione del 2002 riproposta su questo store, con tasti che erano rinominati B1, B2 ecc.., degli sfondi super pixellosi  e un imbarazzante struttering su alcune limit e GF finali, un vero ABORTO.

Questo FF8 remastered ha l'unico scopo di riportare un fan nel suo mondo senza tempo, ma stavolta ci hanno colto davvero a metà.

Non hanno senso le critiche sul 4:3, quando usci FF9 su PC qualche anno fa nessuno se ne lamentò.

Per i fondali sono altamente criticabili visto che io a livello personale volevo un lavoro AD HOC su questi, sono sicuramente meglio di quelli pixellosi della versione precedente ma davvero una delusione.

I nuovi modelli 3D sono assolutamente ottimi, da fan mi ritengo soddisfatto, di design che sono in linea con le Cutscene e questo ci sta tutto, su questo hanno fatto un buon lavoro.

Le facilitazioni nessun giocatore serio le userà mai, ma la velocità aumentata è davvero una piacevole aggiunta, visto che il farming di magie diventa davvero stressante a volte.

In Conclusione, una remastered senza infamia ne lode, sicuramente però, la migliore versione di questo capitolo in circolazione, e ciò personalmente mi basta per rigiocarlo, però davvero potevano lavorarci molto di più, ma tanto si sa, questi sono giochi che li comprano solo noi fan nostalgici, è un lavoro rifatto da zero sui fondali è un pessimo investimento a lungo termine per loro, davvero un grande peccato.

Anyone who has played the Steam releases of FFVII and FFIX should have a pretty good idea of what to expect here, that is the best way I can think of to convey what this remaster is like.

I'm a huge fan of FFVIII so playing this is a blast so far. The character model upgrades look good, I do prefer some of the original designs, but overall the improvements to 3D assets is very nice to see. The story and gameplay are as good as ever and the junction system remains my favourite way of customising character in any FF game. Thankfully they included the original PS1 music this time, I still can't believe they never fixed that in the first Steam release. The cheats and boosters here should be good for replay value, but so far I've only made occasional use of 3X speed. I also appreciate that this port has better controller support than the original port to Steam.

There are three main areas that I think Square dropped the ball. This game suffers from the same flaws that Square's other PS1 remasters have, these come nowhere close to ruining my enjoyment, but if Square fixed these it'd be a nearly perfect remaster.

1. Lack of true analog control.
2. No real work on making the pre-rendered sections match the quality of the 3D assets. 
3. Removal of Chocobo World.

Both the first two were initially jarring to me, I'd love to see an AI upscale and analog control feels so much better in the PS1 release. However, neither of these ruin the game and after an hour or so I'd adjusted to both as I got too invested in what a great game FFVIII really is. The last main disappointment is the removal of Chocobo World, this is the one area that the original Steam release is better. Square say that unique items are now obtainable through Angelo Search, but I have yet to confirm this or if there is a way to level Boko without using Chocobo World, this is more of a completionist complaint since Chocobo World was never essential, but it's a shame that I can't use it here. I should also note that aspect ratio is fixed to 4:3, but that doesn't bother me since the art was all created for 4:3, at least they didn't include a weird border around the screen like with FFIX.

Overall, I'm very happy and have to say that of all the releases of PS1 games to Steam, this is the best Square have done so far. I just wish they'd address the common flaws in all these ports and make them truly definitive versions.

Fidèle à l'original avec un petit lifting pour les persos. Stable et large choix d'options pour le configurer. 

CECI EST UN REMASTERED ET NON UN REMAKE. 

Un remake demande une refonte totale en profondeur, cela n'aurait plus eu le parfum du jeu de l'époque. 
Et non, ce n'est pas de la poudre aux yeux. Il semblerait que certains chouinent car ils n'ont pas compris la nuance. 

Si vous avez aimé le FFIX remastered, vous aimerez celui-ci aussi. Les idiots et les couineurs, passez votre chemin.

Let me start this off with saying that FF8 is a great game. With that said they could have done better with this remaster. My biggest issues at least for the Steam version of this game is: No rumble support, honestly I love rumble and I was one of the angry gamer's when Sony tried to get rid of it on the PS3. I feel like it shouldn't be that hard to support it i mean come on the PS1 version had it this is supposed to be the best way to play and no rumble support??? 

My next issues with this game is that they are trying to market it as a remaster, i think it would have been better to say ff8 HD or something. in most peoples minds nowadays when they hear remaster they expect alot of enhancements.

If they wanted to call it remaster we would need all redone backgrounds. and dont get me wrong at 20 USD I don't expect the world but I would have gladly paid 40 or even 60 USD and been much happier if they put more effort into it and redid the backgrounds in HD added widescreen support. voice acting. It dosn't need to be at the level they are doing it with ff7 remake and honestly i don't want it at that level just enhanced graphics same gameplay! With all that said, I still enjoy the game but i wanted people to know what they are actually getting, not a remaster but a game with some new HD models and that's it..

column8:
Que dire du Final fantasy 8 remastered : 

Y a du positif et du négative dans ce jeu. 

Comparez à l'original, Final fantasy se présente comme un bon Rpg à l'époque sur playstation 1 il a bien été vendu, le jeu était très originale. une histoire fun, la guerre entre étudiants pour ma part c'étais bien construit, rien à dire sûre ceci. Après à la playstation 1 les personnages sont très cubique et on voyait que le graphisme était vraiment pas finie. Dans ce volet qui est sortie le 3 septembre 2019, au niveau de modélisation des personnages ont été retoucher. ça c'est très positive. Ensuite aux niveaux des G-Forces. Golgoltha et shiva sont donnés au début du jeu. Golgotha sans intérêt mais shiva à été un peu refait je la trouve mieux dans cette version que l'originale. Ensuite niveau dialogue, rien n'a été changer saut le caractère des écriture c'est positive car on lit mieux l'essenciel  dans l'interface. 

-  Ensuite je veux parler des codes de triche dans Final Fantasy 8 et dans cette version. 

J'ai tester des partie cheater pour voir la différence. Voici ceux que j'ai trouvé. 

- Final Fantasy 8 normal ( steam ) :

Malgré que vous activer le cheat en fesant F1 F2 F3 et F4 pour activer les codes et ne prendre aucun dégât et taper 9 999 points de dégâts dans toutes les circonstances. Vous réussirez à prendre les g-forces les plus fortes. Ainsi vous aurez aussi la possibilité d'avoir tous les livres de fan ocultes les armes les animaux de Linoa mais dans cette version, il faudra farmer tous les composants qui permettra d'augmenter vos armes. Hélas, c'est pas fournis les objets de craftes. Pour les magies, si vous voulez avoir tous les magies 100, il faut que vous voliez une magie minimum 1 point dans vos sac, quand vous activer ce cheat magie tous les magies existant dans vos sacs deviendront à 100 utilisations. Si vous avez utilisez soins+ 50 en combats par exemple, il vous reste 50. Vous voulez encore revenir à 100 reutilisez le cheat pour reavoir de renouveau 100 points utilisations. Ne croyez pas en fesant le cheat de la magie vous aurez des magies dans vos sacs sans les volés. 

- Final Fantasy 8 remastered ( steam ) :

Quand vous appuyer sur F1 F2 et F3 vous activé les modes pour ne pas vous faire toucher activer le mode pas de combat et le turbo x3 dans le jeu, moi je vous conseille F3 uniquement car le jeu et les dialogues sont des fois un peu trop long. Ensuite dans échappe vous avez un onglet code de triche dans le jeu, si vous l'activer quelques soit le mode de triche ça activera dans votre partie jusqu'à la fin du jeu. Sachez que si vous l'activez juste un les succès de ce jeu ne fonctionne pas par rapport au jeu normal sur steam. 

Si vous êtes accros au succès steam, je vous conseille vivement de ne les pas activer. sinon vous devez recommencer le jeu à zéro. que le normal même activer les code de triche vous aurez quand même les succès. 
Voilà la différence.

Si vous ne connaissez pas le jeu de Final fantasy 8, oui Le remastered est conseiller. il coûte 19.99 € sans réduction, le normal de 19.99 € passe maintenant à 12.99 €. 
Les personnages retouchés et le graphisme reste encore de la playstation 1. 
Pour les fans de Final Fantasy 8, je rejoints les commentaires qui sont en bas de la fiche. je rejoins ceux qui sont marqués. Je ne le conseille pas de l'acheter. rien n'a été modifier ou rien à été rajouté pour avoir un jeu fun et original. de ce côté là je suis quand même déçu qui n'ont rien amélioré.

Pour conclure le jeu en lui même n'est pas bof pas mieux. 
pour les débutant, oui je le conseille de l'acheter, pour les fans non ne l'acheter pas ce jeu, vous économiserez sincèrement 20.00 € après chacuns ses choix. 

- " pour ma part " : 

Je le conseille de l'acheter si vous ne le connaissez pas si vous avez envie de le découvrir.
Pour les pro, et les speedrunners de twitch, non ça ne vaux pas le coups d'être acheter.

Voilà mon avis sur ce jeu personnel.
Bon jeu à tous.

En soit, le jeu est génial, que ce soit l'histoire, les musiques, les combats, les personnages, etc...
Le problème, c'est qu'il l'était déjà sur ps1...
Et concrêtement, la seule chose qui ai changé par rapport à la version ps1, c'est que les personnages sont moins pixelixés. Ce qui donne un rendu absolument dégueulasse lorsque tu te balades en exterieur avec un joli personnage bien lisse, et des textures de fond vieilles de 20ans maintenant.

Bref, ayant encore le jeux ps1, autant rejouer au vrai plutôt que de gaspiller 20e.

For now.. it's better wait to see what patches may roll out.

column8:
Pre-ordered this game. Refunded after 2 days.

It's a tremendously lazy "remaster" to the extent where this should not have been called a "remaster". Please note that this review is being written with emphasis on the tag "Remastered" that Square decided to give this. There's next to no content that's been "redone" or overhauled in this game, to warrant a separate release from the 2013 Steam release and/or at a price point of USD$20.00. The game is what it is. The mechanics are the same. The story is the same. Apart from the updated character models which look decent I must say, and the updated menus, icons and fonts which look very nice now, there's not alot going for a "Remastered" edition of FFVIII here. If you already own the 2013 release of FFVIII here, you may as well skip this. I'm not even going to talk about the unreasonable censorship that Square Enix lazily decided to include in this Steam version, at the behest of Sony. 

Personally, I pre-ordered this because I wanted to support Square Enix and I also wanted to show them that there is a demand for FFVIII. Alot of people take a dump on this game particularly because of the Junction System, but in my opinion, that system was so innovative and allowed for risk/reward play. Invest your time in the Junctioning System and watch your characters grow absurdly powerful. But I wanted to financially support this game because a large part of me actually wants this game to get a total complete remake in the style of FFVII. Of course I wasn't expecting it any time soon but still I'm hoping for that.

However after looking at the poor effort and lethargic work ethic on display by Square Enix here, with this "Remaster" I can't in good faith, recommend this game nor can I justify the USD$20.00 price point. There's just too little updated content here for a separate release of this game. I know Bethesda's not really a shining example these days, but just look at how Steam owners of Skyrim Legendary Edition were given the Skyrim Special Edition for free. And that was not a few simple updates to the game. Skyrim was implemented into the 64bit Creation Engine, in order to give us the Skyrim Special Edition...for free. I'm hard pressed to believe that the work that Square Enix did with FFVIII Remastered is anywhere close to the amount of work Bethesda did on Skyrim Special Edition. Yet still, Square Enix is charging money for this, even if you already owned FFVIII on Steam. A bit greedy and disgusting in my opinion and so, I can't support that type of behaviour and attitude from them.

The pre-rendered backgrounds seemed to have been poorly upscaled and then given a blur mask to help with the obvious pixelation taking place.The FMVs look as I remember them from 20 years ago. Locked at 30fps. And no 16:9 aspect ratio available. You may as well, find yourself a CRT TV and a playstation and play the original. I'm very disappointed as I looked forward to playing this on my PC but since I own the 2013 version on my old PS3, I'll go see if that boots up and play it there instead. I may be just a drop in the bucket and we may now never get a FFVIII remake. But you have to stand against this type of thing. Developers cannot be allowed to continue milking consumers' pockets with subpar "remasters" and games in general. Furthermore they should not be allowed to insult and dishonor classic games such as these, which are near and dear to the hearts of thousands of fans. Fans whose childhoods are surrounded by these old games and their characters.

When I think about it now, it's probably a good thing for Square Enix to not remake FFVIII. If they can't be trusted with a smaller-scale project as a Remaster, then I wouldn't want them to go any further with this game, if their only plan to ruin it's reputation as one of the best RPGs of all time.

Those that haven't tried FF VIII before won't regret the purchase of an updated timeless classic.

修復版最大嘅亮點係建模重製，咁就梗係冇得同老史新出嗰嘀比啦，不過比起20年前嘅原版，可以講係「質嘅飛躍」，具體對比效果自己去官網睇。

另外，修復版仲自帶多隻金手指，包括：

以下可以隨時通過ESC菜單或快捷鍵開關。
[olist]
    [*]快捷鍵F1。戰鬥中血常滿、隨時出招、隨時出特殊技，不過特殊技都係要自己撳掣。
    [*]快捷鍵F2。唔會隨機遇敵，不過劇情戰仍然會觸發。
    [*]快捷鍵F3。3倍遊戲速度，不過戰鬥時敵人都係3倍啵。過場動畫正常播放。計時嘅關卡，例如一開始嘅火窟，雖然動作變快，不過時間仍然會按正常速度去計。
[/olist] 

以下可以隨時通過ESC菜單啟用。可以重複啟用，不過，[u]一旦改咗，冇得還原，而且用咗以下金手指嘅嗰個紀錄唔可以解鎖對應成就[/u]。
[olist]
    [*]獲得幾乎全部道具，包括需要觸發神秘飛碟事件得到外星人卡片後精製而成嘅「食慾魔神之鍋」，各100個，差咁用來得到守護力量（召喚獸）嗰幾種。分別係飛天貓嘅「飛天貓護身符（Mog's Amulet モグのお守り）」、滿巴嘅「友情之證（Friendship ゆうじょうのあかし）」、魔火車嘅「所羅門戒指（Solomon Ring ソロモンの指輪）」，同埋惡魔嘅「魔法燈（Magical Lamp 魔法のランプ）」。
    [*]當前守護力量（召喚獸）學識全部能力，新收嘅守護力量要重新用金手指。[u]一旦改咗，之前食道具學識嘅能力會消失，冇得還原[/u]。
    [*]當前守護力量滿級，新收嘅守護力量要重新用金手指。
    [*]金錢全滿，變成99,999,999蚊。
    [*]當前魔法全滿，新得到嘅魔法要重新用金手指。
    [*]學識全部特殊技及得到對應道具（例如子彈），女老師學識全部青魔法。
    [*]獲得前7級各100張、8-10級各1張，合計7615張、91種、幾乎全部卡牌。
[/olist] 

差咁19張稀有卡牌，分別係：

通過主線劇情，
[list]
    [*]喺火窟打低火精獲得嘅8級守護力量卡[u]「火精」[/u]。
    [*]喺無名王墓打低牛頭怪兄弟獲得嘅8級守護力量卡[u]「細粒牛」[/u]同[u]「聖牛」[/u]。
[/list] 

通過支線劇情，
[list]
    [*]通過神秘飛碟事件獲得嘅5級怪獸卡，外星人[u]「噗噗」[/u]。
    [*]用咸濕雜誌《隔籬屋女仔》換返來嘅8級守護力量卡[u]「濕婆」[/u]。
    [*]通過步行雀親密之證事件獲得嘅8級守護力量卡[u]「步行吱」[/u]。
    [*]打低用魔法燈召喚出來嘅惡魔獲得嘅9級守護力量卡[u]「惡魔」[/u]。
    [*]喺學園大戰時，打低三頭地獄狗卡伯落斯獲得嘅9級守護力量卡[u]「卡伯落斯」[/u]。
    [*]喺中央遺跡打低奧丁獲得嘅9級守護力量卡[u]「奧丁」[/u]。
    [*]喺海洋探察人工島打低天焰龍獲得嘅9級守護力量卡[u]「天焰龍」[/u]。
    [*]喺海洋探察人工島打低終極兵器獲得嘅9級守護力量卡[u]「伊甸」[/u]。
 [/list] 

通過觸發卡牌女王委託獲得嘅，
[list]
    [*]8級守護力量卡[u]「肥步行雀」[/u]。
    [*]9級守護力量卡[u]「不死鳥」[/u]。
    [*]9級守護力量卡[u]「魔火車」[/u]。
    [*]10級人物卡，血刃[u]「基洛斯」[/u]。
    [*]10級人物卡，神槍手[u]「亞榮」[/u]。
[/list] 

通過挑戰卡片俱樂部獲得嘅，
[list]
    [*]8級守護力量卡，兵器收藏家[u]「驕伽魅舒」[/u]。
    [*]9級守護力量卡，結界締造者[u]「丹頂獸」[/u]。
    [*]9級守護力量卡[u]「海渦龍」[/u]。
[/list] 



而修復版最大嘅問題係冇咗迷你遊戲「步行雀世界（Chocobo World）」，導致支綫劇情唔完整。

原本由迷你遊戲得到嘅關鍵道具：
用來得到守護力量飛天貓嘅「飛天貓護身符（Mog's Amulet モグのお守り）」、
用來得到守護力量滿巴嘅「友情之證（Friendship ゆうじょうのあかし）」
都改為通過女主角蓮諾雅隻狗雁召盧喺戰鬥中用隨機絕招「雁召盧掘寶（Angelo Search）」隨機得到。
如果要學識呢招就要喺埃士達（Esthar）書店用一千蚊買本《寵物通信 第5期》，或者用官方自帶金手指得到全道具都得（修改過嗰個紀錄唔會解鎖對應成就）。

至於以前要喺步行雀世界通過英雄救美事件學識嘅幾招步行雀必殺，暫時唔清楚點樣搞。



跟住需要講一講嘅，係紀錄問題。
修復版仲係得60格，而且仲佔用咗第1格作為自動保存，對於經常保存紀錄嘅人來講，實用性唔大。

其實呢樣嘢，《最終幻想9》處理得比較好，首先係真正嘅自動保存，隨時可以退出，下次撳「繼續」（唔係撳「讀紀錄」），就可以接返上次退出時嘅進度，《《最終幻想8 修復版》唔得。而且9代仲多咗好多格畀玩家保存紀錄。

各版本紀錄係通用嘅，

原版：
擺喺安裝目錄下 Save\Slot1 或 Save\Slot2，命名規則係save01… save30，CHOCORPG

優化版：
擺喺我的文檔:\Square Enix\FINAL FANTASY VIII Steam\...\
slot1_save01.ff8… slot2_save30.ff8
chocorpg.ff8
將文件名（包括擴展名）改成一樣就可以讀取，
不過開遊戲時會清空複製嘅紀錄，要先開遊戲，再複製紀錄過去，然後喺遊戲入邊保存一次。

修復版：
擺喺我的文檔:\My Games\FINAL FANTASY VIII Remastered\Steam\...\game_data\user\saves\
slot1_save01.ff8… slot2_save30.ff8
只要將文件名（包括擴展名）改成一樣就可以讀取。



修復版增設咗「退出」掣，喺隊伍菜單退出係返去可以讀紀錄嘅主菜單，如果撳ESC退出，係直接關閉遊戲，退出到可以揀語言嘅啟動界面。

如果有需要，每次開始遊戲前，都可以喺啟動界面切換語言，揀完即變，唔需要好似優化版咁另外下載，而且優化版轉語言後會有少部分文本出錯。


蒸汽成就，有34個，比優化版少咗11個：

[olist]
    [*]喺步行雀世界獲得一個道具。
    [*]步行雀世界100級。
    [*]擁有全部雜誌。
    [*]擁有全部卡牌。
    [*]打牌贏100次。
    [*]女主角隻狗雁召慮學識全部絕招。
    [*]女老師學識全部青魔法。    [*]消滅1萬個敵人。
    [*]其中一個角色升到滿級。
    [*]擁有99,999,999蚊。
    [*]男主角暴風初始等級爆機。
 [/olist] 

修復版有蒸汽卡、徽章、表情、展櫃背景。

卡有6張，水彩風格大頭相，男女主角，兩男兩女4個配角。我想講，大頭相襯粉紅底真係好肉酸。

展櫃背景好暗，得一側有個黑麻麻嘅人影，同《紛爭新章》嘅背景一樣，唔好睇。



最後就係掣位問題。

原版掣位設置係最合理嘅——左手操作指令，食指擺F掣；右手操作方向。

優化版同修復版嘅鍵位都好難用。

column8: I hate leaving a negative review, I really do, but it's truly what this Remaster deserves. There wasn't much effort in this remaster at all. Yes the models are nice, but everything else is virtually untouched if not downgraded especially with the backgrounds. When people say there are fan made mods that put this to shame they aren't kidding. A company with resources such as Square should easily put the rest of us to shame but clearly they don't care and just want your money. I've also seemed to stumble across a bug that makes the in game cursor constantly flicker in the top left on my screen. This bug never goes away while playing and has caused burn in damage to my expensive monitor. This is very unfortunate and it's probably too far along now to receive a refund but that's ok since i've learned a valuable lesson from all of this. Honestly if you're reading this review just completely forget about this remaster. $20 for this sorry excuse of a remaster is almost criminal.

Still an amazing game. First play through is about 50+ hours, and roughly about 100 hours for every last thing to do in this game.

I have much love for this game as it definitely is one of my favorite games of all time next to LOZ Ocarina of time, Final Fantasy 7, Dragon Quest XI. It for sure is different, but it grows on you once you fully understand the concept of the Junction system. Playing cards as well apparently can take A LOT of your time

Great things about this game:
-Enhanced character models. They look fantastic
-Story 10/10. Much better understood and tons of explanations and theories floating online since its 1999 release
-Music. Dear god is it good
-X3 speed. Don't know how we played this in 1999 without it
-Controller compatibility (played this with xbone controller)
-Triple Triad Card Game
-Junction System. You do not need high level characters to make them overpowered
-Secondary pause (esc button) mandatory for those like myself who are short on time
-Multiple save slots that you know what to do with

Bad things about this game:
-Game does not run on 60 fps (renzokuken isn't as smooth as i remember it on ps1)
-Draw/ Junction Magic. Your stock is junctioned to your stats. Meaning the more you use a Junctioned magic, your stats decrease in value. System could of used more polish after 20 years
-Backgrounds are much left to be desired
-Fmv cutscenes are upgraded to 1080p, but lack polish
-missed chance for any dlc
-Analog support missing. characters feel clunky moving around compared to ps1
-Rumble feature missing. Added additional hype when performing limit breaks is sadly gone

column9:
i like it, buy the game and judge for yourself. I'm sure mods will be out for this soon. A few minor things that could of been enhanced like the background, rumble feature, and analog control support 

Still an amazing game. First play through is about 50+ hours, and roughly about 100 hours for every last thing to do in this game.

I have much love for this game as it definitely is one of my favorite games of all time next to LOZ Ocarina of time, Final Fantasy 7, Dragon Quest XI. It for sure is different, but it grows on you once you fully understand the concept of the Junction system. Playing cards as well apparently can take A LOT of your time

Great things about this game:
-Enhanced character models. They look fantastic
-Story 10/10. Much better understood and tons of explanations and theories floating online since its 1999 release
-Music. Dear god is it good
-X3 speed. Don't know how we played this in 1999 without it
-Controller compatibility (played this with xbone controller)
-Triple Triad Card Game
-Junction System. You do not need high level characters to make them overpowered
-Secondary pause (esc button) mandatory for those like myself who are short on time
-Multiple save slots that you know what to do with

Bad things about this game:
-Game does not run on 60 fps (renzokuken isn't as smooth as i remember it on ps1)
-Draw/ Junction Magic. Your stock is junctioned to your stats. Meaning the more you use a Junctioned magic, your stats decrease in value. System could of used more polish after 20 years
-Backgrounds are much left to be desired
-Fmv cutscenes are upgraded to 1080p, but lack polish
-missed chance for any dlc
-Analog support missing. characters feel clunky moving around compared to ps1
-Rumble feature missing. Added additional hype when performing limit breaks is sadly gone
-Initial lack of mod support. This game is emulated and does not have a source folder making it much more difficult to mod

column8: Don't usually write reviews, but the one thing thats just killing the game for me, is the disparity between the high res characters and very blurry backgrounds.  And after looking at comparisons between this, and the modded FFVIII, the MOD did much better try at cleaning up both the characters and the backgrounds.  Not complaining about the price, but just seems like another lazy try from SE yet again for a quick cash grab.  This isn't the first time, and I doubt its the last, that SE will put MINIMAL effort into bringing back the classics (With FFVII probably being the only exception at this point).    If they JUST added some high res backgrounds, I would actually be fully happy with the product.

column8:
I like the character models, I think they fit the story just right. Particulary Squall, Laguna, Julia & Rinoa it's nice that they finally look right all the time, not just in the FMV's because they are the heart of this love story so it's the most important that they look good.

I like that they picked (to me) the best version of the music.

I think many will dislike that the backgrounds and FMV are recycled from the original game, but it wasn't a deal breaker for me, I like the colour palette of this game.

Poor Cid looks ugly though :P

30 fps is fine for a semi-turnbased game too me, where quick reaction aren't needed, just good timing. I also like the original FMV's even if they are lower frame rate.

Even though they changed Rinoa's clothing, she looks closer to the original FMV's and concept drawings now, and I think that matters the most, I like her.

I'm in it for the story so I didn't care that they changed the GF's.

I don't recommend this if you are looking for a complete overhaul, I would then recommend FFX or FFXII.

I recommend this if you could like to play the game with better looking characters in the key scene, and you're in it for the fantasy story.

* The boosters will make it easier to enjoy the story even if you're not prepared to invest the extra 10-20 hours to skill up your character for the end boss.
